title: Proposed Reply Of President Carter To President Padilla’s Letter Of July 6
text:
Date:
          July 08, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Niact Immediate 7151
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ads-00 Sso-00 /026 W ——————103473 082010z /62 O 081931z Jul 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          Proposed Reply Of President Carter To President Padilla’s Letter Of July 6
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PFORN, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          A) LA PAZ 5832, B) LA PAZ 5831
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: I recommend that we use the opportunity of Padilla’s letter to the President to reply promptly and responsively in a way that would strengthen Padilla’s hand in getting his generals to accept the electoral result. Since the mood in the armed forces is somewhat better than we had anticipated, our reply can be less heavy than we earlier considered. The main point should be to indicate to the Bolivian military that democratic government will be a significant boost to Bolivia’s chances to realize its economic, political and diplomatic objectives. Padilla wants to see me Tuesday night, but I could probably put this off to Wednesday night. Hopefully by then I would be able personally to deliver the President’s reply to Padilla.
My suggested draft reply (in paragraphs 4 to 9 below) presumes decisions and actions on two matters: a successful approach to Senator Hart to get him to delay reporting out a stockpile disposal bill until after the Senate’s August recess; and a decision on our delegation to the inauguration, which I hope can be headed by Mrs. Carter, if at all possible. The proposed commitment not to sell tin in 1979 is not really a separate policy decision, since if the Congressional authorization is delayed to September, the normal consultation process will delay sales until 1980 in any event.
Begin suggested draft letter. Dear Mr. President. I have taken to heart your thoughtful letter of July 6, in which you raise your concerns regarding U.S. tin policy and its relationship to Bolivia’s return to constitutional, elected government. I appreciate your raising these concerns with me in the cordial and open manner that is a hallmark of U.S. - Bolivian relations.
First of all, Mr. President, let me congratulate you and Bolivian armed forces for your stalwart leadership in returning your country to democratic rule–a venture which has captured the imagination and admiration of my country and Bolivia’s friends everywhere. The successful completion of this hopeful process with the August 6 inauguration will place Bolivia firmly among the democratic countries of our hemisphere and enhance Bolivia’s international standing and capacity to achieve its economic, political and diplomatic objectives.
On the matter of tin, let me assure you that the United States will manage any eventual disposals so as to safeguard against disruption of the tin market and the economic position of producers, including Bolivia. In response to your letter, the White House has contacted Senator Hart who, in recognition of Bolivia’s return to constitutional rule, has agreed to postpone Senate action on stockpile legislation until after the Senate’s August recess. This should assure that no dramatic news on tin occurs during the final stage of Bolivia’s efforts to complete the election process in your Congress. I can also assure you that no tin sales will take place in 1979, when Bolivia’s elected government is developing and implementing a program to stabilize the country’s economy. Any sales plans in 1980 will be developed on the basis of full consultation with Bolivia’s new, elected government, as well as with other producers, and will be designed to the best of our abilities to avoid depressing the export earnings Bolivia’s new government will need for its stabilization effort. You can also rest assured that my government will work through the international financial institutions and with Bolivia’s new government to help that government raise the financial support necessary to back a sound stabilization program.
I am aware of your country’s plans to raise the issue of Bolivia’s aspiration for access to the sea at the OAS General Assembly meeting this October in La Paz. You know from my remarks to the OAS last year of my personal interest in this question. We will now be awaiting Bolivia’s definition of an approach to this issue with every desire to be supportive wherever we can.
To express as clearly as possible to the Bolivian people our goodwill and deep appreciation of the country’s orderly return to constitutional rule, I am asking my wife Rosalyn (alternate choice) to represent me at the inauguration of Bolivia’s new President on August 6.
As, Mr. President, approach the final stage of Bolivia’s return to constitutional rule, a process which you have so steadfastly overseen, let me wish Bolivia full success in this historic venture, and to you personally all the best in the future. End of suggested draft letter.
The President’s reply to Padilla would be most effective if I could have it in time to deliver personally by P.M. Wednesday July 11.

title: (C) Economic Stabilization Measures By Gob Unlikely, But A Financial Crisis Should Be Avoidable
text:
Date:
          February 17, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 4842
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Sp-02 Ica-11 Aid-05 Eb-08 Nsc-05 Trse-00 Ss-15 Str-08 Omb-01 Cea-01 Ciae-00 Frb-03 Inr-10 Nsae-00 Xmb-02 Opic-03 Lab-04 Sil-01 Com-02 Agr-20 Io-14 Pa-01 Doe-15 Soe-02 /149 W ——————092956 182358z /61 R 171233z Feb 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          (C) Economic Stabilization Measures By Gob Unlikely, But A Financial Crisis Should Be Avoidable
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EGEN, EFIN, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

(C Entire text).
Summary: The return of Planning Minister Gary Prado from the United States has not been followed by economic initiatives, and it seems virtually certain that the Padilla government will not take the economic measures that would result in a stand-by agreement with the IMF.
Finance Minister Alba has announced a so-called austerity budget for the central government (excluding the public enterprises, which account for the major part of the consolidated public sector budget, but whose budgets have not been negotiated yet). The new budget, following approval of the first supplemental appropriations in a Cabinet meeting of February 9, provides for a deficit 41 percent greater than that planned for 1978, and 87 percent greater than the actual 1978 deficit. Although Alba is taking a hard line on salary increases, it does not appear that there is political support for other measures demanded by the IMF, particularly fuel prices increases.
Lacking credits from the IMF, the Bolivian government must obtain loans from other sources to cover its balance of payments deficit. In addition, it will presumably attempt to renegotiate a portion of the debt that falls due during 1979. While financing may be expensive, we believe that sufficient credits can be obtained to avoid a financial crisis before August. End summary.
Planning Minister Gary Prado’s visit to the United States does not appear to have generated additional support within the Padilla government for economic measures. It is highly unlikely that stabilization measures which would facilitate an agreement with the International Monetary Fund will be introduced before the July elections. Although the Minister of Finance has announced an austerity budget, information we have obtained from government sources indicates that the budget may not be quite so tough as its publicity suggests. We do not have a breakdown of the budget, which does not include the public corporations, but the following table summarizes 1978 projected and actual results, and compares them with projections for 1979 adjusted to reflect supplementary expenditures approved by the Cabinet February 9.
  BUDGETED        ACTUAL      BUDGETED
  1978       1978      1979
INCOME 9,288 8,454.7 10,549.4 EXPENSES 11,656.1 10,248.1 13,896.1 SURPLUS (DEFICIT) (2,368.1) (1,793.4) (3,346.7)

Notes: 1. All figures in millions of Bolivians pesos. Exchange rate is 20 pesos to US$ 1. 2. Following the approval of 700 million pesos in additional expenditures at the Cabinet meeting of February 9, the internal GOB document from which we obtained these figures contains a comment to the effect that it will be impossible in 1979 to reduce the consolidated public sector deficit below 12 percent of Gross Domestic Product. This statement indicates that another large balance of payments deficit should be expected in 1979 (a preliminary Ministry of Finance estimate puts the 1979 balance of payments deficit at $184 million), and that large amounts of financing and refinancing will be necessary this year.

Financial officials have recently been jolted by the withdrawal of $21 million credit offer received from a German bank in late 1978 (believed to be the Westdeutsche Landisches Bank). GOB authorities had signed a promissory note for the loan, but had not formalized an agreement. On the basis of the note, a bridge credit was obtained, with the understanding that a formal loan agreement would be signed early in 1979. The German bank has now retracted its offer, apparently because of concern about the Bolivian economic situation, and the GOB must now repay or roll over the $21 million short-term bridge credit.
Despite the failure of this particular transaction, the Padilla government should be able to obtain the funds that it requires to keep the economy afloat until August 1979. We have learned from usually reliable sources that COMIBOL is currently considering a series of major general purpose loan offers, including one of $100 million for short-term (180 day) working capital, and three others of $90, $60 and $80 million at longer (5-8 year) terms. American Express and Librabank, in which Chase Manhattan has a financial interest, are known to be among the banks offering these credits. It is doubtful that all of these transactions could be realized, but in view of the fact that COMIBOL credit requirements are thought to be less than $140 million, a combination might be worked out that would allow some of the funds to be used for balance of payments support. We have also learned that the Central Bank has received an offer of $70 million from Wells Fargo Bank.

title: Opic Insurance Applications: John Lamar Lessor And Charles E. Stokes State Pass Opic Summary. Gob Has Sent Note Indicating Min Ag’s Approval Subject Opic Investment. Telegram Discusses Form Of Note And Comments On Land Investments In Bolivia. End Summary.
text:
Date:
          April 30, 1974

          AmEmbassy La Paz

          SecState WashDC 2968
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ara-16 Iso-00 Sp-03 Aid-20 Eb-11 Nsc-07 Ciep-02 Trse-00 Ss-20 Str-08 Omb-01 Cea-02 Agr-20 Swf-02 L-03 Come-00 Xmb-07 /135 W ——————— 118101 R 302019z Apr 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Opic Insurance Applications: John Lamar Lessor And Charles E. Stokes State Pass Opic Summary. Gob Has Sent Note Indicating Min Ag’s Approval Subject Opic Investment. Telegram Discusses Form Of Note And Comments On Land Investments In Bolivia. End Summary.
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EFIN, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Embassy has received note from Foreign Office asking U.S. to inform OPIC that Bolivian Ministry of Agriculture has approved proposed investment in cattle ranches by subject U.S. citizens.
Ministry official told EMBOFF that note intended to constitute Bolivian Government approval of OPIC insurance for projects. Nonetheless, OPIC will wish to inspect text of note carefully (Embassy translating and pouching) to see if language adequately constitutes foreign government approval since language of note only implies that Min Ag’s approval constitutes GOB approval. In fact, note goes on to further inform OPIC that details of investments must still be approved by GOB’s Institute of National Investment (INI).
This is first GOB action approving new OPIC coverage in several years. Foreign Ministry Economic Office aware of OPIC needs and INI has just established Office of Foreign Private Investment which Embassy is attempting to educate in OPIC matters. If OPIC has suggestion for change in approval format, we will discuss with these offices.
While recognizing potential advantage to Bolivian economy of investment by experienced U.S. cattlemen, Embassy concerned re Bolivia’s history of land tenure disputes and therefore advises that any OPIC insurance contract covering U.S. agricultural investment should carefully define conditions of land tenure being insured and insurance should only be extended to investment in land whose title has been fully cleared by procedure provided by Bolivian law. Insurance should also carefully define character and purposes of investment. This important caveat applies to Lessor and Stokes investments plus pending applications of Clair Peterson and Verne Hutchinson. (Latter’s local contact, Warren Young, told EMBOFF that Hutchinson has decided not, repeat not, to go ahead with investment here.)
Long-term dispute over Applegate-Youngquist land expropriation illustrates potential difficulties which can arise out of Agrarian Reform Law of Bolivia’s 1952 Revolution. Law has frequently resulted, according to practices of past governments, in lengthy legal disputes over titles and outright land expropriations. Law provides for compensation of expropriations in 25-year, 2 percent bonds, but we are told that no, repeat no, such compensation has ever been given. Land titles can be confirmed (given “inafectabilidad”) by several step legal process ending in decree signed by Bolivian President. Law also limits size of private land holdings according to character of investment and land’s location and use. As we read law “large-scale”, “modern enterprises” investing in livestock production in the tropical Beni area must be no larger than 50,000 hectares and have at least one head of cattle for each five hectares. In contrast large enterprise investing in agricultural production in same area would be limited to 2,000 hectares.
Lessor and Stokes’ local attorney states that each investor intends to buy approximately 10,000 hectares in Beni and he foresees each having more than 2,000 head necessary to meet one to five hectares requirement. He correctly notes that Agrarian Reform has resulted in few expropriations in lightly populated Beni and that present GOB has shown no, repeat no, penchant for further land expropriations and has improved administration of law somewhat. On other hand, attorney states that, as with many land parcels in country, those being considered for purchase by Lessor and Stokes have not yet received confirmation by presidential decree. He mentioned that investors contemplating eventually expanding from meat production to processing and canning.
Embassy notes that even in Beni Agrarian Reform has resulted in many title disputes, if not expropriations, and this likely to continue as population and economic activity now increasing. Moreover, present agrarian policies may last only as long as present government. Thus, Embassy sees need to take all possible steps to secure title and decree establishing “inafectabilidad” before issuing OPIC insurance. Insurance contract should also guard against a change in character of investment or use of land that might open it up for challenge under Agrarian Reform Law.

While Report Mentions In Passing Some Rising Payments For Net Oil Exporting Countries, Believe Inadequate Attention Given To Impact On Bolivia. Petroleum Export Earning Increase Likely Be Closer To Us$ 100 Million And Balance Of Payments Likely Be Just Barely In Surplus Although Better Outcome Possible If Export Prices Remain Near Recent Highs. End Summary.
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EFIN, EMIN, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Lumping Bolivia together with other oil exporters such as Venezuela in one sentence in the summary as standing to increase oil earnings by US$ 7 billion is very misleading as it gives the impression that Bolivia has a significant share in the US$ 7 billion, whereas actually Venezuela accounts for about US$ 6 billion and Bolivia only about US$ 100 million.
Table on page 8 shows Bolivia’s petroleum export earnings increasing by US$ 200 million in 1974. It is extremely unlikely that Bolivia’s total petroleum export earnings will reach that amount. As laid out in La Paz A-23, Bolivian petroleum exports totalled only about 11,840,000 barrels in 1973 and earnings were only about US$ 48.0 million. We do not believe petroleum export volume can expand very much as proven reserves are quite limited. We estimate volume will increase by only about 7 percent to 12,700,000 barrels in 1974. At a price of US$ 12.10 per barrel, this volume would generate US$ 153.7 million in earnings and at US$ 15.50 per barrel US$ 196.9 million. The latter average price looks increasingly unlikely for 1974.
Table I of Ref A shows Bolivia producing about 16 million barrels and consuming five million barrels in 1972. This agrees with our data for 1972.
We believe increased prices for imports including freight and handling will reduce gain to Bolivia considerably, not slightly. Moreover, net gain to Bolivia is diminished because of the Gulf Settlement which requires that 25 percent of export volume from former Gulf properties will be used to pay off indemnity. We estimate this payment will be at least US$ 20 million in 1974.
Our Balance of Payments best estimate (La Paz A-23) may be somewhat optimistic as we had estimated the payment to Gulf at only US$ 14 million. Thus, a US$ 11.4 million surplus may be only about US$ 5 million and even this may be too optimistic if some of the financing contained in the loan disbursement table is not realized. Only if oil prices remain close to US$ 15 per barrel and if mineral prices remain near recent highs will a more favorable outcome of a strong surplus be realized.

title: Inopportune Drop In 1979 Bolivian Cotton Production
text:
Date:
          May 08, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          AmEmbassy Lima
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ara-15 Ads-00 Com-04 Agre-00 Ciae-00 Inr-10 Labe-00 Nsae-00 Sp-02 Str-08 Trse-00 Frb-01 Omb-01 Mmo-01 /051 W ——————102908 090721z /14 R 081350z May 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          Inopportune Drop In 1979 Bolivian Cotton Production
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EAGR, EPAP BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Jose Justiniano, general manager of ADEPA, the Bolivian cotton grower’s association, has provided US with information indicating that recent floods have caused more damage to the 1979 cotton crop than originally suspected.
PRODUCTION: The 1979 cotton crop is estimated to total 293,250 QQ (quintal) as compared with 378,633 QQ for 1978, a decrease of 22.6 percent. Yields per hectare should average 8.5 QQ, which compares with 12.0 QQ for 1978. ADEPA estimates that 34,500 hectares were planted for this 1979 season.
EXPORTATION: ADEPA estimates that 195,304 QQ of cotton will be exported and that Bolivia will receive $US 9,677,250. In 1978 exports totaled 304,279 QQ, which represented export revenues of $US 14,317,248. To this date, ADEPA has sold 15,000 bales to Bunge, an English firm, at a price of $US 50/QQ FOB Santa Cruz. Higher transportation costs will increase export costs of this year’s cotton crop. The railroad link between Santa Cruz, the center of cotton production, and the port of Santos, Brazil was severely damaged by flooding and has not been repaired. Cotton exports will begin in early May and must go through Rosario, Argentina until the Brazilian railroad link is temporarily restored sometime in early June.
DOMESTIC DEMAND: This is estimated to increase from 73,655 QQ in 1978 to 97,946 QQ and generating US$ 4,897,300.
COMMENT: The untimely fall in cotton production will aggravate Bolivia’s already serious balance of payments problems. An important non-traditional export, cotton represented 2 percent of total exports and 17 percent of non-traditional exports in 1978.

title: The Return Of Ciro Humboldt
text:
Date:
          August 29, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Immediate 4072
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Pm-07 H-03 Inr-11 L-03 Nsae-00 Nsc-07 Pa-04 Rsc-01 Prs-01 Sp-03 Ss-20 Usie-00 Inre-00 Sso-00 Nsce-00 Drc-01 /082 W ——————— 101365 O 292145z Aug 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          The Return Of Ciro Humboldt
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

EXILED MNR POLITICIAN CIRO HUMBOLDT MADE A DRAMATIC RETURN TO BOLIVIAN POLITICAL LIFE ON AUGUST 28, HOLDING A SURPRISE PRESS CONFERENCE IN THE OFFICES OF THE MNR IN DOWNTOWN LA PAZ. HUMBOLDT REPORTEDLY TELEPHONED THE LOCAL NEWSPAPERS, PRETENDING TO BE MNR EXECUTIVE SECRETARY RUBEN JULIO, AND ANNOUNCED THAT “IMPORTANT DEVELOPMENTS” WOULD BE ANNOUNCED AT MNR HEADQUARTERS. HUMBOLDT HIMSELF THEN STEPPED OUT OF A TAXI IN FRONT OF THE MNR BUILDING AT PRECISELY 4 P.M., WEARING A BEARD AND DRESSED IN A HAT AND DARK CLOTHES, AND ENTERED TO READ A STATEMENT TO THE PRESS.
HUMBOLDT’S STATEMENT AND SUBSEQUENT COMMENTS TO NEWSMEN ARE LARGELY A DEFENSE OF HIS OWN ACTIONS FROM 1971 TO THE PRESENT. CLAIMING THAT HIS ENEMIES USED THE JUNE 5 COUP ATTEMPT AS A PRETEXT TO REMOVE HIM FROM THE SCENE, HUMBOLDT ASKED THAT THE PROOFS OF HIS INVOLVEMENT IN THE YOUNG OFFICERS’ REVOLT BE MADE PUBLIC. AT THE SAME TIME, HUMBOLDT REITERATED HIS CLAIM TO BE THE ACTING NATIONAL CHIEF OF THE MNR; HE DESCRIBED DR. VICTOR PAZ ESTENSSORO AS THE TRUE CHIEF OF THE PARTY AND ADMITTED TO HAVING MET WITH PAZ IN LIMA PRIOR TO HIS OWN CLANDESTINE RETURN TO BOLIVIA. FOLLOWING THE PRESS CONFERENCE, HUMBOLDT LEFT

292229Z
MNR HEADQUARTERS AND DEPARTED AS HE HAD COME, IN A TAXI.

GOVERNMENT AND OFFICIAL MNR REACTION TO HUMBOLDT’S SUDDEN RE-APPEARANCE WERE NOT LONG IN COMING. A MINISTRY OF INTERIOR COMMUNIQUE ANNOUNCED THAT THE MINISTRY WOULD DETAIN HUMBOLDT FOR HAVING ENTERED THE COUNTRY ILLEGALLY. THE COMMUNIQUE ALSO ACCUSED HIM OF HAVING RETURNED SOLELY TO PROMOTE HIS OWN PERSONAL INTERESTS WITHIN THE MNR. ACTING MNR CHIEF GUILLERMO FORTUN AND OTHER HIGH PARTY OFFICIALS ALSO CRITICIZED HUMBOLDT’S ACTION IN RETURNING TO BOLIVIA. IN A BRIEF COMMUNIQUE, THE MNR HIGH COMMAND AGAIN ACCUSED HUMBOLDT OF INVOLVEMENT IN THE JUNE 5 COUP ATTEMPT, AND CHARGED THAT HE HAD VOLUNTARILY ABANDONED HIS POST AS ACTING PARTY CHIEF TO ATTEMPT THE OVERTHROW OF THE BANZER GOVERNMENT.
THE EMBASSY HAS BEEN INFORMED THAT HUMBOLDT WAS TAKEN INTO CUSTODY BY OFFICIALS OF THE MINISTRY OF INTERIOR ON THE MORNING OF AUGUST 29.
COMMENT: SPECULATION IS RUNNING HIGH AS TO THE MOTIVES FOR HUMBOLDT’S BRIEF BUT SPECTACULAR RE-EMERGENCE ON THE BOLIVIAN POLITICAL SCENE. ONE POSSIBILITY, WHICH SEEMS UNLIKELY IN OUR VIEW, IS THAT HUMBOLDT RETURNED TO LEAD OR TAKE PART IN A NEW CONSPIRACY AGAINST THE BANZER GOVERNMENT. ANOTHER, MORE LIKELY, EVENTUALITY IS THAT HUMBOLDT SET OUT ON HIS RETURN TRIP TO BOLIVIA WITH THE INTENTION OF MAKING A SURPRISE APPEARANCE AT THE MNR CONVENTION, ORIGINALLY SCHEDULED TO BEGIN ON AUGUST 28. HOWEVER, WHEN HE ARRIVED IN BOLIVIA AND DISCOVERED THAT THE CONVENTION HAD BEEN POSTPONED AT THE LAST MOMENT, TO SEPTEMBER 27, HE DECIDED TO STAGE A PUBLIC RE-APPEARANCE AS THE BEST WAY OF SAVING THE SITUATION. A RELATED CONSIDERATION IS THE POSSIBILITY OF A PAZ-HUMBOLDT UNDERSTANDING IN LIMA, WHERE-BY HUMBOLDT AGREED TO MAKE HIS CLANDESTINE RETURN TO BOLIVIA AS PART OF APLAN TO FURTHER WEAKEN THE POSITION OF GUILLERMO FORTUN. FORTUN HAS APPEARED, IN RECENT WEEKS, TO BE INCREASINGLY OUT OF FAVOR WITH BOTH THE BANZER GOVERNMENT AND A MAJORITY OF THE MNR’S MILITANTS. WHATEVER THE LONG-TERM EFFECTS OF HUMBOLDT’S RETURN, HE IS LIKELY NOW TO BE QUICKLY BUNDLED OFF INTO PRISON OR EXILE BY GOB SECURITY

292229Z
OFFICIALS, WHO ARE PRESUMABLY EMBARRASSED BY THE THEATRICAL MANNER IN WHICH THE FORMER MNR LEADER MADE KNOWN HIS RENEWED PRESENCE IN BOLIVIA. PARKER

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Sixth plenary session (Oct. 25) opened with the Bargadian Fonmin Henry de B Ford who expressed his country’s solidarity with Bolivia. He referred to CIECC meeting in Barbados and criticized US for not having co-sponsored the resolution of Bridgetown which 22 others adhered to. He expressed his opinion that the US left grave doubts as regards its true intentions towards the future of the voluntary funds. In the same vein Forde added that security was not provided by military expenditure alone, and felt that the US, being the most powerful country, could not escape its responsibility to contribute to equitable development in the region. He was followed by Ecuador’s Subsecretary of Foreign Relations, Mario Alleman and Paraguay’s Fonmin, Albert Nogues, who gave very general presentation.
Committee 2 on economic affairs completed discussions on agenda items dealing with trade issues with lengthy but relatively moderate debate on protectionism. On discussion of GSP exclusion of OPEC countries, Venezuela remained silent and Ecuador cited objections to conclusion of bilateral agreement with US. Bolivia made a relatively mild statement about adverse effects of US tin disposal. US responded with exposition on tin prices since 1972 and on production falling behind consumption. Indication is that Bolivia does not intend to table a resolution on tin.
Only substantive resolutions tabled thus far, not yet discussed, are one by Ecuador on Panama Canal tolls, calling for continued OAS study on negative impact on Latin American trade, and resolution by Costa Rica expressing Latin American concern over pending meat import legislation and asking USG to find long-term solutions that will not restrict meat imports from Latin America and the Caribbean.
Third committee met in afternoon for first working session and completed consideration of the resolutions of 1978 CIECC of Santiago and the 1979 CIECC of Barbados. On the resolution of Bridgetown the US delegate referred to the position of the US against language implying commitment to 66 percent contribution. The US delegate also stated that the resolution contradicted the “voluntary” nature of the funds in its reference to a “proportion” for FEMCIECC. The delegate of Barbados acknowledged that in fact a kind of informal quota had been operating with regard to FEMCIECC. No other delegation spoke to the issue and the resolution was passed by consensus with the US reserving as was the case in Bridgetown. A working group was formed, including the US, to draft a resolution which would instruct the Secretariat and CEPCIECC to develop alternative criteria and procedures to achieve the goals of the resolution of Bridgetown.
Committee 1 started substantive business with consideration of IAHRC annual report. USDEL made statement of strong support for Commission’s work and we are preparing draft resolution in close coordination with IAHRC Chairman Aguilar. We expect work on this item to continue tomorrow after which El Salvador human rights report will be considered. Venezuelan and Salvadorean reps are developing appropriate resolution on this item which we will co-sponsor.
Declaration of La Paz. A working group was set up to revise the proposal of the Andean Group. Mexican Ambassador De La Colina called for a total redrafting to focus on principles and goals for the Inter-American system. Brazil, Chile, Argentina joined Mexico and US in pressing for the elimination of references to specific problems like Bolivia’s access to the sea and tin. US and Brazil were the only delegations with specific language changes to present. Working group meets again tomorrow to consider new draft with changes proposed in today’s session.
Bolivia’s access to the sea. GOB is lining up co-sponsors for its resolution. Corridor talk indicates that several countries are urging language changes as conditions for their support and that drafts by other delegations are also circulating.

text:

          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Sso-00 /031 W ——————— 090311 O 042125z Apr 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Possible Bolivian Interest In Usg Good Offices To Achieve Outlet To The Sea For Assistant Secretary Kubisch From Ambassador
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PFOR BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

I am detecting some thinking within the Foreign Ministry that it might be propitious for Foreign Minister Guzman to raise with senior US authorities during forthcoming meeting with Secretary Kissinger the suggestion that US help Bolivia achieve an outlet to the sea through the extension of good offices or some form of mediation. This is probably a natural development from the current burst of Bolivian interest in regaining a seacoast and also Bolivian recognition of the diplomatic skills of Secretary Kissinger. I sense some views within the Foreign Ministry that the USG might, for example, ask the foreign ministers of Chile, Peru and Bolivia to meet together on the subject of an outlet to the sea at some time during the forthcoming meeting in Washington.
Since I have not had this possibility put to me formally I have not been able to deal with it directly. However, I have used some recent opportunities to restate our present policy of hoping that Bolivia, through diplomatic negotiations with Chile and Peru, can achieve its objective. This is an indirect way of stating that it is not now the policy of the USG to involve itself in this issue. I hope to preclude any formal request for our assistance which might be rejected as this could conceivably cause a very adverse reaction at the present time when all Bolivians are vocalizing an emotional interest in a return to the sea.
I would be most appreciative for your views on this subject, especially if you sense that there is any possibility that the USG might consider some form of good offices to assist Bolivia. It would be most helpful if I could have your views by Monday, April 8 as it is quite likely that I will have opportunities, informal and formal, to see senior Ministry officials before their departure for Washington, now tentatively planned for either the 13th or 14th of April.

text:

          Ref:
          (A) LA PAZ 10725, (B) LA PAZ 10745, (C) STATE 330263
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: GOB Finance Minister signed a letter of intent requesting Standby and Trust Fund drawing from IMF December 27. The letter also indicates the GOB will seek EFF credit at the conclusion of Standby in late 1980. The Finance Minister also believes the World Bank is committed to providing a program loan once the Standby is approved by IMF and he plans to approach IBRD President McNamara accordingly. End summary.
After receiving informal approval by the IMF on December 24, Bolivian Finance Minister Augusto Cuadros Sanchez signed late December 27 a formal letter of intent requesting the IMF to provide a Standby and indicating that at the termination of the Standby the GOB will request a credit from the Extended Fund Facility. The letter was accompanied by a memorandum on GOB economic policy over the four-year period 1980 through 1983, a technical memorandum of understanding with several tables, and a separate short letter requesting a Trust Fund drawing. According to local IMF representative Jorge Sol Perez, the Fund will give formal approval to the Standby and the Trust Fund drawing in mid-January.
The Standby request is for 66.375 million SDRs, while the Trust Fund drawing request is estimated conservatively at 15 million SDRs, for a total of 81.4 SDRs or about 105.8 million dollars. Sol Perez estimates that, because of the rising price of gold, the Trust Fund drawing will more likely be in the neighborhood of 20 million SDRs and therefore that the total will be closer to 86.4 SDRs or 112.3 million dollars. Disbursements (using the more conservative estimate of the Trust Fund drawing) will be as follows:

JANUARY 1980 41.4 SDR MARCH 1980 14.0 SDR JUNE 1980 13.0 SDR SEPT 1980 13.0 SDR TOTAL 81.4 SDR
The GOB would expect to receive the first tranche of the EFF credit in January 1981.

Cuadros Sanchez’s memorandum on economic policy analyzes Bolivia’s current economic problems and their origins, defends the economic measures already taken by the GOB and describes additional measures to be taken in the future. The object of the GOB’s efforts in 1980, according to the memorandum, is “to create the bases to achieve sustained economic growth during subsequent years” and therefore “to put public finances and the administration of monetary instruments in order and to establish regulations and controls over public-sector external debt operations, with the purpose of reducing the balance of payments deficit.” For the 1981-1983 period, the economic program’s objective will be “to achieve and maintain an acceptable level of economic growth in real terms, avoiding inflationary pressures and seeking to strengthen still further the balance of payments.” An acceptable level of economic growth is defined as four-and-a-half to five percent annual growth in the Gross Internal Product, compared with the two percent reportedly registered in 1979. The memorandum notes that among the objectives for 1980 will be a “viable” exchange rate, reduction of the overall public sector deficit, rationalization of public investment, adjustment of the prices of public-sector goods and services to realistic levels, and control of the external debt of the public sector and the private banking system. The memorandum strongly implies the possibility of future devaluation of the peso by stating that, “in the future the value of the peso will be determined by the behavior of the Bolivian economy, particularly the International Reserve position of the Central Bank and the relationships between external and internal costs.”
In addition, the memorandum notes, the administration will present to the Congress in 1980 tax reform legislation intended to stimulate economic growth and increase public sector revenues. Specifically, according to Cuadros Sanchez, the GOB will broaden the coverage of taxes on profits, introduce some new indirect taxes, reduce drastically exemptions from import duties, maintain a rate of expansion in the money supply which conforms to the projected growth of private sector savings and to balance of payments objectives, establish new incentives for savings and modify the taxation of the mining sector to promote increased investment and production. The GOB will not, says Cuadros Sanchez, impose any more restrictions in 1980 on international payments and transfers nor will it tighten present restrictions, if such actions would violate the IMF’s prescriptions. He expects that during the first semester of 1980 the GOB will be current on its external debt service.

Dr. Marcos Lezama, a Venezuelan national who is president of the Fundacion Bolivariano, called at the Embassy on March 25 to indicate that he was planning to visit Washington on or about April 1. He indicated that he would participate in a ceremony in which a medal would be presented to AOS Secretary-General Galo Plaza. He indicated that he and the Ambassadors in Washington of the Bolivarian countries would be requesting an appointment with Secretary Kissinger.
Dr. Lezama has been in and out of La Paz frequently in recent months. He presided over a ceremony in which President Banzer was given the Good Citizenship Award of the Fundacion Bolivariano. Most recently he has been here as the head of a conference setting forth Bolivia’s claim for a seaport on the Pacific Coast. In his conversation at the Embassy, he cited his great friendship for the US, his knowledge of many leading Americans, and his earnest desire to strengthen US/Latin American ties. He said that he is a writer and the owner of a radio station in Caracas, Venezuela.
Dr. Lezama confined his visit to the Embassy to matters of courtesy and provided information about his trip without requesting any assistance or favors.

text:

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: The first day of the conference proceeded smoothly, with adoption of the agenda, appointment of the board, designation of working committees and selection of their boards, opening speeches by ECLA Executive Secretary Enrique Iglesias, and by Bolivia’s Planning Minister Gary Prado Salmon. An otherwise harmonious opening day was marred only by remarks in Prado’s statement concerning loss of its coastal land and the development constraints which stem from that loss, and his accusing the US of “economic aggression” directed towards Bolivia through sales of tin from our strategic stockpile.
The first two agenda items concerned election of officers, and adoption of the agenda and organization of work of the 18th Session. Without objection, the make-up of the board was established as follows: Chairman-Gary Prado (Bolivia), 1st Vice Chairman-Victor Barrelo (Mexico), 2nd Vice Chairman-Ludwing Zuiverloon (Suriname), Rapporteur-Wilburg Castro (Costa Rica). The provisional agenda, issued March 6, was adopted with a modification calling for a separate committee to be formed to deal with water-related activities. Accordingly, three committees were established. Committee I will address agenda items III and IV, convening respectively, the economic and social development and external economic relations of Latin America, and cooperation among developing countries and regions. Committee II will deal with agenda item five, activities of the ECLA system since the 17th Session and program of work for the period 1979-81. Committee III, as stated, will consider regional coordination in actions related to water. Boards were selected for all committees but Committee III, where it was agreed committee members would select their own officers. Committee I officers were selected as follows: Chairman-Ecuador, 1st Vice Chairman-Cuba, 2nd Vice Chairman-Argentina, Rapporteur-Venezuela. Committee II officers are: Chairman-Peru, 1st Vice Chairman-Jamaica, 2nd Vice Chairman-Uruguay, Rapporteur-Brazil.
Iglesias’ brief opening remarks called for a strong ECLA role in galvanizing a unified Latin American view of the appropriate development strategy as the Third Development Decade approaches. He pointed out that the world economic situation is fraught with uncertainties, and that enhanced cooperation among the developing countries would moderate some of those problems. He urged particular attention to agenda item four, which he hoped would result in a strong follow-on to the Buenos Aires Plan of Action for Technical Cooperation among Developing Countries (TCDC), established in September, 1978.
As host to the session, Bolivia’s Planning Minister Prado gave the keynote address which began with a litany on the stages of Bolivian economic and social development since the country’s independence. He claimed that Bolivia’s status as one of the region’s poorest countries would be different had what he said was its richest land and access to the sea not been plundered (by Chile in the 1879 War of the Pacific). Probably forewarned of Prado’s remarks, the Chilean delegation did not attend the inaugural session. Prado noted that Bolivia’s economic growth rate did not begin to equal those of its neighbors until the 1960s and 70s, although he decried the fact that the benefits of that growth were unequally distributed. The task of Bolivia, and the rest of Latin America, in the next decade, he said, was to emphasize equity, a consideration overlooked in the past two decades when the pursuit of growth dominated development strategy. The obligation to move away from the strategy which encouraged the misuse of scarce capital and luxury consumption, to one encouraging mass employment and widening of consumption throughout the population, is one which rests primarily with individual governments, Prado averred. But he also mentioned the role which external capital and the TNCs have to play in equitable development. He felt TNCs had not always operated in the best interests of developing countries; claiming that the region’s mineral resources were underexplored, he blamed that on TNCs which traditionally controlled investments in the extractive industries. In order to realize Latin America’s mineral potential, Prado proposed the creation of a regional fund to finance investments in the minerals sector, and urged ECLA to undertake a study to determine the feasibility of such a fund, and how it might coordinate its activities with other international institutions. (Comment: We expect the Bolivian delegation to introduce a resolution to this effect in Committee I. End comment.) In the context of the importance of minerals to Bolivia’s economy, Prado castigated the US for what he termed economic aggression in manipulating the world prices of commodities, alluding to an expected sale from US tin stocks. Since Bolivia is moving towards democratic elections and is trying to improve the welfare of its poor, Prado wondered out loud how US actions on tin can be reconciled with avowed US espousal of human rights and democracy.

text:

          Subject:
          Congress Chooses Gueiler To Be Interim President Of Bolivia
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, PINS, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Shortly after 8 PM tonight (Nov 16), the Congress in plenary session unanimously approved a resolution (a) revoking the presidential mandate of Walter Guevara and (b) naming congressional chairperson Lydia Gueiler as interim president of the country until August 6, 1980.

Although not so stipulated, the congressional resolution of last August calling for presidential and vice presidential–rather than general–elections evidently remains in force.

The selection of Ms. Gueiler presumably was approved in principle during last evening’s bilateral negotiations between representatives of the Armed Forces and the Congress. Immediately afterward, Col. Natusch, appearing on national television, formally resigned.
At approximately 8:05 PM Ms. Gueiler took the oath of office on the floor of the Congress. After congressmen and spectators sang a verse of the national anthem, she gave a brief, emotional address recalling her 30 years of “patriotic struggle” as a “revolutionary woman” and pledging to defend the Congress and the Constitution.
Gueiler, about 60 years old, was one of the founding members of the Nationalist Revolutionary Movement (MNR). After the 1952 Revolution, she held a position in the Ministry of Labor, and in 1960 she served as a congressional deputy. She subsequently joined Juan Lechin to form the labor-oriented Party of the Revolutionary Left (PRIN). In the late 1970s, when the PRIN became schismatic, she established her own party faction. In the 1979 elections, she was a member of Victor Paz Estenssoro’s MNR alliance; Edwin Moeller, a former husband, headed a second PRIN faction which supported Hernan Siles’ UDP. Ms. Gueiler has a grown daughter, and a grandchild who is currently studying at a university in Florida.

Address: Casilla 1867, Calle Bozo 119, La Paz, Bolivia. Cable: Turinmo, La Paz. Telex: BX5353. Phone: 55821. Officer: Domingo Linale Urioste, manager.
Description: Large firm established 1968. Employs 60. Acts as agent, retailer, distributor, and importer of automobiles, trucks, pick-up trucks, tractors, and motor vehicle parts and accessories. Is the local representative of “Fiat”. Firm buys from Italy, Argentina, and Brazil. Sells throughout the country. Corresponds in Spanish and English.
References: Financial references: Banco do Brasil, Banco Mercantil, Banco del Estado, Banco de Santa Cruz de la Sierra, Banco de la Nacion Argentina, Banco Popular del Peru, Banco Nacional de Bolivia, all of La Paz. Assessment: Even though Turin Motors has been in operation only four years, it is today regarded as one of Bolivia’s more aggressive and successful import houses, and its Fiat products are rapidly gaining acceptance in the Bolivian market. This firm is Bolivia’s representative for Fiat-Concord, which is installing a tractor assembly plant in Cochabamba (see Refair) which will have a monopoly in the Bolivian market on certain sizes of tractors. Two local banks report that the firm has a good financial reputation and meets obligations promptly. A third bank reports that the firm has a well managed checking account but reports no credit experience. A fourth La Paz bank reports that the firm in the past was slow to pay on occasion but that its present obligations are met regularly. The firm itself reports paid-in capital the equivalent of US$ 34,000 and 1972 sales the equivalent of US$ 2 million. The firm is recommended as a good trade contact.

          STATE 028448 DATED FEBRUARY 13, AND PREVIOUS.
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Following receipt of reftel, DCM spoke with legal advisor and Subsecretary of Justice Ledezma on February 20 concerning our desire that Penaranda be expelled from Bolivia into US custody. DCM stated that Washington authorities were of the view that procedure earlier outlined by Ledezma (La Paz 0712) seemed to be indistinguishable from formal extradition request, particularly need to channel documents through Foreign Office. DCM inquired whether Ledezma viewed his procedure as, in effect, an extradition procedure and whether Foreign Office channel could not be omitted. Ledezma replied that he did not regard procedure earlier outlined as formal extradition route. Rather, Foreign Office channel seemed to him to be required only in order that signature of Bolivian Consul in New York could be duly certified by Foreign Ministry. (Ledezma had not earlier mentioned need for Bolivian consul certification). When pressed as to the real need for use of Foreign Office channel, Ledezma agreed that this could be dropped and the relevant documents submitted directly to him. Assuming that documents are in good order, he would then authorize issuance of an arrest warrant for Penaranda. It was clear in the conversation with Ledezma that he views the documents as legally necessary to support issuance of an arrest warrant against a Bolivian citizen.
Ledezma then stated that it would be necessary for the new Minister of Interior, Juan Pereda Asbun to be briefed by the Embassy on the case and the Minister’s assent obtained to turning Penaranda over to USG jurisdiction. Minister Pereda has told Ambassador he wishes to discuss in private matters of current interest soon, perhaps next week. Ambassador will then take up Penaranda case and other matters. Embassy has no reason to believe that Minister Pereda will raise objections to procedure outlined by Ledezma.
Embassy believes that with Ledezma’s having dropped the Foreign Ministry requirement, objections raised in reftel have been overcome. What Ledezma now agrees to is in effect an informal procedure whereby Penaranda can be delivered to US jurisdiction. We have very carefully considered what complications might arise if we follow the new procedure outlined by Ledezma. Assuming Minister Pereda’s concurrence, we foresee none. If, however, complications should arise subsequent to the presentation of the documents to Ledezma, we still believe it would be fairly easy to back-off, should such be necessary to avoid jeopardizing Bolivian narcotics cooperation.
Action requested: Embassy requests that the following documents be obtained from New York court authorities and transmitted to Embassy for delivery to Ledezma:

Certified copy of arrest warrant against Jose Kenneth Penaranda, with accompanying Spanish translation, all legalized by Bolivian Consul.
Certified copy of indictment of Jose Kenneth Penaranda, with Spanish translation, all legalized by the Bolivian Consul.

Saturday, August 4, 1979
5:30 P.M. Mrs. Carter arrives.

3:10 P.M. Pool no. 1 assembles in filing center, board press vehicle, and depart en route Government Palace.

10:30 P.M. Pool no. 3 arrives.

8:30 A.M. Press vehicles depart La Paz Sheraton en route El Alto Airport.
8:55 A.M. Press arrive airport; proceed to press area.

9:55 A.M. Mrs. Carter departs La Paz, Bolivia.

text:

          Subject:
          Establishment Of Narcotics Advisor Position In Usaid/Bolivia
        
                    
          TAGS:
          SNAR, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

In order to facilitate coordination with the Bolivians and to avoid the dissipation of authority and effectiveness which too much overlapping of responsibilities engenders, I have assigned clearly defined areas of jurisdiction to the individual members of the Narcotics Committee. In making these assignments, it became obvious to me that at this formative stage in the development of the Bolivian narcotics control effort, we need all the qualified personnel strength we have at the moment to isolate and cope with the problems in this major area of concern. We will not be able to replace or retain one of our key team members for the next fiscal year unless we get a new position.
I therefore request your assistance in assuring that an exclusively narcotics-related job is established in USAID/B as of the beginning of FY ’75. The embassy will produce a revised NCAP budget for FY ’75 incorporating this new cost should it be approved.
I do not foresee the need for this new position beyond FY ’75. If the need should exist beyond that time, we could then study the matter again.
For the coming year, however, we do not want another enforcement officer. Instead, we need to increase our efforts of an advisory nature, our institution building role (including the establishment of a basic narcotics training facility in the Police Academy) and our research capabilities on the production, distribution and consumption of coca leaf during this first, formative year of Bolivia’s concerted approach to the narcotics problem. USAID has the kind of man I envision for this role which will give us the kind of clout with the Bolivians that I want to have at this stage in our incipient narcotics relationship.
This request is strongly supported by the USAID Mission Director and the embassy’s Narcotics Coordinator. The duties of the incumbent of this position will not impinge upon the work of DEA here. The two DEA agents presently on board are going to be fully occupied in the enforcement area, which for the next couple of years will include the responsibility of devising and implementing, in conjunction with the Bolivian Narcotics Director, U.S. Government commodity assistance and budgetary support for the operations of the Enforcement Department of Bolivia’s narcotics entity. Stedman

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

SURPRISE RESIGNATIONS OF RECTOR AND VICE-RECTOR OF SAN ANDRES UNIVERSITY (UMSA) IN LA PAZ DURING EARLY MORNING HOURS OF JUNE 18 MAY OPEN WAY TO INTERIM RESOLUTION OF UNIVERSITY POLITICAL PROBLEM. IN PAST TEN DAYS, PRESS AND RADIO ASSOCIATION OF BOLIVIA HAS BEEN ACTING AS INTERMEDIARY BETWEEN EDUCATION OFFICIALS AND UNIVERSITY STUDENTS IN EFFORT TO SEEK COMMON GROUNDS FOR AGREEMENT. THIS MEDIATION EFFOR, HOWEVER, WAS OPPOSED BY UMSA AUTHORITIES IN PERSONS OF FALANGE RECTOR MARIO AGUILAR AND MNR VICE-RECTOR GONZALO SANCHEZ DE LORIA. STUDENT-LED INTER-FACULTY COMMITTEE ALSO HAD INDICATED THAT UNIVERSITY STUDENT STRIKE BEGUN ON MAY 21 WOULD NOT END UNTIL RECTOR AGUILAR RESIGNED HIS POST. AT PRESENT, UNIVERSITY STUDENTS CONTINUE ON STRIKE AT UMSA AND IN SUCRE, COCHABAMBA AND POTOSI.
NOW THAT CONTROVERSIAL UMSA RECTOR HAS BEEN REMOVED FROM SCENE, POSSIBLE BASIS FOR A TRUCE MAY BE PROVIDED BY FIVE- POINT AGREEMENT REACHED BY STUDENTS AND NATIONAL COUNCIL ON HIGHER EDUCATION (CNES) JUNE 16. BOTH PARTIES AGREED TO NEED FOR MODIFICATION OF 1972 FUNDAMENTAL LAW OF BOLIVIAN UNIVERSITY

191441Z
BY A NEW SUPREME DECREE, FOLLOWING WHICH A UNIVERSITY ASSEMBLY
(CLAUSTRO UNIVERSITARIO) COULD MEET TO SELECT NEW ACEDEMIC AUTHORITIES. AGREEMENT ALSO WAS REACHED TO HOLD PUBLIC EX- AMINATIONS OF COMPETENCE FOR CURRENT TEACHING PERSONNEL IN BOLIVIAN UNIVERSITIES, MANY OF WHOM OBTAINED THEIR POSTS THROUGH POLITICAL CONNECTIONS. STUDENTS AND EDUCATION AUTHORITIES ALSO DETERMINED THAT ELECTIONS FOR STUDENT REPRESENTATIVES SHOULD BE HELD IN NEAR FUTURE, AND IN MEANTIME ANNOUNCED CLOSURE OF CUB AND FUL OFFICES SINCE LEADERS OF THESE BODIES WERE NOT ELECTED TO THEIR POSTS AND THUS LACK OFFICIAL UNIVERSITY RECOGNITION. STEDMAN

title: Us Response To Economic Plight Of Bolivia’s New Civilian Government
text:
Date:
          November 16, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Immediate 9333
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ads-00 Sso-00 /031 W ——————071398 162301z /15 O 162235z Nov 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          Us Response To Economic Plight Of Bolivia’s New Civilian Government
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EFIN, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

(C - ENTIRE TEXT)
THE RAVAGES OF COLONEL NATUSCH’S TWO-WEEK REGIME AND THE POPULAR RESISTANCE TO IT HAVE LEFT BOLIVIA’S CIVILIAN GOVERNMENT WHICH SHOULD BE FORMED LATE TONIGHT WITH AN IMMEDIATE FINANCIAL CRISIS AND SEVERE DAMAGE TO THE ECONOMY. REMAINING LIQUID EXCHANGE RESERVES HAVE BEEN EXHAUSTED, THE BANKS ARE CLOSED, THE DOLLAR (PREVIOUSLY 20/1) IS NOW SELLING IN THE STREETS AT THE PANIC LEVEL OF 39 PESOS AND THERE IS CLEARLY NO WAY EXCHANGE TRANSACTIONS BY THE BANKING SYSTEM CAN BE RENEWED ON MONDAY WITHOUT A FLOAT OR DEVALUATION (MORE LIKELY A FLOAT SINCE THE CENTRAL BANK HAS NO RESERVES TO DEFEND A NEW RATE). AT LEAST THREE WEEKS OF MINING AND ENERGY PRODUCTION HAVE BEEN LOST, ASSURING THAT THE GOVERNMENT’S FINANCES AND THE BALANCE OF PAYMENTS WILL BE HUNDREDS OF MILLIONS OF DOLLARS IN THE RED FOR 1979. SHORT SUPPLIES OF FOOD AND FUEL, PLUS EXCHANGE RATE DEVELOPMENTS HAVE ALREADY CAUSED PRICES OF SOME

162254Z
BASIC CONSUMPTION ITEMS IN LA PAZ TO RISE ABOUT 20 PERCENT. PREVIOUS GOVERNMENTS HAVE MADE NO ARRANGEMENTS TO MEET BOLIVIA’S NEEDS FOR WHEAT BEYOND JANUARY 15, 1980.

ONE OF THE REASONS NATUSCH AND SOME OF HIS COTERIE YIELDED WAS THAT THE MILITARY COULD NOT FIND THEIR WAY OUT OF THIS FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC CRISIS. IT
      Sheryl P. Walter 

   Sheryl P. Walter 

WILL BE IMPORTANT FOR THE FUTURE OF THE BOLIVIAN POLITICAL PROCESS THAT THE CIVILIAN GOVERNMENT CAN INDEED FIND ITS WAY OUT, WITH INTERNATIONAL HELP.

THE US SHOULD RESPOND PROMPTLY AND GENEROUSLY TO THE NEW GOVERNMENT’S PLIGHT. IN SIGNIFICANT PART WE CAN DO THIS BY REVIVING ALL OUR SUSPENDED ECONOMIC AID PROGRAMS, SOME WITH AN AMENDED FOCUS, AND OFFERING IMMEDIATE HELP ON WHEAT IMPORTS. IN PARTICULAR I SUGGEST THE FOLLOWING:

–OFFERING AN IMMEDIATE $10 MILLION CCC CREDIT, AS THE FASTEST WAY TO TRY TO GET SOME WHEAT HERE BY MID-JANUARY. HOPEFULLY THE SECRETARY OF AGRICULTURE CAN AGREE TO RE-PROGRAM THIS MODEST AMOUNT FOR BOLIVIA;
–NEGOTIATING AN AMENDMENT TO THE PL-480 TITLE III AGREEMENT AS SOON AS POSSIBLE FOR $17 MILLION WORTH OF WHEAT, WHICH WOULD COME IN BEHIND THE CCC WHEAT AND MEET VIRTUALLY ALL OF BOLIVIA’S CONSUMPTION NEEDS FOR THE REST OF FY 80. THE COUNTERPART FROM OUR TITLE III WHEAT WILL ALSO HELP THE GOVERNMENT TO CONTINUE SOME PUBLIC INVESTMENT IN THE RURAL SECTOR;
–WE SHOULD BE IMMEDIATELY AUTHORIZED TO CONCLUDE
162254Z
THE AGRICULTRUAL CREDIT LOAN ($14 MILLION), IN THE NEXT WEEK OR SO.

THESE THREE MEASURES SHOULD, IF POSSIBLE, BE ANNOUNCED IN A SINGLE $41 MILLION PACKAGE, AT THE EARLIEST POSSIBLE MOMENT. WE SHOULD OBVIOUSLY NOT MAKE SUCH AN ANNOUNCEMENT UNTIL AN AGREEMENT IN PRINCIPLE HAS BEEN REACHED WITH THE IMF (NOT BOARD ACTION); HOWEVER, THIS POINT MAY COME VERY SOON, SINCE THE BASIC ACTIONS IN THE IMF’S LONG-STANDING PROPOSALS (EXCHANGE RATE CHANGE AND INCREASED PETROLEUM PRODUCTS PRICES) ARE LIKELY TO BE TAKEN WITHIN THE NEXT 72 HOURS. THE OTHER PARTS OF THE IMF PROGRAMARE NOT CONTROVERSIAL.
WE SHOULD ALSO RENEW OUR EARLIER OFFER (TO PRESIDENT GUEVARA) TO TRY TO REFLECT ANY BOLIVIAN SUGGESTIONS IN OUR PROPOSED PROGRAM OF TIN SALES TO BE PRESENTED TO THE ITC FOR CONSULTATION. NEUTRALIZING ANY IMPACT OF GSA SALES ON THE TIN PRICE REMAINS VITAL TO BOLIVIA’S PRECARIOUS PROSPECTS FOR ECONOMIC STABILIZATION AND RECOVERY.
   Sheryl P. Walter 

   Sheryl P. Walter 
THE TIMING AND CONTENT OF DECISIONS ON MILITARY ASSISTANCE ARE MORE COMPLEX AND SHOULD BE DEFERRED FOR NOW. I RECOMMEND, HOWEVER, THAT WASHINGTON MOVE AS FAST AS POSSIBLE TO PUT US IN A POSITION TO MAKE SOME ANNOUNCEMENT ON THE ECONOMIC PACKAGE ABOVE. BOEKER

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

GOB delegation to IDB Annual Meeting reportedly will consist of Lic. Manuel Mercado, President, Central Bank, Luis Viscarra, General Manager, Central Bank, Guiddo Valle, ex-IDB Director for Bolivia, Paraguay and Uruguay, Hector Ormachea, ex-Minister of Industry and Commerce and Director Designate of still to be established Institute of External Financing.
MINFIN, who is IDB Governor, will not attend. He had promised Embassy coordinated response points (A) and (B) of para 2 ref A, but did say that flood damage reconstruction financing would be major topic for Bolivia at meeting and that specific IDB loan problems such as loans for YPFB refineries and Oruro-Quillacollo Highway probably would be dealt with in meetings with IDB missions already in Bolivia or soon to arrive.
MINFIN subsequently asked Ormachea to call ECONOFF to discuss points (A) and (B). According to Ormachea, GOB del will wish discuss with U.S. del possible second loan for the Central Bank Agricultural Rediscount Fund (FRA), further PL-480 Title I Sales Agreement and flood reconstruction financing. GOB position on matters to be formally raised in plenary has not yet been established. Mercado and Ormachea agreed to meet with ECONOFF on March 25 to provide further info on points (A) and (B).
Re point (C) para 2 ref (A), believe Treasury officials of U.S. del should explore with Mercado and Viscarra Bolivia’s balance of payments estimates (which are being carefully reviewed by annual Art. VIII IMF mission at present time) and with Ormachea YPFB’s prospects, plans and creditworthiness for possible Eximbank financing for major projects such as gas pipeline from Santa Rosa-Yapacani fields to Brazilian border at Corumba and Mutun iron/manganese deposit, fertilizer, pesticide and herbicide plants. YPFB also requires some US$ 30 million additional financing over US$ 46.5 million thus far offered by IDB for refineries program and has been negotiating with commercial banks to cover this requirement.
Ref B provides Mission’s current views on IDB program for Bolivia. We reiterate our concern that all agencies, bilateral and multilateral continue urge upon GOB desirability preparation agricultural production plan and coordination of its financing.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM

SUBJECT FIRM IS THE NATIONAL AIRLINE 99 PERCENT OWNED BY THE BOLIVIAN GOVERNMENT. BRANIFF AIRLINES OWN LESS THWN 1 PERCENT OF SHARES. PER A-188, A PARTIAL WTDR IS HEREBY SUBMITTED TO SATISFY REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.
ADDRESS: CASILLA 691, AVENIDA CAMACHO 1460, LA PAZ, BOLIVIA. CABLE: LAB LA PAZ. TELEX: LAB LPZ BX 5309. PHONE: 53054. OFFICER: EMILIO BALDIVIA, PRESIDENT.
LLOYD AEREO BOLIVIANO IS BOLIVIAN NATIONAL AIRLINE CURRENTLY SERVING MAJOR DOMESTIC ROUTES AND INTERNATIONALL ROUTES TO LIMA, SAO PAULO AND BUENOS AIRES. LOCAL BRANIFF VICE PRESIDENT SITS ON LAB’S BOARD. ONLY OTHER NATIONAL PASSENGER CARRIER IS MILITARY-RUN TRANSPORTES AEROS MILITARES (TAM) COVERING ROUTES TOUCHING POINTS EVEN MORE REMOTE THAN LAB’S MOST RURAL STOPS.
FINANCIAL REFERENCES: N/A, PER A-188. TRADE REFERENCES: N/A, PER A-188. TRADE REFERENCES: N/A, PER A-188.
MAJOR FOREIGN FIRMS REPRESENTED: N/A PER A-188.

062104Z

LAB HAS BEEN FREQUENT TARGET OF PUBLIC CRITICISM,

INCLUDING CHARGE THAT IT EMPLOYS EXCESSIVE STAFF. WITH CHANGE OF MANAGEMENT, MID-YEAR 1973, LAB TRIED TO STWNDARIZE AROUND FEWER AIRCRAFT TYPES. AS CONSEQUENCE OF THIS AND OTHER REFORMS, COMPANY’S PRESIDENT REPORTED IN 1973 FIRST ANNUAL PROFIT IN MANY YEARS. COMPANY REORGANIZATION NOW CONTINUING UNDER NEW PRESIDENT APPOINTED JULY 1974. LAB HAS RECEIVED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FROM INTERNATIONAL AGENCIES IN PAST. IN 1971 US EXPORT-IMPORT BANK LOAN FOR PURCHASE OF FIRST 727 FROM BOEING AND TWO F-27 FROM FAIRCHILD. AS PART OF RE-CAPITALIZATION OF AIRLINE IN 1973, GOB TREASURY ASSUMED RESPONSIBILITY FOR LOANS. IN MAY 1974 LAB PURCHASED SECOND JET, A USED 727, OUT OF OWN CASH FLOW AND LOAN FROM GOB CENTRAL BANK. WITH ADDITIONAL CAPACITY LAB NOW PLANNING EXTENSIONS OF AND INCREASED FREQUENCIES ON INTERNATIONAL ROUTES WHICH ARE MAIN PROFIT-POINT IN LAB’S OPERATION. LAB IS FURTHER CONTEMPLATING TO REPLACE IN NEAR FUTURE SIX DC-3 TYPE AIRCRAFT WITH SMALL TURBOPROPS WHICH CAN MORE ECONOMICALLY SERVE REQUIRED STOPS IN MORE REMOTE AREAS.

LAB DOES ITS OWN CENTRALIZED PURCHASING. PURCHASES BOTH LARGE AND SMALL TICKET ITEMS DIRECTLY FROM FOREIGN MANUFACTURERS AND SUPPLIERS. LAB HAS UNTIL NOW BOUGHT ONLY FROM USA. BUT HAS BEGUN EGOTIATIONS WITH SOUTH AFRICAN AIRLINE FIRM. LAB IS LATELY LOOKING FOR LONG TERM CREDIT LOANS TO PURCHASE SMALL TURBOPROPS. THIS INFORMATION WAS PROVIDED TO THIS EMBASSY AS AN ADVANCE IN HIS PLANS BY LAB’S NEW PRESIDENT.
DATE OF INFO: 08/74. STEDMAN

title: Proposed Reply Of President Carter To President Padilla’s Letter Of July 6
text:
Date:
          July 08, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Niact Immediate 7151
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ads-00 Sso-00 /026 W ——————103473 082010z /62 O 081931z Jul 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          Proposed Reply Of President Carter To President Padilla’s Letter Of July 6
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PFORN, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          A) LA PAZ 5832, B) LA PAZ 5831
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

C-Entire text.
Summary: I recommend that we use the opportunity of Padilla’s letter to the President to reply promptly and responsively in a way that would strengthen Padilla’s hand in getting his generals to accept the electoral result. Since the mood in the armed forces is somewhat better than we had anticipated, our reply can be less heavy than we earlier considered. The main point should be to indicate to the Bolivian military that democratic government will be a significant boost to Bolivia’s chances to realize its economic, political and diplomatic objectives. Padilla wants to see me Tuesday night, but I could probably put this off to Wednesday night. Hopefully by then I would be able personally to deliver the President’s reply to Padilla. End summary.
My suggested draft reply (in paragraphs 4 to 9 below) presumes decisions and actions on two matters: a successful approach to Senator Hart to get him to delay reporting out a stockpile disposal bill until after the Senate’s August recess; and a decision on our delegation to the inauguration, which I hope can be headed by Mrs. Carter, if at all possible. The proposed commitment not to sell tin in 1979 is not really a separate policy decision, since if the Congressional authorization is delayed to September, the normal consultation process will delay sales until 1980 in any event.
Begin suggested draft letter. Dear Mr. President. I have taken to heart your thoughtful letter of July 6, in which you raise your concerns regarding U.S. tin policy and its relationship to Bolivia’s return to constitutional, elected government. I appreciate your raising these concerns with me in the cordial and open manner that is a hallmark of U.S. - Bolivian relations.
First of all, Mr. President, let me congratulate you and Bolivian armed forces for your stalwart leadership in returning your country to democratic rule–a venture which has captured the imagination and admiration of my country and Bolivia’s friends everywhere. The successful completion of this hopeful process with the August 6 inauguration will place Bolivia firmly among the democratic countries of our Hemisphere and enhance Bolivia’s international standing and capacity to achieve its economic, political and diplomatic objectives.
On the matter of tin, let me assure you that the United States will manage any eventual disposals so as to safeguard against disruption of the tin market and the economic position of producers, including Bolivia. In response to your letter, the White House has contacted Senator Hart who, in recognition of Bolivia’s return to constitutional rule, has agreed to postpone Senate action on stockpile legislation until after the Senate’s August recess. This should assure that no dramatic news on tin occurs during the final stage of Bolivia’s efforts to complete the election process in your Congress. I can also assure you that no tin sales will take place in 1979, when Bolivia’s elected government is developing and implementing a program to stabilize the country’s economy. Any sales plans in 1980 will be developed on the basis of full consultation with Bolivia’s new, elected government, as well as with other producers, and will be designed to the best of our abilities to avoid depressing the export earnings Bolivia’s new government will need for its stabilization effort. You can also rest assured that my government will work through the international financial institutions and with Bolivia’s new government to help that government raise the financial support necessary to back a sound stabilization program.
I am aware of your country’s plans to raise the issue of Bolivia’s aspiration for access to the sea at the OAS General Assembly meeting this October in La Paz. You know from my remarks to the OAS last year of my personal interest in this question. We will now be awaiting Bolivia’s definition of an approach to this issue with every desire to be supportive wherever we can.
To express as clearly as possible to the Bolivian people our goodwill and deep appreciation of the country’s orderly return to constitutional rule, I am asking my wife Rosalyn (alternate choice) to represent me at the inauguration of Bolivia’s new President on August 6.
As, Mr. President, approach the final stage of Bolivia’s return to constitutional rule, a process which you have so steadfastly overseen, let me wish Bolivia full success in this historic venture, and to you personally all the best in the future. End of suggested draft letter.
The President’s reply to Padilla would be most effective if I could have it in time to deliver personally by P.M. Wednesday July 11.

El Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores y Culto, saluda muy atentamente a las Honorables Misiones Diplomaticas acreditadas ante el Gobierno de Bolivia y tiene a honra poner en su conocimiento que, al restablecerse el orden democratico iniciado en agosto ultimo, como es del dominio publico, el Honorable Congreso Nacional ha designado a la Excelentisima Senora Dona Lidia Gueiler Tejada como Presidente Constitucional Interino de la Republica.

Our government welcomes Bolivia’s return to democratic processes and through this Embassy has the honor to inform the Ministry that the Government of the United States fully reciprocates the desire expressed in the Ministry’s note to continue the cordial relations between our two governments.

title: Bolivian Foreign Minister Plannig To Deliver Letter From President Banzer To President Nixon
text:
Date:
          April 15, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 2826
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Sso-00 /031 W ——————— 074228 R 151710z Apr 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Bolivian Foreign Minister Plannig To Deliver Letter From President Banzer To President Nixon
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PBOR PFOR BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Bolivian Foreign Minister Guzman intends to deliver to Secretary Kissinger a letter from President Banzer to President Nixon. According to the Foreign Minister, the letter requests comprehension of the USG of Bolivia’s hopes for an outlet to the sea. The letter will also express Banzer’s regret at not having been able to visit the US in fall 1973 and will note Banzer’s interest in making the visit at sometime in the future.
Sub-Secretary Foreign Ministry told me that the letter to President Nixon is not drafted as a request for any action on our part but rather is a review of what Bolivia considers to be an unjust situation and is designed to elicit from the US favorable understanding. The Sub-Secretary indicated that Bolivia may discuss its land-locked position with other Foreign Ministers but for the moment has put aside the idea of a circular memorandum to other Foreign Ministers.
Foreign Ministry has come under domestic political pressure to show some forward motion on behalf of Bolivia regarding an outlet to the sea. Leading La Paz newspaper Diario has criticized the Foreign Minister for ineptness in previous meetings and has joined others in calling on the Foreign Minister to express more clearly in meetings in Washington/Atlanta Bolivia’s deep-seated desires for an opening to the sea.
If the letter is indeed drafted as I have been told, it should not be difficult to answer. However, in the current emotional state here on return to sea, the reply should be written bearing in mind that it very likely will be published in the Bolivian press. With regard to a repeat invitation to President Banzer to visit the US, I would hope for a bland acknowledgment, again suggesting that it would be possible but at a mutually convenient time for both Presidents.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Reftel gives the FY 74 allocation of MAP for Bolivia at $2.730 million (Materiel $2.300, Training $.400). Since this represents a substantial cut in anticipated level and will dismay GOB and cause problems for US with GOB military at a crucial time in Bolivian political situation, I would appreciate urgent reconsideration and upward ajustment in the Bolivia program for FY 74 to a level not less than the Continuing Resolution authority which has become common knowledge. I offer the following reasons in support of my request: A. The FY 74 allocation of $2.73 million is a reduction from the Continuing Resolution level of $3.5 million consisting of $2.9 million MAP-M and $.6 million MAP-T. To go below $3.5 million will mean heavy cuts of much needed equipment and training to operate equipment already delivered under the FY 72 and FY 73 programs for all services. B. Bolivian authorities have been pressing US hard in recent weeks for expeditious delivery of equipment in ongoing programs. They appear to be wondering whether we are holding back for some un-stated reasons. Were I to inform the Bolivian government at this time that the MAP grant program is now down to $2.73 million when they have knowledge that CR level is $3.5 million, their concerns would be increased and our rapport cum credibility reduced. C. A reduction in the Military Aid Program will be viewed as companion piece to “bad news” on PL480. We have had to tell the GOB that there will be no further PL-480 Title One program for FY 74 and that the chances are slim that there will be any for FY 75. The impact on President Banzer, personally, will be quite negative. D. Recently the Bolivian military authorities came to US with an urgent appeal for ammunition, and while we did approve the sale, we initially conditioned it on their coming to Panama to pick it up and our making a collection of payment in advance of its delivery. While this was ultimately worked out to our and the Bolivians satisfaction, nevertheless our conditions were not well received. E. I would observe that this 2.73 figure is drastically below the MAP figures in our approved CASP (4.7 million), in the Congressional Presentation Document (4.450 million) and in the Congressional Presentation Document as published (5.2 million). I have no basis on which to explain to the GOB why these higher figures are inoperative or what has caused this cut in the Bolivian MAP. While we may be misinformed, we have heard informally that the Congress has authorized funds sufficient to cover the approved Bolivian program. F. Bolivia is passing through a critical and fluid political/military period. President Banzer, although an army general, is now quite dependent on the Bolivian Armed Forces for his survival. Recent decisions on the economic front have brought the popularity of the Banzer regime to its lowest point since the October ’72 devaluation, with a consequent increase in divisive tendencies within the military. In a setting such as this, we can further our interests at little cost; or we can lose effective rapport by making the downward cut in our FY-74 MAP. The military program has been one of my principal influence and leverage mechanisms with the GOB. I have been able through the military program to apply pressure or to enlist support where political and economic means were not appropriate. To reduce the effectiveness of the tool will harm my ability to operate effectively.
In view of foregoing, I strongly recommend that ways be found to hold the FY-74 MAP program at the FY-73 level. Meantime, I shall not inform GOB nor will I have MILGP do so either.
