title: Us/Gob Narcotics Program: Proposed Demarche By President Carter’s Representative To Bolivian Inaugural
text:
Date:
          July 21, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Priority 7352
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ara-11 Ads-00 Deae-00 Ciae-00 Inr-10 Io-14 Jus-01 Nsae-00 Ctme-00 Sp-02 Trse-00 Ica-11 Nsc-05 Oes-09 Omb-01 Ss-15 Hew-04 Dode-00 Agr-01 Aid-05 /095 W ——————113256 211257z /43 P 211200z Jul 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          Us/Gob Narcotics Program: Proposed Demarche By President Carter’s Representative To Bolivian Inaugural
        
                    
          TAGS:
          SNAR, OVIP, PDIP, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

I recommend that the US delegation to the Bolivian August 6 inauguration, headed by Mrs. Carter, take this opportunity for a strong demarche to the President-elect on US desire for more effective GOB cooperation on our US/GOB narcotics program. This newly elected president will be beholden to us for our support of democratization in Bolivia. He will also have significant requests for further economic and political support from us. Therefore, it is the right time for us to raise our desiderata. Since late 1977 there has been a lack of strong commitment and drive from the top of the GOB, partly resulting from the electoral campaigns of 1978 and 1979. The US must seize the opportunity of the inauguration to impress upon the President-elect our major concern with illicit cocaine trafficking and production. The main point to impress upon him is that sterner, more disciplined GOB policies and enforcement action from the cabinet on down should be adopted. To help finance this increased Bolivian effort and to make it politically tolerable for the new president, the US will need to offer new financial support for narcotics programs in Bolivia. We should offer in return for Bolivian commitments $15 million (over five years) for measures to control the coca leaf market and, in addition to presently planned USAID projects for Bolivia in FY80, $19 million for an agricultural development program which will provide small farmers the incentives to cease or restrict their production of coca. Our ideas on the general content of a memorandum for the White House proposing such a demarche follow.

A. Problem 1. Since November 1977, when then President Banzer announced that elections were to be held in July 1978, progress in achieving our goal of reducing the illicit flow of cocaine to the US has been disappointing. While substantial progress has been made in laying structural and institutional foundations for future efforts and drug seizures in 1979 have increased somewhat, the Bolivian Government has not shown the will to live up to its commitments. Primarily for political reasons related to election campaigns, the GOB has been weak and ineffective in the narcotics area, as indeed in others. 2. The GOB needs a sharp kick to awake it to its responsibility to: * Move against major traffickers; * Curtail or destroy new, illegal coca plantings; * Support vigorously an effective program of replacement income for farmers in coca areas; * Reduce corruption in the judicial system and keep traffickers in jail. 3. Bearing in mind the weakness of Bolivian political institutions and the US goal of encouraging free, democratic elections in Bolivia, we have not recently sought to force these issues. We should now, however, seek the new President’s commitment on these four points and, if we get it, offer our cooperation to implement a comprehensive strategy. 4. If the new government is found unwilling to cooperate with the USG in this respect, we should review again our narcotics strategy vis-a-vis Bolivia. A modest enforcement support program and a DEA presence in Bolivia will always be worthwhile for the US. However, without effective GOB action on enforcement, penal and judiciary reforms and destruction of new coca plantings, it is doubtful that major expansions of enforcement programs, large-scale agricultural development and coca income substitution plans or the establishment of a coca crop marketing monopoly would ever be successful in reducing production to the level demanded by the legal (chewing and leaf exports) market.
B. Talking Points 1. For over three years the US has been engaged in an intensified cooperative campaign with the GOB to suppress the production and illicit traffic in cocaine. The US has contributed about $8.5 million to this effort since 1975 and has plans for greatly increased contributions and expanded efforts during the forthcoming years. 2. Nevertheless, the flow of cocaine continues unabated. As much as 48 metric tons of cocaine hydrochloride and base valued at about $170 million may continue to be exported from Bolivia. 3. The actual and potential danger which this represents to Bolivian youth continues and the corruptive and distorting effects on Bolivia’s young democracy of the flows of black money resulting from the traffic are on the increase.

text:

          1979 Human Rights Report: Bolivia Text Of 1979 Human Rights Report For Bolivia Follows: (Begin Text) Introduction
        
                    
          TAGS:
          SHUM, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Located in the heart of South America, land-locked Bolivia achieved its independence August 6, 1825. Since that time political instability has been an impediment to economic and social progress which in turn has resulted in an uneven record in terms of human rights observance. However, this trend began to change in 1977 when President Banzer initiated a liberalization of virtually all major restrictions on human rights, releasing all political prisoners, allowing exiles to return and scheduling elections for July 1978. The momentum of human rights progress has continued for the succeeding two years, with the sole dramatic exception of the violent 15-day rule of coup leader Alberto Natusch in November 1979.
The human rights momentum was not checked by the Pereda coup (August 1978) or the Padilla take-over (November 1978). Instead, while representing brief interruptions in the democratization process, both governments contributed to the improving human rights situation: Pereda by abrogating the feared State Security Law, and Padilla by holding in July 1979 perhaps the most democratic elections in Bolivia’s history.
Since none of the eight presidential hopefuls achieved the needed majority of the popular vote in the July 1979 elections, the Congress selected Senate President Walter Guevara Arze to be interim president with new elections scheduled for May 1980.
Guevara’s government came to an abrupt end November 1, 1979, when a group of military officers and civilians under the leadership of Army Colonel Alberto Natusch Busch seized the government. Strong popular reaction against the coup and its interruption of the democratic process, resulted in the implementation of press censorship, a state of siege, and martial law. Uncontrolled military elements confronted protesting but unarmed civilians, resulting in the confirmed death of approximately 208 persons, the wounding of 207 others, and the unaccountable disappearance of 124 citizens, now presumed dead. Popular discontent, an unprecedented seven-day strike by the Confederation of Bolivian Workers (COB), and Natusch’s repressive measures hastened the demise of his regime.
Consequently on November 16 he was forced to resign and was replaced by Chamber of Deputies President Lidia Gueiler according to an agreement reached between the Congress, the COB, and the Armed Forces. President Guevara, who had become a resistance symbol in hiding during the Natusch regime, returned to his former Senate position. Ms. Gueiler is to be Bolivia’s interim president until the inauguration on August 6, 1980 of the winner in May elections.
Bolivia’s dire economic situation will undoubtedly complicate matters. Faced with dwindling foreign reserves and declining production of petroleum and tin, the new government will have to take strong economic measures to return Bolivia to economic solvency.

Section 1 - Respect for the integrity of the person, including freedom from: A. Torture

The Bolivian Constitution clearly prohibits cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment. Presidents Padilla and Guevara respected this constitutional guarantee; there were no reports of torture during their brief governments. Allegations of torture during the short-lived Natusch regime remain unsubstantiated, but are currently under investigation by the Permanent Assembly on Human Rights (PAHR).
The assembly was also tasked by the Bolivian Congress on November 19 to document all cases of persons killed, wounded, or missing as a result of Natusch’s repressive tactics. When completed, these lists of names will be made public, although it is questionable whether such evidence will lead to any trials and convictions in the near future.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Dr. Jorge Del Villar, member of Law of Sea Department of Foreign Ministry, told Emboff March 15 that GOB is beginning intensive preparations for Caracas Conference in effort to avoid improvisation which characterized previous Bolivian participation in UN-sponsored LOS meetings. Bolivians are currently working on Kampala Landlocked States Conference, where Bolivia will be represented by Dr. Felipe Treidinnick Abasto, Minister-Counsellor of the Bolivian Embassy in Madrid, Spain. Dr. Treidinnick is a career diplomat and lawyer who has specialized in question of Bolivia’s right to an access to the sea.
According to Dr. Del Villar, Bolivia is hopeful that Kampala conferees will agree to a unified position which will enable these nations to bargain as a bloc with other participants in forthcoming Caracas Conference. Bolivia already has carried out extensive consultations with Paraguay, and feels confident that the Paraguayans will go along with Bolivia’s initiatives at Kampala meeting. Bolivia’s major initiative at latter conference will be call for establishment of an international organization to control exploitation of sub-surface sea resources, and apportion proceeds from these resources among both coastal and landlocked states. Del Villar expressed great interest in learning details of U.S. Government’s position on this issue.
Regarding the 200-mile limit question, Del Villar stated that Bolivia continues to oppose position adopted on this issue by four of its neighbors (Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru). Although he did not rule out possibility of bilateral bargaining on this issue between Bolivia and its neighbors, in return for concessions to Bolivia’s desire for a share in sub-surface sea resources, Del Villar said that Bolivian position on the territorial sea at present conforms much more closely to U.S. position on that issue.
Comment: This Embassy would appreciate receiving full information on any common positions adopted at Kampala Meeting of Landlocked States. At same time, Embassy also wishes to receive guidance on U.S. position re: exploitation of sub-surface sea resources, and Department’s views on degree of potential compatibility between our posture and that adopted by GOB, as expressed in paragraph 2 above.

          STATE 282993
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Embassy officer made points outlined reftel to MFA under secretary for exterior political affairs Moise Fuentes. Fuentes was not aware of the issue, but did note that Bolivia followed a line supportive of the Camp David Accords and one that eschewed introduction of divisive political issues in UN technical agencies. Hence his off-the-cuff reaction was that Bolivia would be helpful. Nevertheless, he requested an aide memoire to follow-up, since Bolivia will probably be represented at the conference by a technical functionary from the Agriculture Ministry, who would otherwise be unacquainted with some of the political issues.
We are preparing the memoire, and will provide name of Bolivian delegate when appointed, since follow-up in Rome might be useful. Fuentes also noted he had not been approached by Egyptian Embassy on the matter. A check with Egyptian Embassy reveals they have similar instructions, but had not planned their demarche before November 5.
Foregoing was prepared before attempted overthrow of Guevara regime, which is still in process. Hence follow-up will probably not be possible for an undetermined period.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED
Subject: First Person Note From Foreign Minister Guillermo Bedregal
The Ambassador received on the morning of November 3, the following first person note dated November 2, 1979 from Foreign Minister Guillermo Bedregal, announcing the installation of the Natusch regime:
Señor Embajador:
Tengo a honra poner en su conocimiento que el día de ayer, primero de noviembre, por decisión de las Fuerzas Armadas y con el apoyo del Movimiento Nacionalista Revolucionario Unificado y Renovado, además de vastos sectores de la ciudadanía, se constituyó en esta capital el popular y democrático Gobierno Civil Militar de índole constitucionalista y de izquierda nacional, que lideriza el señor Coronel Alberto Natusch Busch como Presidente de la República.
El Gobierno del Coronel Natusch Busch se ha comprometido solemnemente al mantenimiento cordial y efectivo de las relaciones internacionales con todos los países del mundo, dentro del más amplio pluralismo ideológico, así como al respeto de los convenios y tratados suscritos por Bolivia de acuerdo con las normas del Derecho Internacional. Asimismo, aspira a ser, en lo interno, el fiel y devoto servidor de las legítimas aspiraciones populares y en tal virtud mantendrá la más plena observancia de los Pactos de Derechos Humanos, Políticos y Sociales.
Cúmpleme informar también a Vuestra Excelencia y por su digno conducto a su ilustrado Gobierno, que es propósito del Gobierno de Bolivia encauzar el país dentro del más cuidadoso ejercicio de la democracia participativa y que, para tal fin, una de sus primeras medidas en el orden político interno será la convocatoria en un plazo prudencial, a una Asamblea Constituyente, a fin de que ella fije las nuevas normas constitucionales del Estado Boliviano, de acuerdo con las necesidades y aspiraciones del pueblo y las peculiaridades propias de su acontecer histórico.
Me valgo de la oportunidad para expresarle las seguridades de mi consideración más alta y distinguida.
Dr. Guillermo Bedregal Gutierrez Minister of Foreign Relations and Worship

text:

          Subject:
          Bolivia Four Shortages
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EAID, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          LA PAZ 0246, AND LA PAZ 244 SUMMARY: BOLIVIA CURRENTLY EXPERIENCING SERIOUS FLOUR SHORTAGE WITH SERIOUS POLITICAL IMPLICATIONS FOR GOVERNMENT. ALTHOUGH PRECISE REASONS FOR CURRENT PROBLEM DIFFICULT TO UNTANGLE, BASIC CAUSE APPEARS TO BE FAILURE OF ARGENTINA TO FULFILL COMMITMENTS FOR FLOUR DELIVERIES. THIS HAS BEEN COUPLED IN RECENT WEEKS WITH GREATER THAN USUAL TRANSPORTATION DIFFICULTIES FROM PORTS, ESPECIALLY PERUVIAN RAIL STRIKE WHICH SLOWED MOVEMENT OF PL-480 WHEAT FROM MATARANI. SITUATION MAY IMPROVE THIS WEEK AS RAILROADS NOW MOVING WHEAT AT NORMAL PACE AND SMALL QUANTITY OF FOUR DUE TO ARRIVE FROM ARGENTINA, BUT SHORTAGES LIKELY TO REAPPEAR SINCE STOCKS WILL CONTINUE LOW AND SCARCITIES HAVE INDUCED SPECULATION AND CREATION BLACK MARKET. END SUMMARY.
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

According to Millers’ Association on January 10, mills had only 1,525 M.T. of wheat stocks. Two of three La Paz mills and one of two mills in Oruro were out and closed January 11. Mills reopened January 14 using wheat that arrived over weekend. Oruro and La Paz are supplied from Matarani. Mills in Cochabamba, supplied from Antofagasta, have improved position in first week of year but mills in other interior towns also showed decline in stocks. Authorities estimate that daily wheat consumption is 632 M.T. in country, of which 138 M.T. consumed in La Paz.
Under normal circumstances 2,000 M.T. of wheat can be moved from Matarani per week and 1,680 M.T. from Antofagasta. In fact, in December only 10,250 M.T. of PL-480 reached Bolivia from ports. On January 10, 6,000 M.T. of PL-480 wheat from October arrivals still in Antofagasta and 5,935 M.T. in Matarani from arrivals in November and before.
As reported earlier, GOB contracted last year for 86,000 M.T. flour from Argentina. When agreement failed to function it renegotiated in October for delivery 30,000 M.T. flour in following three months. At minimum Bolivia thus expected to receive 15,000 M.T. before end of year. Only 5,000 M.T. arrived. Sub-Secretary of MININD/COM traveled to Buenos Aires last week and government has announced that 1,500 M.T. Argentine flour due to arrive at border this week.
Scarcity of foodstuffs, including sugar, meat and cooking oil, has become principal Bolivian conversation topic. Week January 7, long waiting lines evident throughout city, especially in working barrios. Small demonstration of workers in Quillacollo near Cochabamba protesting shortages and prices broken up by police January 11. Nasty charges of hoarding and profitmaking have been aimed at millers and bakers. Government has made highly publicized “raids” on warehouses and La Paz authorities are now supervising distribution of certain products. Problem becoming political issue. Element of FSB called for end of wheat subsidy and another dissident FSB element published PL-480 arrival information and implied that quantities being misdirected. (Comment: We have no evidence of this. Problem seems to be shortfall arrivals).
On TV broadcast January 15, MININD/COM stated that contraband routes into Peru and Chile had been closely checked in recent weeks and that only very small amounts of flour had been found. Said this suggested that flour being hoarded and black marketed. After review steps being taken to speed deliveries Argentine flour to La Paz, said situation should ease in seven to ten days. (Comment: Situation not likely to improve much or for long unless flour and wheat stocks can be built up).

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM

EMBASSY WISHES TO CALL THE ATTENTION OF THE DEPARTMENT AND USDEL LOS CONFERENCE CARACAS TO THE REFERENCED MESSAGES, CONCERNING A PROPOSED VISIT OF PROFESSOR CHARLES COCHRAN, US NAVAL ACADEMY, TO A PRIVATE-SPONSORED CONFERENCE IN LA PAZ OCTOBER 24-26 ON THE SUBJECT OF “LAW OF THE SEA: POST CARACAS”. ACCORDING TO INFORMATION SUPPLIED BY THE US NAVAL ACADEMY, PROFESSOR COCHRAN WISHES TO ATTEND THE CONFERENCE IN ORDER TO GATHER INFORMATION AND EXCHANGE IDEAS ON STATE RESPONSIBILITY AND LIABILITY IN THE AREA OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION, WHILE ALSO STUDYING THE DEVELOPMENT OF DISPUTE SETTLEMENT MECHANISMS FOR A NEW LOS STRUCTURE.
THE EMBASSY WISHES TO INFORM THE DEPARTMENT OF CERTAIN CONSIDERATIONS WHICH AFFECT THE ADVISABILITY OF GRANTING COUNTRY CLEARANCE FOR PROFESSOR COCHRAN’S ATTENDANCE AT THE SUBJECT CONFERENCE. FOR THE PAST SIX MONTHS, THE GOB HAS BEEN ENGAGED IN AN INTENSIVE PUBLICITY AND PROPAGANDA

092243Z
CAMPAIGN TO STIMULATE INTERNATIONAL AWARENESS OF ITS CLAIM
TO AN ACCESS TO THE SEA. BOLIVIAN DELEGATIONS TO MOST RECENT INTERNATIONAL MEETINGS AND CONFFERENCES, INCLUDING THE LOS CONFERENCE IN CARACAS, HAVE TAKEN THE OPPORTUNITY TO RAISE THIS SENSITIVE ISSUE, WHICH AS THE DEPARTMENT IS AWARE AFFECTS PRIMARILY THE NATIONAL INTERESTS OF BOLIVIA ITSSELF AND OF ITS TWO WESTERN NEIGHBORS: CHILE AND PERU. IT IS NOT UNLIKELY THAT BOLIVIA ALSO WILL SEEK TO USE A REGIONAL LEGAL CONFERENCE ON LOS, ESPECIALLY ONE TAKING PLACE IN LA PAZ, TO SEEK TO OBTAIN A RESOLTUION SUPPORTING THE GOB’S CURRENT POLITICAL OBJECTIVES IN THIS REGARD; THE POSITION OF A U.S. DELEGATE TO THE CONFERENNCE COULD THEN BECOME ESPECIALLY DELICATE, DUE TO THE GOB’S DESIRE TO ELICIT EXPRESSIONS OF SUPPORT FROM ANY INDIVIDUAL WHO HAS OFFICIAL LINKS TO THE US GOVERNMENT.

IN ADDITION, THE FOREIGN MINISTRY’S DIRECTOR-GENERAL OF INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS, DR. MOISES FUENTES, HAS INDICATED TO US THAT THIS CONFERENCE IS BEING PRIVATELY SPONSORED AND ORGANIZED BY DR. FEDERICO NIELSEN REYES, A POLITICAL OPPORTUNIST WHO HAS MADE SOMETHING OF A REPUTATION FOR HIMSELF AS AN IDEOLOGUE OF BOLIVIA’S “RIGHT” TO AN ACCESS TO THE SEA. NIELSEN WAS RECENTLY NAMED A MEMBER OF THE GOB’S “MARITIME COMMISSION,” WHICH IS CHARGED WITH DEVELOPING NEW STRATEGIES FOR THE ATTAINMENT OF THE DESIRED OUTLET TO THE PACIFIC OCEAN. WE BELIEVE THAT IT WOULD BE OUT OF CHARACTER FOR AN INDIVIDUAL OF NIELSEN’S BACKGROUND NOT TO ATTEMPT TO USE THIS CONFERENCE FOR THE PURPOSE OF DRUMMING UP SUPPORT FOR THE CAUSE TO WHICH HE HAS DEVOTED A GREAT PROPORTION OF HIS ATTENTION IN RECENT YEARS.
THE EMBASSY WOULD APPRECIATE RECEIVING THE DEPARTMENT’S VIEWS REGARDING THE ADVISABILITY OF GRANTING COUNTRY CLEARANCE FOR THIS VISIT, IN VIEW OF THE CONSIDERATIONS NOTED IN PARAGRAPHS TWO AND THREE. STEDMAN

          Applegate - Youngquist Land Expropriation Case Reference: 1) State 047381: A) State 46969
        
                    
          TAGS:
          ETRD, EAGR
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

The Embassy has received a copy of a letter signed by the Ministry of Industry and Commerce to Mr. J.A. Moran, attorney for Applegate-Youngquist, in reply to his letter to GOB of January 11. GOB reply inter alia 1) states the GOB cannot be subject to pressures or threats; 2) renews offer of compensation in form of land; 3) asks for documentation regarding Applegate-Youngquist payment of taxes prior to seizure of land, deeds of title and appointment of legal representative for Applegate & Youngquist, or alternatively their presence in Bolivia, in order to deal with GOB on the matter. Although the letter is somewhat brusque in tone, we do not necessarily consider it a step backward since the documents sought by GOB are presumably available in one form or another from Applegate & Youngquist.
GOB’s letter, of course, does not advance case beyond where it stood in December 1973 when GOB offered land in compensation but refused to pay any monetary compensation. Reftels, however, suggest that members House Agricultural Committee may have idea that GOB is totally intransigent on matter when in point of fact GOB offer of compensation in land represents considerable improvement in GOB position from what it was a few years ago. As regards Moran’s statement to Committee that he unaware of any “good faith efforts being made to settle case”, this at variance with his letter to GOB of January 11 in which he says “offer land compensation is first specific proposal for settlement received from GOB” and emphasizes “our appreciation” for offer. It should be noted also that Applegate & Youngquist would be free to sell land received in compensation if they do not choose to farm it. If land received in compensation can be sold at a price equivalent to the value of Applegate-Youngquist property at the time of taking, is this not in fact the same thing as monetary compensation? Finally, as far as Embassy aware, no Bolivian or foreigner has ever been compensated in any form for lands expropriated pursuant to Agrarian Reform legislation.
If House Committee seriously considering tightening discretionary provisions Sugar Act, Section 408 (C), with possible subsequent invocation against GOB, we believe Committee should have the full picture before acting. Testimony of lobbyist for GOB as reported State 046969, does not strike us as having given a complete picture of case. If Department unable to provide House Committee with current status report on case, we recommend that Bolivia’s lobbyist be advised promptly to do so.
We are pouching to ARA/BC copy of GOB letter of March 1.

IN VIEW OF RECENT INTELLIGENCE RECEIVED BY U.S. MISSION ON THIS TOPIC, EMBASSY SUGGESTS SOME EDITORIAL CHANGES IN PARAGRAPHS 24 AND 25 OF SUBJECT PAPER DEALING WITH BOLIVIA.
REVISED TEXT WOULD READ AS FOLLOWS: “PRESIDENT HUGO BANZER WOULD ALMOST CERTAINLY TRY TO EXPLOIT INCREASED TENSIONS BETWEEN PERU AND CHILE TO GAIN ACCESS TO THE PACIFIC OCEAN, PROBABLY BY ENCOURAGING BOTH COUNTRIES TO VIEW BOLIVIA AS A POTENTIAL BUFFER. COMMON HISTORICAL BACKGROUND, AND A COMMON AND DEEPLY ROOTED ANTIPATHY
TOWARD CHILE. HOWEVER, ALTHOUGH BOLIVIA HAS TRADITIONALLY VIEWED CHILE AS AS ENEMY, THE TWO GOVERNMENTS ARE PRESENTLY ON BETTER TERMS THAN AT ANY TIME SINCE THE 1962 BREAK IN DIPLOMATIC RELATIONS. BRAZIL HAS ALSO BEEN ENCOURAGING AS BOLIVIAN-CHILEAN RAPPROACHMENT. SECRET
SECRET
031412Z
ON BALANCE, IT APPEARS THAT IN THE FACE OF IMMINENT OR ACTUAL
HOSTILITIES, BOLIVIA WOULD MOST LIKELY REMAIN UNCOMMITED DUE TO A REALIZATION BY THE BANZER GOVERNMENT THAT POSSIBLE IMMEDIATE GAINS OBTAINED THROUGH INTERVENTION WOULD BE MORE THAN OFFSET IN THE LONGER TERMS BY DIFFICULTIES CAUSED BY BOLIVIA’S AFFECTED NEIGHBORS. IT SHOULD

SIDE, IT WOULD MOST LIKELY NOT BE WITH A MAJOR TROOP COMMITMENT, BUT ANY SUPPORT IT RENDERED WOULD HAVE A PSYCHOLOGICAL AS WELL AS DIVER- SIONARY EFFECT ON OPERATIONS AT THE FRONT.” STEDMAN

          Subject:
          President Banzer Comments On Us Economic And Military Assistance In Private Conversation With Ambassador
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PFOR EAID MASS BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

I CALLED ON PRESIDENT BANZER MAY 13 AT MY INITIATIVE TO REVIEW BILATERAL MATTERS PRIOR TO MY DEPARTURE FOR WASHINGTON. I TOLD THE PRESIDENT THAT OVER THE WEEKEND THE RECONSTRUCTION ASSESSMENT TEAM HAD DEPARTED AND THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE TEAM TO ASSESS ALTERNATE CROPS TO SUBSTITUTE FOR COCA HAD ARRIVED. I NOTED THAT AID WAS PREPARING AS EXPEDITIOUSLY AS POSSIBLE NEW LOANS IN THE AGRICULTURAL AREA, EDUCATION, AND FOR RURAL ELECTRIFICATION. I ALSO REPORTED THAT SEVERAL PIECES OF MILITARY EQUIPMENT HAD REACHED PERUVIAN PORTS IN RECENT DAYS AND THAT THE MILGP WAS IN THE PROCESS OF EXPEDITING ONWARD SHIPMENT TO LA PAZ.
PRESIDENT BANZER SAID THAT THE MOST URGENT NEED FOR EXTERNAL ASSISTANCE FROM THE LENDING AGENCIES WAS FOR REHABILITATION OF THE NATION’S RAILROADS AND ROADS AND THE CONSTRUCTION OF DEFENSES AGAINST FUTURE FLOOD DAMAGE. HE SAID HE HOPED THAT THE REPORT OF THE RECONSTRUCTION ASSESSMENT TEAM WOULD BE FOLLOWED PROMPTLY BY FINANCING FROM WASHINGTON AGENCIES. HE URGED THAT CONSIDERA- TION BE GIVEN TO A LOAN THROUGH THE EXISTING PADES MECHANISM FOR

141613Z
A SIGNIFICANT PART OF THE RECONSTRUCTION WORK. HE SAID THAT THE PADES MECHANISM EXISTS, FUNCTIONS WELL, AND COULD EASILY ABSORB
ADDITIONAL FUNDS FOR PUBLIC WORKS PROJECTS BUT THAT GOVERNMENT REVENUES WERE NOT AVAILABLE FOR THIS PURPOSE

PRESIDENT BANZER SAID THE NEXT MOST URGENT NEED IN EXTERNAL LENDINGWAS FOR COCA CROP SUBSTITUTION. FOLLOWING IN THE ORDER OF TIMING IN HIS JUDGMENT WERE THE LONG-TERM DEVELOPMENT LOANS OF AID. HE DEMONSTRATED FAMILIARITY WITH THE NEW LANDS LOAN AND SOME INFORMATION ON THE RURAL ELECTRIFICATION AND EDUCATION PROJECTS.
THE PRESIDENT EXPRESSED PLEASURE THAT MAP GRANT MILITARY EQUIPMENT WAS ARRIVING AND ASKED ME IF I WOULD HELP BOLIVIA OBTAIN C-130 TRANSPORT AIRCRAFT. HE SAID WHILE IT IS DESIRABLE TO HAVE TWO AIRCRAFT, NATURALLY THE COUNTRY WOULD BE SATISFIED TO START OFF WITH ONE. HE ADDED THAT WHILE IT WAS DESIRABLE TO HAVE NEW C-130’S, IT IS IMPORTANT TO HAVE UNITS ARRIVE PROMPTLY, SO THAT HE WOULD APPRECIATE OFFERS OF USED C-130’S IN GOOD CONDITION. HE SAID THAT IT WAS HIS HOPE THAT THE $4 MILLION FMS CREDIT WHICH HE HAS AUTHORIZED BOLIVIAN AUTHORITIES TO ACCEPT COULD BE CONSIDERED AS THE FIRST PAYMENT TOWARD ONE OR TWO USED C-130’S.
PRESIDENT BANZER ASKED ME TO EXPRESS TO US AUTHORITIES HIS BELIEF THAT THE ECONOMIC SITUATION IS IMPROVING BUT THAT THE NEEDS IN A COUNTRY IN THE LOW STATE OF DEVELOPMENT AS BOLIVIA ARE ENORMOUS. THUS HE WELCOMES CONTINUED RESOURCES FOR DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES IN BOLIVIA. HE SAID THAT POLITICALLY THE COUNTRY WAS TRANQUIL AND THE SITUATION STABLE. HE SAID THAT HE ANTICIPATES MAKING NO CHANGES IN THE CABINET WHICH HAS PROVEN ITSELF TO BE COMPETENT AND TECHNICALLY WELL QUALIFIED. HE WILL BRING IN REPRESENTATIVES OF THE SMALLER POLITICAL PARTIES BUT NOT AT THE CABINET LEVEL, PROBABLY BRINGING THEM INTO SUB-CABINET POSITIONS IN MINISTRIES AND PUBLIC SECTOR AGENCIES.
PRESIDENT BANZER WAS SUFFERING FROM A HEAVY COLD AND LOOKED TIRED AND RUNDOWN. HOWEVER, HIS MOOD WAS CONFIDENT AND, AS USUAL HE WAS VERY FRIENDLY. STEDMAN

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

COUNTRY TEAM BELIEVES US INTERESTS WELL SERVED BY CONTINUATION PRESENT LEVEL OF PUBLIC SAFETY TRAINING OF BOLIVIANS AT FACILITIES IN CONTINENTAL US, PARTICU- LARLY WHERE SUCH TRAINING INCLUDES NARCOTICS COURSES. AS DEPT AWARE, EMBASSY IS RECEIVING CLOSE COOPERATION FROM BOLIVIAN POLICE IN COMBATTING ILLICIT NARCOTICS TRAFFIC.
RELAXATION OF POLITICAL TENSIONS IN WAKE OF FORMATION OF ALL-MILITARY CABINET AND ANNOUNCEMENT OF ELECTIONS IN 1975 SHOULD BE REFLECTED IN GREATER TOLERANCE OF POLITICAL ACTIVITY, INCLUDING THAT OF OPPOSITION GROUPS. AS PRE- VIOUSLY REPORTED, MIN OF INTERIOR HAS BEEN INVOLVED FOR SOME TIME IN REVIEWING THE CASES OF POLITICAL PRISONERS. THIS REVIEW PROCESS HAS ALREADY RESULTED IN THE RELEASE OF SEVERAL PRISONERS, AND IT APPEARS MORE WILL BE RELEASED IN THE COMING WEEK.
POLITICAL PARTIES, INCLUDING SOME OPPOSITION GROUPS, HAVE APPLAUDED GOVERNMENT’S DECISION TO CALL FOR ELECTIONS IN 1975, THOSE IN OPPOSITION ANTICIPATING THAT A FAIRLY BROAD AMNESTY WILL BE DECLARED IN THE NEXT FEW WEEKS WHICH WILL ENABLE SOME EXILED LEADERS SUCH AS GUEVARA ARCE (PRA) AND BENJAMIN MIGUEL (PDC) TO RETURN AND RESUME THEIR PARTI-

111447Z
CIPATION IN BOLIVIAN POLITICS.

IN SHORT, THE GOB’S PERCEIVED NEED FOR SOME POLITICAL REPRESSION WHEN ANTI-GOVERNMENT PLOTTING IS UNCOVERED HAS NOW BEEN GREATLY REDUCED, AND WE FORESEE A POLITICAL OPENING OF SORTS WHICH SHOULD HELP TO IMPROVE BOLIVIA’S IMAGE IN THE US. STEDMAN

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED
As Department is aware, resalization of the Mutun project depends entirely on construction of the proposed Bolivia-Brazil gas pipeline. And although pipeline feasibility studies as well as conversations between the Bolivian and Brazilian governments are continuing, for political reasons it is highly unlikely that any final decision to go ahead with the pipeline will be taken this year. Therefore, realistically, we can expect no real progress on the Mutun project until at least late 1979. If, however, any new information on Mutun does surface, it will immediately be reported.

text:
Date:

          TAGS:
          PINT BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          LA PAZ 4777
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

THE NATIONAL COUNCIL OF STRUCTURAL REFORMS (CONARE), WHICH IS TO STUDY A SERIES OF PROPOSALS FOR FUNDAMENTAL CHANGES IN BOLIVIA’S POLITICAL INSTITUTIONS, WAS SWORN INTO OFFICE BY PRESIDENT BANZER ON JULY 30. CABINET MINISTERS, POLITICAL PARTY LEADERS AND THE JOINT COMMAND OF THE ARMED FORCES WERE PRESENT AT THE CEREMONY, WHICH MARKS THE FIRST

STAGE IN A PROCESS OF “CONSTITUIONALIZATION” SCHEDULED TO TERMINATE WITH THE INAUGURATION OF A NEW PRESIDENT IN DECEMBER 1975. IN IS SPEECH, BANZER NOTED THAT HIS GOVERNMENT SEEKS TO CREATE THE CONDITIONS WHICH WILL PERMIT THE ARMED FORCES TO RETURN TO THEIR BARRACKS, FOLLOWING TEN YEARS OF MILITARY RULE. AT THE SAME, TIME, HOWEVER, THE PRESIDENT
012206Z
NOTED T AT THE MILITARY WILL “OBSERVE AND GUARANTEE”
THE TRANSITION PROCESS TO CIVILIAN RULE, WHILE SUBSEQUENTLY RETAINING ITS ROLE AS THE “TRUE POWER FACTOR” IN BOLIVIAN SOCIETY.

THE THIRTY-MAN COUNCIL, -9 OF WHOSE MEMBERS TOOK OFFICE ON JULY 30, WILL NOW COMMENCE AN INTENSIVE PERIOD OF STUDY OF DIFFERING REFORM PROPOSALS. RECOMMENDATIONS FROM THE COUNCIL MUST BE PRESENTED TO THE GOB BY JANUARY 23, 1975, WHEN CONARE’S MANDATE EXIIRES; THESE PROPOSALS WILL THEN BE STUDIED, AND POSSIBLY MODIFIED, BY THE GOVERNMENT, PRIOR TO THEIR PRESENTATION TO THE PUBLIC IN A NATIONWIDE REFERENDUM ON MARCH 23, 1975. ACCORDING TO THE INTERNAL RULES OF PROCEDURE ADOPTED BY CONARE IN ITS FIRST MEETING, ALL MEMBERS OF THE COUNCIL WILL WORK FULL-TIME ON THEIR OFFICIAL DUTIES, FOR WHICH THEY WILL RECEIVE A SALARY FROM THE GOB. MOST OF CONARE’S WORK WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED IN COMMITTEES AND STUDY GROUPS; WHEN THE COUNCIL MEETS IN PLENARY SESSION, AN ATTEMPT WILL BE MADE TO ACHIEVE “CONSENSUS” ON EACH SUBJECT TO BE DEBATED, AND NO VOTES WILL BE TAKEN.
COMMENT: AS ORIGINALLY CONCEIVED BY THE BANZER GOVERNMENT, CONARE WAS TO BE COMPOSED OF FOUR REPRESENTATIVES FROM EACH OF THE GOVERNMENT PARTIES (MNR, FSB AND FUERZAS REVOLUCIONARIAS BARRIENTISTAS), CAMPESINOS AND THE ARMED FORCES, TOGETHER WITH 10 DISTINGUISHED PROFESSIONALS WHO WOULD PROVIDE THE COUNCIL WITH TECHNICAL EXPERTISE. HOWEVER, CONARE PRESIDENT EDWIN TAPIA, SECRETARY-GENERAL OF THE PRESIDENCY AND LEADER OF THE FRB, HAS ENCOUNTERED SERIOUS DIFFICULTIES IN ASSEMBLING THE COUNCIL’S MEMBERSHIP. IN THE WAKE OF THE OUTRIGHT REFUSAL BY ALL OPPOSITION PARTIES TO PARTICIPATE IN THE COUNCIL’S DELIBERATIONS, PLUS THE DECISION OF THE ARMED FORCES NOT TO BE OFFICIALLY REPRESENTED ON THE COUNCIL, CONARE IS NOW COMPOSED OF THE FOLLOWING GROUPS OF CITIZENS: THREE DELEGATES EACH FROM THE MNR, FSB AND FRB; ONE REPRESENTATIVE FROM EACH OF THE NINE DEPARTMENTS OF BOLIVIA: SIX REPRESENTATIVES FROM NON-POLITICAL INSTITUTIONS (LABOR, BUSINESS AND CAMIESINO ORGANIZATIONS) AND SIX IROFESSIONALS.
CONARE’S MEMBERSHIP REFLECTS THE GOB’S DIFFICULTY IN

012206Z
ATTRACTING PROMINENT POLITICAL NAMES TO THE COUNCIL. NO OPPOSITION POLITICIANS ARE PRESENT ON THE COUNCIL, WHILE THE REPRESENTATIVES OF THE PRO-GOVERNMENT PARTIES ARE LESSER POLITICAL LIGHTS, FEW OF WHOM ARE WILL-KNOWN IN BOLIVIAN
POLITICAL CIRCLES. CAMIESINO AND LABOR DELEGATES TO THE COUNCIL ALSO APPEAR TO HAVE BEEN CHOSEN MORE FOR THEIR
SUBSERVIENCE TO THE GOB’S WISHES THAN FOR ANY ABILITY TO SPEAK FOR THE CONSTITUENCIES WHICH THEY NOMINALLY REPRESENT. THE MOST NOTABLE COMMON CHARACTERISTIC OF THE COUNCIL’S TWENTY-NINE MEMBERS IS THEIR UNUSUALLY HIGH EDUCATIONAL LEVEL; 8 OF THE 29 ARE SUFFICIENTLY WELL-EDUCATED TO PREFACE THEIR NAMES WITH THE HONORARY TITLE OF DOCTOR. ALSO, SOME TEN OF THE COUNCIL’S MEMBERS HAVE RECEIVED LEGAL TRAINING.

THE COUNCIL WILL BE COMILETED WHEN A FURTHER LABOR REPRESENTATIVE IS CHOSEN; IF THE MINE WORKERS’ FEDERATION REJECTS THE POSITION OFFERED TO IT, THE LAST SEAT ON THE COUNCIL WILL GO TO A REPRESENTATIVE OF EITHER THE RAILWAY OR PETROLEUM WORKERS. A COMPLETE LIST OF THE COUNCIL WILL FOLLOW SHORTLY BY AIRGRAM. STEDMAN

          TAGS:
          ECON, EFIN, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

As of June 30, 1979, total GOB contracted external debt amounted to $US 3,381,342,000, an increase of 15 percent from December 30, 1978. Total disbursements were $US 1,867,350,000 as of June 30, 1979; $US 386.3 million was disbursed in 1978 and $US 186.0 million during the first six months of 1979.
The Central Government’s contracted debt represents the largest portion, 50 percent or $US 1,690.7 million, of the GOB’s total. Second largest is YPFB, the state oil company, with 12 percent or $US 409.8 million. COMIBOL, the state mining company, has 3 percent or $US 116.8 million and CBF, the state development corporation, $US 112.6 million.
Private foreign bank loans averaging 11.8 percent for 7.1 years represent 28.1 percent or $US 951.2 million of the GOB’s total contracted debt. The Central Government and YPFB have the greatest proportion, 30.5 and 23.3 percent respectively, of GOB total private foreign bank loans of which the largest part, $US 517.7 million or 54 percent, is placed with the mining, hydrocarbon and metallurgical sectors.
Although the GOB’s total contracted debt climbed by 21 percent from 1977 to 1978, debt service payments climbed by 40 percent to total $US 223.7 million in 1978. This year Bolivia’s debt service payments are estimated to total $US 272.4 million and are expected to reach $US 313.9 million in 1980 and $US 372.4 million in 1981. The debt service ratio increased from 25 percent in 1977 to 35 percent in 1978.

title: President Banzer Comments To Ambassador On Soviet Offers Of Military Equipment
text:
Date:
          June 21, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 3470
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 /031 W ——————— 111235 R 211247z Jun 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          President Banzer Comments To Ambassador On Soviet Offers Of Military Equipment
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PFOR MASS BL UR
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

DURING CALL I MADE JUNE 20 ON PRESIDENT BANZER FOR ANOTHER PURPOSE, I INDICATED THAT I HAD HEARD THAT BOLIVIAN MILITARY OFFICERS WERE EXPLORING POSSIBLE EQUIPMENT PURCHASES FROM EUROPEAN COUNTRIES AND THAT ONE OFFICER HAD RECEIVED OFFERS OF COMMUNICATIONS EQUIPMENT AND TANKS FROM THE SOVIET UNION. I INDICATED THAT I DID NOT KNOW VERY MUCH ABOUT THIS MATTER BUT HAD HEARD THAT THE BOLIVIAN ARMY WAS INTERESTED IN TANKS SINCE THEY HAD BEEN IN TOUCH WITH US RECENTLY. PRESIDENT BANZER PICKED UP MY REMARKS AND SAID THAT COL. RIVERA HAD MADE A TRIP FOR OTHER PURPOSES TO EUROPE AND HAD MADE A VISIT TO THE SOVIET UNION WHERE HE HAD RECEIVED OFFERS OF SOME MILITARY EQUIPMENT. PRESIDENT NOTED THAT SOVIET AMBASSADOR TO BOLIVIA HAD BEEN ACTIVE IN RECENT MONTHS TRYING TO PRESS MILITARY EQUIPMENT ON BOLIVIA AND ALSO HAD BEEN ACTIVE IN OFFERING SOVIET FINANCIAL AND TECHNICAL COOPERATION FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE BALA DAM. PRESIDENT ALSO INFORMED ME THAT HE WAS PLANNING TO NAME A NEW AMBASSADOR TO THE SOVIET UNION AND PROBABLY WOULD SEND DR. RICHARDO ANAYA OF COCHABAMBA. IN THE LATTER CONNECTION, HE SAID THE SUBJECT HAD COME UP AS TO WHETHER OR NOT BOLIVIA SHOULD ACCEPT EXCHANGE OF PERSONS PROGRAMS, INCREASED CULTURAL PRESENTA- TIONS, AND HOW TO DEAL WITH MILITARY EQUIPMENT OFFERS. PRESIDENT BANZER SAID THAT THERE HAD BEEN NO FORMAL OFFER MADE TO THE GOB AND THAT THE GOVERNMENT HAD NOT MADE ANY DECISION TO ACCEPT

211825Z
SOVIET EQUIPMENT. PRESIDENT SAID, ON HIS OWN VOLITION, THAT THE
GREAT DIFFICULTY WITH SOVIET EQUIPMENT, EVEN IF IT IS A GIFT, IS THAT IT GENERALLY COMES ACCOMPANIED BY TECHNICIANS WITH OTHER INTERESTS. HE SAID HIS OWN EXPERIENCE WITH THE SOVIETS HERE IN BOLIVIA WAS THAT HE HAD TO KICK OUT SEVERAL MEMBERS OF THE SOVIET MISSION FOR INTELLIGENCE ACTIVITIES. BUT, SAID PRESIDENT BANZER, THE PROBLEM IS THAT THE MORALE OF THE BOLIVIAN ARMY IS DEPENDENT UPON YOUNGER OFFICERS HAVING RELATIVELY NEW EQUIPMENT TO WORK WITH. GOB HAS NO INTENTION OF USING MILITARY EQUIPMENT, BUT THERE IS A NEED TO BOOST MORALE IN THE TROOPS. HE SAID THE BEST WAY TO COUNTER THE SOVIET PRESSURE FOR BOLIVIA TO ACCEPT THEIR MILITARY EQUIPMENT IS FOR THE PROMPT DELIVERY BY FRIENDLY COUNTRIES OF ITEMS APPROPRIATE FOR THE BOLIVIAN MILITARY.

PRESIDENT BANZER SAID THAT HE KNEW QUITE A BIT ABOUT THE TANK SITUATION AS THAT WAS HIS BASIC MILITARY SPECIALTY, HAVING BEEN TRAINED IN THIS IN THE U.S. HE SAID HE KNEW THE M-48 BUT CONSIDERED IT TOO HEAVY FOR BOLIVIA. HE VOLUNTEERED THAT HE KNEW THAT THE M-41 WAS NO LONGER AVAILABLE. IN SUM, HE SAID THAT HE WAS WELL AWARE THAT THE U.S. NO LONGER PRODUCES A MEDIUM SIZE TANK APPROPRIATE FOR BOLIVIA. ACCORDINGLY HE SAID THAT IT WOULD BE AN APPROPRIATE ALTERNATIVE IF WE WERE TO PROVIDE FOR BOLIVIAN PURCHASE OF “CARROS DE ASALTO.” HE SAID THAT HE HAD PERSONALLY PURCHASED SOME EQUIPMENT FROM CADILLAC-GAGE AND FELT THAT LATE MODELS OF ASSAULT CARS WOULD SATISFY THE MORALE NEEDS OF THE BOLIVIAN ARMY. I ASKED HIM DIRECTLY WHETHER HE FELT TAHT US SALE OF ASSAULT VEHICLES OF THIS SORT WOULD ELIMINATE ANY INTEREST IN TANKS OFFERED BY OTHER COUNTRIES. HIS REPLY, WHILE SOMEWHAT ELLIPTICAL, WAS BASED ON THE FINANCIAL ASPECT OF OTHER COUNTRIES’ OFFERS. HE NOTED IT WOULD BE MOST DIFFICULT FOR BOLIVIA TO PASS UP WHAT MIGHT AMOUNT TO A GIFT. HE SAID THAT HE WOULD HAVE DIFFICULTIES WITH YOUNGER MEMBERS OF THE ARMED FORCES WERE HE TO REFUSE TO ACCEPT EQUIPMENT FROM OTHER SUPPLIERS AT LITTLE OR NO COST, ALTHOUGH HE HIMSELF DID NOT WISH TO HAVE OTHER COUNTRIES’ TECHNICIANS PHYSICALLY PRESENT IN THIS COUNTRY. THE WAY HE LEFT THE SUBJECT WAS THAT PROMPT DELIVERIES OF PROGRAMMED AND SUITABLE MILITARY EQUIPMENT FROM OTHERS WOULD REDUCE SOVIET PRESSURES TO GIVE EQUIPMENT AND ANY JUNIOR MILITARY OFFICERS DESIRES TO HAVE SUCH EQUIPMENT. STEDMAN

IN MY CONVERSATION OF JUNE 20 WITH PRESIDENT BANZER, I DID NOT MAKE A DETAILED PRESENTATION OF U.S. CONCERN ABOUT GOB RECEIPT OF SOVIET MILITARY EQUIPMENT. THE PRESIDENT EXPRESSED HIS AWARENESS OF THE DANGERS OF INTELLIGENCE ACTIVITIES BY SOVIET TECHNICIANS AND INTIMATED HIS OPPOSITION TO RECEIPT OF SOVIET EQUIPMENT. YET HE IS ANXIOUS TO GET MORE UP-TO-DATE MILITARY EQUIPMENT FOR THE ARMY, PARTICULARLY, TO IMPROVE ITS MORALE. HE MENTIONED THAT DURING HIS RECENT VISITS TO MILITARY UNITS IN THE WAKE OF THE COUP ATTEMPT HE FOUND KULL SUPPORT FOR HIMSELF AND THE GOVERNMENT, BUT WAS QUESTIONED BY MANY YOUNGER OFFICERS ABOUT THE MILITARY EQUIPMENT THEY HAVE BEEN EXPECTING. I CONCLUDED DURING OUR TALK THAT WITHOUT SPECIFIC P&A DATA ON A TANK SUBSTITUTE SUCH AS AN ASSAULT CAR, THE PRESSURE ON US FOR EQUIPMENT WOULD INCREASE IF I APPLIED MORE PRESSURE ON HIM NOT TO ACCEPT MATERIEL FROM THE USSR. ALSO I BELIEVE THE ODDS ARE AGAINST THE GOB ACCEPTING SOVIET EQUIPMENT AND ESPECIALLY TECHNICANS.
IF I CAN BE ARMED WITH P&A DATA ON A SUITABLE VEHICLE AS AN ALTERNATIVE TO A TANK TO GIVE PERSONALLY TO PRESIDENT BANZER, I COULD THEN, MORE SUCCESSFULLY I BELIEVE, MAKE A DEMARCHE, IF THE SECRET

RANKING OFFICERS OF THE BOLIVIAN ARMY HAVE SHOWN NO INTEREST IN CADILLAC-GAGE ASSAULT CARS, PRESIDENT BANZER MAY BE ABLE TO CONVINCE THEM OF THEIR SUITABILITY. AS I REPORTED IN REFTEL, HE BROUGHT THESE UP HIMSELF IN MY JUNE 20 TALK. STEDMAN

text:
Date:

          Subject:
          Pl 480 Title I For Bolivia
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EAID BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          STATE 5919
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

President Banzer called me to his office on January 11 to inquire whether Embassy had received official reply from Washington to GOB request for PL-480 Title I program. He asked me to make every effort to obtain such a reply if it had not been received. I told him that this very day we had received the definitive answer from Washington which unfortunately was negative. I told him, in accordance with State/AIDAC 5919, that no further PL-480 Title I wheat will be possible during FY 74. I told him that FY 75 availabilities and allocation not yet determined but situation is bleak. President Banzer was dismayed at the news which he characterized as “very bad.” He asked whether he should dispatch the Minister of Industry and Commerce to Washington on an emergency mission to try to seek reconsideration of Washington’s position. I told him that such a mission would be fruitless because there is no wheat for PL-480 allocation in the next five months. The President then inquired what Bolivia could do under these circumstances, given that Argentina has not met its commitments to deliver flour for the Bolivian market. I indicated that export credits may be available from private US banks and/or private exporters for the importation of wheat for Bolivian consumption. He immediately telephoned the Minister of Industry and Commerce to relay to him what he called the “bad news” and asked the Minister to undertake immediately to work out some alternative basis for acquisition of wheat.
We will now do what we can to interest US banks represented here and also to stimulate representatives of commodities concerns to make best possible offers to GOB. In this connection Washington help with major wheat suppliers would be welcomed. We intend have early meeting with Ministry of Industry and Commerce and will report results those talks.
Reftel states that CCC credit policy is to continue financing under existing lines of credit but not to authorize new lines. I would like to ask for special consideration for Bolivia under CCC so as to get the best possible terms for financing of Bolivia’s wheat import requirements. The volume of wheat required to meet demand for the balance of this calendar year is such that the ordinary commercial terms would place an extraordinary burden on the present foreign exchange earning capacity of this economy. Politically, it would be in the best interests of the US to move by stages, if that is necessary, away from PL-480 to straight commercial transaction by passing through a CCC credit arrangement at least for this year. I might note that in a recent meeting with US businessmen in La Paz, many of whom are long time residents here, I was told that the present wheat situation is the gravest that they have seen and outweighs, in their judgment, on political and economic terms, the expulsion of Dr. Victor Paz, head of the MNR, from the country. I am especially interested in having as forthcoming as possible a USG policy in face of the critical shortage of wheat at this time in Bolivia. A CCC credit for Bolivia would go a long way toward meeting those interests. Stedman

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM

The Embassy appreciates the careful review made by the Department of the Army of the delivery status of already funded MAP items destined for Bolivian Army Tipo regiments. We are particularly pleased that the M-113A1 armored personnel carriers (14) and the 4.2 in. mortars (11) and the AN/VRC 18 radios (4) are scheduled for delivery not later than June 30 of this year. We are mindful of the difficulties inherent in the delivery schedules for AN/GRC and AN/PRC radios and for the 81 mm mortars, but hope that something can be done to accelerate delivery of at least a few of these items ahead of the dates as given in Reftel A. As indicated in Reftel B, even token deliveries of these items would assist us in dealing with recurrent GOB complaints that we are falling behind in our commitments under our Military Assistance Program to Bolivia.
In view of the reasons given for the inability to forecast deliveries for the 81 mm mortars and the radios, we do not feel it would be particularly useful for DOD to send an officer to Bolivia unless he would have authority to advance delivery dates ahead of the schedules given in Reftel A.

In response to paragraph 2 reference A, Embassy assumes growth over the last two years has absorbed a good portion of unutilized industrial and mining capacity and land easily put under cultivation without irrigation or costly clearing. Therefore, it also assumes an Incremental Capital Output Ratio (ICOR) of at least three would be required to assure long-term growth at recent rates. Such an ICOR means investment would have to rise to about 16 percent of GDP. If additional investment is not well placed in productive sectors or efficiently managed, the ICOR is likely to be even higher. Note that we stated in paragraph 3D reference B that we believed investment would have to exceed 15 percent of GDP to assure continuation of current growth rates. We estimate that investment would have to reach about 19 percent to reach “self-sustaining” growth rates of 8 percent to 9 percent. This will be discussed with the IMF mission when it arrives.
We believe estimates of the subsidy paid in 1973, and what probably would have been paid in 1974, in comparison to the estimated wage increase cost in 1974, provide a better basis for seeing how the budget might worsen (paragraph 3 reference A). MinFin’s original budget (never released) did not allow for any 1974 wage increase. An IMF representative, on the basis of discussions with MinFin officials, estimates the total cost to the Treasury of wage increases granted thus far in 1974 at about $B 897 million, partly under the personal services line and partly under the current transfers to public sector line. On the other hand, we estimate the flour subsidy in 1973 was no more than $B 200 million. Without the increase in flour price in January from $B 177 per quintal to $B 300 per quintal, the subsidy in 1974 is likely to have been as much as $B 500 million.

However, In Terms Of Effective Market Prices Increases Were Only About 20 Percent Higher, Except For Bread Which Was Subsidized By Gob. DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Product scarcities for above items were extreme in last month, although Bolivia was frequently plagued by problem throughout 1973. These scarcities were basically result of low domestic prices relative to external market and in the case of wheat flour absolute shortages caused by world-wide scarcities, failure of Argentina to supply flour under its agreements with Bolivia and possibly contraband movement of wheat flour to neighboring countries. Official price announced per pound for sugar is $B3.05 which 118 percent over previous official price of $B1.40 and 20 percent over effective market price of $B2.54 per pound. Common bread (pan de batalla) price was 30 centavos per unit of about 66 grams. Price increase to 50 centavos and reduction in weight to 53 grams results in increase of about 100 percent. New wheat flour price was increased approximately 52 percent over earlier official price and 10 percent over “black market” price. Price increased 145 percent over official price and about 20 percent market price.
Wage and salary increase of 400 perso per month represents 47 percent increase for lower income group, 27 percent for medium/low income group. On basis MINFIN salary survey, above groups represent approximately 84 percent of work force.
Comment: Price increases for the above products may be considered adequate in light of effective market prices. However, the maintenance of GOB presence in the pricing decisions implies that continued speculation could take place if prices inadequate relative to prices in neighboring countries. In case of flour world-wide availability, but especially availability from Argentina, will determine whether scarcity can be overcome at new price. It is unclear whether GOB will have to continue flour subsidy which depends on price in world market. For present GOB has not included subsidy in budget. Wage and salary increase for public sector which implies $B214 million in additional expenditures not fully included in budget. Concentration of increase in low income category means immediate translation into consumption expenditures adding further pressure on prices and imports. Appears that inflationary process will be difficult to slow in 1974–placing heavy burden on GOB incomes and monetary policies for remainder of year. Stedman

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: Briefing centered on Bolivia coup and demonstrations in Iran. Also covered were the reported South African raid into Angola, Rhodesia sanctions and USG meetings with the Patriotic Front, and the Secretary’s meeting with the Black Caucus on October 31.
Briefing commenced with following statement: “According to our information some military units around La Paz, Bolivia, have taken control of the central area of that city and declared their intention to install an Army Colonel, Alberto Natusch Busch, as President. The attitude of military units elsewhere in the country toward the attempted coup is not clear. Bolivia’s Constitutional President, Walter Guevara Arze, and the Commander of the Armed Forces, General David Padilla, have denounced this attempt to change the government by non-constitutional means. The United States is following these events with deep concern and would deplore any disruption in Bolivia’s democratic process.”
Questions centered on whether Secretary Vance delivered a message to Bolivian political figures warning against a coup during his recent trip there. Reston replied, “I want to put that in a positive framework. I think the Secretary emphasized our position in returning to democracy, which we have been seeing in the Andean Region. I think they are aware of our position.” Taken questions concerned Colonel Natusch’s background, U.S. relations with Bolivia, and diplomatic contacts with other governments in the region.
In response to a question on the anti-U.S. demonstration in Tehran, Reston replied: “There was a demonstration. Its purpose apparently was to protest the presence of the former Shah here in the United States. It seems to have been organized by religious groups associated with the regime in Iran. There were about 3,500 demonstrators. They were shouting slogans and placing banners on the walls of the American compound. The demonstration was peaceful and controlled, and at no time did any of the demonstrators enter the Embassy compound. The organizers of the demonstration have instructed their participants not to proceed to the Embassy and to end their demonstration at a place about three miles from the Embassy. That is what the main group did. We don’t have any accurate information about the size of the main group. I want to state, with regard to the protection that was afforded to our people and property in Tehran, that the Iranian government met fully its responsibility to provide security for the Embassy in Tehran by augmenting the police elements which normally protect the compound. We, the American government, appreciate the Iranian government’s additional steps for assuring the safety of the men and women who work in our Embassy.”
Related questions focused on whether Iran regime organized the demonstrations and if a group of 3,500 which approached the Embassy were acting according to plan. No response was offered which went beyond guidance in Paragraph 4 above.
On the reported South African raid into Angola, Reston replied, “We have been informed by representatives of the Angolan government and have seen press reports of the South African raid into Angola. We have no independent evidence to confirm these reports. If true, however, these reports only emphasize the urgency of obtaining an international settlement for Namibia. As we have stated before, we deplore any acts which contribute to the escalation of violence in the area. We note that Angola has requested a Security Council meeting for today on this matter. I would expect that the Western Contact Group will be making a further statement at that time.”
On Rhodesia sanctions, Reston went no further than to reiterate support for the British pre-independence proposals. A related question concerned a report that senior Patriotic Front officials were to meet with the Secretary. Reston replied, “Well, as you know, the Secretary is out of the country; he’s in Korea. And there is no such meeting scheduled. Let me say that, however–and let me go on background to say this–Mr. Josiah Chinamano of the ZAPU wing of the Patriotic Front and Mr. Edgar Tekere, who is Secretary-General of ZANU, were in Hot Springs, Virginia, last week to attend the Tenth African-American Conference, which is sponsored by the African-American Institute. The Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Mr. Richard Moose, also attended that conference, had an opportunity for an exchange of views with those two particular leaders.”
A question on the Secretary’s meeting with the Black Caucus concerned the subject of that meeting. A posted answer that afternoon read that the Middle East was the primary topic of discussion, although there was one question from a Caucus member which did not pertain to that area.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

During courtesy call on the Bolivian Foreign Minister General Guzman January 9, Congressman Charles Whalen (R.-Ohio) asked whether Bolivia had any special points it intended to raise during the forthcoming meeting of Foreign Ministers with SecState Kissinger. The Foreign Minister indicated that the staff of the Foreign Ministry is working on some positions but basically Bolivia has no particular points; rather wishes to participate with the other Foreign Ministers in the preparatory session in Mexico to work out a constructive agenda. He expressed interest in special tariff preference legislation and hoped that the Congressman would assist in bringing about a final and helpful bill inasmuch as Bolivia considers opportunities in relations with the U.S. as more potentially beneficial than benefits to be derived from Latin American integration which is going so slowly. Foreign Minister indicated his appreciation for U.S. assistance and hoped for a continuation of such cooperation, without which, he said, Bolivia cannot break out of its low level of development. He repeated the GOB’s interest in PL-480 wheat imports from the U.S. because of the acute shortage of flour and wheat which could create political problems. Mr. Whalen said that there was a high demand for wheat and a consequent short supply in the world. He did say though that he understood that Bolivian and U.S. authorities were discussing the Bolivian request, and he knew that the USG would do whatever it could, although the situation with regard to wheat is bleak.
Congressman Whalen inquired about Bolivia’s attitude toward the OAS and Cuba. Foreign Minister expressed support for an effective OAS and felt that efforts should go forward to reconstruct it for the benefit of all members. Foreign Minister said that Bolivian Ambassador Valencia, who occupies double capacity of Ambassador to the U.S. and to the OAS, would join him in Mexico as his advisor on key discussions of OAS aspects during the Foreign Ministers’ meeting. As to Cuba, he said the position of the GOB is constant and firm in viewing Cuba as a menace which has harmed Bolivia seriously. Foreign Minister said that Bolivia does not wish to have any variation in the present OAS policy toward Cuba.
Congressman Whalen asked if the Foreign Minister would give him any official explanation for the expulsion of Dr. Victor Paz on January 8. The Minister said that the departure of Dr. Paz was a surprise to him and that the instructions to deport him were directed by President Banzer himself.

          LA PAZ 7697 SUMMARY: MININD/COM PEREDA CALLED AMBASSADOR TO MINISTRY JANUARY 2 AND MADE STRONG PLEA FOR NEW PL-480 AGREEMENT AND FOR WHEAT ARRIVALS TO TAKE CARE OF SHORTAGES EXPECTED AFTER MARCH 1974. ACTION REQUESTED: ADVISE STATUS OF GOB REQUEST FOR NEW PL-480 AGREEMENT (SEE LA PAZ 5021 OF AUGUST 16, 1973, AND SUBSEQUENT.)
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Minister blamed Bolivian difficulties on failure of Argentine government to fulfill October 1973 agreement for 30,000 metric tons of wheat flour. According to Pereda, despite repeated assurances from Argentine embassy, only 5,000 tons have arrived to date and Bolivians have concluded that they cannot count on Argentina to meet vital need for flour imports. While recognizing that Argentina too had wheat problem, Minister opined that slowness of shipments due to “politics” connected with bilateral gas and petroleum negotiations.
Minister’s anxieties seemed to be prompted by report Presidential Economic Advisor Willy Vargas brought back from his Washington visit alleging that U.S. officials not RPT not contemplating further wheat shipments in first semester 1974. MININD/COM officials made confused deduction from this that U.S. wished to place PL-480 agreement on U.S. fiscal year basis. As reported REFTEL and confirmed by Minister, PL-480 shipments now underway are believed sufficient with national wheat to meet needs until end of March. Minister thus feared that country would be without wheat from then until July.
Ambassador expressed understanding of Minister’s anxieties but recorded that embassy has not yet received instructions for negotiation of new agreement. ADCM Whiting explained that if new agreement worked out in time, shipments theoretically could be made in March to July period but stressed uncertainties re wheat availabilities. In view possibility Argentina might not supply, he mentioned need for GOB to study commercial purchases from countries other than Argentina. Minister asked embassy convey his request urgently to Washington authorities and said he would send instructions to GOB Embassy Washington ASAP.
Comment: Minister’s concern is without doubt genuine. Price and scarcity of flour has been one of GOB’s most constant and truculent political problems as evidenced by long lines of unhappy housewives waiting to purchase bread or flour that have reappeared periodically in recent months. Bolivia has relied on Argentine shipments not only because southern neighbor historical supplier to Bolivia but also because last year’s bilateral agreement gave favorable price (US$ 165/metric ton). Now with problem of Argentine deliveries added to worldwide shortage, GOB seems to be aware of serious need to stimulate national wheat production. It will take time, however, to improve past performance and GOB is relying on U.S. to help avoid politically sensitive shortage after March. GOB has urgent need to know what supplies it can count on. Therefore, we should respond on new agreement ASAP, and we recommend as affirmatively as possible in view political and economic justifications and apparent inability and unwillingness of usual supplier–Argentina–to ship flour.

Following is text of supreme decree issued January 28 declaring state of siege throughout the territory of Bolivia:
General Hugo Banzer Suarez, President of the Republic A. Considering: That, protected by the guarantees and liberties granted by the Nationalist Government, foreign-supported subversive activities of a guerrilla-type continue to occur. B. That, the above facts have reached a limit with the destruction of bridges, interruption of railroad lines, blocking of roads and terrorist acts organized with the purpose of provoking supply shortages in the cities and from the cities to the countryside, creating popular discontent. C. That, it is the duty of the Supreme Government to guarantee the supply of goods, the security of town and villages and the life of their inhabitants.
The Council of Ministers decrees: A. Article 1 - A state of siege is hereby declared throughout the territory of the Republic. B. Article 2 - The relevant authorities will adopt measures toward the maintenance of public order, security of the State, normal supply, productive activities and public services. C. Article 3 - All meetings and public demonstrations are hereby forbidden.
The Ministers of Interior and of National Defense are charged with the execution and fulfillment of this decree.
Given in the Palace of Government in the city of La Paz on the twenty-eighth day of January in the year nineteen seventy four.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

On February 23 President Padilla asked the Ambassador to come to the palace with Messrs. Paul and Bartolucci of AID who are in Bolivia to consider possible location here of an AID-financed regional center for remote sensing. President Padilla presented the Ambassador with the text of a letter to President Carter (repeated beginning paragraph 5 below with informal English translation). The original letter is being forwarded through the Bolivian Embassy in Washington.
President Padilla said he wanted to emphasize his deep personal interest in locating the Latin American Regional Remote Sensing Center in Bolivia. He noted that this was an area of advanced technology where Bolivia’s capability was well established and known to the U.S. through previous U.S.-Bolivian collaboration. President Padilla wanted to assure us that the Bolivian Government would do all that was necessary to support such a regional center if the U.S. could agree to locate it in Bolivia. He wanted to provide blanket assurance that the facilities and full cooperation of such a regional center would be available to all other Latin American countries without reservation, including Chile. The President also underlined that under several governments in Bolivia there has been continuity in the managers and technical personnel of Bolivia’s remote sensing programs and that this continuity would pertain in the future as well.
The Ambassador noted that we were indeed deeply impressed with Bolivian capabilities in the area of remote sensing technology and its productive application. He said that we do indeed consider Bolivia to be a solid candidate, among several others, for location of the regional center. The Ambassador said that he would do what he could to encourage location of the center in Bolivia.
Mr. Paul explained the background of the proposal for a Latin America Regional Center and the experience AID has had with such centers in Africa and Asia. He noted that funds to support such a center could be available not only from AID but from the United Nations, the Andean Pact and other institutions as well.
There follows Spanish text of letter to President Carter from President Padilla as presented to the Ambassador:


LA PAZ, 23 DE FEBRERO DE 1979 EXCELENTISIMO SENOR PRESIDENTE: TENGO A HONRA DIRIGIRME A VUESTRA EXCELENCIA, PARA PONER EN SU DIGNO CONOCIMIENTO QUE MI PAIS, COMO UN POSITIVO EFECTO DE LA EXCELENTE UTILIZACION DE LA TECNICA DE SENSORES REMOTOS LOCALIZADOS EN PLATAFORMAS ESPECIALES DE LA SERIE LANDSAT DE LA ADMINISTRACION NACIONAL DE AERONAUTICA Y DEL ESPACIO (NASA) DE LOS ESTADOS UNIDOS, HA PODIDO OBTENER SIGNIFICATIVAS APLICACIONES Y RESULTADOS EN EL ESTUDIO DE LOS RECURSOS NATURALES DE BOLIVIA. HACIENDO REFERENCIA A LA POLITICA DELINEADA POR SU ADMINISTRACION EN FECHA 11 DE OCTUBRE DEL PASADO ANO ACERCA DEL USO CIVIL DEL ESPACIO Y EN LA CUAL VUESTRA EXCELENCIA SE HA SERVIDO ENFATIZAR LOS IMPORTANTES RESULTADOS QUE LOS SENSORES REMOTOS APORTAN AL DESARROLLO DE NUESTROS PAISES, DESEO EXPRESARLE MI VIVO INTERES EN QUE EL ILUSTRADO GOBIERNO DE VUESTRA EXCELENCIA TENGA A BIEN CONSIDERAR LA POSIBILIDAD DE IMPLEMENTAR UN CENTRO REGIONAL DE ADIESTRAMIENTO EN EL CAMPO DE LOS SENSORES REMOTOS EN BOLIVIA, PRINCIPALMENTE LANDSAT, QUE BENEFICIARIA NO SOLAMENTE A MI PAIS, SINO A TODAS LAS NACIONES LATINOAMERICANAS. PARA ESTA FINALIDAD, MI GOBIERNO SE HALLA RESUELTO A PONER A DISPOSICION DE TAN NOBLE OBJETIVO, TODAS LAS FACILIDADES ACTUALMENTE EXISTENTES, LAS CUALES HAN SIDO EVALUADAS POR LOS MIEMBROS DEL PROGRAMA DE SENSORES REMOTOS DS/ST DE LA AGENCIA DE LOS ESTADOS UNIDOS PARA EL DESARROLLO INTERNACIONAL (AID). EN ESPERA DE TENER UNA POSITIVA RESPUESTA SOBRE ESTE ASUNTO QUE TANTO INTERESA A BOLIVIA, HAGO PROPICIA LA OPORTUNIDAD PARA OFRECER A VUESTRA EXCELENCIA, LAS SEGURIDADES DE MI CONSIDERACION MAS ALTA Y DISTINGUIDA. GRAL. DIV. DAVID PADILLA ARANCIBIA, PRESIDENTE DE LA HONORABLE JUNTA MILITAR DEL GOBIERNO DE BOLIVIA. AL EXCELENTISIMO SENOR DON. JIMMY CARTER PRESIDENTE DE LOS ESTADOS UNIDOS DE NORTEAMERICA WASHINGTON D.C. U.S.A.

Press report cited reftel a not rpt not correct. Gob “Arancel Aduanero de Importaciones 1972” still in effect and addendum of February 28, 1973 has expired.
Two temporary exceptions to 1972 Arancel have been put in effect in 1974. First, Supreme Decree No. 11345 of February 13, 1974 created sliding percentage reductions of normal customs rates for raw materials and parts needed by Bolivian industries. Each exemption must be approved separately. Second, Supreme Decree 11358 of February 22, 1974 suspended duties (but not all fees) on importation certain basic food commodities including powdered milk, rice, vegetable oil, lard, wheat flour, tuna fish, salmon and sardines. Original decree was for 90 days which was subsequently extended another 180 days, that is to November 18, 1974.
Three to five percent sales tax on imports still in effect but also suspended for these basic food items. Consular fees do not appear in tariff columns. Embassy pouching above decrees and consular fee schedule.
Bolivia’s tariff regime will be described in greater detail in post’s answer to Department’s A-3164 of April 19 which now being prepared.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

IN ACCORDANCE WITH INSTRUCTIONS IN REFTEL, I RAISED WITH MINISTER MINES LEMA ON MAY 6 THE SUGGESTION THAT GOB ARRANGE FOR ARBITRATION, THIRD PARTY PROCEEDINGS, NEGOTIATION, OR OTHER ACCEPTABLE MEANS TO SETTLE DIFFERENCES BETWEEN FRANK TYE AND THE GOB ABOUT IMPC/EMBOSA. I POINTED OUT TO MINISTER LEMA THAT USG DOES NOT TAKE ANY POSITION ON THE MERITS OF THE CASE. I NOTED THAT USG DOES NOT WISH TO BECOME DIRECTLY INVOLVED IN PROCEEDINGS BETWEEN THE PARTIES. I TOLD THE MINISTER THAT TYE HAD PRESENTED HIS ARGUMENTS TO THE DEPARTMENT WHICH HAD MADE A REVIEW OF THE CASE TO DETERMINE HOW WE COULD HELP RESOLVE THE PROBLEM. I STRESSED THAT THE DEPARTMENT BELIEVES THAT THE APPROACH WE ARE SUGGESTING SEEMS TO US TO OFFER BEST PROSPECT FOR SOLUTION.
MINISTER LEMA RESPONDED THAT BOLIVIAN AUTHORITIES, PRIOR TO EMBOSA LIQUIDATION, HAD CONSIDERED ARBITRATION PURSUANT TO ARTICLE 41 OF THE STATUTES BUT IDEA WAS DISCARDED AS NOT FEASIBLE WAY OF SETTLING DISAGREEMENT WITH TYE. COMPANY WAS THEN LIQUIDATED IN ACCORDANCE WITH STATUTES. GOB BELIEVES LIQUIDATION AND ALL

072056Z
MATTERS PERTAINING THERETO WERE CORRECTLY HANDLED, LEGALLY AND
TECHNICALLY. FURTHERMORE, GOB BELIEVES FRANK TYE ADEQUATELY COMPENSATED BY PRESENT BOLIVIAN REGIME BY CASH PAYMENT US$1.4 MILLION FOR IMPC EXPROPRIATION. IN VIEW OF FOREGOING, MINISTER SAID IT WOULD NOT BE POLITICALLY ACCEPTABLE NOR LEGALLY APPROPRIATE FOR GOB TO ORGANIZE NOW AN ARBITRATION OR OTHER PROCEEDINGS FOR MATTER WHICH IT FEELS HAS BEEN FAIRLY AND CORRECTLY HANDLED. MINISTER THEN SAID GOB IS ABOUT TO PRESENT “DENUNCIA” AGAINST TYE FOR US$400,000 WHICH GOB ASSERTS TYE OWES COMIBOL FOR OPERATING COSTS IN THE PERIOD OF MARCH TO NOVEMBER 1973. MINISTER LEMA ALSO SAID THAT HE HAD HEARD THROUGH FRIENDS THAT FRANK TYE HAD SAID HE WOULD TAKE CERTAIN LEGAL ACTIONS IN US AGAINST BOLIVIA. MINISTER OBSERVED THAT FOR GOB TO ENTER INTO SOME FORM OF ARBITRATION AFTER REPORTED THREATS OF ACTION AGAINST GOB WOULD BE IMPOSSIBLE TO EXPLAIN SATISFACTORILY IN BOLIVIA. HE ALSO SAID THAT HE ALSO BELIEVES THAT IT WOULD NOT BE IN US INTEREST FOR THE GOB TO ARRANGE FOR ARBITRATION BECAUSE MOST BOLIVIANS WOULD ASSUME THAT PROCEED- INGS OPENED UNDER PRESSURE BY USG AND WOULD REACT NEGATIVELY. THE MINISTER CONCLUDED BY STATING THAT SINCE IT GENERALLY BELIEVED THAT TYE ONLY WISHES TO EXTRACT MORE MONEY FROM BOLIVIA AND SINCE GOVERNMENT ABOUT TO PRESENT CLAIM AGAINST HIM, ARBITRATION NOT ACCEPTABLE TO GOB.

I CHOSE TO RAISE MATTER WITH MINISTER OF MINES BECAUSE HE IS THE RESPONSIBLE OFFICIAL IN THE MINING SECTOR AND TO HAVE GONE AROUND HIM ON SUCH A SENSITIVE MATTER WOULD HAVE BEEN DETRIMENTAL TO OUR OTHER INTERESTS IN THE MINING FIELD. FURTHERMORE, RECENT RUMORS ARE THAT LEMA MIGHT BECOME MINISTER OF ENERGY AND HYDRO- CARBONS, A SECTOR OF INCREASING IMPORTANCE TO US. ALSO I DO NOT BELIEVE THAT LEMA HOLDS DIFFERENT VIEWS ABOUT TYE AND IMPC THAN, ACCORDING TO REPORTS, ARE HELD BY PRESIDENT BANZER, EX- MANAGER OF COMIBOL GENERAL MIRANDA, EX-PRESIDENT EMBOSA BOARD MANUEL MERCADO (NOW PRESIDENT OF CENTRAL BANK), MINISTER FINANCE QUIROGA, AND EX-MINISTER SECRETARY GENERAL OF PRESIDENCY GUIDO VALLE.
IN PRELIMINARY PLEASANTRIES WITH THE MINISTER, I MENTIONED THAT I PLANNED TRIP TO US SOON AND HOPED TO HAVE CONSULTATIONS IN DEPARTMENT OF STATE. AS I WAS DEPARTING FROM HIS OFFICE, MINISTER LEMA SUGGESTED THAT I TAKE ADVANTAGE OF CONSULTATIONS TO EXPLAIN TO SENIOR US OFFICIALS THE REALITIES OF THE PRESENT

072056Z
BOLIVIAN SITUATION WHICH MAKE ARBITRATION OF THIS MATTER UN- ACCEPTABLE. HE NOTED THAT BANZER REGIME RECORD OF AMIACABLE RESOLUTION OF INVESTMENT DISPUTES SHOULD BE BORNE IN MIND.

I DID NOT REQUEST, NOR DID THE MINISTER OFFER, ANY INFORMATION ABOUT QUID PRO QUOS IN FORM OF TAX CREDIT RELATING GIBRALTAR HUARI-HUARI VENTURE WITH IMPC/EMBOSA CLAIM. I WOULD LIKETO NOTE THOUGH THAT IN PARAGRAPH 4, THE FYI SECTION, OF REFTEL, IT IS

STATED THAT “TYE INDICATED HE MIGHT BE WILLING TO DROP IMPC/EMBOSA CLAIM IF GOB WOULD NOT EXERCISE ITS STOCK OPTION ON GIBRALTAR HUARI-HUARI MINING VENTURE WHICH EXPIRED MARCH 1.” WE HAVE COPY OF TYE’S LETTER DATED JANUARY 21, 1974, ADDRESSED TO MARSHALL WRIGHT, THEN ASSISTANT SECRETARY OF STATE OF CONGRESSIONAL RELATIONS, IN WHICH TYE WROTE “WE WOULD BE WILLING TO ACQUIESCE IN SUCH (COMIBOL) OWNERSHIP AND RELINQUISH OUR CLAIM WITH RESPECT THERETO IF THE BOLIVIAN GOVERNMENT WILL RELINQUISH ITS OPTION, GRANTED TO IT IN THE NATIONALIZATION SETTLEMENT, TO ACQUIRE 51 PERCENT OF GIBRALTAR HUARI-HUARI MINE CORPORATION.” SINCE GOB HAS DROPPED ITS OPTION, I HAD THOUGHT TYE WOULD, ACCORDING TO HIS OWN LETTER, DROP EMBOSA CLAIM.

I HOPE THAT THERE WILL BE AN OPPORTUNITY TO DISCUSS THIS MATTER FURTHER IN WASHINGTON DURING MY CONSULTATION. STEDMAN

          Subject:
          Patrol Craft For Bolivian Navy; Letter Offer From Adm. Zumwalt To Bolivian Cno.
        
                    
          TAGS:
          MASS BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Admiral Zumwalt has signed a letter dated December 13, 1973 to Admiral Pinto of the Bolivian Navy, offering “two small unarmed patrol craft, PBRs” to meet the Bolivian Navy’s “requirements.” Admiral Zumwalt’s letter goes on to state: “The estimated cost of the craft, including necessary repairs to place them in good operating condition as training craft is $25,000 each. In order that we can expedite the procedures to transfer these units to your Navy, I would suggest the submission of a diplomatic note to the U.S. government stating your country’s wish to make this purchase. The means of funding the craft is, of course, at your discretion. The use of MAP funds might be a possibility and this avenue would require coordination with our Military Group in Bolivia. Another means is by a direct purchase through the Foreign Military Sales. After the diplomatic note has been submitted and approved, precise price and availability information of the patrol craft can be provided. This will, in turn, provide the basis for an official letter of offer and acceptance. I would estimate that the craft would be ready for shipment to Bolivia within sixty days after the financial arrangements have been completed.”
Upon receipt of information that this letter had been sent to the Bolivian Navy, I have had a special meeting with the appropriate members of the MILGP and the Defense Attache’s office to evaluate the offer and to formulate our responses if we receive a note as Admiral Zumwalt has suggested to the Bolivian Navy. As a result of this meeting, I have concluded that there is no objection on substantive grounds to the acquisition of these vessels from US, but I wish to record in the following paragraphs some observations about the manner in which this offer was made.
Although Admiral Zumwalt’s letter invites the GOB to consider inclusion of the patrol craft under MAP, this is a matter which of course should be reviewed by the IG/ARA and by the PMG if this mission were to recommend it, which we do not. Our position is that the Bolivians should either pay cash or use FMS. Accordingly, we are informally undertaking to discourage the Bolivian Navy from asking us to provide these vessels under MAP. We believe that this actually coincides with the Bolivian Navy’s wishes to be on a more independent basis. If this analysis is correct, then the MAP suggestion in the letter may not cause us any political problems.
The concerns I have about the manner in which the offer of the patrol craft was made are both substantive and procedural. The U.S. is conducting a MAP program in Bolivia and has sought over the past several years to develop a concept of coordinated or joint planning for this program. Thus, requests from Bolivian authorities for military equipment should be channeled through the MILGP here and then reviewed in an appropriate inter-agency forum in a systematic way in Washington. If Washington approval is then given to an offer of equipment, such an offer should be made by me or by elements of my mission at my direction so as to reinforce the Embassy’s role as the responsible agency for the conduct of U.S. foreign affairs in Bolivia. Even if ceremonial or protocolary communications are made on a service to service basis, they should of course go through me, or be subject to my concurrence. On the substantive side, we now find that the two patrol craft are in fact to be substituted for a naval vessel already programmed under MAP which was to have replaced the existing MAP patrol craft, the J.F.Kennedy. The vessel which will now be deleted had been selected in a careful way as being the appropriate unit for use on Lake Titicaca. Again, we believe that we may be able to delete this vessel without political problems but cannot be completely sure.
In view of the foregoing, I would appreciate it if the Department would take up with the Navy Department my concerns in the manner by which this offer of patrol craft was made to Bolivia and to seek agreement on the points that I have made to insure the more orderly conduct of our affairs in Bolivia.
