          Ref:
          (A) LA PAZ 3396; (B) STATE 83632 BEGIN SUMMARY: AT REQEUST OF MINCOORDINATION, CHARGE AND ADCM CALLED ON MINMINING ON JUNE 4, PRESENTING POINTS PREVIOUSLY SUBMITTED TO MINCOORDINATPON CONTAINED REF (B) AND REQUESTED ARBITRATION OR SIMILAR PROCEEDING. AFTER REVIEWING CASE MINMINING STATED THAT THERE WAS NO BASIS FOR ANY CONCEIVABLE CLAIM OR DEMAND TYE MIGHT HAVE IN MIND OR FOR ARBITRATION. END SUMMARY.
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

CHARGE AND ADCM CALLED ON MINMINES LEMA JUNE 4 AT REQUEST OF MINCOORDINATION CAPRILES. CHARGE EXPLAINED TO MINMINES THAT FOLLOWING AMBASSADOR’S CALL ON MINMINES, EMBASSY HAD BEEN INSTRUCT- ED RAISE MATTER WITH MINISTER CAPRILES (SEE REF A) WHO, AFTER CONSULTING AND CONSIDERING FOR FEW DAYS HAD INFORMED CHARGE THAT HE SHOULD SEEK MEETING WITH LEMA. CHARGE AGAIN PRESENTED POINTS CONTAINED REF (B) AS HE HAD DONE IN MEETING WITH CAPRILES.
LEMA RESPONDED BY RHETORICALLY ASKING WHAT TYE WAS CLAIMING AND WHAT HE WANTED. LEMA SAID HE HAD BEEN PAID MORE THAN HE SHOULD HAVE BEEN PAID SO HE COULD NOT BE SEEKING MORE MONEY. SAID MINISTRY OF MINES INITIALLY RECOMMENDED PAYMENT OF ONLY $US 700,000 AS VALUE OF EQUIPMENT, ETC., BUT, IN VIEW OF NEWNESS AND FRA-

062219Z
GILITY OF BANZER GOVERNMENT AND “PRESSURE” FROM JOHN CONNOLLY ON
PRESIDENT BANZER, MORE LIBERAL INTER-MINISTERIAL ASSESSMENT ES- TABLISHED ABOUT \(US 1,350,000 AS VALUE WHICH WAS SUBSEQUENTLY
INCREASED (PRESUMABLY BY FINAL CABINET ACTION) TO ABOUT\)US 1,450,000. TYE HAD THEN SIGNED QUIT CLAIM. 3. MINISTER SAID TYE COULD NOT WANT RESTORATION OF MIXED ENTERPRISE BECAUSE NEITHER COMIBOL NOR GOB WANTED TO HAVE ANYTHING TO DO WITH TYE. MINISTER SAID TYE WAS BADLY BEHAVED (MAL CRIADO) INDIVIDUAL WHO SO INCENSED SUBSECRETARY IN MINISTRY OF MINES THAT TYE WAS SUBSEQUENTLY FORBIDDEN ENTRY TO THAT OFFICE. 4. LEMA SAID THERE WAS NO POINT TO ARBITRATION BECAUSE THERE WAS NOTHING FOR TYE TO GAIN OUT OF IT. BESIDES, HE SAID, ARBIT- RATION WAS POLITICALLY DANGEROUS FOR HIM AS MINISTER, FOR GOB AND FOR U.S. –BOLIVIAN RELATIONS. SAID MIXED COMPANY HAD BEEN LEGALLY DISSOLVED AFTER COMIBOL PAID ABOUT $US 23,000. IN REGISTRATION TAXES TYE SHOULD HAVE PAID TO ESTABLISH MIXED COMPANY IN FIRST PLACE. TYE FAILED TO PRESENT HIMSELF AT ANY OF EMBOSA BOARD MEETINGS PRECEDING DISSOLUTION. ADCM ASKED WHETHER TYE’S LAWYER REQUESTED ARBITRATION BEFORE DISSOLUTION. MINISTER SAID HE DID NOT KNOW, BUT THAT AS MAJORITY STOCKHOLDER COMIBOL HAD RIGHT TO DISSOLVE COMPANY ON PERFORMANCE GROUNDS SPECIFIED IN CONTRACT. MINISTER NOTED THAT TYE FAILED BEAR HIS SHARE OPERATING LOSSES RUNNING ABOUT $US 70,000 PER MONTH AND THAT HIS MINISTRY HAD PREPARED $US 270,000 CLAIM AGAINST TYE WHICH INCLUDED TYE’S SHARE OF REGISTRATION TAXES AND OPERATING LOSSES. 5. CHARGE SAID ARBITRATION NEED NOT BE PUBLIC AFFAIR BUT COULD SERVE USEFUL PURPOSE OF CLEARING AIR. ASKED ADCM TO GIVE HIS IMPRESSION OF WHAT TYE CLAIMED OR WANTED. ADCM SAID HE UNDERSTOOD TYE HAD WANTED MINISTRY OF DEFENSE TO NOT EXERCISE ITS OPTION TO TAKE 51 PERCENT OF SHARES IN GIBRALTAR HUARI-HUARI IN RETURN FOR ASSUMPTION OF VARIOUS TYE DEBTS. SAID TYE MIGHT ALSO WANT SOME SORT OF TAX BREAK IN CONNECTION WITH HIS NEW ARRANGEMENT WITH NEW JERSEY ZINC. FINALLY, ALTHOUGH TYE HAD NOT CLEARLY PRESSED FOR IT, HE MIGHT WANT 45 PERCENT SHARE (BASED ON HIS SHARE OF EMBOSA STOCK) OF ANY NET ASSETS. 6. MINISTER SAID EMBOSA CHARTER CLEARLY STATES COMIBOL OWNS ALL EQUIPMENT OF FIRM SO NOTHING TO SHARE. TYE WAS TO HAVE 45 PERCENT SHARE OF EQUITY IN RETURN FOR CONTRIBUTING FINANCING. HIS PATENTED PROCESS WAS TO BECOME COMIBOL’S AFTER ONE YEAR. 7. MINISTER THEN SAID IMPC CONTRACT HAD BAD ODER FROM VERY BEGINNING. CONTRACT HAD BEEN APPROVED DURING BARRIENTOS REGIME WHEN
062219Z
PARLIAMENT WAS FUNCTIONING. TYE HAD GOTTEN CONTRACT APPROVED WITH HELP OF INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL ALLIES. TORRES REGIME HAD NATION- ALIZED EXTERPRISE AND BANZER REGIME HAD MADE GENEROUS SETTLEMENT. TYE HAD BEEN UNABLE TO MEET REQUIREMENTS OF EMBOSA CHARTER, NOT BECAUSE MANAGEMENT CONTRACT WAS NOT SIGNED, BUT BECAUSE TYE WAS IN POOR FINANCIAL CONDITION. IBRD HAD BEEN READY AT ONE TIME TO LEND UP TO $US 9 MILLION TO EMBOSA BUT TYE COULD NOT PUT UP HIS PORTION OF FINANCING. TYE, IN FACT, OWED $US 1 MILLION TO PHILLIP
BROS. ($US 500,000 OF WHICH WAS REALLY OWED THROUGH PHILLIP BROS. TO MITSUBISHI) AND HE STILL OWED SOME AMOUNT TO COMIGRA, ORIGINAL OWNERS OF HUARI-HUARI. REPAYMENT OF TYE’S $US 200,000 DEBT TO BANCO MINERO HAD BEEN POSTPONED FOR TWO YEARS BY MINDEFENSE OPTION CONTRACT. THIS POSTPONEMENT WAS CONTRARY TO LAW, INJURED BANCO MINERO, AND WAS ANOTHER GENEROUS FEATURE OF SETTLEMENT WITH TYE WHEN HE WAS PAID $US 1,450,000. FINALLY, TYE HAD ARRANGED WITH NEW JERSEY ZINC TO PAY DEBT TO BANCO MINERO FEW DAYS BEFORE EX- PIRATION OF OPTION CONTRACT. MINISTER LEMA CLAIMED HE DID NOT KNOW DETAILS OF TYE’S ARRANGEMENTS WITH NEW JERSEY ZINC OR LATTER’S EFFORTS FORM MIXED COMPANY WITH PRIVATE BOLIVIAN COMPANIES TO EX- PLOIT HUARI-HUARI MINE. LEMA WRYLY COMMENTED THAT OF $US 200,000 TYE BORROWED FROM BANCO MINERO ONLY $US 30,000 TO $US 40,000 HAD BEEN INVESTED IN DEVELOPMENT OF HUARI-HUARI WHICH WAS FAR RICHER MINE THAN MINA MATILDE. 8. MINISTER NOTED THAT BOLIVIAN LAW REQUIRED THAT MINES OR MINERAL DEPOSITS NOT BEING EXPLOITED OR WITHOUT DEVELOPMENT PLANS MUST REVERT TO GOVERNMENT. 9. ADCM STATED THAT BESIDES CLEARING AIR, ARBITRATION MIGHT SERVE TO AVOID ACTION MINISTER LEMA HAD MENTIONED IN EARLIER MEETING WHICH TYE HAD THREATENED, I.E., TO BLOCKADE OR HOLD BOLIVIAN TIN SHIP- MENT TO TEXAS SMELTER. MINISTER RESPONDED THAT TYE WAS NO BETTER REGARDED IN U.S. THAN BOLIVIA DUE TO HIS ASSOCIATION WITH FIRMS BROUGHT INTO BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS. MINISTER SAID TYE WAS AN ADVENTURER WHO HAD USED CONTACTS TO ACCOMPLISH HIS PURPOSES. 10. MINISTER CONCLUDED DISCUSSION BY REPEATING THAT HE SAW NO BASIS FOR ARBITRATION OR SIMILAR PROCEEDINGS. BREWIN

          Subject:
          Empc/Embosa Refs: (A) State 014154; (B) La Paz 0225; (C) State 013783; (D) A-245 November 26, 1973. Summary: Embassy Agrees That There Are Contradictory Assertions As Stated In Ref A. In View Of These And Because We Not Convinced There Still Is Recourse To Arbitration, We Hesitate To Urge Gob To Arbitrate When Matter Has Been Legally Closed. Not Yet Clear Whether Tye’s Lawyer Effectively Requested Arbitration Before Embosa’s Board Resolved To Liquidate Company Or Whether Arbitration Can Be Requested Following Liquidation Period. End Summary.
        
                    
          TAGS:
          BDIS, EMIN, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

First contradiction is in first paragraph of Tye’s letter to Senator Bentsen dated November 30, 1973, wherein Tye states IMPC received half million dollars in compensation for nationalization of its property. Embassy will send ASAP translation and copy in Spanish of original receipt and document of payment signed by Tye and IMPC’s lawyer, Luis Soux, declaring and “confessing” they received check duly endorsed for US$ 1,447,066 which they recognize as just and fair indemnification for all its investments in Bolivia and those made in foreign countries for investigations related to treatment and mining of tin tailings.
Second contradiction in same paragraph is that “we had to give 51 percent interest in another mine which was not nationalized.” We have not found any written evidence in documents that Huari-Huari deal related to IMPC settlement. According documents we hold, Tye gave on March 16, 1972 to Ministry National Defense a two year option contract as of March 1, 1972 to purchase 51 percent of stock of Gibralter Huari-Huari Corporation. Option expires on March 1, 1974.
Third contradiction is that according to Ref A, item A, Tye claims EMBOSA’s legal status ‘impersoneria juridical’ established August, 1973, but appears it was first recognized May 3, 1972 by Supreme Resolution 162872 and according De La Rocha was finally implemented by Supreme Resolution No 163617 dated August 16, 1972.
Fourth contradiction is that according to COMIBOL and MINMINES records, plant operated from May to November, 1972 and produced 139.9 metric tons fine tin content in concentrate form whereas according Ref A Tye claims was operating from February to July, 1972 and produced 154 metric tons fine tin. Under COMIBOL management plant operated from January to December, 1971 and produced 249.0 metric tons of fine tin equivalent.
According to Dr. Luis Soux, IMPC’s previous lawyer, and IMPC’s present lawyer, Dr. Hugo De La Rocha, neither attorney had requested arbitration in writing before liquidation of EMBOSA. Soux states on September 27, 1973 when board of directors liquidated EMBOSA, he made oral appeal for arbitration. De La Rocha now trying to obtain legalized record of minutes of this meeting. Embassy notes that board resolved to liquidate EMBOSA on meeting of September 12, 1973, which perhaps would have been time indicated for Soux to have made written appeal for arbitration. As reported in Ref B, Tye sent letter to MINMINES stating he had tried to see Minister “to try to reach an arbitrated agreement.” According De La Rocha this written expression of interest in arbitrated settlement can also be taken as request for arbitration.
FYI. De La Rocha on January 23, 1974 told EMBOFF he had advised Tye to forget EMBOSA and concentrate on Gibralter Huari-Huari affairs.
In view of many contradictions and questions of fact in this case we believe USG position at this time probably could be no more than simply to urge GOB to submit dispute to arbitration as specified in Article 41 of Statute of Incorporation and we are not even sure we can do this. We not entirely convinced even this opportunity to use arbitration has not already been lost to IMPC. If it turns out that minutes of last stockholders’ meeting do not show that IMPC rep requested arbitration then Article 41 may not be available to IMPC because request may have been made during life or liquidation phase of EMBOSA. We do see some possible merit in De La Rocha’s view that COMIBOL should have referred matter to arbitration rather than proceeding directly to liquidation. End FYI.
Action requested: That Department lawyers carefully examine statutes, decrees, resolutions and other documents in this case and advise what position we should take. (These documents being pouched under airgram). In meantime, lawyers may wish review what we believe are salient clauses sent Ref D.

title: Banzer Goes On Trial Before Congress
text:
Date:
          August 31, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz

          Info:
          Oct-01 Ads-00 Ha-05 Sy-05 Sye-00 Ciae-00 Nsae-00 Nsce-00 Sso-00 Icae-00 Inre-00 Acda-12 Io-14 Anae-00 Aid-05 Pm-05 H-01 Inr-10 L-03 Pa-01 Inc-01 Sp-02 Ss-15 /095 W ——————033175 011257z /41
        
                    
          Subject:
          Banzer Goes On Trial Before Congress
        
                    
          TAGS:
          POINT, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: On August 30 former President Hugo Banzer went on trial before the Congress. This is the sixth such trial in Bolivian history since 1857, and none so far has resulted in convictions. On the eve of the hearing several political parties expressed solidarity with the proceedings. That same day, Banzer went on television to defend his regime and pledge he would go along with the verdict of the people and history. On the first day of the trial, PS-1 Deputy Marcelo Quiroga presented the lengthiest and most detailed of the two accusations made in the time span allowed. While no one can predict at this time how these proceedings will end, the possibility exists that the process—particularly if the Armed Forces become involved as an institution—could jeopardize the consummation of Bolivia’s transition to democracy.
Introduction: If any informed observer of Bolivia had predicted in the summer of 1977—at the very height of the Hugo Banzer dictatorship—that in only two years a constitutionally-elected Congress would have President Banzer on trial for high treason, misuse of funds, and violation of human rights, the observer would have been regarded as something of a doomsday freak. We are not aware that anyone made such a prediction, but the event, highly unlikely in 1977, is now taking place, for the much heralded trial in the Congress began August 30, 1979. It is the sixth time since 1857 that trials of high government officials have taken place. No convictions have ever occurred.
Background: A. In 1857, General Cordova’s entire cabinet was charged with violating the Constitution and the civil rights of the people. The Congress dismissed the charges. In 1893, similar accusations against President Mariano Baptista—one of Cordova’s accusers—were also dismissed by the Congress. That same year, General Daza was accused of treason during the war with Chile, graft, and violation of the Constitution. He was never tried. Returning from Europe to defend himself, Daza was assassinated in 1894. José Manuel Pando and his cabinet was charged in 1913 with the same crimes as Cordova and Baptista, and like them was never tried. Finally, in 1917, the trial of President Ismael Montes led to a riot that kept his accusers away from the Congress. He too escaped prosecution.
B. Presently, charges against public officials can be brought under the 1967 Political Constitution, and the Law of Responsibilities (passed October 23, 1944, modifying a similar law enacted October 31, 1884). The process calls for:

Accusations against a President or other high government officials “for crimes committed in the exercise of their functions” must be presented in open session to the Congress;
Afterwards, the matter is to be promptly referred to a special commission to study the evidence, and within 15 days, present Congress a recommendation to either dismiss or sustain charges;
The accused may defend themselves in person or through deposition. Once their defense is heard, Congress must decide, by a two-thirds vote, whether to dismiss charges or refer the matter to the Supreme Court. (Note: The Congress is not bound by the commission’s recommendation.)
The Supreme Court, acting on evidence and testimony previously presented, issues a decision and imposes a sentence.

C. In preparation for the trial of the former President, the Congress petitioned the GOB to provide detailed information on persons detained, persecuted, and exiled during the Banzer years. When given advance notice of this request, the press reports the Interior Minister asked for 90 days to prepare a reply. Oscar Zamora, MNR Senator from Tarija and PCML leader, reportedly refused to grant the Minister’s request and trenchantly suggested the information be expeditiously obtained from Armed Forces J-2 files, which he qualified as the most complete source of political information.
D. On the eve of the trial, August 29, many political parties appeared in favor of it. Press reports quoted Casiano Amurrio, leader of the PCML and Deputy for Cochabamba, “The MNR alliance is not out for revenge, but only seeks justice be done and the law respected.” Qualifying those remarks, Jose Harb, an MNR leader and Deputy for La Paz, cautiously told reporters he could not comment on the position the alliance would take at the hearings. Jaime Tapia Alipaz, ADN leader and Deputy for La Paz, told the press his party will seek to include under the present trial all governments since 1952, particularly the governments of Paz Estenssoro, Siles Zuazo and Ovando. He reasoned these governments repeatedly violated the rights of individuals, and hoped the present trial would prevent recurrence of past errors. Finally, Banzer in a televised statement August 29 defended his regime, asked the trial be conducted in an atmosphere of respect and proper decorum, and claimed he would

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: You are authorized to provide the following response to General Banzer in answer to his letter of September 19, to President Carter.
Begin Text: Dear General Banzer: I have been asked to respond to your thoughtful letter of September 19 addressed to President Carter.

My government sees the decision on the part of Bolivia to place itself in consonance with the Andean region’s movement toward democracy as a highly important accomplishment. It is our belief that this step will enhance Bolivia’s international standing and ability to realize its most important diplomatic and economic objectives. There should be no question of our support for the democratization process which is continuing, and our admiration for the accomplishments realized thus far. My government also shares a deep concern for the possible consequences which might arise through indiscriminate, uncontrolled sale of tin. It is for this reason that the United States is committed to consult, prior to any sales, with the International Tin Council as well as with the tin producers. President Carter has assured the Government of Bolivia that we will manage any eventual disposals from the strategic buffer stocks so as to safeguard against disruption of the tin market and the economic position of producers.
The United States believes that consumers and producers share an interest in a healthy world tin market. It has thus been a matter of increasing concern to us that in recent years world tin production has lagged behind demand despite rapidly increasing prices. World consumption of tin metal is expected to exceed production again in 1979, and world stocks are well below historical levels. In view of these considerations, we believe it is in the long run interest of all signatories to the International Tin Agreement to compensate for this shortage and thus discourage further substitution of alternative materials for tin.
The legislation now pending in the United States Congress would provide authority for the disposal of 35,000 tons of tin, of which up to 5,000 tons is authorized for a contribution to the International Tin Council buffer stock. The sales would be carried out over a period of three or more years. It is the position of the United States that a disposal program which is conducted with careful regard for developments in the world economy, and in consultation with the International Tin Council and tin producers, will not jeopardize the foreign exchange earnings which are so vital to the continued economic growth of Bolivia.
In closing, I wish to reiterate that the United States is deeply aware of the need to ensure the democratization process in Bolivia. I am sure you share this view and will be reassured that the legislation now being considered by the United States Senate would not disrupt the world tin market. Sincerely, Paul H. Boeker. End Text.

text:
Date:

          Oct-01 Iso-00 Omb-01 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Pm-07 H-03 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Nsc-10 Pa-04 Rsc-01 Prs-01 Spc-03 Ss-20 Usia-15 Sam-01 Aid-20 Pc-10 Come-00 Eb-11 Lab-06 Sil-01 Drc-01 /149 W ——————— 006487 R 301855z Jan 74

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Following is text of President Banzer’s speech of January 28 announcing institution of state of siege throughout Bolivia.
“Fellow Bolivians:
I must denounce before the country an international conspiracy, to which I have referred several times in the past.
This activity, whose details I have made known to the directors of the press and radio in a manner, and which was originally planned for a later date, has suddenly commenced in the belief, that – with the new economic measures – its time has come. The plan has begun with the destruction of bridges, blockage of roads, interruption of railroad lines and explosion of grenades in urban centers, concluding with the criminal sabotage of our petroleum production, all of which is aimed at creating a state of confusion and chaos wherein the cities would suffer shortages of goods, provoking the people’s anger; at this moment when the conditions were ripe, the extremists would call for an armed uprising, converting our country, as it is easy to imagine, into a battlefield of ideological and armed struggle in South America.
It is not, hence, a plan which seeks a new type of government appropriate for our nation’s problems, but rather one which seeks to establish in our country, aside from a puppet government, a new center of continental extremist activities; it is a conspiracy which intends to regain for extremism the positions recently lost in America, and, this action, as we have previously pointed out, is being carried out in our country because of its special political and geographic situation. The plan is not new or original; we have suffered before from the same type of attempts. The popular armed rejection of extremist aggression is still fresh in our memory.
The solid integration of the Armed Forces, the Nationalist Revolutionary Movement, Bolivian Socialist Falange, the Farrientist Forces and the citizens of the countryside and of the cities does not reflect the mere permanence in power of interests or partisan groups but rather the deep ideological, nationalist conviction which unites them together in order to keep Bolivia from any international dependency, within the framework of Christian moral and spiritual principles, with full awareness of the responsibilities the workers and employers share in the common enterprise which their work involves. Some narrow-minded persons who do not understand this scheme try to channel their personal ambitions through a dozen “displaced” persons and want to surprise us with ingenious commando-style coup attempts. Those who consciously or unconsciously are engaged in this new adventure, which ultimately favors the international conspiracy, are hereby warned that my government will be inflexible in imposing the existing legal sanctions.
In the same manner that in August 1971 the Armed Forces supported the popular effort to guard our national integrity and call a halt to the excessive acts of anarchy, today in the presence of these serious acts I take my place to fight this new battle for our nation.
To the farmers, to the workers in the cities, to the miners, to all those who are deceived in their good faith, whom the extremists are trying to induce to act against the forces of public order, converting them into cannon fodder, I make a call so that they will become aware of the seriousness of this situation, realizing that the solution to the problem of supply and salaries can not come via an armed confrontation or the blocking of roads, but only by cooperating with Government’s effort to obtain more resources in order to face the world food shortage. It is necessary to establish clearly that the line of the Government is firmly outlined and explained in my New Year’s Message, an”

Summary: As of the evening of April 21, Committee II’s work has been virtually completed, the committee having fully discussed the Secretariat’s activities over the last two years, the Secretariat’s projected work program for 1979-81, and having considered 25 out of 26 draft resolutions before it. The US delegation played an active role and was successful in promoting greater concern over the need for budgetary discipline and the need to stop the proliferating number of international meetings and subsidiary bodies of ECLA. A very good resolution on decentralization (restructuring) of UN activities was adopted which incorporates the concept of redeploying resources from New York to the regional commission to enable the latter to effectively assume their growing responsibilities (text to be sent septel). Only remaining business on Committee II agenda is consideration of Uruguayan draft resolution on energy which is still before Latin American Working Group and adoption of Committee II report which will be forwarded to Plenary. End summary.
Committee II, which was assigned to review the Secretariat’s activities and work program, has completed virtually all items on its agenda and dealt with 25 draft resolutions. In addition to the resolutions noted in reftel, the following nine resolutions were also considered:


COM II/19: Withdrawn
COM II/21 SPONSOR: Venezuela SUBJECT: Amends Resolution 13 US POSITION: Yes, with reservation COMMENT: Objectionable language on graduation removed, US supported consensus
COM II/22: Withdrawn
COM II/23: SPONSOR: Argentina, Costa Rica, Cuba, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Venezuela SUBJECT: Economic and social projections US POSITION: Yes
COM II/24 SPONSOR: Uruguay SUBJECT: Decentralization of UN activities US POSITION: Yes COMMENT: Approved with US amendments on transfer and redevelopment of resources.
COM II/25 SPONSOR: Bolivia SUBJECT: The needs of children and the shaping of the coming generations within the framework of the development process. US POSITION: Yes
COM II/26 SPONSOR: Uruguay SUBJECT: Energy US POSITION: To be decided COMMENT: Remanded to working group
COM II/27 SPONSOR: Cuba, Guatemala, Mexico SUBJECT: Regional cooperation in the field of human settlement. US POSITION: No COMMENT: US opposed creation of ECLA intergovernmental committee. No consensus by committee.
COM II/28 SPONSOR: Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras SUBJECT: Methodological research for the inclusion of the patrimony of resources in the system of national accounts. US POSITION: No COMMENT: US opposed because of financial implications. No consensus by committee.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM

EMBASSY BELIEVES REFTEL WITH MINOR CHANGES APTLY DESCRIBES TRADE PROBLEMS AFFECTING BOLIVIA. THIS TELEGRAM RETRANSMITS PARAS. 3.A.2., 3.A.3., AND 3.C.1. OF REFTEL WITH EMBASSY’S SUGGESTED CHANGES.
PARA. 3.A.2. - EX-IM BANK CREDITS. THE EX-IM BANK CURRENTLY REFUSES TO MAKE LOANS OR ISSUE CREDIT GUARANTEE FOR SALES TO BOLIVIA DUE TO GOB DEFAULT ON DEBTS IN THE PAST AND, MORE RECENTLY, LATE PAYMENT OF DEBTS. THE GOB HAS MADE STRONG REPRESENTATIONS TO THE USG ASKING THAT THE EX-IM POLICY BE RECONSIDERED BUT TO NO AVAIL. THE GOB SEES THE EX-IM POLICY AS A SERIOUS ROADBLOCK IN ACHIEVING ITS CAPITAL INVESTMENT GOALS, AND AS A PREJUDICIAL USG VIEW OF BOLIVIA IN LIGHT OF MORE FORTHCOMING ATTITUDE OF BRAZIL, U.K., FRG AND JAPAN, AMONG OTHERS.
PARA 3.A.3. - SUGAR ACT. THE GOB WILL UNDOUBTEDLY BE UNHAPPY IF THE SUGAR ACT IS NOT RENEWED. THIS REACTION WILL BE MUTED SO LONG AS THE INERNATIONAL PRICE REMAINS ABOVE THE QUOTA PRICE AND WORLD DEMAND REMAINS STRONG, ALTHOUGH GOB MAY YET SEND

032111Z
US NOTE ON SUBJECT.

PARA. 3.C.1. - BOLIVIAN-ARGENTINE TRADE PROBLEMS. THE GOB HAS BEEN CONCERNED FOR ALMOST A YEAR OVER WHAT IT REGARDS AS GOA NON- PERFORMANCE ON COMMITMENTS TO BOLIVIA. THE PRIMARY COMPLAINT IS WITH REGARD TO FULFILLING CONTRACTS TO PROVIDE WHEAT AND FLOUR TO BOLIVIA AT PRICES AGREED IN 1973 AND WITH APPARENT ARGENTINE FOOT- DRAGGING ON CONSTRUCTION OF AHIGHWAY FROM POTOSI TO THE ARGENTINE BOFDER AT BERMEJO. THE GOB IS CONVINCED THAT THIS STANCE REFLECTS GOA PIQUE WITH THE GO’S DEMANDS TO INCREASE PRICES ON NATURAL GAS AND PETROLEUM SUPPLIED TO ARGENTINA. THIS SUTUATION MAY BECOME MORE AGGRAVATED AS A RESULT OF THE RECENT SIGNATURE OF AN IMPORTANT AGREEMENT BETWEEN BOLIVIA AND BRAZIL WHICH COMMITS BOLIVIA TO SELL LARGE QUANTITIES OF NATURAL GAS AND PETROLEUM TO BRAZIL IN EXCHANGE FOR LARGE AMOUNTS OF BRAZILIAN ASSISTANCE. TALKS TO STRAIGHTEN OUT THE COMPLEX OF ARGENTINE-BOLIVIAN ECONOMIC RELATIONS (OTHER EXAPLES, GOA WANTS BOLIVIAN IRON ORE AND GOB WANTS ARGENTINE AVGAS AT LOW PRICE) HAVE NEVER GOTTEN OFF THE GROUND. STEDMAN

La Paz agrees completely with Quito 0059. After considerable consultation with appropriate country team members, we do not feel that having a seminar in Lima would benefit Mission objectives in La Paz. Our representative to Andean PAO meeting did not understand simultaneous seminars to mean sending participants to other country.
Normal spin-off benefits from seminars include: A. Strengthening contacts with key individual through close proximity over a period of time. B. Being able to present points to further local CASP and CPM courses of action. C. Using local media to convey to a larger audience the key points brought out during the discussions. D. Using the STAG’s as entre to groups with whom one would not ordinarily have easy access.
None of these benefits would accrue to Bolivia if we participated in Peru’s seminar. Under the circumstances, we prefer not to participate in the proposed Vogel, Pollack, Turpin seminar. Like Quito, we feel our money could be better spent in a locally produced seminar later in the fiscal year. We are consulting with Economic/Commercial Section on practical aspects to be covered and will submit details and STAG requests later.

THE CONSUMER COST OF ELECTRIC POWER VARIES WIDELY THROUGHOUT

MINISTER OF EXTERNAL RELATIONS GUZMAN RECENTLY TOLD AMBASSADOR BOLIVIA RUNNING SHORT OF AVIATION GASOLINE BECAUSE ESSO REFUSED TO DELIVER CONTRACT AMOUNTS. SAID SHORTFALL FROM REQUIREMENTS WOULD

291410Z
BE DISASTROUS FOR MAINTENANCE OF INTERNAL SECURITY AND ECONOMY WHICH
DEPENDENT ON PISTON AIRCRAFT FOR PROVISION OF MEAT TO LA PAZ AND WIDE VARIETY OF SUPPLIES TO MOST TOWNS IN BOLIVIA’S NORTH WHICH NOT CONNECTED BY ROAD OR RAIL TRANSPORTATION TO “OUTSIDE”. WE ALSO KNOW GOB ALREADY HAS PLACED RESTRICTIONS ON AVGAS USERS, INCLUDING MILITARY.

YPFB HAS SUPPLIED US WITH CONTRACT, DECREE, LETTERS, TELEXES AND OTHER DOCUMENTS WHICH ESTABLISH SITUATION AS DESCRIBED BELOW.
CONTRACT BETWEEN ESSO AND YPFB SIGNED JAN 1, 1973, VALID FOR THREE YEARS BEGINNING NOV 1, 1972, STATES YPFB WILL BUY 3,300,000 U.S. GALLONS OF 100/130 OCTANE AVIATION GASOLINE PER YEAR PLUS OR MINUS 10 PERCENT ACCORDING TO YPFB’S NEEDS. CONTRACT ALSO STATES THAT IF YPFB NEEDS TO BUY AVGAS FROM CAMPANA, ARGENTINA(AN ESSO SUBSIDIARY)..”ALL THE TERMS OF THE SELLERS OFFER EXPRESSED IN THE LETTER OF AUGUST 24, 1972 (ANNEX 3) WOULD APPLY TO THIS PURCHASE..” LETTER OF AUGUST 24, 1972 CONTAINS DELIVERY SCHEDULES THAT WORK OUT TO 2,060,520 GALLONS PER YEAR THROUGH ARICA, SAME AMOUNT THROUGH ANTOFAGASTA AND 951,012 THROUGH CAMPANA, ARGENTINA FOR 5,072,052 TOTAL. AS YPFB PURCHASED ALMOST ONE MILLION BARRELS FROM CAMPANA IN JULY TO DECEMBER PERIOD OF 1973, IT APPEARS TO BELIEVE ALL PRO- VISIONS OF AUGUST 24, 1972 LETTER IN FORCE INCLUDING TOTAL QUANTITY INDICATED IN LETTER OF MORE THAN FIVE MILLION BARRELS PER YEAR.
YPFB HAS ASKED EMBASSY, AS FIRST PREFERENCE, TO SEEK REDRESS AND BETTER UNDERSTANDING SITUATION BY APPEALING TO ESSO HEAD OFFICE. RECOMMEND DEPARTMENT RAISE MATTER WITH ESSO 1) ON BASIS YPFB REDING OF CONTRACT TERMS AND IMPORTANCE AVGAS HAS FOR ECONOMIC AND POLITICAL STABILITY OF BOLIVIA AND/OR 2) BASIS PRESENTED BY RENE URQUIDI, ESSO REP IN LA PAZ, THAT ESSO HAS ENJOYED 22 YEARS OF VERY GOOD BUSINESS AS SINGLE SELLER OF AVGAS TO BOLIVIA AND SHOULD DO EVERYTHING IN ITS POWER TO MEET BOLIVIA’S REQUIREMENTS TO MAIN- TAIN THIS GOOD RELATIONSHIP.
ESSO CURRENTLY DELIVERY AT 4.7 MILLION GALLON RATE, ACCORDING TO YPFB DATA, BUT ACCORDING URQUIDI THIS HIGH LEVEL WAS DUE TO CONTROL ERROR ESSO ARGENTINA AND ESSO NOW INSISTING IT WILL NOT DELIVER MORE THAN 3.3 MILLION GALLONS SPECIFIED IN CONTRACT PLUS TEN PERCENT.

291410Z

YPFB OFFICIAL SAID URGENT EXCHANGE OF PAST TWO DAYS HAD RESULTED IN ESSO AGREEMENT TO DELIVER IMMEDIATELY EXTRA 10PERCENT (OR 330,000 GALLONS) ALLOWED UNDER TERMS OF CONTRACT WHICH WILL STAVE OFF SERIOUS SHORTAGE UNTIL SEPTEMBER, 1974.
YPFB TELEXED JOSE VARELA, ESSO ARGENTINA IN BUENOS AIRES ON JANUARY 21, 1974. REQUESTING 430,000 GALLONS PER MONTH (5,160,000 ANNUAL RATE) BEGINNING IN FEBRUARY FOR DELIVERY IN ANTOFAGASTA AND

ARICA. TELEX CITES SUSPENSION F DELIVERIES FROM ARGENTINA DUE TO RAIL TRANSPORT DIFFICULTIES. VARELA REPLIED BY LETTER DATED MARCH 25 THAT FOLLOWING A CHECK WITH CORAL PETROLEUM CO.(ESSO REFINING SUBSIDIARY IN ARUBA) THAT NOT POSSIBLE ACCEDE TO YPFB REQUEST AS WORLD SUPPLY SITUATION PREVENTS IT. YPFB REPLIED IN APRIL 8 LETTER TO VARELA, REFERRING TO CLAUSE THAT BRINGS INTO FORCE LETTER OF AUGUST 24, 1972, AGAIN CITING TRANSPORT DIFFICULTIES FROMARGENTINA AND STATING THAT YPFB HAD BEEN RECEIVING 395,000 GALLONS PER MONTH (4,740,000 GAL. ANNUAL RATE) AND ONLY ASKING FOR 35,000 GALLONS PER MONTH(420,000 GAL. ANNUAL RATE) MORE.

ON OTHER HAND, CONTRACT AND LETTER OF AUGUST 24, 1972 CONTAIN FORCE MAJEURE CLAUSES THAT WE THINK WOULD ALLOW ESSO TO ESCAPE FROM ITS CONTRACT OBLIGATIONS IN VIEW OF WORLD SUPPLY SITUATION AND ACTIONS TAKEN BY GOVERNMENTS OF OIL EXPORTING COUNTRIES.
URQUIDI NOTES THAT WHEN BOLIVIA RAISED PRICE ON ITS CRUDE TO US$ 16 PER BARREL IN JANUARY, ARGENTINA RAISED PRICE ON AVGAS SUPPLIED BY CAMPANA IN ROUGHLY PROPORTIONAL AMOUNT. URGUIDI BELIEVES, ON OTHER HAND, THAT ESSO ARGENTINA SO OCCUPIED WITH PROBLEMS RELATING TO ARGENTINA, URUGUAY AND PARAGUAY IT UNABLE TO GIVE ADEQUATE CONSIDERATION TO BOLIVIAN PROBLEM.

10 DURING CONVERSATON WITH YPFB OFFICIAL, HE OPENED DOOR TO POSSIBILITY OF SUPPLYING ESSO WITH BOLIVIAN CRUDE IN EXCHANGE FOR ADDITIONAL AVGAS AND ALL AVGAS DELIVERIES TO ARICA AND ANTOFAGASTA.

YPFB SECOND PREFERENCE IS THAT SOME OTHER U.S FIRM SUPPLY ADDITIONAL QUANTITY REQUIRED.AT DEPARTMENT’S DISCRETION, USDOC SHOULD BE ASKED TO INFORM U.S. AVGAS SUPPLIERS TO CONTACT ING. BELMONTE, YPFB, TELEX BX-5267. NOTE, HOWEVER, THAT ESSO’S FULL COOPERATION WILL BE REQUIRED IN EFFICIENT SUPPLY OF AVGAS TO BOLIVIA FROM ANY SOURCE OTHER THAN ESSO BECAUSE ESSO CONTROLS ESSENTIAL

291410Z
SHIPPING AND TANK FARMS AT ARICA AND ANTOFAGASTA. ESSO PROBABLY WILL HAVE TO MERGE OTHER SUPPLIES INTO ITS SHIPPING AND TANK STORAGE CAPACITY. URQUIDI BELIEVES ESSO WILLING GIVE ITS FULL COOPERATION. STEDMAN

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

THE MINISTER OF LABOR HAS STARTED DISCUSSIONS WITH BOLIVIA’S MAJOR CONFEDERATIONS AND FEDERATIONS ON THE POSSIBILITY OF RE- OPENING THE CENTRAL OBRERA BOLIVIANA (COB). THIS REPRESENTS A MAJOR CHANGE IN THE GOVERNMENT’S LABOR POLICY SINCE THE DISESTAB- LISHMENT OF THE COB HAD BEEN A KEY TACTIC IN THE BANZER REGIME’S STRATEGY OF KEEPING THE LABOR MOVEMENT DIVIDED.
THE MINISTER OF LABOR HAS INDICATED IN A NUMBER OF STATEMENTS ON THIS ISSUE THAT TO BE ACCEPTABLE TO THE GOVERNMENT THE COB WOULD HAVE TO BE REORGANIZED AS AN APOLITICAL ORGANIZATION STRICTLY DEVOTED TO TRADE UNION MATTERS. THERE IS SOME SUPPORT FOR THIS VIEW AMONG CERTAIN LABOR ORGANIZATIONS WHO BELIEVE THAT THE COB STATUTES GIVE DISAPROPORTIONATE VOTING STRENGTH TO THE MINERS AND FACTORY WORKERS. MODERATE TRADE UNIONISTS WOULD ALSO LIKE TO SEE ORGANIZATIONS NOT STRICTLY TRADE UNION SUCH AS STUDENT GROUPS AND “FREE PROFESSIONALS” SEPARATED FROM THE COB. THE MINERS FEDERATION IS, OF COURSE, OPPOSED TO ANY CHANGES IN THE COB’S STATUTES.
COMMENT: THE REOPENING OF THE COB WOULD STRENGTHEN THE BARGAINING POWER OF THE LABOR MOVEMENT MANYFOLD AND INEVITABLY ENABLE THE MOVEMENT TO PLAY A MORE EFFECTIVE ROLE AS CRITIC

021911Z
OF THE ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL POLICIES OF THE GOVERNMENT. IT
SEEMS PROBABLE THAT VARIOUS UNIONS MIGHT ACCEPT SOME CHANGES IN THE COB’S TRADITIONAL STRUCTURE IF IT MEANT THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN HAVING A CENTRAL OR NOT. STEDMAN

title: Annual Narcotics Status Report
text:
Date:
          April 04, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 5598
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Io-14 Ads-00 Aid-05 Ciae-00 Inr-10 Juse-00 Nsae-00 Ctme-00 Inm-05 Trse-00 Ica-11 Nsc-05 Oes-09 Omb-01 Agre-00 Hew-04 Dode-00 /080 W ——————098058 062350z /61 R 041350z Apr 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          Annual Narcotics Status Report
        
                    
          TAGS:
          SNAR, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          STATE A-434
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

(LOU only where noted.)

I. Country Perception of Illicit Narcotics Activities and its Control Efforts
(LOU) As of 1978, Bolivia’s perception of the narcotics problem might be described as maturing. Political leaders know that they have a problem, but in a year of electoral campaigns, fraud at the ballot box and military coups, there has not been the will on the part of the GOB to enforce key measures. Most glaring has been the failure to enforce the law which calls for the destruction of unregistered new plantings of coca. While we continue to urge action, there is no prospect that the present caretaker military government will do anything effective. We believe, however, that the chances of action from an elected government, scheduled to take over in August, are good. For 1978, and up to the present, political and other major concerns have overshadowed the drug problem in the minds of Bolivian leaders. The broader spectrum of Bolivian business, social and educational leadership, with some exceptions has only begun to appreciate that cocaine is a menace to this society as well as to the US. Firm conviction that something must be done soon to protect Bolivian society is still lacking. Embassy believes, nevertheless, that awareness of the problem has heightened during the past three years. On the positive side, the GOB with US help has considerably enhanced the capacity of the DNSP and Customs to take effective action against traffickers and cocaine processors. While this was not reflected in the very slight increase in seizures in 1978 (236 kilos of sulphate and HCL) as compared with 1977 (210 kilos of sulphate and HCL), there has been a notable increase during Jan.-Mar. 1979 (over 160 kilos of sulphate and HCL). The DNSP has also pushed ahead with the registration of coca merchants, transporters and retailers, and expects to open checkpoints at 25-50 locations along the coca farm-to-market routes. If effectively and honestly operated, these checkpoints, given Bolivia’s limited road network, could prove a significant deterrent to uncontrolled, illegal coca shipments. In short, the GOB does perceive coca and cocaine as a threat and the US does get cooperation. In 1978, however, due to an unfortunate mix of politics, corruption and inefficiencies, the GOB was not prepared to make the hard decisions needed for a full-scale crackdown on traffickers and illegal plantings. (End LOU.)

US Interest

In cooperation with the GOB, the US hopes to achieve (1) a reduction of coca production to the level of legal consumption (about 12,000 MT) and (2) a decrease in illegal exports of cocaine by a high percentage.
A. Progress: We cannot point to significant progress in 1978 in terms of either reduction of coca plantings or of seizures of cocaine. The indications are, in fact, that plantings increased and, while we have no reliable estimates, it is likely that illicit cocaine exports also increased in 1978. Definite progress can be reported, however, in studies, research and data-gathering essential to a successful crop diversification/coca reduction program. Under the “Agricultural Development in Coca Zones” project, the Felt-Needs Study, aerial photography of the coca areas, the “Multidisciplinary Study” and the coffee productivity and sanitation campaign in the Yungas were completed. Construction of the La Jota Experimental Station in the Chapare has progressed substantially and the cacao productivity and sanitation campaign is well under way. Regarding enforcement, the most significant step forward was the beginning in October of the DNSP program, assisted and supported by the Mission, to register and license all dealers and merchants and coca. Scheduled for completion in March 1979, the registration will open the way for greatly improved controls on coca movements and marketing. (Peruvian narcotics authorities visiting Bolivia in December were highly impressed with this initiative.) In addition, DNSP territorial coverage and communications were improved as well as detector dog capabilities. The DNSP, with its own US-trained officers, conducted its first in-country narcotics training course. The Embassy also completed an extensive narcotics strategy paper, with a reassessment of our programs and a proposal for the establishment of a GOB coca marketing board, an “Estanco”. The board, by purchasing and marketing all or most of the Bolivian coca crops, would assure an adequate supply of coca at reasonable prices for legal users (chewers primarily) while the overall crop is reduced as a result of crop diversification and enforcement programs.

title: Consultations Among Policy Planning Staffs
text:
Date:
          September 03, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz

          Info:
          Oct-01 Ara-16 Iso-00 Pm-07 Nsc-07 Ss-20 Rsc-01 L-03 Inr-11 Drc-01 /070 W ——————— 013405 P 032100z Sep 74

          TAGS:
          PFOR, XM, US, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          STATE 192211
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

ALTHOUGH I RECOGNIZE THAT BOLIVIA IS NOT A “KEY” COUNTRY IN LATIN AMERICA, I BELIEVE THAT THERE ARE SEVERAL SOUND REASONS FOR INCLUDING IT AMONG THOSE COUNTRIES ON THE CONSULTATION LIST. THE MOST IMPORTANT OF THESE REASONS IS THAT BOLIVIA INEVITABLY WILL BE A FACTOR IN ANY CONFLICT BETWEEN CHILE AND PERU. WITH PROPER ENCOURAGEMENT AND SUPPORT, BOLIVIA COULD PLAY A CONSTRUCTIVE ROLE AND PERHAPS AN IMPORTANT ONE IN PREVENTING CHILEAN-PERUVIAN TENSIONS FROM GETTING OUT OF HAND. OUR CONSULTATIONS MIGHT HELP PRECLUDE BOLIVIA FROM MAKING AN IRRATIONAL MOVE TO SUPPORT ONE SIDE OR THE OTHER AND COMPLICATE THE ISSUES EVEN FURTHER.
ANOTHER IMPORTANT REASON IS THAT THE PRESENT BOLIVIAN GOVERNMENT, WHICH TOPPLED AN EXTREMIST AND HOSTILE REGIME, IS VERY FRIENDLY TO US; DISPOSED TO COOPERATE WITH US ON INTERNATIONAL ISSUES; AND IS MOVING TOWARD OPENING ITS DOMESTIC POLITICAL PROCESSES. THESE CONSULTATIONS WOULD HELP ASSURE CONTINUED BOLIVIAN SUPPORT FOR OUR POSITIONS, BUT MORE IMPORTANTLY, WOULD PROVIDE A USEFUL SHORING UP OF PRESTIGE FOR THE BANZER REGIME. I BELIEVE BANZER HAS A GOOD CHANCE TO STAY ON UNTIL ELECTIONS SOMETIME IN 1975,

032232Z
BUT HIS ABILITY TO GOVERN EFFECTIVELY DURING THIS TIME AND
TO KEEP THE PROCESS OF CONSTITUTIONALIZATION ON THE TRACK WOULD BE ADVANCED IN THE MEASURE THAT HIS PRESTIGE IS AUGMENTED. THIS WOULD BE IN OUR INTEREST.

A THIRD REASON APPLIES TO ALL THE SMALLER COUNTRIES IN THE HEMISPHERE, I.E., OUR NEW DIALOGUE SHOULD BE CARRIED ON WITH ALL THE COUNTRIES, NOT JUST THE BIG ONES, OR WE MAY IN THE PROCESS OF CONSULTING WITH THE “KEY” COUNTRIES OFFEND THE SMALL ONES, PARTICULARLY THOSE WHO HAVE BEEN OUTSPOKENLY FRIENDLY. THIS WOULD BE PARTICULARLY TRUE IN BOLIVIA’S CASE WERE OUR TEAM TO VISIT PERU AND CHILE AND NOT BOLIVIA.
THERE ARE SOME GOB-GROUPS IN EXISTENCE NOW THAT HAVE POLICY PLANNING FUNCTIONS AFFECTING FOREIGN POLICY, SUCH AS THE COMISION MARITIMA, THE CONSEJO POLITICO NACIONALISTA, THE ALTO MANDO MILITAR, AND THE AS YET UNSTAFFED ADVISORY COUNCIL TO THE FOREIGN MINISTRY. NEVERTHELESS, EACH OF THESE HAS CERTAIN DRAWBACKS, AND IT PROBABLY WOULD BE BETTER IF THE GOB FORMED A SPECIAL GROUP OF DECISION MAKERS AND PLANNERS TO MEET WITH OUR TEAM. THIS WOULD NOT PRESENT A PROBLEM. ON THE CONTRARY, IT WOULD PROVIDE USEFUL PUBLICITY HERE AND ENSURE THE KIND OF PARTICIPATION THAT WE WANT. I WOULD IMAGINE THAT SUCH A GROUP WOULD BE CHAIRED BY THE UNDER-SECRETARY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS, MARCELO OSTRIA, AND COMPOSED OF SENIOR MEMBERS OF THE ARMED FORCES, FORMER FOREIGN MINISTERS SUCH AS ALBERTO CRESPO AND OTHER EXPERTS DRAWN FROM THE GROUPS MENTIONED ABOVE.
CERTAINLY THE GOB WOULD WISH TO TALK ABOUT ITS PROBLEM OF LACK OF ADEQUATE ACCESS TO THE SEA AND THE CURRENT TENSIONS BETWEEN CHILE AND PERU WHICH MIGHT BEAR ON THIS PROBLEM. ANOTHER THEME OF INTEREST TO BOTH SIDES IS OUR STOCKPILE POLICY ON STRATEGIC ITEMS AND HOW BOLIVIA CAN COOPERATE IN THAT POLICY. BOLIVIA OF COURSE WOULD WISH TO DISCUSS CUBA POLICY, AND WOULD BE RECEPTIVE TO DISCUSSING WAYS TO UNDERCUT STEAMROLLER TACTICS BY THE LDC’S IN INTERNATIONAL FORA. AS THE DEPARTMENT KNOWS, BOLIVIA CONTINUES VIGOROUSLY TO OPPOSE THE RE-ENTRY OF CUBA INTO THE OAS AND TAKES VERY SERIOUSLY OUR PLEDGE TO CONSULT WITH OAS MEMBERS BEFORE WE CHANGE OUR CURRENT CUBA POLICY. WE COULD USE THE

032232Z
OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN MORE ABOUT THE FOREIGN PLICY OF BRAZIL, ARGENTINA AND VENEZUELA AS SEEN THROUGH BOLIVIAN EYES.

I BELIEVE IT WOULD BE PRUDENT, AT LEAST IN THE EARLY STAGES OF THESE CONSULTATIONS, TO STAGGER THE VISITS TO PERU, CHILE AND BOLIVIA SO THAT IT DOES NOT APPEAR THAT WE HAVE DECIDED TO TAKE AN ACTIVE PART IN SETTLING THE PROBLEMS INVOLVING THESE COUNTRIES. FOR THE DOMESTIC

POLITICAL REASONS MENTIONED ABOVE, IT WOULD BE PREFERABLE TO SCHEDULE THE VISIT TO BOLIVIA EARLIER RATHER THAN LATER.

PLEASE ADVISE. STEDMAN

title: Padilla Passes The Baton To Guevara Who Promises Government Of National Conciliation
text:
Date:
          August 08, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Niact Immediate 7642
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ads-00 Ciae-00 Pm-05 H-01 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Pa-01 Sp-02 Ss-15 Ha-05 Aid-05 Trse-00 Eb-08 Omb-01 Sph-01 Io-14 Nsce-00 Sso-00 Icae-00 Inre-00 /087 W ——————123774 082206z /73
        
                    
          Subject:
          Padilla Passes The Baton To Guevara Who Promises Government Of National Conciliation
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: In a simple, moving ceremony Walter Guevara Arze took the oath of office as interim president of Bolivia at 1pm on August 8, and was promptly given a bear hug by outgoing President General David Padilla – the emotional centerpiece of the ceremony. Padilla’s receding speech stressed that he and the armed forces had now done exactly what they promised to do – restore Bolivia to constitutional rule. Guevara promised a government of national conciliation, but regretted that apparently not all groups would participate in his yet-to-be formed cabinet. His major tasks, Guevara said, will be confronting Bolivia’s economic crisis and reforming the electoral laws to provide for a second round popular vote in the May 1980 elections. This modest inauguration and its indications of the pragmatic evolution of Bolivia’s young democracy are most encouraging for U.S. interests. End summary.

Interim president Guevara’s inauguration address was short and conciliatory. He noted that his government emerged from exceptional circumstances, a deadlocked indirect election, and commended the flexibility and maturity of the major party leaders in resolving an impasse that in other eras of Bolivian history would have ended in violence.


His political task, Guevara said, was to avoid confrontations and violent solutions. His government should therefore be a symbol of national consensus, and his central task would be to consolidate the constitutional process already in train and to resolve some of the political and administrative problems that have been postponed. In that regard he enlisted the support of all sectors – the parties, the armed forces and the unions – and emphasized their right to speak out and propose their own ideas in participating in the resolution of Bolivia’s problems. He proposed to reform the electoral system to create an independent electoral authority, to install a modern system to tabulate promptly the results of the popular vote and to provide a second round popular vote if necessary to assure that a candidate gets a majority of the popular vote.


Guevara called for unity and strength within the armed forces to reinforce the constitutionalization process. He paid special tribute to Padilla, noting that the latter’s place in Bolivian history had been firmly established, a reference which invoked a strong round of applause.


Of foreign policy, Guevara stated that an effort would be made to resolve the sea outlet problem. Formulas would be developed and submitted to a national consensus. At the same time, Bolivia would maintain a policy of openness in its external relations, emphasizing states and not ideologies. He reaffirmed his country’s primary objective of maintaining good relations with its immediate neighbors.


Guevara said his government would examine and attack the causes of Bolivia’s economic crisis rather than symptoms. He alluded to the tremendous size of the country’s external debt, and lowered production of petroleum and minerals, as well as the crisis in the modern agricultural sector. But he noted that a transitory government could not resolve all the problems. He would propose medium and long term programs to resolve the problems, but emphasized that it was not up to the government alone to tackle them, but everyone’s task. He exhorted the Congress, political alliances and fronts, and leaders of all sectors to bring their influence to bear on helping make the right decisions to resolve these problems.


Guevara did imply some specific actions in discussing the great deficit in the country’s balance of payments. He said “almost immediate action” was needed to reduce this deficit. He also implied that he would seek renegotiation of Bolivia’s external debt, which he termed unsupportable. Guevara also said petroleum product prices have to reflect costs.


In concluding, Guevara said his purposes must be to get Bolivia moving again and build a bridge between the past and the future.

          TAGS:

          Ref:
          (A) STATE 207984 310241Z AUG 77 (B) STATE 252478 DTD 211400Z OCT 77 (C) STATE 47743 DTD 240237Z FEB 78 (D) LA PAZ 5726
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

The Bolivia Air Force (BAF) has requested a letter of offer and acceptance for the following air defense weapons system and related support items:

10 F-5E aircraft
2 F-5B’s
Spare parts for 2 years
Related ground support equipment
Related pilot and aircraft mechanic training in the USA
Related technical assistance in Bolivia
Related appropriate air defense munitions

The following responses are keyed to Para 5E, Reference A.

A. The BAF has no viable air defense capability. The BAF defensive air order of battle includes eight very old and marginally armed and maintained F-86 aircraft of which possibly 4 could be launched simultaneously and thirteen even older T-33 and TF-33 aircraft, of which 6 or 7 could be launched simultaneously. It is estimated that only 50 percent of these aircraft could be turned to a second sortie. The BAF clearly and seriously recognizes its primary mission to defend, in conjunction with the other Bolivian Armed Forces, the territorial sovereignty of Bolivia. At the same time, the BAF, and all of Bolivia’s neighbors (except perhaps Paraguay), realize that the BAF does not possess a deterrent defensive capability. The regional and sub-regional tensions stemming from historical and contemporary territorial disputes provide the BAF a bona fide requirement to purchase a limited number of modern fighter aircraft. The BAF (and also the other armed forces) believe that the possibility of conflict within the region is real. This view is held not only by the high command, but also the company and field grade officers. The GOB has not expended funds to modernize the BAF fighter fleet since the modest acquisition of the Korean War vintage F-86 aircraft from Venezuela in the early 1970’s. Further, the impending withdrawal of the armed forces from direct involvement in the government, with the avowed purpose of returning to the barracks, has placed very heavy internal pressures on the BAF leaders to initiate a token (albeit costly) modernization program. Bolivian leaders cannot ignore or discount such pressures in light of the imminent return to non-military government, nor should we. In addition to the F-5, BAF acquisition studies are known to include consideration of Mirage and Jaguar aircraft.
B. Acquisition of the F-5 aircraft would permit the BAF to organize and train a modest air defense force. While the effectiveness of such a force is debatable in light of the overwhelming materiel superiority of Bolivia’s neighbors (excepting Paraguay), it would provide Bolivia with a marginal air defense capability. The provision of F-5 aircraft to Bolivia would not exacerbate the arms imbalance of the region. In fact, it would serve to reduce the present imbalance. Neither would such an acquisition serve to introduce for the first time this weapon system to South America.
C. The BAF, with appropriate training, should be able to employ and maintain the F-5 system. We estimate that two or three civilian technical representatives would be required for the first 2 years after acquisition. This would enable the BAF to initially maintain and subsequently develop a satisfactory maintenance capability. The BAF has pilots who, with normal familiarization training in CONUS, would be fully qualified to pilot the F-5.
D. GOB has requested USG financing or sale approval with subsequent commercial financing. The BAF desires the most reasonable interest rates possible with a 2 year grace period followed by an extended repayment schedule (15 to 20 years total). The BAF Command expressed verbally, in conversations with US Ambassador Boeker and members of this MILGP, that the repayment of such loans would come from the normal BAF yearly budget, supplemented if and as necessary by income derived from commercial utilization of the BAF fleet of C-130s and F-27s.
E. We believe Bolivia will attempt to finance such a purchase through some medium term borrowing arrangement from commercial sources. Repayments, not to begin before 1981, which, if the case, would postpone any immediate impact upon the Bolivian economy. Amortization would derive from the regular Air Force budget which BAF sources indicate will not require any appreciable increase because of inter alia increased revenues from their air cargo service. Moreover, if Bolivia is determined to go through with this Air Force upgrading, purchase of the F-5’s would constitute a burden of considerably less dimension than would purchase of known alternative aircraft (i.e., a purchase of $75-100 as opposed to approximately $200 million).

text:
Date:

          Interim President Lidia Gueiler
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, PINS, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Lidia Gueiler Tejada, chosen by the Congress to serve as Bolivia’s interim president until Aug 6, 1980, is, by her own account, “not a great intellectual,” but rather a “revolutionary woman” guided by the experience of “30 years of struggle.” Although she previously served as president of the Chamber of Deputies (and as acting chairperson of the bicameral Congress), Ms. Gueiler is not a very well known politician. Her roots are in the Nationalist Revolutionary Movement (MNR), which she joined when it began to gather force in 1946. Regarded for many years as “leftist” and labor-oriented, she split from the mainstream MNR before the 1960 general elections to help Juan Lechin form the Revolutionary Party of the National Left (PRIN). In early 1978, she veered away from Lechin to found her own PRIN faction. In 1979, she and her small band of followers became affiliated with Victor Paz Estenssoro’s MNR alliance. Her subsequent emergence as president of the lower house–a circumstance that led to her being selected Chief of State on Nov 16–was more attributable to Paz’ machinations than to any of her own.
A secretary and accountant by training, Gueiler early achieved recognition through her willingness to adopt and defend labor and far left political positions. At the same time, however, she is not widely regarded as an ideologue or dogmatist–particularly since assuming the chairmanship of the Congress. Perhaps of interest in this regard, she recently told an EMBOFF that she had come to realize that contentious social and economic issues take on more complex dimensions when one is in a position of responsibility. Her leadership in Congress has been steady, at times courageous, but never brilliant. Some of her critics maintain that she is “controlled” by Victor Paz; others that she is guided by Beijing-line Communist leader Oscar Zamora, with whom, in a non-doctrinaire fashion, she has been politically associated in the past. Given the heavy influx of MNR Alliance figures into her cabinet, the Embassy’s assumption at this juncture is that Paz’ influence will be greatest. But Ms. Gueiler is a strong-willed woman, and, insofar as she feels within her depth, she will probably try to plot her own course.
More checkered is Ms. Gueiler’s personal history, which, inevitably, has been distorted by rumor and deliberate slander. In the early 1960’s, for example, while serving as Bolivia’s Charge d’Affaires in Bonn, she reportedly was declared non grata, perhaps for trying to propagate her political views or for engaging in contraband. Twice divorced, she married her first husband, a Paraguayan surnamed Perez, when he was being held prisoner in Cochabamba during the Chaco War. Her second husband, Edwin Moeller, currently heads up a rival PRIN faction which was affiliated with Hernan Siles’ UDP in the last elections. Prior, between and after her marriages, Ms. Gueiler is widely rumored to have engaged in liaisons with a number of prominent political figures. While these stories may not be true, they have conferred on her a “racy” reputation which her appearance would otherwise belie. According to biographic data now circulating in La Paz, she was born on Aug 28, 1926. We estimate that this date is about ten years off. She has at least one daughter, Maria Teresa Perez Gueiler, about 45, and a grandson studying at a university in Florida.
In addition to some of the above information, Ms. Gueiler’s curriculum vitae lists these accomplishments: –Primary and commercial studies in Cochabamba at the Instituto Americano (degree in accounting). –Languages: Quechua, German (fair) and English (fair). –Joined MNR in 1946. –Subsecretary of Ministry of Peasant Affairs. –Twice Lower House deputy. –Charge d’Affaires in Bonn. –Chief of departmental “command” (Cochabamba) of MNR. –Chief of national command of MNR. –Author of book entitled “Women and Revolution.” –Candidate for Vice President of the Republic. –Vice President of the Leftist Revolutionary Front (FRI). –Invited to visit Albania and the People’s Republic of China as representative of the Bolivian Woman’s Union. –President of the Chamber of Deputies. –President of the Congress. –Interim President of Bolivia.

title: Spanish Version Of A Speec On The Andes Pact
text:
Date:
          March 28, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz

          Oct-01 Iso-00 Pa-01 Inr-01 /005 W ——————— 127913 R 281823z Mar 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Spanish Version Of A Speec On The Andes Pact
        
                    
          TAGS:
          SCUL, XM, ANDES PACT
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED
La Paz.- Con el propósito de acelerar la integración educativa, cultural y científica en el área que comprende el Pacto Andino, ayer (miércoles 27) fueron inauguradas las labores de la Quinta Reunión de Ministros de Educación de la Subregión Andina y en la que también participan representantes especiales de la OEA, UNESCO, BID y otras entidades internacionales.
En la ceremonia de inauguración, el Ministro de Educación de Bolivia, Doctor Mario Serrate Ruiz, afirmó que el Convenio “Andrés Bello”, como elemento complementario de los organismos de integración del Pacto Andino, “está obligado a coadyuvar en la solución de los problemas de recursos humanos del área, incorporando a la inmensa mayoría de marginados al proceso de desarrollo, por los beneficios de la educación.”
Luego, el Ministro de Educación del Perú, General Alfredo Carpio Becerra, en representación de las misiones participantes, hizo resaltar la necesidad de “emplear todos nuestros recursos para realizar un pleno desarrollo económico, social y cultural”. “Por eso - agregó - el Gobierno Revolucionario del Perú considera que no debe distraerse o malgastarse el dinero del pueblo en una carrera armamentista en la que solo pueden estar interesados y salir gananciosos los mercaderes de la guerra”.
Finalmente, el Presidente de Bolivia, General Hugo Banzer Suárez, abogó por la urgencia de modificar los sistemas de educación “a fin de preparar mejor y más rápidamente a los jóvenes que pugnan por aportar sus energías y su capacidad creadora a la tarea común de acelerar el progreso de nuestros pueblos”.
Después de la ceremonia de inauguración, los Ministros de Colombia, Chile, Ecuador, Perú, Venezuela y Bolivia y sus delegaciones iniciaron sus deliberaciones sobre un amplio temario, las mismas que se prolongarán hasta mañana viernes.
Morton

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

SUMMARY: SINCE THE REOPENING OF THE UNIVERSITIES IN 1972, PERSISTENT CRITICISM HAS BEEN VOICED OF THE LARGE BUREAURACY CREATED BY THE NEW FUNDAMENTAL LAW OF THE BOLVIAN UNIVERSITY, THE INCREASED ROLE OF POLITICAL PARTIES IN THE UNVERSITY AND THE FAILURE TO HOLD ELECTIONS FOR STUDENT LEADERS. THESE DIS- SATISFACTIONS, SHARED BY STUDENTS, PROFESSORS AND MANY OUTSIDE OBSERVERS OF THE UNIVERSITY SCENE, WERE CRYSTALLIZED BY THE RESIGNATION MAY 9 OF THE RECTOR OF SAN ANDRES UNIVERSITY IN LA PAZ. SUBSEQUENTLY, A CHAIN REACTION F APPOINTMENTS TO AND RESIGNATIONS FROM THE RECTORSHIP, COUPLED WITH STUDENT PROTEST MEETINGS, LED TO THE CLOSING OF THE COUNTRY’S LARGEST UNIVERSITY ON MAY 21. ALTHOUGH SAN ANDRES UNIVERSITY IS NOW SCHEDULED TO REOPEN ON JUNE 3, THE POWER STRUGGLE BETWEEN COMPETING POLITICAL FACTIONS WITHIN THE UNIVERSIT SYSTEM HAS ONLY JUST BEGUN, AND IS LIKELY TO INTENSIFY OVER THE NEXT FEW MONTHS. END SUMMARY.
THE SURFACE CALM IN BOLIVIA’S UNIVERSITIES OVER THE PAST

01 OF 02 311516Z
TWO YEARS HAS HIDDEN A GROWING MEASURE OF DISCONTENT WITH
SOME OF THE CHANGES IN THE UNIVERSITY SYSTEM WHICH WERE BROUGHT ABOUT BY THE 1972 FUNDAMENTAL LAW OF THE BOLIVIAN UNIVERSITY. THIS LAW RESTRICTED UNIVERSITY AUTONOMY TO THE REALM OF ADMINISTRATIVE AND ACADEMIC AFFAIRS, WHILE CREATING A NEW NATIONAL COUNCIL OF HIGHER EDUCATION (CNES) TO OVERSEE THE OPERATION OF THE NATION’S NINE UNIVERSITIES. OTHER ASPECTS OF THE POST-1971 UNIVERSITY SCENE WHICH HAVE BRED DISSATIS- FACTION AMONG STUDENTS, PROFESSORS AND MANY OUTSIDE OBSERVERS INCLUDE THE INCREASED ROLE OF POLITICAL PARTIES IN THE UNIVER- SITIES, A RAPID GROWTH IN THE NUMBER OF SUPERNUMERARIES OCCUPYING ADMINISTRATIVE POSTS WITHIN THE UNIVERSITY SYSTEM AND THE FAILURE TO HOLD ELECTIONS FOR STUDENT LEADERS.

THE RESIGNATION OF RECTOR FELIPE HARTMANN OF SAN ANDRES UNIVERSITY (UMSA) IN LA PAZ ON MAY 9, FOLLOWING A SERIES OF CLASHES BETWEEN HARTMANN AND CNES OVER THE UNIVERSITY AUTONOMY ISSUE, CRYSTALLLIZED MUCH OF THE EXISTING DISCONTENT OVER THE FUNCTIONING OF THE BOLIVIAN UNIVERSITY SYSTEM. WITH HARTMANN’S REPLACEMENT BY VICE RECTOR MARIO AGUILAR, A MEMBER OF THE FALANGE PARTY, FSB MEMBERS WERE RAPIDLY NAMED TO A SERIES OF HIGH-LEVEL ADMINISTRATIVE POSTS WITHIN THE UNIVERSITY. THIS ATTEMPT TO GIVE A PARTISAN POLITICAL CAST TO THE NATION’S LARGEST UNIVERSITY PROVOKED A THREAT FROM THE MNR TO WITHDRAW ALL OF ITS ADMINISTRATIVE AND ACADEMIC PERSONNEL FROM UMSA. FOLLOWING A SERIES OF HURRIED POLITICAL CONSUL- TATIONS WITHIN THE GOVERNMENT, CHANGES IN THE COMPOSITION OF CNES WERE ANNOUNCED ON MAY 15-16 WHEREBY AGUILAR JOINED THAT BODY AND WAS REPLACED AS RECTOR OF UMSA BY COLONEL JOSE ZELAYA. ZELAYA, A PROFESSOR OF GEOGRAPHY AND ENGINEERING, THUS BECAME THE FIRST MILITARY OFFICER EVER TO HOLD THE POST OF RECTOR OF SAN ANDRES UNIVERSITY.
STUDENT REACTION TO THE APPOINTMENT OF A MILITARY OFFICER TO THIS POST WAS IMMEDIATE AND STRONGLY NEGATIVE. AT A PUBLIC MEETING CALLED BY THE STUDENT-ELECTED INTER-FACULTY COMMITTEE ON MAY 17, THE ASSEMBLED UMSA STUDENTS APPROVED RESOLUTIONS RE- JECTING BOTH ZELAYS AND CNES, AND DECLARED A 24-HOUR STRIKE. IN THE FACE OF STRONG OPPOSITION TO HIS NOMINATION, ZELAYA RE- SIGNED THE RECTORSHIP ON MAY 19, AND WAS REPLACED ON THE FOLLOWING DAY BY AGUILAR. STUDENT LEADERS NOW ATTEMPTED TO TAKE ADVANTAGE

01 OF 02 311516Z
OF THE CONFUSED ATMOSPHERE AT UMSA BY CALLING A MEETING ON MAY 21, AT WHICH THEY PLANNED TO DENOUNCE AGUILAR’S REAPPOINTMENT, CALL FOR THE ELECTION OF RECTORS BY STUDENTS AND PROFESSORS, AND APPROVE POLITICAL RESOLUTIONS IN FAVOR OF THE REOPENING OF THE COB AND DECLARING VISITING BRAZILIAN PRESIDENT GEISEL PERSONA NON GRATA. THIS MEETING WAS ABORTED BY A SQUAD OF FALANGE YOUTH, ARMED WITH TEAR GAS AND REVOLVERS, WHO CLEARED OUT THE SITE OF THE STUDENT ASSEMBLY IN A RAPID
COMMANDO-TYPE ACTION: SUBSEQUENT ATTEMPTS BY THE STUDENTS TO REASSEMBLE WERE DISPERSED BY THE POLICE. IN THE WAKE OF THESE EVENTS, INTER-FACULTY COMMITTEE LEADERS CALLED FOR A 48-HOUR STRIKE, AND WERE SUPPORTED BY SYMPATHY STRIKES AT THE CATHOLIC UNIVERSITY AND THE UNIVERSITIES OF COCHABAMBA AND SUCRE. ON THE SAME DATE, MAY21, THE RECTOR OF UMSA RE- SPONDED BY ANNOUNCING THE INDEFINITE CLOSURE OF SAN ANDRES UNVERSITY.

THE IMPORTANCE OF ACHIEVING A POLITICAL SETTLEMENT TO THE ONGOING UNIVERSITY CRISIS WAS IMPRESSED UPON THE GOVERNMENT BY THE INVOLVEMENT OF NEW GROUPS IN THE CRISIS IN SUCCEEDING DAYS. ON THE DAY OF THE UNIVERSITY’S CLOSURE, THE ARMED FORCES ISSUED A JOINT STATEMENT SUPPORTING COLONEL ZELAYA’S ACTIONS AND CALLING UPON ALL PARTIES TO THE DISPUTE TO REFLECT UPON THE NEGATIVE CONSEQUENCES OF THEIR ACTS: IN PARTICULAR, THE DOCU- MENT MADE CLEAR THE “FIRM DECISION” OF THE MILITARY INSTITUTION TO “CAUSE THE ESTABLISHED ORDER AND SUBMISSION TO THE PRINCIPLES OF AUTHORITY AND DISCIPLINE TO BE RESPECTED.” STATEMENTS BY GROUPS OF PROFESSORS AND PARENTS OF UNIVERSITY STUDENTS CALLING FOR THE REOPENING OF THE UNIVERSITY WERE SUPPORTED ON MAY 27 BY A COMBINED DECLARATIONOF SUCH KEY UNIONS AS THE MINERS, BREWIN

title: Conversation Between Walter Guevara Arze And Assistant Secretary Vaky
text:
Date:
          December 14, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          SecState WashDC
        
                    
          To:
          AmEmbassy La Paz Priority
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-00 Ads-00 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Pm-05 H-01 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Nsc-05 Pa-01 Sp-02 Ss-15 Ica-11 Aid-05 Pc-01 Eb-08 Come-00 Trse-00 /082 R
        
                    
          Subject:
          Conversation Between Walter Guevara Arze And Assistant Secretary Vaky
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Walter Guevara Arze, accompanied by his son and Bolivian Ambassador Roberto Arce, called on Assistant Secretary Vaky and ARA/And Director Barnebey on December 11.
Guevara offered his observations on the following items: A. Stabilization Measures – There has been a strong reaction to the measures as they were originally announced. Paz has the votes necessary to avoid a congressional censure of the government, and Gueiler’s personal relationship with Juan Lechin will help in overcoming resistance to the decrees. There was greater opposition, however, on the part of the peasants and transport workers because food prices had remained frozen and gasoline was much more expensive. Guevara thought Gueiler would agree to some adjustment of food prices which would satisfy the peasants. B. The military, the real power in Bolivia, remain in their headquarters in Miraflores. The same people who supported Natusch are still in command and believe the real enemy of Bolivia is the Bolivian people. Democracy and the current military structure in Bolivia are incompatible because too many officers see themselves as having to guide the country (“tutelar de la patria”). Guevara also said that President Gueiler will have no influence over the December promotion, retirement and transfer list. C. Elections – It would have been better to tackle only economic problems during 1980, and leave elections for 1981. There is a danger that Paz will attempt to take advantage of his influence over the government for electoral purposes. Assuming Siles and Banzer will both be candidates, the 1980 elections will be a replay of those of 1979. The fact that the elections will not be general poses a problem because the terms of office for the president and vice president will no longer coincide with that of the Congress.
Assistant Secretary Vaky observed that the failure of the Natusch coup will have a beneficial effect internationally, including on the Peruvians. He also said that what is happening in Bolivia is of great interest to the international community, especially with regard to the stabilization measures. He hoped this point could be conveyed to political party figures in La Paz.

text:
Date:

          Oct-01 Iso-00 Sab-01 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Pm-07 H-03 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Nsc-07 Pa-04 Rsc-01 Prs-01 Sp-03 Ss-20 Usia-15 Aid-20 Eb-11 Ciep-02 Trse-00 Str-08 Omb-01 Cea-02 Come-00 Frb-02 Xmb-07 Opic-12 Lab-06 Sil-01 Agr-20 Swf-02 Tar-02 Io-14 Cg-00 Dote-00 Drc-01 /207 W ——————— 068220 R 022111z Apr 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Bolivian Views On Proposed Panama Canal Toll Increase
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PFOR, PN, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          LA PAZ 1831, STATE 58007
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

The Foreign Ministry has now responded to the Embassy’s note of March 25, concerning a proposal by the Panama Canal Company to increase tolls by twenty percent. Following is the text of the Foreign Ministry’s comments on the proposed toll increase.
Quote: The Government of Bolivia would view with concern any increase in canal tolls and is opposed to any new charge for the following reasons:

Bolivia, because of its land-locked situation, bears the burden of a surcharge of more than ten percent on its foreign trade. This fact diminishes the competitiveness of its exports.
Likewise, should the proposed toll increase take place, Bolivia would have to support an increase in the prices of its mineral and agricultural exports, the latter of which are at present starting to diversify Bolivia’s export situation. In the same manner, it would suffer damage to its import capability, in such areas as mining machinery, smelting equipment, agricultural and industrial machinery, etc. Therefore, in case an increase takes place, it is undeniable that Bolivia would suffer severely from both the direct and indirect effects of this measure. It should be emphasized that most of Bolivian foreign trade passes through the Panama Canal.

Past experience teaches us that additional transportation charges give rise to adverse cumulative effects influencing the general level of internal prices for commodities and services.
Likewise, it should be taken into account that Bolivia has been classified with the group of nations of least economic development, and for this reason, as well as because of its transitory land-locked status, it should receive preferential treatment.
Consequently, the Government of Bolivia supports fully the resolution approved by the Special Committee for Consultation and Negotiation (CECON) which states that an increase in canal tolls would adversely affect “some import sectors” of the economies of the developing countries in Latin America, especially those which, because of their geographic situation, are users of the Canal. End quote.

SO FAR AS WE ARE AWARE, THE CURRENT GOVERNMENT HAS NO INTEREST IN BUYING THE COMPANY. text:
Date:

          (A) STATE 271747, (B) LA PAZ 8767
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

In lieu of a press conference or departure statement, we suggest a press release at the time of the Secretary’s departure from La Paz Wednesday, October 24. We have used this technique before, e.g. for Under Secretary Newsom’s visit, and found it gets excellent coverage from local press.
Needless to say, substance, e.g. on tin, will have to be adjusted in the course of the Secretary’s visit, but we submit the following so the Secretary can consider the type of release we propose.
Begin draft press release

The American Secretary of State Cyrus Vance, accompanied by Mrs. Vance, departed early Wednesday morning, October 24, after spending three days in La Paz as head of his country’s delegation to the General Assembly of the Organization of American States. In the course of his visit to Bolivia, the Secretary conferred with President Walter Guevara Arze and Minister of Foreign Affairs Gustavo Fernandez, who also hosted a dinner Sunday evening for Secretary Vance and Foreign Ministers of Andean Pact countries attending the OAS General Assembly.
The American Secretary of State also had the opportunity to talk to a number of foreign ministers attending the General Assembly to discuss matters of mutual interest.
The Secretary noted his great satisfaction at having had the opportunity to visit Bolivia for the first time and to get to know the leaders of its constitutional government. He also expressed his pleasure in meeting some of the leading figures of Bolivia’s armed forces who had successfully overseen the transition to elected, civilian rule. The Secretary indicated that he, like Bolivia’s other friends in the hemisphere, was impressed with the openness and viality of free political debate here and with the admirable respect for human rights in the current Bolivian scene.
The presence of the Foreign Ministers of the Americas in La Paz for the OAS Assembly was already, the Secretary felt, a reflection of the prestige Bolivia has gained. “Your return to constitutional rule has placed this country in the historical tide that is affecting the entire Andean Community and has lent enhanced political and moral force to its voice in many forums,” he said.
The Secretary noted that he had “long desired this opportunity to visit Bolivia and to meet with those whose contributions to Bolivian life he had followed from afar. Americans know Bolivians as a proud people, he said, whose heritage goes back to one of the great civilizations of the past and whose efforts in the last century kindled the movement for independence in Latin America. The Secretary observed that Bolivia had just accomplished the essence of democracy through free elections, selecting its leaders according to its own constitutional process.”
In his meeting with President Walter Guevara Arze, Secretary Vance assured him that the U.S. would fully meet its obligations under the International Tin Agreement and that disposals of surplus U.S. tin stocks will only be carried out in the closest coordination with your (the Bolivian) government, with those of other tin exporters and with the International Tin Council. Secretary Vance noted that any sales would be gradual, over at least a three-year period, to avoid disruption of the tin market.
Secretary Vance underlined U.S. support for a resolution of Bolivia’s aspirations for access to the sea on a basis acceptable to the countries directly involved in the region.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM

Following is Spanish text of Bolivia access to the sea as approved by the General Committee.

“Acceso de Bolivia al Oceano Pacifico
(Proyecto de resolución aprobado por la Comisión General en su segunda sesión celebrada el 26 de octubre de 1979 y revisado por la Comisión de Estilo)
La Asamblea General,
Declara:

Que es de interés hemisférico permanente encontrar una solución equitativa mediante la cual Bolivia obtenga acceso soberano y útil al Oceano Pacifico, y
Que para lograr el objetivo señalado en el punto anterior y consolidar una paz estable que estimule el progreso económico y social en el área de América directamente afectada por las consecuencias del enclaustramiento de Bolivia, el noveno periodo ordinario de sesiones de la Asamblea General de la Organización de los Estados Americanos, con espíritu de fraternidad e integración americana,

Resuelve:

Recomendar a los estados a los que este problema concierne más inmediatamente, que inicien negociaciones encaminadas a dar a Bolivia una conexión territorial libre y soberana con el Oceano Pacifico. Tales negociaciones deberán tomar en cuenta los derechos e intereses de las partes involucradas y podrían considerar, entre otros elementos, la inclusión de una zona portuaria de desarrollo multinacional integrado, y así mismo tener en cuenta el planteamiento boliviano de no incluir compensaciones territoriales.”
