title: 1979 Bolivia Human Rights Report
text:
Date:
          December 26, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          SecState WashDC
        
                    
          To:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-00 Ads-00 Ha-05 /020 R
        
                    
          Subject:
          1979 Bolivia Human Rights Report
        
                    
          TAGS:
          SHUM, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED
Bolivia’s past political instability has been an impediment to economic and social progress and, therefore, at least partially responsible for the country’s uneven record in terms of human rights observance. In 1977 then President Banzer initiated a liberalization of virtually all major restrictions on human rights, releasing all reported political prisoners, allowing exiles to return, and scheduling elections for July 1978. This positive human rights momentum was not checked by the Pereda coup (August 1978) or the Padilla takeover (November 1978). While the first represented a brief interruption in the democratization process and the second was designed to put it back on track, both governments contributed to the improving human rights situation: General Pereda by abrogating the feared State Security Law, and General Padilla by overseeing in July 1979, possibly the most democratic elections in Bolivia’s history.
As none of the eight presidential hopefuls achieved the needed [majority] of the popular vote in the July 1979 elections, the issue went before the Congress where, similarly, none of the three leading candidates succeeded in obtaining [majority]. Finally, the Congress selected Senate President Walter Guevara Arze to serve as interim president with new elections scheduled for May 1980.
Guevara’s interim government came to an abrupt end November 1, 1979, when a group of military officers and civilians under the leadership of Army Colonel Alberto Natusch Busch seized the government. The Natusch government responded to strong popular reaction against the coup and its interruption of the democratic process with the implementation of press censorship, a state of siege, and martial law. Protesting but unarmed civilians were confronted by undisciplined soldiers resulting in the death of approximately 200 persons, the wounding of some 200 others, and the unaccounted for disappearance of about 125 citizens, many of whom are now presumed dead. Popular discontent, a seven-day strike by the Confederation of Bolivian Workers (COB), and Natusch’s repressive measures hastened the demise of his regime.
After Natusch’s resignation on November 16, an agreement was reached between the Congress, the COB, and the armed forces appointing Chamber of Deputies President Lidia Gueiler as interim president. President Guevara, who had become a resistance symbol in hiding during the Natusch regime, returned to his former Senate position. Ms. Gueiler is to be Bolivia’s interim president until the inauguration on August 6, 1980 of the winner of the 1980 elections, which will probably be held in June.

Respect for the Integrity of the Person, Including Freedom From:
A. Torture
The Bolivian constitution prohibits torture and other forms of cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment. The Padilla and Guevara administrations apparently respected this constitutional guarantee; there were no reports of torture during their brief governments – nor during the first weeks of President Gueiler’s administration. Allegations of torture during the short-lived Natusch regime remain unsubstantiated, but are currently being investigated by the Permanent Assembly on Human Rights (PAHR), Bolivia’s principal non-governmental organization promoting respect for human rights.
The Bolivian Congress also requested the PAHR on November 19 to document all cases of persons killed, wounded, or missing as a result of Natusch’s repressive measures. The findings are expected to be made public.
B. Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment
No reports of cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment were received during the Padilla or Guevara governments nor during the first weeks of the Gueiler government. There are unsubstantiated allegations of beatings of political and labor leaders detained during the Natusch regime.
Although the Bolivian constitution prohibits cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in all circumstances, PAHR representatives indicate that infractions occur. According to the PAHR, policemen sometimes beat persons accused of common crimes during interrogation to force confessions. Most such detainees do not file complaints, however, presumably either because they are unaware of their civil rights or because they fear reprisals. The PAHR believes that only a few police officials engage in such practices, and it is attempting to document cases of mistreatment so that offending policemen can be punished.
Most prisons in Bolivia are old and overcrowded. Sanitary conditions are poor, and prisoners’ diet is inadequate. These conditions result in part from Bolivia’s low level of economic development and associated poverty. Many prisoners, however, receive supplementary money, food, clothing and medicines from relatives or friends. Others manufacture smalls for outside contractors in exchange for money or food to supplement prison fare. Prisoners have no opportunity to become rehabilitated through learning job skills or improving their education while in prison. Prison officials recognize the problems in the present system, but indicate that lack of adequate funding precludes early improvement.
C. Arbitrary Arrest or Imprisonment
The Padilla, Guevara, and Gueiler governments have not imprisoned persons for their political beliefs or activity. During the Natusch coup before press censorship was imposed, newspapers and the radio reported the arrest of several labor leaders and politicians in various parts of the country. These people were held only briefly. Additional reports of similar short-term detentions appeared in the press after censorship was lifted. There have also been reports that as many as 125 people disappeared during this two-week period, the majority of whom are unaccounted for. There were no known political prisoners in Bolivia at the end of November, 1979.
Persons are frequently arrested and held for brief periods without charge in Bolivia. Occasionally, especially in serious criminal cases, a suspect is held longer than the 24 hours stipulated in the constitution before being brought before a judge. This is probably due more to procedural delays than any attempt by the police to deny justice. Habeas corpus exists and is respected in practice.
D. Denial of Fair Public Trial
Persons arrested in Bolivia are entitled by law to a fair public trial. However, the judicial process moves slowly, with some criminal cases taking years to complete because of inherent faults in the judicial system – antiquated procedures, shortage of qualified personnel, etc. Defendants may hire their own counsel, and may confer with them in private. Civil courts are independent of the military and civilians are not tried in military courts.
E. Invasion of the Home
The sanctity of the home is constitutionally protected. There were no reports of invasions of the home during either the Padilla or Guevara governments nor were there during the first weeks of the Gueiler government. During the Natusch coup, however, illegal searches were made of the houses of some persons opposed to his takeover – mainly labor leaders and politicians – for weapons and for members of the Guevara “government in hiding”.
Governmental Policies Relating to the Fulfillment of Such Vital Needs as Food, Shelter, Health Care and Education:
Bolivia remains an underdeveloped country. Nevertheless, despite recurring serious macroeconomic problems, the government of Bolivia has succeeded in significantly improving the quality of life for the majority of its citizens. Since 1975, successive governments implemented a five-year Economic and Social Development Plan emphasizing a rapid growth, export-oriented strategy. The Plan’s original goals included improving national income distribution (an OAS study indicates that 5 percent of the Bolivian population controls 31 percent of the national income), incorporating the rural (mostly Indian) population into the modern life of the country, and improving overall welfare through education, health, and agricultural programs. While Bolivia’s worsening economic situation prevented the fulfillment of major elements of the plan, World Bank figures showed that by 1979 per capita GNP had reached $630 in 1977 dollars, up from $352 in 1960. The Gueiler government in its first weeks implemented an economic stabilization program, which, if well carried out, can provide the basis for resuming soundly-based long-term economic growth.
Average life expectancy is 52 years. The nationwide annual death rate is estimated at 18.5 per thousand and the infant mortality rate for children under one year of age in rural areas is 235 per thousand. These figures are partially the results of communicable, respiratory, and gastrointestinal diseases and malnutrition among the population. The health problems persist largely because of inadequate financing and direction to improve the quality and distribution of health services. Of the rural population, 11.2 percent lives in areas which have adequate sewage disposal; 12 percent have access to potable water.
An estimated 40 percent of the Bolivian population over the age of 15 is illiterate. In an effort to overcome this problem the government provides a free public education system through the university level. Unfortunately, rural poverty forces many children to neglect their studies in favor of working to help support their families. Also, school sessions are often interrupted by labor strife or political activity.
The lack of adequate housing is a serious problem. The majority of housing units in the major cities are substandard. Rural families typically live in adobe dwellings without basic sanitary facilities. The poor environmental conditions accompanying such housing exacerbate problems of sanitation, nutrition and other impediments to health.
Government programs to fulfill basic human needs are hampered primarily by the lack of financial, human, and material resources. Although there have been occasional reports of corruption in the administration of some of these programs, it does not appear that corruption has been a major factor impeding their effective implementation.
Respect for Civil and Political Liberties, Including:
A. Freedom of Speech, Press, Religion and Assembly
Under the Padilla and Guevara governments, there were no reports of violations of any of these freedoms which are constitutionally guaranteed. Soon after assuming power, Colonel Natusch, however, imposed press censorship, a state of siege, curfew, and martial law. After a crippling seven-day general strike called by the COB, Natusch agreed to lift these measures in exchange for an end to the strike. The National Press Association (ANP), and the Vice President of the Bolivian Ecumenical Conference, among others, protested the press censorship and the silencing of several radio stations during the two-week military takeover. Before the Natusch coup, the press in Bolivia exercised a degree of “self-censorship”, ostensibly to avoid political controversy that could jeopardize the democratization process.
Freedom of speech, the press, and assembly were restored by the Gueiler government. There are no restrictions on religious freedom.
B. Freedom of Movement Within the Country, Foreign Travel and Emigration
Freedom of movement, travel, and emigration is constitutionally protected although as a vestige of the MNR days of the 1950s Bolivians outside the country must apply at a Bolivian consulate for a visa to enter their own country. Only under the two-week Natusch regime were there any new restrictions on travel and these were eliminated when President Gueiler took office.
C. Freedom to Participate in the Political Process
Political parties and labor unions have been able to operate freely since early 1978. In July 1979, eight political parties or coalitions participated in the general elections; none was the official party. Despite some allegations of electoral fraud by the contending parties and coalitions, it is generally accepted that the Electoral Court did its job well and that actual fraud in these elections was minor. All citizens 21 years of age and older may vote.
Traditionally, women have not enjoyed equal opportunity in Bolivia. However, this is changing. For example, before becoming interim president, Lidia Gueiler had been elected President of the Chamber of Deputies and awarded the Order of the Condor, Bolivia’s highest decoration, for her political activities. Two women presently serve in the Congress, and two in the cabinet. Indian women in both rural and urban areas continue to play a major role in the commercial sector and contribute substantially to family incomes.
Labor unions exercise considerable power in Bolivian society, as evidenced by the general strike in early November, 1979 which contributed to the demise of the Natusch regime. Trade unions profess to maintain neutrality among political parties. Individual union members, however, often actively participate in partisan political activities.
Government Attitude and Record Regarding International and Non-Governmental Investigation of Alleged Violations of Human Rights:
The Permanent Assembly on Human Rights (PAHR) is Bolivia’s principal non-governmental organization promoting respect for human rights. It maintains close contact with other international human rights organizations, whose members often travel to Bolivia for consultations on the state of human rights. The PAHR is working for the ratification of UN human rights agreements to which Bolivia is not yet a party.
Bolivia is the only Latin American country whose parliament has a human rights committee in each house. As part of its effort to improve human rights observance, Bolivia became a party to the American Convention on Human Rights in 1979.

Embassy has previous projected Bolivia’s 1979 tin exports at approximately 30,000 metric tons with the caveat that serious political problems or possible civil strife connected with the upcoming elections could invalidate our estimate. (Bolivia’s 1978 exports of tin were 29,696 MT’s worth approximately US$335.76 million.)
However, based on an apparent moderate slowdown in tin production which is now being noted, we now project that this year’s exports will be closer to 28,500 MT’s. Again, the caveat cited in Para one applies to this estimate also. (If exports simply maintained the pace of the first trimester, exports would reach only about 26,000 MT’s. We believe, however, that this rate will pick-up somewhat.)
In spite of the projected fall in tin production, expected higher prices for Bolivia’s other metallic minerals exports (principally silver, tungsten, lead and zinc) are expected to provide Bolivia with total 1979 export earnings of approximately $527 million (CIF value), 3.1 percent higher than the total achieved last year.
Embassy’s projections have been shared informally with IMF officials in La Paz. Although the IMF’s own estimates of physical volumes closely parallel ours, the fund’s higher price for tin gives a more optimistic bottom line.

          Subject:
          Recent Developments In Bolivia’s Quest For An Access To The Sea. Panama For Uscincso
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, PFOR, BL, CI, PE
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: President Banzer’s mid-March interview with Chilean President Pinochet in Brasilia, where both men were attending the inauguration of Brazilian President Ernesto Geisel, set off a wave of speculative commentary in Bolivia on prospects for realizing the country’s long-standing desire to regain an access to the sea. Banzer himself did much to stimulate this renewed upsurge of interest in the historic Bolivian obsession with “returning to the sea” by his optimistic appraisals of the outcome of his talks with Pinochet. Although the Banzer-Pinochet meeting coincided with the beginning of Bolivia’s annual “Week of the Sea” celebrations, most Bolivian political observers displayed a new willingness, in the wake of the talks, to put aside patriotic rhetoric in favor of a pragmatic search for possible grounds of agreement with its Pacific coast neighbors. At the same time, however, politicians and government officials alike realized the enormous difficulties facing Bolivia in its efforts to convince Chile and/or Peru to grant it renewed direct access to the sea. The major point upon which both the majority of political observers and the government of Bolivia itself appeared to be in agreement was the necessity for Bolivia to abstain from self-defeating threats of violence, much less actual recourse to physical force, in favor of peaceful, diplomatic initiatives toward resolving the country’s century-old landlocked status.
The principal theme of political discussion in Bolivia during March 1974 was the renewed prospect for movement on Bolivia’s desire for an access to the sea, opened up by the Banzer-Pinochet meeting in Brasilia at mid-month. Even before the two presidents held their widely-publicized “secret” meeting, political observers in La Paz were engaging in intensive speculation about the possibility that such an encounter could produce an improvement in Bolivian-Chilean relations. President Banzer himself lent credence to such speculation upon his return March 19 from the inauguration of President Geisel. According to press accounts, Banzer’s initial comments upon his interview with President Pinochet were as follows: Quote “President Pinochet has expressed to me his willingness to seek a solution to the fundamental problems (between Bolivia and Chile), considering that the fundamental problem of Bolivia is its maritime reintegration. He has demonstrated his good will, and let us hope that in a not too distant future we can take positive steps toward the solution of this problem.” Quote. Subsequently, in the face of Pinochet’s statement that the two presidents had agreed not to discuss Bolivia’s desire for a sea outlet, Banzer retreated to the position that he and Pinochet had quote “discussed the fundamental problems that have interrupted our relations (since 1962)” quote but that no specific discussion of possible solutions to Bolivia’s landlocked status had taken place.
Although the Banzer-Pinochet meeting coincided with the beginning of Bolivia’s annual “Week of the Sea”, commemorating the loss of its seacoast to Chile in 1879, the tone of the president’s remarks appears to have influenced government officials and most political commentators to reduce traditional patriotic rhetoric in favor of a pragmatic search for possible grounds of agreement with Bolivia’s Pacific coast neighbors. Thus Jaime Ponce Caballero, secretary-general of the government’s Nationalist Popular Front, called upon public opinion to put aside “demagogic slogans” and support the president’s quest for improved relations with Chile. A considerable majority of Bolivian journalistic and political opinion also appeared to approve of the initial Banzer-Pinochet conversation, and expressed the hope that working-level talks could soon be initiated between the two countries.
While discussion of the prospects for improved Bolivian-Chilean relations predominated in political circles, a number of observers also considered the problem of Bolivia’s desire for an outlet to the sea in the larger context of Bolivian-Chilean-Peruvian trilateral relations. Here an atmosphere of pessimism tended to prevail, despite spirited attempts by some commentators to raise the possibility of a summit conference of the three presidents, at which an accord might be reached to grant Bolivia a “corridor” to the sea. More typical of Bolivian views on the attitudes of its western neighbors was the comment of one politician that “Peru is willing to give us an outlet to the sea, through Antofagasta, and Chile will gladly grant us access to the sea through Tacna.”

title: Opic Insurance Operations In Bolivia
text:
Date:
          September 06, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 4149
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ara-16 Iso-00 Eb-11 Come-00 Aid-20 L-03 Ciae-00 Inr-11 Nsae-00 Agr-20 Int-08 /102 W ——————— 054922 R 061930z Sep 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Opic Insurance Operations In Bolivia
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EINV,BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          LA PAZ 1972: LA PAZ 5513
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

MANSBACH’S VISIT WAS USEFUL TO US AS IT PROVIDED US WITH OPIC’S CURRENT THINKING ON ITS OPERATIONS IN BOLIVIA AND SOME ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ON SPECIFIC CASES.
IN A CONVERSATION WITH AMB STEDMAN AND ECOM OFFICERS, MANSBACH INDICATED THAT OPIC CURRENTLY WAS INTERESTED MAINLY IN LOAN AND LOAN INSURANCE OPERATIONS, AND ESPECIALLY WAS LIMITING ITSELF TO THESE OPERATIONS IN THE CASE OF FIRMS EXPORTING 80 PERCENT OF THEIR PRODUCTION TO THE ANDEAN MARKET AND THEREFORE RAISING THE DECISION 24, ARTICLE 51 SUBROGATION PROBLEM. MANSBACH INDICATED OPIC LAWYERS WERE CONSIDERING SOMEHOW SEPARATING OPIC INSURANCE CONTRACTS AND THE NECESSARY FGA’S FROM THEPROVISIONS OF ART. 51, YET PRESER- VING SUBROGATION RIGHTS UNDER THE BILATERAL AGREEMENTS. THIS MIGHT BE BASED ON INTERPRETING ART. 51 TO REFER ONLY TO GOVERNMENT “INSTRUMENTS RELATING TO INVESTMENT” WHILE MAINTAINING THAT OPIC INVESTMENT INSURANCE CONTRACTS ARE NOT OR WILL NOT BE GOVERNMENT INSTRUMENTS.MANSBACH SAID THAT OPIC MIGHT HIRE A LOCAL LAWYER TO LOOK INTO SUCH POSSIBILITIES. WE BELIEVE THAT OPIC CANNOT HAVE IT BOTH WAYS. IF IT IS A PRIVATE INSURANCE COMPANY, THEN ITS RIGHTS SHOULD NOT BE SUBROGATED TO USG, EXCEPT PERHAPS BY THE PROCESSES OF STATE DEPT. ESPOUSAL OF PRIVATE CLAIMS. WE DOUBT,

062118Z
HOWEVER, THAT THE ANDEAN PACT COMMISSION OR GOB WILL AGREE THAT
ART. 51 REFERS ONLY TO GOVERNMENT INVESTMENT INSTRUMENTS IF THEY ARE AWARE THAT THE “PRIVATE” INSURER INTENDS TO AVAIL ITSELF OF THE BENEFITS OF A GOVERNMENT TO GOVERNMENT BILATERAL TREATY.

MANSBACH INDICATED THAT OPIC PLANS TO INSURE LOAN OR LOANS TO NEW JERSEY ZINC (NJZ), A SUBSIDIARY OF GULF AND WESTERN, PERHAPS SUPPLEMENTED BY A DIRECT OPIC LOAN AND DIRECT INVESTMENT INSURANCE IN CONCERT WITH A JAPANESE INVESTMENT IN THE MIXED COMPANY NJZ SEEKS TO FORM. WE RECALLED THAT IN LA PAZ 2284 WE WARNED THAT THE EMBASSY MIGHT RECOMMEND AGAINST INSURANCE FOR NJZ. WE STATD USG SHOULD HAVE BIAS AGAINST INSURING INVESTMENTS IN SENSITIVE MINING SECTOR AND THAT WE DID NOT HAVE SUFFICIENT INFO ON NJZ PLANS TO PROPERLY EVALUATE SITUATION. IT APPEARED TO US THAT NJZ HAD MADE ITS MOVES TO BUY GIBRALTAR HUARI-HUARI BEFORE IT COULD HAVE BEEN ASSURRED OF HAVING OPIC INSURANCE, ESPECIALLY IN VIEW OF THE PARA- GRAPH OPIC PUT IN ITS REGISTRATION NOTICE OF APRIL 2, 1974 WHICH PLACES NJZ PROJECT UNDER “LARGE AND SENSITIVE POLICY GUIDELINES” AND WARNS NJZ THAT ISSUES SHOULD BE DISCUSSED WITH OPIC AND RESOLVED BEFORE IT PROCEEDS TO INVEST OR COMMIT THE PREDOMINANT PART OF ITS PROPOSED INVESTMENT. WE REPORTED IN LA PAZ 1972 THAT NJZ HAD PAID IMPC/GIBRALTAR HUARI-HUARI DEBTS TO BANCO MINERO TOTALLING US$ 240,000 BEFORE MARCH 28, 1974. IT APPEARS THAT NJZ’S INTEREST WAS SO GREAT THAT IT MADE THIS PAYMENT ON OR BEFORE THE DATE OF ITS REQUEST FOR OPIC INSURANCE. REPORTEDLY NJZ ALREADY HAS INVESTED AT LEAST US$ 1.4 MILLION AND PERHAPS AS MUCH AS US$ 4.4 MILLION IN ITS GIBRALTAR HUARI-HUARI PROJECT. IT SEEMS LIKELY, THEREF ORE, THAT OPIC INSURANCE IS NOT ESSENTIAL TO NJZ DECISION TO GO AHEAD WITH THIS PROJECT.
IN RESPONSE TO THESE VIEWS, MANSBACH SAID “ADDITONALITY” NOT ALWAYS ESSENTIAL AND THAT OPIC NEEDS TO SPREAD ITS RISKS IN SOME CASES TO SOUND INVESTMENTS THAT MAY NOT BE “ADDITIONAL” DUE TO THE OPIC INSURANCE INCENTIVE. WE BELIEVE THAT BOLIVIAN MINING SECTOR IS ONE OF LAST PLACES OPIC SHOULD LOOK FOR DIVERSIFYING INTO SOUND INVESTMENTS. WE SUSPECT NJZ INVESTMENT WILL BE ECONOMICALLY SOUND, BUT POLITICALLY RISKY.
GULF AND WESTERN ALSO OWNS, THROUGH ITS SUBSIDIARY BROWN & CO., KELLGUANI MINE. TOGETHER WITH GIBALTAR HUARI-HUARI, GULF AND

062118Z
WESTERN COULD RAPIDLY BECOME BIGGEST AND MOST VISIBLE PRIVATE MINING INTEREST IN BOLIVIA.

MINOR POINT IS THAT IMPC/GIBRALTAR HUARI-HUARI HAS ALREADY INVESTED US$ 1.2 MILLION ORE MORE. OPIC WOULD HAVE TO BE QUITE CLEAR ON EXACLY WHAT IT WOULD BE COVERING.
GIVEN ALL THESE CONSIDERATIONS, WE BELIEVE IT IS IN USG

INTEREST TO OPPOSE OPIC INSURANCE FOR NJZ, AT LEAST UNTIL DETAILED INFORMATION MADE AVAILABLE TO EMBASSY. CAREFUL DECISION CAN THEN BE MADE ON BASIS SUCH INFORMATION.

MATTER OF INVESTMENTS IN AGRICULTURAL LAND WAS RAISED BY STATE 185136 DURING MANSBACH’S VISIT. AS EMBASSY HAD NOT RECEIVED RESPONSE TO EARLIER MESSAGES ON STOKES APPLICATION (AS WELL AS TO SOME OTHER APPLICATIONS), WE SENT LA PAZ 5513 OPPOSING INSURANCE FOR STOKES AT LEAST UNTIL ISSUES RESOLVED. EMBASSY CONSIDERS AGRICULTURAL LAND TO BE SECTOR AS SENSITIVE AS MINING IN VIEW LONG STANDING AGRARIAN REFORM POLICIES AND UNRESOLVED LAND INVESTMENT DISPUTE (APPLEGATE/ YOUNGUIST CASE). WHILE THIS GOVERNMENT HAS DONE NOTHING TO EXTEND REACH OF AGRARIAN REFORM, IT HAS ALLOWED COFADENA (MILITARY CORPORA- TION) TO TAKE OVER CAMPO LUMINOSA, ONE OF BOLIVIA’S LARGEST CATTLE RANCHES WHICH HAD OVERDUE DEBTS WITH BANCO DEL ESTADO. AS POPULATION PRESSURE MOUNTS IN SANTA CRUZ, CHAPARE BENI AND NORTHERN LA PAZ, WE EXPECT FURTHER EXTENSION AGRARIAN REFORM WILL BECOME BURNING POLITI- CAL ISSUE WHICH ALMOST ANY PROSPECTIVE GOVERNMENT LIKELY TO RESOLVE TO SOME EXTENT IN FAVOR OF BOLIVIAN SMALL FARMER AT EXPENSE OF LARGE FOREIGN FARMER. MOREOVER, AS WE HAVE NOTED PREVIOUSLY, LAND TITLE EVEN AMONG LARGE DEVELOPERS APPARENTLY MATTER OF CONTINUAL DISPUTE. MANSBACH ASKED EMBASSY TO CONSIDER MATTER CAREFULLY TO DECIDE WHETHER WE WISHED RAISE OBJECTIONS TO INVESTMENTS IN AGRICULTURAL LAND ON POLITICAL GROUNDS.
AFTER CONSIDERATION OF OPIC POSITIONS IN GENERAL ON SIGNIFICIANCE OF REGISTRATION NOTES, SUBROGATION AND INVOLVEMENT OF OTHER USG PROGRAMS IN EFFORTS ARRANGE PAYMENTS TO OPIC INSURED FIRMS IN NATIONALIZA- TION CASES, AS WELL AS RECENT EXPERIENCE WITH HANDLING APPLICATIONS COVERING MINING AND AGRICULTURAL LAND INVESTMENTS, WE CONFIRM OUR EARLIER POSITION THAT THERE SHOULD BE A STRONG BIAS AGAINST INSURING SUCH INVESTMENTS IN BOLIVIA, BUT WE STILL DO NOT WISH TO CLOSE THE

062118Z
DOOR COMPLETELY. AS MAJORITY OF “BOLIVIAN” APPLICATION TO OPIC APPEAR TO BE TWO MOST SENSITIVE AREAS AND AS OPIC PROCEDURES NOW RESULT IN ALMOST IMMEDIAT AND AUTOMATIC ISSUANCE OF REGISTRA- TION NOTICE AND AS OPIC BENDS EVERY EFFORT TO GRANT INSURANCE ONCE REGISTRATION NOTICE ISSUED, WE BELIEVE BEST PROCEDURE TO MEET OUR POLITICAL AND PROGRAM CONCERNS IN SENSITIVE AREAS, DEFINED AS MINING AND AGRICULTURAL LAND, WOULD BE ALONG FOLLOWING LINES: 1) OPIC WOULD ADVISE APPLICANT THAT REGISTRATION NOTICE CANNOT BE ISSUED UNTIL DETAILED INVESTMENT PROPOSAL PRESENTED TO OPIC AND OPIC CAN CONSULT WITHIN USG: 2) EMBASSY SHOULD BE PROVIDED WITH THESE DETAILS AND ALLOWED TO MAKE RECOMMENDATION BEFORE REGISTRA- TION NOTICE ISSUED: 3) IF INVESTOR ALTERS APROJECT, EMBASSY SHOULD BE ADVISED SO RECOMMENDATION CAN BE REVIEWED.
10.EMBASSY FULLY REALIZES THAT OPIC CAN DEAL WITH MANY PROBLEMS
BY CAREFUL DRAFTING INSURANCE CONTRACT, BUT SUCH ADJUSTMENT MAY NOT BE SUFFICIENT IN SOME CASES. WE BELIEVE BEST INTERESTS USG WILL BE SERVED BY GIVING MOST CAREFUL, CAUTIOUS AND BROAD CONSIDER- ATION TO INSURING U.S. INVESTMENTS IN SENSITIVE AREAS RATHER THAN EMPHASIZING OVERCOMING (PERHAPS ONLY SUPERFICIALLY) ANY OBSTACLES THAT APPEAR AND OBJECTIONS THAT MIGHT BE RAISED. STEDMAN

“Mr. Minister:”In my position as representative of International Metal Processing Corporation, I have remained in the country two weeks trying to contact you, Mr. Minister, and with other authorities, to discuss the problem that has arisen with Embosa and try to reach an arbitrated agreement as provided in Article 39 of the social statutes of the cited enterprise. “Unfortunately, I have not had the opportunity sought for, surely due to the extremely heavy workload of all the persons whom I have tried to contact.”In the face of this negative result, we, the stockholders of International Metal Processing Corporation, think that the present situation is the same as that of January, 1971, the date when the enterprise was nationalized by the government headed by General Juan Jose Torres. Consequently our present position is one of repeating our request to the Supreme Government of Bolivia for the payment of adequate and just indemnization which we solicit along with accumulated interest because of the non-performance of the Mining Corporation of Bolivia. “The situation resolved in this leval, just and equitable manner, International Metal Processing Corporation would have the right and freedom to recuperate the process patent and to utilize it in the manner most convenient to its interests.”I express to you in advance, Mr. Minister, that the liquidation of the Bolivian Metallurgical Enterprise, S.A. (mixed) has not arisen for the reasons indicated in Article 39 of the statutes, as I am able to demonstrate that financing could not be obtained, due precisely to the lack of a series of requirements that are not imputable to IMPC. “I very respectfully ask you, Mr. Minister, to consider carefully the historical facts presented in very summary form and to channel them adequately within the juridical order presently extant in the country so that they reach a satisfactory solution which contemplates the interests of both sides.”With this purpose I repeat to you assurance of my highest and distinguished consideration. “International Metal Processing Corporation”Frank M. Tye, Jr. President”.
Comment: Due continued absence Minattache and careful review our files, following comment should be regarded as preliminary and tentative. During Tye’s earlier visit to La Paz he showed to Emboffs decided lack of interest in pressing his claim through arbitration clause as provided in statutes. Difficult accept proposition that liquidation Embosa returns situation to January, 1971 situation as we understand Tye accepted check for US$ 1.4 million in December, 1971. Statutes state patent to be property of Comibol after one year of use. End Comment.
We understand Tye in La Paz (as indicated Reftel) accompanied by “two foreigners”, probably Americans. He has not called on Embassy. Stedman

La Paz. “Presencia”, uno de los periódicos de mayor circulación en Bolivia, en su editorial del sábado último (febrero 9), bajo el título de “Solución al Problema del Canal de Panamá”, entre otras cosas dice: “Si queremos construir una América fuerte y progresista, es imprescindible la cooperación entre las naciones ricas y pobres del hemisferio. De ahí la importancia que tiene que reconocerse a las buenas relaciones entre Estados Unidos y América Latina y la necesidad que hay de eliminar aquellas condiciones que llevan a malos entendidos.”Un paso notable se ha dado recientemente, cuando Estados Unidos y Panamá suscribieron un documento en el cual se sientan las bases para llegar posteriormente a un tratado que substituya al de 1903, todavía vigente, y que, por las injusticias que contiene es fuente de continuos roces… En los últimos veinticinco años, Estados Unidos fue impulsor de la independencia de muchas naciones coloniales y, por lo tanto, no podía negarse a seguir la misma ruta en lo que toca a relaciones similares, si no iguales, que mantiene con algunos territorios. Que la nueva mentalidad se abre camino es comprobado por varios hechos, como la finalización de la guerra de Vietnam, varias declaraciones oficiales de los últimos años y la actitud ante las justas reclamaciones panameñas”.
Luego de afirmar que el caso de Panamá tenía que ser resuelto por varias razones y mostrar su creencia de que también el caso de Guantánamo será resuelto cuando mejoren las relaciones entre Estados Unidos y Cuba, el editorial de “Presencia” finaliza diciendo: “Si los principios ahora acordados llegan a concretarse en un tratado, como esperamos que suceda, todos habremos ganado, inclusive Estados Unidos, que podrá integrar en mejores condiciones la Comunidad Americana y eliminar una fuente de incomprensiones. Así lo han de ver quienes, en la potencia norteña, no tengan vista de corto alcance y adviertan lo mucho que podemos hacer todos en una acción mancomunada. Y sostenida en la igualdad y la amistad.”
French acting

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM

In hour and half meeting with Emboffs Minmines agreed to prudent postponement of automatic revision of January 26, 1974 to Gob of Sapi’s unworked concessions about (12,000 hectares) as ordered by Law Decree No. 10998 of July 26, 1973. Embassy believes postponement may be one month.
Minmines insists that Sapi end delaying tactics and not try to bargain reversion of concession issue with settlement of old tax problems not yet settled by Ministry which now matter for Controller General as well. He acknowledged Sapi right in some of old tax problems but wrong in others.
Despite position on tax matter as reported Para 2, Minmines stated three separate issues are involved and wants three issues settled in package deal. Issues are (A) unresolved tax matters pending for over ten years, (B) reversion of 12,000 hectares of concessions which Minister thought Sapi would never mine, and (C) future of Sapi in Bolivia involving Sapi’s plans to participate in joint venture operation with Bolivian private capital to work on part of old Bolinca concession.
Minister asked for guarantee of USG that these three matters would be resolved and that Sapi would end delaying tactics. Emboffs replied that to our knowledge Sapi had tried to resolve problem at least as early as October, 1973 and that USG could not offer guarantees but that Mission would use its best offices toward finding rapid solution.
Asked whether O’Neill’s presence in Bolivia required, Minister said not necessary until package deal is ready to sign.
FYI. Minmines blamed most of ill will between Sapi and Gob on Sapi’s lawyer, Rene Rojas, who always waited to very end before trying to settle issue. End FYI. Remarked Sapi contract very bad one for Bolivia. Stated for 15 years Sapi only worked 700 hectares and Gob unwilling to wait for another ten years to get land back which Sapi had indicated it does not intend to work.
Minmines stated old tax question had been referred to Bolivia’s Internal Revenue Department (Direccion Nacional de la Renta, DNR), and to Controller General. Said commission formed by Ministry of Mines to look into tax question, mostly involving taxes paid on redredging of tailings, will visit Sapi’s old working sites and would be accompanied by representatives of Controller General, DNR, and Banco Minero. Minister added that under Bolivian law tax claims could not be a matter of negotiation and compromise as is often the case in the U.S. He said this especially true at present due to intensive “moralization campaign” being conducted by Minister of State Curruto which bringing out number of old unresolved tax issues.
Comment: Minmines seemed disposed to grant new gold mining concession to Echazu Group which would have connection with Sapi, but it was obvious that Minister prefers concession to be in national hands.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

BOLIVIANS CALLED FOR MEETING AFTER CHILEAN AUTHORITIES ONCE AGAIN RAISED PORT AND RAIL CHARGES LAST JUNE. CHILEAN DELEGATION OF ELEVEN HEADED BY AMBASSADOR HENRIQUE BERNSTEIN MET WITH BOLIVIAN DELEGATION OF TWENTY-SIX, INCLUDING REPRESENTATIVES FROM PRIVATE SECTOR.
EARLY STATEMENTS STRESS CORDIAL ATMOSPHERE OF TALKS BUT PRESS CARRIED STORIES DESCRIBING CARGO DELAYS AND MISHANDLING IN CHILEAN PORTS AND CHARGE THAT RECENT FLOUR SHIPMENTS STORED

091701Z
IN OPEN AIR HAVE BEEN DAMAGED BY LIGHT RAIN IN ARICA. FRONT-
PAGE STORIES CONCLUDED SEPT. 5 THAT TALKS WERE FAILURE BECAUSE CHILEAN DELEGATION WAS NOT IN FACT EMPOWERED TO NEGOTIATE AGREEMENT AND “ONLY PROMISED TO RECOMMEND” TO GOC THAT JUNE INCREASE IN CHARGES BE TEMPORARILY SUSPENDED. FON OFF RELEASE POINTED OUT THAT COMMISSIONS AGREED TO MEET AGAIN WITHIN SIXTY DAYS TO MAKE TECHNICAL STUDY OF NOMENCLATURE AND TARIFF STRUCTURE, TAKING INTO ACCOUNT FOR FIRST TIME BOLIVIA’S ” NEEDS FOR ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT.”

COMMENT: PORT CHARGES HAVE BEEN CONTINUAL PROBLEM DUE TO CHILEAN INFLATION. CHILEAN DELEGATION PROPOSED AND BOLIVIANS RE- JECTED SUGGESTION THAT CHARGES BE COLLECTED IN U.S. DOLLARS AS WAY

OF AVOIDING NEED FOR FREQUENT ADJUSTMENT. (BOLIVIAN CUSTOMARILY OBTAIN BLACK MARKET ESCUDOS TO PAY PORT CHARGES.) BOLIVIA IS SUFFERING ONE OF PERIODIC PORT CRISES WITH LARGE BACKLOGS OF CARGO IN PERUVIAN PORT OF MATARANI (SEE A-169 OF SEPT 9) AND APPARENTLY ALSO ARICA.
LATTER PORT HAS RECEIVED LARGE QUANTITY OF FLOUR DESTINED FOR BOLIVIA AND THIS HAS SLOWED DOWN OTHER SHIPMENT. COMMISSIONS DID NOT DIS- CUSS LONGER-RANGE SOLUTIONS TO PORT PROBLEMS. BOLIVIANS INSTEAD TAKE OUT THEIR FRUSTRATIONS ARISING THEIR LACK OF CONTROL OF OWN FACILITIES BY MAKING SHORT-TERM PRACTICAL SOLUTIONS MORE DIFFICULT. NEGATIVE PUBLICITY DURING MEETING CAME FROM MINISTRY OF INDUSTRY AND COMMERCE SOURCES. STEDMAN

EDGAR L. ROJAS, COMATT, CHAIRMAN.

PHILLIP MCLEAN, ECONOMIC/COMMERCAIL OFFICER

GOB DECISION MEMBERS ARE:

CAPT. DE NAV., WALTER NUNEZ RIVERO, MINISTER DE TRANSPORTE Y COMUNICACIONES, EDIFICIO LA URBANA, AVENIDA CAMACHO, LA PAZ, BOLIVIA; TELEPHONE 26509.
MR. ALFONSO GUZMAN, SUB-SECRETARY DE COMUNICACIONES, EDIFICIO LA URBANA, AVENIDA CAMACHO, LA PAZ, BOLIVIA, TELEPHONE 26511.
MAJOR VICTOR AGUILAR DORADO, GENERAL MANAGER, TELEVISION BOLIVIANA, CASILLO 900, LA PAZ, BOLIVIA, TELEPHONE 50481.

THE PRIME DECISION MAKER WILL BE MAJOR VICTOR AGUILAR DORADO. THE ZENITH LOCAL REPRESENTATIVE, MR. OSCAR HANDAL,

302255Z
AGENCIAS INTERNACIONALES LTDA., ADVISED OF A CONVERSATION
HE HAD RECENTLY WITH MAJOR AGUILAR IN WHICH THE MAJOR TOLD MR. HANDAL THAT THE U.S. COLOR SYSTEM IS PREFERRED. THE REASON GIVEN WAS THE COST OF PROGRAMMING, WHICH IS LESS FOR U.S. SYSTEM.

MR. HANDAL HAS SOLD 30,000 BLACK AND WHITE ZENITH TV SETS SINCE THE ESTABLISHMENT OF TV STATION IN 1969. THE TOTAL NUMBER OF ALL SETS SOLD IS ESTIMATED AT 70,000. HE ESTIMATES A MARKET OF 200,000 BLACK AND WHITE SETS.
THE U.S. TV BROADCASTING EQUIPMENT COMPANY, TELEMATION OF SALT LAKE CITY, UTAH, RECENTLY SOLD TELEVISION BOLIVIANA A NEW BROADCASTING SYSTEM. IT CAN BE USED FOR EITHER BLACK AND WHITE OR COLOR AND IS EQUIPPED WITH A CONVERTER TO USE EITHER THE EUROPEAN OR U.S. COLOR SYSTEM. THIS EQUIPMENT WILL SERVE THE LA PAZ AREA. WITH THE EXCEPTION OF A PORTABLE REPEATER SYSTEM IN AND AROUND MINING CENTERS NEAR ORURO, TV IS NOT AVAILABLE ELSEWHERE.
TELEMATION IS PRESENTLY CONDUCTING A STUDY FOR TELEVISION BOLIVIANA. TELEMATION IS REQUIRED, INTER ALIA, TO RECOMMEND EITHER THE EUROPEAN OR AMERICAN TV STANDARD FOR THE ESTABLISH- MENT OF TV BROADCASTING IN THE CITIES OF COCHABAMBA AND SANTA CRUZ. IF THE U.S. STANDARD IS ACCEPTED FOR THESE TWO CITIES, IT IS ALMOST CERTAIN THAT BOLIVIA WILL RECOMMEND THE NTSC COLOR SYSTEM.
AS LA PAZ IS NOW ON THE EUROPEAN STANDARD OF 625 LINES, 50 CYCLES, ACCEPTANCE OF THE AMERICAN STANDARD WILL CAUSE TV VIEWING PROBLEMS TO THOSE VIEWERS NOT EQUIPPED WITH TRANSISTORIZED SETS. AS TV BROADCASTING IS ONLY FIVE YEARS OLD, THERE ARE FEW TUBE SETS AND AS THE MARKET FOR BLACK AND WHITE SETS IS NOWHERE NEAR SATURATED, THE RATIO OF TRANSISTOR TO TUBE SETS WILL GROW FAR GREATER. (PERHAPS PROGRAMS WOULD HAVE TO BE INTRODUCED TO SATISFY LA PAZ TV VIEWERS EQUIPPED WITH TUBE SETS BY INSTALLING SUB-CARRIERS.) MAJOR AGUILAR RECOGNIZES THAT U.S. COLOR PROGRAMS ARE AVAILABLE IN GREATER QUANTITY, BETTER QUALITY AND AT LOWER COST THAN PAL PROGRAMS. THEREFORE, WE HOPE THAT ESPECIALLY THE LOWER COST OF PROCURING NTSC COLOR PROGRAMS, WILL CAUSE THE CHOOSING

302255Z
OF THE AMERICAN TV STANDARD FOR COCHABAMBA AND SANTA CRUZ.

TELEVISION BOLIVIANA IS FAMILIAR WITH THE NTSC SYSTEM AND ITS ADVANTAGES. AT PRESENT, TWO OF THEIR ENGINEERS, INCLUDING THEIR OPERATIONS ENGINEER, ARE UNDERGOING A COURSE AT TELEMATION. IN ADDITION, TELEVISION BOLIVIANA HAS CONTRACTED WITH TELEMATION FOR THE COCHABAMBA, SANTA CRUZ STUDY. NATURALLY, THIS U.S. COMPANY IS PROMOTING THE U.S. STANDARD

AND COLOR SYSTEM. WE SEE NO REASON AT THE PRESENT TIME TO USE THE LEADER GRANT PROGRAM.

GOB INTEGRATION OFFICIALS STATE THAT GOB IS ACTIVELY CONSIDERING POSITION IT WILL TAKE ON COLOR TELEVISION QUESTION IN ANDEAN CONTEXT AND DECISION EXPECTED IN NEXT FEW WEEKS. PARKER

title: The Walpurgisnacht of the Bolivian Right: The Hangover Will Be Bad
text:
DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
CONFIDENTIAL

    
      
              
          Date:
          November 06, 1979

          The Walpurgisnacht of the Bolivian Right: The Hangover Will Be Bad
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          La Paz 9512
        
            
    
    
  

1. Summary
Some will say that the ghastly orgy of the Bolivian Right in the last 5 days was an inevitable, cathartic phase of Bolivia’s difficult course to civilian democracy. I had hoped it was not and still feel it could have been avoided if the civilian parties, backed by the decent–and then dominant–sector of the military, had come to a coalition agreement with President Walter Guevara even 48 hours earlier. Whether an unavoidable relapse set in or a very near rescue operation fell short by a hair, the scars of the bloody November eruption are clear and will be long lasting. End Summary.


2. The Radical Right has had its Witches’ Sabbath
In the upside-down world of its own nightmares. For 5 days black has been white, repression has been deliverance, unarmed workers and innocent bystanders have been Trotskyite terrorists and phantom Cuban cadres. And the frightened recruits egged on by the officers of the paranoic Right really showed them. The phantoms were mowed down by the dozens to save Bolivia from the anarchy and chaos of the “tyrant” Walter Guevara–a quiet, fatherly intellectual who in fact presided over a peaceful and open Bolivian society in which no one was hurt and most people felt good about Bolivia again.
But the Right knew better, only they–the totem, self appointed savior Alberto Natusch, the psychotic Carlos Mena (Interior Minister) and the frustrated knights without dragons like Doria Medina (Commander of the spearhead armoured unit)–could see the real demons that hid beneath this placid surface.


3. The Warning from Military Leaders
The good men who led the Bolivian Armed Forces until November 1, Generals David Padilla and Ramon Azero in particular, told these glassy eyed zealots that they were wrong and that the real Bolivia was otherwise. We did as well, repeatedly over the last 6 months. They were told again, within days of the November 1 coup that:

The Bolivian people wanted civilian democracy and would not stand idly by while some colonels told them they could not have it;
The labor unions would try to shut this country down before acquiescing in a military takeover;
Only repression could keep one of these colonels on top of an unwilling country;
In the futile effort to sustain such a repressive regime the unity and reputation of the Bolivian Armed Forces would be destroyed and Bolivia’s international image stained;
In the end the decent military would not stomach the necessary amount of repression.

Most of these consequences have already been incurred while the last remains perilously suspended. But somehow the true believers would not take it from us nor their own commanders.


4. Civilian Casualties and Resistance
Most of the deaths in the last 5 days, to our knowledge, have been unarmed civilians gunned down by the military with automatic weapons. Yet the civilians have come back each day to mark their protest and hurl their ire. Threats of shooting and summary firing have not got them back to their jobs. Neither destruction by gun fire and sacking of the labor confederation headquarters nor deadly fire into crowds of militants gathered before it have broken the general strike. So far the Natusch regime’s appallingly indiscriminate firing at civilians has had the opposite of the intended effect. Resistance of the militants has been steeled and the most common people are afraid to enter the inner city to take up their jobs.


5. Negotiations
Negotiations between Natusch and the Congress continue. But in the end no compromise between civilian democracy and the military right of Natusch is possible: they are incompatible forces. The fanatics around Natusch, particularly Mena, keep telling him he must hang on or perish, and they are right. If Natusch accepts a graceful out of almost any kind, he and his sort, given the killing they have caused, will be swept by a counteraction out of the country if not out of this world. There may, therefore, be no graceful out for Natusch and his right-wing band of officers. If he is deposed, it is more likely to come from within the military than from negotiations with the Congress. There remains the fear that these negotiations are not in good faith and are only part of Natusch’s efforts to hold off military pressures to unseat him. Yet so far the focal point for a military counter move has not appeared.


6. Reaction of “Good Officers”
The good officers are appalled and in tears of mixed rage and sorrow over the killing of civilians and degradation of the military as a political and social force in Bolivia. Generals Padilla and Azero, Colonel Caioja and others have lost their jobs and staked their lives over bold public calls to get the military out of the city, Natusch out of the palace and civilian democracy restored. But the bulk of the military is still watching and waiting.


7. Damage Assessment
Whether Natusch and his band leave tomorrow, next month or later, some awesome damage has already been done to Bolivia and its tortuous, but determined course to civilian, constitutional rule.

The fabric of military-civilian cooperation, so important to the democratic transition so far, has been rent by betrayal, blood and bitterness;
The fragile unity of the armed forces has been shattered by schisms of deep resentment and shame–and dissension in the armed forces has been the only serious threat to the peace that modern Bolivia has known;
The military has been disgraced and its ability to play a stabilizing, behind the scenes role damaged and perhaps destroyed;
The credibility in the eyes of the people of the moderate, civilian political parties has been shaken by the despicable instigating role in the coup of a handful of turncoats from the MNR and MNRI–Guillermo Bedregal, Jose Fellman Velarde, Edel Sandoval Moron and Abel Ayoroa Argandona.



8. Conclusion
The possible positive effects in the hangover from the Walpurgisnacht of the Right are meager or nil. Just perhaps the arrogant, paranoic right of the military will be purged after the bloody binge on which they have misled their institution, perhaps civilian politics will throw out or indict the quislings who viewed a bloodbath as a small price for a government job. But neither one may happen and both together would not justify perhaps 100 dead and many more wounded, nor the lasting damage to an open society and Bolivians confidence in each other or themselves.
BOEKER

text:
Date:

          Oct-01 Ads-00 Sye-00 /006 W ——————111997 172221z /34 O 172214z Oct 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          Intelligence Report For Sec Of State’s Visit To La Paz,
        
                    
          TAGS:
          ASEC, OVIP (VANCE, CYRUS)
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: On October 16, 1979, the US Senate passed a bill which will permit the U.S. government to dispose of 35,000 tons of tin. The Bolivian economy is based on tin, as Bolivia is the world’s second largest producer of tin. Therefore, the selling of stockpiles of tin by the U.S. is perceived by Bolivians as being anti-Bolivian. The potential exists for demonstrations and rallies to occur during the stay of the Secretary to express their displeasure with the congressional procedure. Intelligence information from Embassy intelligence sources along with information obtained from GOB police officials does not indicate any projected violence to the Secretary of State or OAS members. The tin issue is a very volatile situation in Bolivia; however, the OAS conference is widely viewed by Bolivians as contributing to their international prestige and enhancing their reputation. For these reasons, neither the left nor right-wing parties desire any type of action that would cause disgrace or harm to Bolivian pride and national goals. In summary, while the tin issue remains antagonistic, there appears to be negative information directly related against the Secretary of State, and no hard intelligence to warrant any assassination attempts.

Boeker

162206Z
NEEDS OF BOLIVIA, HAS BEEN ARRANGED AND WILL BE CONDUCTED
ON JULY 3 AND 4, 1974.

title: Gob Announces Economic Measures
text:
Date:
          November 30, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Immediate 9551
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ads-00 Aid-05 Ciae-00 Com-02 Eb-08 Frb-03 Inr-10 Nsae-00 Trse-00 Xmb-02 Opic-07 Sp-02 Lab-04 H-01 Sil-01 Omb-01 Ss-15 Str-08 Cea-01 Sso-00 Nsce-00 Icae-00 Inre-00 Doe-17 /103 W ——————041274 302226z /64
        
                    
          Subject:
          Gob Announces Economic Measures
        
                    
          TAGS:
          ECON, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          LA PAZ 9970 (NOTAL)
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

This morning, November 30, at 0345 hours, the GOB announced a package of economic measures much along the lines of reftel. The program includes the following:

A devaluation of 25 percent to 24.51 pesos (buying) 25 pesos (selling) to the dollar.
A graduated wage bonus for private and public sector employees earning less than 9,000 pesos per month.
Increases in hydrocarbon prices and the cost of public transportation.
A 1980 consolidated public sector budget equivalent to the 1979 levels plus the cost of the wage increase. Some small increases would be permitted for the ministries of Defense, Health, Education, and the Interior.
Creation of a Council of Monetary Stabilization (Consejo Nacional de Politica Monetaria) to monitor the program.
Monetary measures include increases in time and demand deposit interest rates, changes in the legal reserve requirements, a prior import deposit of 100 percent replacing the previous 500 percent deposit, and a new tax on commercial bank credit for both peso and dollar loans. Bankers have been in meetings with the Central Bank most of the day finding out what the new measures mean to them. For this reason, commercial banks are not carrying out foreign exchange transactions today. Money exchange houses are open and are buying dollars at the official rate and selling them at near 25 pesos to the dollar but, according to one exchange house manager, there are no dollars to sell.
Price controls on flour, some pasta products, rice, sugar, bread, and rent controls on all housing.

We anticipate some popular reaction, since the Bolivian Labor Federation, which caused the measures to be postponed, apparently was not included in the government’s decision to go ahead with the measures. Nevertheless, we anticipate that after some show of protest, Juan Lechin and his COB will go along.
According to local IMF representative Jorge Sol Perez, the GOB’s economic measures include the basic program outlined in reftel. The Central Bank is authorized to make daily exchange rate adjustments and plans to do so until the rate reaches an equilibrium. The price hike for petroleum products will average 136 percent. Sol Perez said that an IMF mission will arrive over the coming weekend; he expects a letter of intent to be prepared and ready for signature by late next week.
After the early morning announcement of the economic measures, Bolivia’s major cities remain calm and business is normal. This morning a student demonstration rumored to be against the measures turned out to be students gathering at one of La Paz’ main plazas for the final leg of an early morning marathon. Minister of Finance Augusto Cuadros Sanchez told the ambassador that so far public reaction to the measures had been calm and philosophical, that in a sense the measures turned out less severe than the public had anticipated. Cuadros was sanguine the stabilization program would now go forward without the threat of a major strike by the labor sector.

title: Pereda Making Headway On His Election Plan
text:
Date:
          August 03, 1978
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Immediate 1973
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 /001 W ——————076696 031628z /41 O 031445z Aug 78
        
                    
          Subject:
          Pereda Making Headway On His Election Plan
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          LA PAZ 6172, LA PAZ 6107
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Natush Busch told me evening of August 2 that Pereda’s meeting with the La Paz garrisons, which Natush attended, went quite well. The garrisons asked for six days to give their response in writing, but Pereda was still hoping that all needed approvals could be obtained in time for an August 6 announcement of new elections. Natush said Carlos Iturralde (GOB ambassador in Washington) had been sent to see Banzer in Santa Cruz to solicit a nod of approval from him to Banzer loyalists in the military on the election plan. Natush thought that if Banzer would cooperate this would assure success but he was optimistic in any case. Pereda, he said was meeting his commitments to US.
This morning Edwin Tapia called me to say that Pereda’s meetings with garrisons in La Paz, Cochabamba, and Santa Cruz had gone well and it looked good for approval of elections in late 1979 or very early 1980. He too was optimistic that Pereda could make his speech on August 6 or, at the latest, one or two days later. Tapia asked whether we could now proceed with affirmation of continuing US-Bolivian relations. I told him I would see what I could do.
Comment. Nothing in Bolivia is ever certain until it happens. But it is clear that Pereda is making progress, that he is now on the right side of the election issue, and a little boost to him now would probably help both our objectives–new elections and maintenance of peace and, ergo, the human rights environment in Bolivia. Therefore, I recommend we now acknowledge receipt of the Foreign Minister’s note and that I be authorized subsequently to request an appointment with the Foreign Minister to discuss on-going business, such as the prisoner exchange treaty.

text:

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

On January 30, local representative of Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation stated that he was recommending to his firm to make an offer to GOB to construct smelter under mixed enterprise arrangement with ENAF. Russian, German, Japanese, Brazilian, French, Polish and Czechoslovak offers reportedly also likely to be made.
Comment: According to Singmaster and Bryer (consultants to U.S. Steel and COMIBOL) report of 1969, there is no technical reason why an electrolytic zinc plant could not be installed and operated successfully in Bolivia despite problems of high altitude. However, report also stated that economic success of the zinc refinery depended on electric power costs, sufficient reserves for guaranteed delivery of zinc concentrates for 20 years, and guaranteed market for sulphuric acid produced, which due to high transportation costs, would have to be marketed internally. For zinc refinery with annual output of 33,600 metric tons of zinc, 265,440 pounds of cadmium, and 360 tons of copper residues, 61,000 metric tons of sulphuric acid would be produced. Embassy believes that whether present economics of smelter are justifiable or not, smelter will be built in any event.
Action requested: USDOC is requested to encourage potentially interested U.S. firms to communicate directly with Minister of Mining and Metallurgy, Raul Lema Patino, Ministero de Mineria y Metalurgia, 1769 Avenida 16 de Julio, La Paz, Bolivia and copy to Empresa Nacional de Fundiciones (ENAF), Casilla 4298 La Paz Bolivia. ENAF’s cable address is “ENAFBOL”, La Paz: its telex numbers are BX5271 and ITT 3560090.
The tender will be reported to USDOC when issued.

text:
Date:

          Bolivian Minister Of Defense Indicates Little Interest In Soviet Military Equipment
        
                    
          TAGS:
          MASS PFOR BL UR
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

DURING COURTESY CALL I MADE JULY 10 WITH MILGP COMDR SHAHA ON GENERAL RENE BERNAL, NEW MINISTER OF DEFENSE, I MENTIONED THAT I HAD HEARD THAT THE USSR HAD MADE OFFERS TO BOLIVIA OF MILITARY EQUIPMENT. BERNAL SAID THAT MY INFORMATION WAS CORRECT AND THAT HE HAD BEEN INVITED SEVERAL WEEKS AGO TO MAKE A TRIP TO THE SOVIET UNION. IN ADDITIONA, THE SOVIET AMBASSADOR HAD INVITED HIM TO THE SOVIET EMBASSY FOR A SOCIAL FUNCTION AT WHICH A SOVIET MOVIE WAS SHOWN. BERNAL SAID THAT HIS ATTENDNANCE AT THE MOVIE WAS THE MINIMUM DIPLOMATIC RESPONSE HE COULD MAKE TO THE SOVIETS, AND HE HAD NO INTENTION OF TRAVELING TO THE SOVIET UNION. HE SAID HE OPPOSED COMMUNISM AND THE SOVIET SYSTEM AND LEFT ME WITH THE IMPRESSION THAT HE HAD LITTLE INTEREST IN SOVIET EQUIPMENT.
THIS EXCHANGE FOLLOWED AN EXTREMELY FRIENDLY CONVERSATION DURING WHICH BERNAL EXPRESSED AFFECTION, RESPECT, AND ADMIRA- TION FOR THE U.S., ITS PEOPLE, ITS ACCOMPLISHMENTS, AND ITS ROLE AS LEADER OF FREE WORLD. STEDMAN

UNCLASSIFIED

FOLLOWING STATISTICS OBTAINED FROM Y.P.F.B. ARE ONLY FOR FIRST FOUR MONTHS OF 1974 COMPARED TO SAME PERIOD IN 1973. PETROLEUM PRODUCTION FOR PERIOD IN 1974 DECLINED TO 5,229,035 BARRELS COMPARED TO 5,752,980 IN 1973. PETROLEUM EXPORTS ALSO DECLINED 1,010,934 BARRELS FROM 4,876,175 IN 1973 TO 3,8YTNWRQ IN 1974. HOWEVER, VALUE OF PETROLEUM EXPORTS INCREASED IN PERIOD FROM US$ 11,63 MILLION IN 1973 TO US$59.98 MILLION IN 1974.
GAS EXPORTS TO ARGENTINA DURING THIS TIME INCREASED SLIGHTLY FROM 16,783,715 THOUSAND CUBIC FEET (TCF) IN 1973 TO 16,791,667 TCF IN 1974. VALUE OF GAS EXPORTED IN SAME PERIOD IN 1974 IS US$ 7,023,958 COMPARED TO US$ 4,671,961 IN 1973.
COMMENT: WHILE CURDE PRODUCTION ABOUT 9.1 PERCENT LESS IN FIRST FOUR MONTHS, EXPORTS ABOUT 20.7 PERCENT LESS. WE WILL ATTEMPT OBTAIN MORE INFORMATION TO ESTABLISH TO WHAT EXTENT CONSUMPTION AND STOCKS MAY HAVE INCREASED. BREWIN

title: Message To The Nation Delivered By President Banzer On June 5, 1974. Quote:
text:
Date:
          June 06, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Priority 3332
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Ss-20 Nsc-07 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Inr-10 Nsae-00 Pa-04 Rsc-01 Usia-15 Prs-01 Sp-03 Drc-01 /083 W ——————— 057173
        
                    
          Subject:
          Message To The Nation Delivered By President Banzer On June 5, 1974. Quote:
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, PGOV, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

TO THE COMRADES OF THE ARMED FORCES OF THE NATION WHO DURING MY ABSENCE AND WITH EXEMPLARY POLITICAL MATURITY DEMONSTRATED BEFORE HISTORY, THE FIRM PURPOSE OF THE (MILITARY) INSTITUTION TO MAINTAIN, ABOVE ALL PERSONAL AMBITIONS AND SECTARIAN INTERESTS, THE CONTINUITY OF THE NATIONAL REVOLUTION, AS THE SOLE ALTERNATIVE TO ATTAIN SUCCESS IN OVERCOMING BACKWARDNESS AND DEPENDENCY.
TO EACH OF THE MEMBERS OF THE NATIONALIST POPULAR FRONT, WHO IN A FEW MINUTES DEMONSTRATED, TOGETHER WITH THE ARMED FORCES OF THE NATION THEIR CAPACITY OR STRUGGLE.
TO THE SECURITY UNITS OF THE STATE, THAT WITH DISCIPLINE EFFECTIVELY

FOLLOWED THE INSTRUCTIONS GIVEN BY THE MINISTRY OF INTERIOR
062121Z
RENEWING THUS THEIR FULL IDENTIFICATION WITH MY GOVERNMENT.

TO THE FARMERS AND WORKERS, DEVOTED MEN WHO FULLY REALIZE WHO ARE THOSE WHO WORK AND FIGHT FOR THEIR GOALS AND WHO ARE THOSE WHO ATTEMPT TO ENGAGE IN SMALL ADVENTURES AGAINST THE NATION, CONTRARY TO REASON AND HISTORY.
TO THE CITIZENS WHO, FACING THE CHOICE BETWEEN A COUNTRY WITH DIGNITY AND DEVELOPMENT, OR A REGRESSIVE AND DESTRUCTIVE CHAOS, ADOPTED THE GREAT DECISION TO FIGHT THE BATTLE AGAINST THOSE WHO ATTEMPTED TO MAINTAIN POVERTY.
TO THE PERSONAL FRIENDS WHO, AT THE TIME OF TRIAL, SUPPORTED THE IDEALS OF THE GOVERNMENT AND SUPPORTED ME.
I ADDRESS ALL OF YOU, WITH THE REWARDING FEELING OF A DEFINITE AND CLEAN VICTORY, BUT AT THE SAME TIME WITH THE BITTERNESS CAUSED BY THE INCONSISTENCY AND MEANNESS OF SMALL GROUPS WHO TRY NOT TO UNDERSTAND THAT THE HEROIC DESTINY OF OUR COUNTRY DEMANDS GREATNESS OF SPIRIT, AND THE HUMAN QUALITY WHICH CHARACTERIZES THE BOLIVIANS WHO LEAD THE GREAT CHANGES THAT THE COUNTRY REQUIRES.
BOLIVIA IS GOING THROUGH A DIFFICULT TIME IN ITS DEVELOPMENT. FOR THIS, WE ARE USING OUR SACRIFICE, DISCIPLINE AND WORK IN ORDER TO EST ABLISH THE BASES WHICH WILL MAKE POSSIBLE A SUSTAINED RHYTHM OF SHARED PROGRESS AND WELFARE.
THE BASIC OBJECTIVE OF MY GOVERNMENT IS THAT OF DEVELOPMENT. THE PEOPLE OF THIS WORTHY LAND ARE ENTITLED TO WORK, THINK, AND BELIEVE WITH NO OTHER LIMITATION THAN THAT OF THEIR OWN POSSIBLITIES. WITH A THIRELESS EFFORT, WE ARE WORKING DAY AND NIGHT, SO THAT OUR BELOVED COUNTRY WILL TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THE OPPORTUNITIES AND MEANS OFFERED US BY CONTEMPORARY SOCIETY: AND VERY SOON IT WILL BE POSSIBLE THAT BOLIVIA WILL ACT JOINTLY WITH THE OTHER COUNTRIES OF THE WORLD IN EQUAL CONDIDTIONS AND WITHIN A FRAMEWORK OF MUTUAL BENEFIT AND RESPECT.
DURING THE CONSULTATION MEETING HELD IN COCHABAMBA, CONVINCED OF THE NECESSITY TO MOBILIZE ALL RESOURCES OF THE COUNTRY IN ORDER TO

062121Z
FACE THE CHALLENGE OF POVERTY, I ASKED THE BOLIVIAN PEOPLE FOR THEIR UNITY AROUND THE ARMED FORCES OF THE NATION. SUPPORTED BY THE STRENGTH OF MY DEEPEST CONVICTION, I ALSO RAISED THE ISSUE OF NATIONAL PARTICIPA- TION SO THAT EACH TASK COULD BE ACCOMPLISHED WITH THE HELP OF THE DECISION AND CAPABILITY OF EACH BOLIVIAN. THE ANSWER RECEIVED FROM THE
ANTI-NATIONAL GROUPS, WHO ARE MOTIVATED BY ANGER AND UNILIMITED
AMBITION. HAS BEEN A TOTAL LACK OF UNDERSTANDING, ISOLATED VIOLENCE, GROUNDLESS CRITICISM, AND OPPOSITION FOR THE SAKE OF OPPOSITION.

AS A PART OF OUR INTERNATIONAL STRATEGY IN THE CONTEXT OF THE STRUGGLE FOR CONTRO OF THE WORLD, BOLIVIA, BECAUSE OF ITS GEOGRAPHIC POSITION AND BECAUSE OF THE DEFICIENCES OF OUR HERITAGE, HAS BEEN CHOSEN AS THE CENTER OF EXTREMIST ACTIVITIES OF THOSE WHO HAD INTENDED TO SPEAD THEIR VIOLENT ACTIVITIES INTO OTHER COUNTRIES OF THE HEMISPHERE.
UNFORTUNATELY, AMBITIOUS POLITICIANS, SUCH AS HUMBOLT AND VALVERDE, WITHOUT INTELLIGENCE ENOUGH TO UNDERSTAND INTERNATIONAL EVENTS, ALLOWED THEMSELVES TO BE USED IN SUCH PLANS WITHOUT RELAIZING THE HUGE DAMAGE CAUSED TO THE NATION.
BUT THE MOST SERIOUS FACT ABOUT THE PERSONS WHO ASSUMED THIS ATTUDE IS THAT IN THEIR EFFORT TO GAIN FOLLOWERS, THEY TURNED TO THE MILITARY HEADQUARTERS, TOOK ADVANTAGE OF INGENUOUS OFFICERS AND DAMAGED THE IMAGE AND UNITY OF THE ARMED FORCES OF THE NATION.
THE AUTHORS OF EVENTS OF THIS KIND WILL BE DISCIPLINED WITH THE SEVERITY PRESCRIBED BY THE LAW, BECAUSE ULTIMATELY THE UNITY OF THE ARMED FORCES OF THE NATION IS THE UNITY OF THE COUNTRY.
I ACCOMPLISH WITH HONOR THE MISSION TO DISMISS THE CHARGES AGAINST THE AIR (FORCE) BASE AND THE MILITARY ACADEMY MADE BY CERTAIN NEWSPAPERS, MAKING CLEAR THAT THESE UNITS MAINTAINED FULL AND CONSISTENT LOYALTY TOWARD THE CONSITUTED ORDER.

16 IT IS ALSO MY DUTY TO EMPHASIZE THE LOYAL AND DISCIPLINED CONDUCT OF ALL THE GARRISONS OF THE INTERIOR OF THE COUNTRY, TO WHOM I EXPRESS MY APPRECIATION.
062121Z

ONCE MORE, I TAKE THIS OPPORTUNTY TO MENTION THAT THE EFFORT I MAKE, TOGETHER WITH THE ARMED FORCES OF THE NATION AND WITH ALL Y CO-WORKERS, I S NOT TO ATTAIN AN OBJECTIVE OF A PERSONAL NATURE. I AM LEADING THE GOVERNEMENT BECAUSE I BELIEVE IN BOLIVIA AND ITS CAPACITY TO BE A GREAT (COUNTRY) VERY SOON: WITHIN THE FRAMEWORK OF THIS CONCEPT, WHEN FACING THE CHOICE BETWEEN BOLIVIA AND ITS GRETNESS OR ACTIVITIES WHICH DISTURB PEACE AND DEVELOPMENT, I WARN THAT I SHALL UNHESTATINGLY CHOOSE BOLIVIA OVER THE ENEMIES OF ITS GREATNESS.
THE VICTORY WHICH HAS BEEN ATTAINED DURING MY ABSENCE BY THE PEOPLE SHOWS THE HISTORIC STRENGTH OF MY GOVERNMENT. I SHALL NOT WASTE SUCH MORAL AND MATERIAL STRENGTH OVER SMALL OBSTACLES. MY EFFORT

WITH THE PEOPLE AND WITH THE COUNTRY’S PRINCIPAL INSTITUTIONS IS DECISIVE.
WE SHALL WIN THE BATTLE AGAINST MISERY SO THAT IN THE FUTURE THERE WILL BE NO TEARS FOR LACK OF BREAD, NOR BITTERNESS OVER TREASONOUS ACTS.

BOLIVIANS: I HAVE RECEIVED AGAIN THE LIVING LOYALTY OF MY PEOPLE, OF THE ARMED FORCES OF THE NATIONA, THE NATIONALIST POPULAR FRONT, THE FARMERS, WORKERS AND ALL HONEST AND NOBLE MEN OF BOLIVIA. THIS BEAUTIFUL AND MAGNIFICENT DEMONSTRATION DEFINITELY COMMITS ME TO CONTINUE STRUGGLING TOGETHER WITH THE BOLIVIAN PEOPLE FOR THE GREAT NATIONAL DESTINY. THANK YOU. UNQUOTE. BREWIN

text:
Date:
          November 14, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz

          SecState WashDC 9269
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ara-11 Eur-12 Ea-10 Ads-00 Com-02 Int-05 Gsa-02 Ciae-00 Inr-10 Nsae-00 Dode-00 Aid-05 Frb-03 Ica-11 Trse-00 Xmb-02 Opic-07 Sp-02 Lab-04 H-01 Sil-01 Omb-01 /098 W ——————077704 172316z /64 R 141850z Nov 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          The Economic Effects Of Bolivia’s Political Crisis - Tin
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EMIN, ECON, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Although Bolivia’s private mining sub-sector is working, three Comibol mines/mills–Colquiri, Siglo XX, Catavi–are formally on strike. (Together these three entities represent slightly more than a third of Comibol production.) Additionally, the remainder of Comibol’s mines are on quasi-strike, i.e., there is little production.
Obviously, the final effect of the current political crisis on Bolivia’s 1979 tin output depends on how long the strikes/slowdowns persist. However, even prior to the November 1 coup, 1979 tin production was lagging slightly more than five percent behind 1978’s 30,880 metric tons. The effect of production lost just since November 1 now requires a revised estimate that 1979’s shortfall over 1978 will be at least ten percent. If stoppages continue (and spread to the private mines) and there is little further production through the end of the year, the 1979 total could be as low as 24,500 metric tons.

title: Bolivian Financial Crisis Deepens
text:
Date:
          May 11, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Priority 6225
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ads-00 Com-02 Lab-04 Aid-05 Ciae-00 Eb-08 Frb-03 Inr-10 Nsae-00 Ica-11 Trse-00 Xmb-02 Opic-07 Sp-02 Sil-01 Omb-01 Nsc-05 Ss-15 Str-08 Cea-01 Doe-15 Soe-02 /118 W ——————014714 121327z /47 P 112130z May 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          Bolivian Financial Crisis Deepens
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EFIN, EGEN, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: The Bolivian financial situation, which was critical before today’s cabinet changes, may deteriorate sharply during the next six weeks. If the government cannot obtain substantial financial credits (i.e., in the vicinity of $100 million) before elections, a substantial buildup of arrearages on foreign obligations by the end of July is virtually a foregone conclusion.
According to a reliable source who spoke with Minister Alba the evening of May 9, Alba told the cabinet meeting that morning that the country “had reached an historic landmark: reserves (i.e., the international reserves of the consolidated banking system) had fallen to zero.” According to source, Alba also tried to press for action on hydrocarbons, referring to an earlier cabinet agreement in principle on the subject, but found that whatever accord may have existed had evaporated. At the same meeting, Minister of Energy and Hydrocarbons Candia is said to have informed the cabinet that YPFB (the government-owned petroleum company) will not have sufficient funds to meet its June payroll.
In line with the gloomy economic news given the cabinet, the President of the Central Bank informed us that in the absence of new financial credits he doubted the government could continue to meet its financial obligations beyond June 15. He added that he had received offers of up to $150 million in financing, but that they were contingent upon the adoption of an economic stabilization program. In the absence of such a program he doubts that even short-term financing can be obtained, and he (a career banker) claims to have taken the position within the government that he will not lend his reputation to a search for credits unless, at a minimum, meaningful price increases in hydrocarbons are instituted.
President Padilla’s reaction to this pressure has been to fire both Finance Minister Alba and probably Central Bank President Fabri as well. He has replaced Alba with a loyal military man whose job will be to stop talking about economic reforms and start looking for enough borrowed money to finance reserve losses and essential domestic expenses, in particular government salaries, until the August transition. This will be Padilla’s last word on economic measures unless financial collapse forces action.
Lt. Colonel Javier Alcoreza, whom President Padilla named Minister of Finance May 11, although regarded as an able and intelligent officer, has no known experience in economics or finance, and is a relative stranger to domestic and international bankers. He is a close associate of President Padilla and has most recently been occupied with negotiating the bulk of Bolivia’s 1979 arms purchases. The appointment as Minister of Finance of a man who lacks experience in economics and banking, and, more importantly, who is unknown to the international financial community, should make it more difficult for Bolivia to obtain credits from legitimate sources, particularly because it appears the government does not intend to implement policies (i.e., substantial price hikes in domestic hydrocarbons) which would gain the support of the IMF.
As of April 30, the net international reserves of the Central Bank amounted to $111.2 million, and the bank was approximately $65 million overdrawn in its foreign exchange accounts with other banks. Both the IMF and the Central Bank report heavy buying of dollars by the public during the last two days. This demand for foreign exchange has undoubtedly moved the net international reserves of the consolidated banking system from zero, as reported by the Minister on May 9, into a negative position.
During the next three months, Bolivia owes $68.88 million dollars in debt service payments: May $25.4 million, June $21.649 million; July $21.832 million. In addition, the nation faces heavy current obligations arising from a growing trade imbalance. Imports are said to be approximately 45 percent above 1978 levels for the first quarter, and Central Bank authorities are anticipating a current account deficit of at least $500 million. Unless new financial credits amounting to approximately $100 million are obtained during the next three months, the Padilla government will be unable to meet its foreign payment obligations beginning some time in July. Under present circumstances the Padilla government will have great difficulty raising these credits.

          Subject:
          Walter Guevara Arze, Bolivia’s New Interim President
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, PINR, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: In electing Walter Guevara Arze, 67, as Bolivia’s first constitutionally-elected president in 13 years, the Congress has picked one of Bolivia’s most intelligent and attractive moderate politicians. He is widely respected by those outside Bolivia who know him for his rational and direct approach to political problems. One of the founders of the MNR in the 40s, he has not recently been close to Victor Paz and is not a leading insider in that party. Following the 1952 MNR Revolution Guevara served as Foreign Minister (1952-56), Ambassador to France (1956-58) and Minister of Interior (1958-59). Guevara split with Victor Paz in 1959 and formed the Authentic Revolutionary Party, a conservative offshoot of the MNR. In the 1960’s he again served as Foreign Minister (1967-68) and as Bolivia’s Permanent Representative to the United Nations (1968-71). Following several years of exile in the mid-1970’s Guevara returned to Bolivia and allied himself with Paz in both the 1978 and 1979 presidential elections. He was elected Senator from Cochabamba in the July 1979 elections and then President of the Senate from which position he emerged as Bolivia’s interim president when the Congress was unable to choose between either of the two leading vote getters, Hernan Siles or Victor Paz. Although he has at times been critical of the US, Guevara is generally considered to be friendly towards the United States. The US should have a close and cooperative working relationship with Guevara. End summary.
Guevara was born in the city of Cochabamba on March 12, 1912 and attended primary and secondary school there. After serving in the Chaco War (1932-1935) and being decorated for bravery he graduated from the Law School of the University of San Andres in La Paz. He served as Director of the Miners’ Bank (1937) and as a deputy in the Congress (1938) before being named Secretary-General of Government (1943-44), a position with cabinet rank. During the early 1940’s Guevara participated, along with Victor Paz and Hernan Siles, in the founding of the MNR. He resigned his cabinet position in 1944 to make a successful bid for a seat in the Congress. After election, however, Guevara chose to accept a scholarship for postgraduate work in sociology at the University of Chicago. He remained in the US until 1946 when, following the overthrow of the government of Gualberto Villarroel, Guevara went into exile in Argentina. He returned to Bolivia in 1949 to engage in underground activities for the MNR. Following the MNR’s successful revolution in 1952 Guevara was named Minister of Foreign Relations. Considered a moderate at this time Guevara was forced to resign this position in early 1956 because of a dispute with Juan Lechin, leader of the MNR’s left wing. When Hernan Siles Zuazo was elected president in 1956 Guevara was named Ambassador to France and, in 1957, concurrently to Israel. Guevara returned from France in 1958 to enter the Siles cabinet as Minister of Government. He resigned this position in 1959 in a dispute with Paz and Lechin and formed his own conservative offshoot of the MNR, the Authentic Revolutionary Party (PRA).
In 1960 Guevara was the PRA’s candidate for president of Bolivia. Guevara remained estranged from Paz during the latter’s third term (1960-64) and went into exile from 1962 to 1963. He was elected a Senator in the national elections of 1966. From 1967 to 1968 he served as Minister of Foreign Affairs under President Barrientos and in 1968 was named Bolivia’s Permanent Representative to the United Nations. He was dismissed in 1971 and returned to Bolivia. In 1974, following some criticism of the Banzer regime’s policy toward Brazil, he was exiled to Paraguay. He later went to Caracas where he served as an advisor to Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez. Guevara returned to Bolivia in 1978 and patched up his longtime feud with Victor Paz in time to support the latter’s campaign for president in 1978. When those elections were annulled and a new round called for July 1979 Guevara again supported Paz. In the elections Guevara was elected to the Senate from Cochabamba. Subsequently, he was elected President of the Senate from which position he became interim president of Bolivia when the Congress was unable to choose between either of the two leading vote getters in the July elections, Hernan Siles or Victor Paz.
In his early years Guevara was known as a leftist and in 1944 he publicly admitted that he was a Marxist and Soviet sympathizer. However, he began to move to the right and in the mid-1950’s he was considered a moderate and by the 1960’s a conservative. When he founded the PRA in 1959 he declared he favored private initiative over economic statism, a responsible and vigorous central government, business-like management of the mining industry, and a labor policy which recognizes that increased productivity is the only non-inflationary source of salary increases. Guevara’s views are not believed to have changed significantly since then.
Hard-working, responsible, realistic, articulate and very intelligent, Guevara is an able negotiator and parliamentarian who gives meticulous attention to detail. He tends to be somewhat pedantic in his manner and at times approaches questions legalistically. Somewhat inscrutable and reserved on first acquaintance, he responds best to directness and simplicity of manner.
Although his strong personal and national pride has sometimes led him to be critical and resentful of the United States, he is generally considered to be friendly toward the US. He speaks good English, in addition to Spanish and French, and in years past was reportedly well-read on matters pertaining to the United States.
Guevara has been married twice. His first wife, Lola Anaya de Guevara, died in the mid-1950’s. His second wife, Rosa Elena Rodriguez de Guevara, was born in Cochabamba and is 60 years old. He has three sons – Walter (37) who attended St. Lawrence University, Ramiro (24) and Carlos (30). Moderate in his personal habits, Guevara drinks socially, enjoys puns, and in years past played poker, handball and golf, although he has not been seen on the golf course in the past two years.
