DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: The Nov 30 economic package announced by the GOB addresses many immediate problems which the GOB is facing. The measures include a 25 percent devaluation, changes in the interest rates for time deposits and bank loans, changes in commercial bank reserve requirements, wage adjustments, hydrocarbon price increases, creation of a Monetary Stabilization Council, and limitations on GOB public sector expenditures. Much to the dissatisfaction of the commercial bankers, the Central Bank has not completed regulations for the implementation of the new measures. End summary.
Decree 17123. This decree authorizes the Central Bank to make future exchange rate adjustments while maintaining a two percent difference between the buy and sell rate to cover transaction costs. The decree does not mention the new exchange rate; Minister of Finance Augusto Cuadros Sanchez announced that the GOB had devalued the peso 25 percent setting the new buying rate at 24.51 pesos to the dollar. This decree clearly facilitates future exchange rate adjustments which bankers and the local IMF representative Jorge Sol Perez consider inevitable. The procedure–whether mini-devaluations or infrequent movements of some magnitude–will be the decision of the GOB and will certainly take into account political considerations and the social impact. Until it becomes clear to what extent the Central Bank will honor foreign exchange obligations of the commercial banks and money exchange houses, these institutions are limiting sales of foreign exchange. Although there is no “run” on the financial institutions, the demand exceeds previous normal levels; only a relatively small percentage of customers are being turned away. So far exchange rate expectations of larger firms in the private sector appear mixed. One of the larger customers of one US bank, converted about $US 600,000 to pesos on Dec 3. National banks report, however, that speculation continues; larger firms have not brought back all of the large amounts of dollars converted from pesos before the devaluation.
The Decree 17123 requires all exporters from the private and public sector to deliver 100 percent of their export earnings to the Central Bank. Only transactions fees and royalties paid in foreign exchange need not be turned over. The decree also stipulates that public sector agencies and the state enterprises cannot maintain foreign exchange accounts either in Bolivia or outside; any such funds must be delivered to the Central Bank by Dec 10, 1979. All foreign exchange transactions must pass through the Central Bank, which must be informed of the agencies’ monthly foreign exchange requirements. One banker indicated that these restrictions on the public sector agencies were to avoid a recurrence of the large purchases (estimated to be up to $US 60 million) of foreign exchange for speculative purposes which took place the last days of the Natusch regime.
Decree 17123 forbids banks and money exchange houses from maintaining accounts outside of Bolivia. It also sets the following new limits on total commercial bank short and medium term foreign credits replacing those established by Decree 15719 based on total credits in June 1978:

Banks surpassing their limits will have their reserve requirement in foreign exchange increased by 100 percent of the excess. It is expected that the Central Bank will allocate individual bank credit ceilings based on their Oct 1979 foreign lines of credit. One banker pointed out that these ceilings will harm the big banks with large existing lines and will be to the advantage of the new, small Bolivian banks. One US banker said the ceilings would have almost no effect on his operations since the local branch acts as an agent between his bank’s branches outside of Bolivia and local firms seeking direct lines of credit. The availability of foreign exchange for payment of foreign debt obligations is of greatest concern to both US and foreign bankers. Most believe that, recognizing the importance of maintaining good relations with foreign commercial banks, the Central Bank will not be too stringent, but will examine each loan on an individual basis for proper registration with the Central Bank. One banker noted that Central Bank record keeping is so poor that he doubts that many loans which his bank took care to register properly will be located on Central Bank records; thus he feels the verification process could be long and involved. According to a US banker, the Central Bank, which did not require registration of direct credit lines to Bolivian firms, may now restrict sales of foreign exchange to firms to preclude any new lines of credit or even a drawing down of existing lines.

Decree 17123 discontinues, as of Nov 30, 1979, the maintenance of value clause for peso savings accounts and peso certificates of deposit. During the first 15 days of March 1980 and perhaps sooner, account holders qualifying for maintenance of value guarantees, will be paid the difference in pesos at the Nov 30 exchange rate. DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

I reviewed structure and substance of Mexico City Foreign Ministers meeting with Dr. Marcelo Ostria, Director General of the Bolivian Foreign Ministry’s Division of International Political Affairs. I covered the same ground that I did with the Foreign Minister on Feb. 12 but in more detail. Ostria took notes and was pleased to receive the information which he indicated he would use to guide the Foreign Minister’s conduct and substantive conversations in Mexico.
Ostria said Bolivia understands that it will not play a significant role in the Mexico City Conference, given the power of others and the aggressiveness of a few. He expressed a great interest in having the conference arrive at a consensus that aid providers give preference to assistance to the poorer countries in the region. He feels this is not a bilateral issue in its totality and thus can be raised in a multilateral meeting.
As to bilateral matters, Ostria noted that the U.S. and Bolivia have no specific problems, that relations are excellent and that if any minor matters needed to be discussed bilaterally, it is the policy of the Bolivian Government to raise them with the Embassy here in La Paz.
Ostria then briefly touched on a personal idea of his which is long-range achievement of a satisfactory access to the sea by Bolivia based on improving relations with Chile. He said in confidence that the Ministry has an indication that the Chilean Foreign Minister may take the initiative in Mexico to meet with Foreign Minister Guzman to attempt to set the stage for improvement in Bolivian/Chilean relations. Ostria said it is hoped that over time this could be converted into some tangible settlement of Bolivia’s long felt need for a seacoast. He noted another personal idea that some time in the future one or two of the larger countries in the region might wish to lend good offices to assist Chile, Peru and Bolivia in reaching some satisfactory accord.
Ostria is a bright, articulate, friendly career Bolivian diplomat with whom the Embassy has had close and effective working relations for some time. In our view, he will be the key member of the Bolivian delegation.

title: Pereda’s Plans
text:
Date:
          August 01, 1978
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Immediate 1935
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 /001 W ——————039362 020104z /64 O 011710z Aug 78
        
                    
          Subject:
          Pereda’s Plans
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          STATE 193264
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

I met with Pereda for one hour at Colonel Natusch Busch’s home and with Natusch for another hour. (The role of Natusch, one of the few charismatic figures in the military, is not clear. A Banzer loyalist but personal friend of Pereda, Natusch berated Pereda on coup day for his disloyalty to the military and his damaging of Bolivia’s international image through an ill-conceived coup. Subsequently, however, Natusch has been helping Pereda pick up the pieces and urging him to save the situation by new elections in 1979.)
Pereda’s main message was that he needed to change his tactics to get military support but that the basic plan was to proceed with announcement of a new election plan, on August 6, if at all possible (although this date is no longer firm). Pereda said that there was opposition to elections, even plotting among some of the “generational” officers. He had decided that a meeting of unit commanders in La Paz was not the way to win over these officers–especially since all of them would not be represented. He had decided, therefore, to cancel the meeting and instead to make a personal whirlwind trip around the country to talk to all of the officers of each of the major units. He said he would meet today (August 1) with La Paz units (mostly Banzer loyalists) and leave tonight on a four-day trip around the country, returning Saturday, August 5. If all went well, we would still go ahead with his speech on August 6.
Pereda described his main problem among some younger officers as exaggerated fear of the left and concern that early elections meant turning over the country to Hernan Siles and his, inter alia, communist supporters. If that was the problem, I said, it ought to be possible to make the point that nothing would strengthen the position of the left more than a protracted period of de facto government and continuing growth of anti-military sentiment which the left was obviously better at exploiting than anyone else. Both Pereda and Natusch said they agreed with this and thought the points could be made, but more effectively in a series of unit meetings than in a large meeting of commanders.
Pereda wanted me to review the US position, stressing that soon US support was going to be needed to consolidate support behind a political plan to avoid chaos. I reviewed our interest in a) early elections and b) internal peace and stability in Bolivia so its people could progress. I said we saw these two as related since a credible plan for return to democratic rule was the best means to gain the needed cooperation of all political elements in the transition process. Pereda said he agreed and that he needed not only cooperation in a political plan, but also tolerance for tough economic measures. He mused that he still faced a difficult time between now and announcement of a new election plan.
I once again raised the question of whether elections in 1979 would not be the best rallying point for national unity. Natusch opined that he thought 12-18 months from now was the right time for elections. Pereda was noncommittal, pointing out that the military hurdle was now the critical one to get over.
Pereda asked several questions on US “recognition” and aid. I reviewed our position on affirmation of relations as previously presented to Tapia. I also told him that we had not made final decisions on FY78 aid, but that if all went well it would still be possible to sign some aid assistance in August, if this would be helpful in consolidating a good democratization plan.
Comment. Pereda obviously does not have all his ducks lined up yet for any election plan. He is working hard on this, but his own weak position and the bitter legacy of the coup are serious disadvantages. Boeker

UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: A procedural dispute over selecting the leadership of state-owned corporations has somewhat marred President Walter Guevara’s honeymoon with the Congress that elected him. As the executive and legislative branches thus shake down to one another, the major political groups are beginning to try to organize themselves for next year’s elections. Although the UDP, the MNR Alliance and the ADN have all publicly expressed optimism about the political future, their real perspectives are considerably more complex. The UDP is still plagued by the internal tensions that almost pulled it apart earlier in the year; the MNR Alliance has not yet found a way of accommodating the ambitions of some of its younger (albeit middle-aged) leaders; and the ADN, chiefly concerned with the anti-Banzer accusations in Congress, may maneuver for elections in 1981, instead of next year. The armed forces, in the meantime, have accomplished their retreat to the barracks smoothly. Against this background, attention is now beginning to focus increasingly upon the labor sector, which is still considering how–or whether–to press its demands for significant wage hikes. End summary.
In the past two weeks, the interim government of President Walter Guevara and the Congress that elected him have begun to shake down to one another. Relations between the two entities, generally speaking, have been tentative and cordial. On August 23, however, a confrontation erupted when Guevara decided to fill several upper-level positions at COMIBOL, the state mining corporation, without bothering to consult the Chamber of Deputies first, in accordance with Act 62 of the Constitution. Crying foul, the deputies promptly issued a resolution pointing out that it was the lower house’s constitutional prerogative to submit a list of three candidates for “social and economic” positions in all state corporations. Later that same evening, Guevara responded, in effect, with a demurrer. He acknowledged that the legislature’s rights were as stated and said that he had no intention of usurping them. But, he added, allowances must be made for the special circumstances that obtain during a “transitional” government. The appointments, therefore would stick. In response, the deputies threatened interpellation of ministers, which prompted the President to seek a meeting with the leadership of both houses and reach an accommodation. There will be no interpellation as such, but ministers will agree to present reports on their activities to the Congress. In return, the government will henceforth respect the legislature’s prerogatives under Article 62 to submit three nominees for top managerial jobs in the state enterprises. (Comment: Guevara appears to have made a tactical error by overlooking the legislative prerogative, probably by oversight rather than design. The issue now appears to have been satisfactorily accommodated, but the new Congress made its point and has effectively served notice on the government. Despite the flare-up between executive and legislature, however, the honeymoon appears to continue on course. End comment).
As the government and the Congress feel their way forward, the major political groups have begun to reorganize and to look toward the future. Spokesmen for the MNR, the UDP and the ADN have publicly proclaimed that Victor Paz Estenssoro, Hernan Siles and Hugo Banzer will again head their respective slates in the elections scheduled for May 4 next year. Underlying these proclamations, however, are considerably more complex realities.


The UDP, as earlier in the year, is experiencing internal strains. The mainstay MNRI party is divided on whether to permit Siles to run again with an MIR vice presidential candidate. The Moscow-line Communists (PCB) share these re-emerging reservations about the MIR, while the MIR members themselves have not resolved whether their standard bearer next round should be Jaime Paz (as in 1979) or Antonio Aranibar, currently a lower house deputy. Another point of contention is the scope of the next elections: the MNRI wants them to be general, rather than simply for President and Vice President; the Communists, on the other hand, do not want to risk their newly-won congressional seats.
The MNR Alliance is hardly more unified. Victor Paz remains the “indispensable” leader, but, according to a good source, he refuses to allow an objective review of 1979 election errors. Moreover, he remains resistant to “generational” pressures from ambitious young leaders such as Robert Jordan

title: President Banzer Announces New Concept Of Government
text:
Date:
          April 08, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Priority 2781
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Pm-07 H-03 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Nsc-07 Pa-04 Rsc-01 Prs-01 Sp-03 Ss-20 Usia-15 Aid-20 Come-00 Eb-11 Lab-06 Sil-01 Drc-01 /134 W ——————— 008365 P 082150z Apr 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          President Banzer Announces New Concept Of Government
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, PFOR, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Since at least November 1973, when President Banzer decided to ignore the desires of Dr. Paz Estenssoro and appoint MNR cabinet members of Banzer’s own choosing, the President has been engaged in a deliberate policy of weakening the voice and influence of the two major political parties (FSB and MNR) making up the so-called Nationalist Popular Front (FPN).
The FPN has not been an effective governing mechanism. On the contrary, the allocation of fixed numbers of government ministries to the FSB and the MNR and the need to give priority to political patronage in making all appointments to government office (national and local) had created an unwieldy, largely ineffectual bureaucracy. In turn, the two parties – entrenched in their ministries, with their smaller bureaucratic followings – hampered the implementation of development programs and contributed to a generalized discontent in the body politic, including within the military establishment.
The President has now taken the opportunity to at last disengage from the FPN scheme of government by seizing upon the national concern for an outlet to the sea, making this issue the vehicle for a campaign to achieve national political unity and the end of political partisanship. By one major initiative: the Gran Consulta Nacional in Cochabamba, the President wrested approval from most of the political personages assembled (including representatives of the FSB and the MNR) for a free hand in reorganizing the government without regard to political party concerns. In addition, he orchestrated – by prior arrangement – the presentation of a document by the Armed Forces which called for the very program of action eventually adopted by the meeting. The rationale behind giving the President a free hand to reorganize the government along non-partisan, technical lines is that Bolivia must be economically strong and politically stable if it is to succeed in the eventual negotiations for a sea outlet.
To help the Executive in its development tasks, a National Consultative Council will be nominated, consisting of approximately fifty persons of national stature, to draw up policy papers recommending approaches to a broad spectrum of political, economic, and social problem areas. On the political side, this Council will devise a formula to encourage the formation of a single party of National Reconciliation, which will gather together all those elements who are neither of the extreme left nor extreme right. The model is likely to be that of the PRI in Mexico. In any case, direct popular elections are not likely to be held in the foreseeable future; rather, some method of indirect election or referendum may be devised to effect a succession in the office of President sometime in 1975.
There will be a number of cabinet changes in the next week or two which will see some MNR and FSB ministers depart the scene. The caliber of the new cabinet appointments, as well as the representative character of the appointments to the National Council, will be important in assessing the degree of support the President can expect in the future from the Armed Forces and key civilian opinion-makers.

In any event, however, we may expect that elements in both the MNR and the FSB – who recently argued in favor of their parties’ withdrawal from the dying FPN – will now advocate the political advantage of distancing themselves from a government in which the two parties no longer have a significant role to play.
The PDC-PRA did not sign the so-called “Declaration of Cochabamba.” Guevara Arze’s comments decrying the lack of meaningful debate or dialogue at the Cochabamba meeting have put him at the head of the dissenting faction in the new political scheme of things. If, in spite of this dissent, he is still appointed to the National Council (as an expert in foreign relations), the prospects of eventually organizing single political force would be improved.
Although we have not received any news of organized opposition or protest over these political developments, the GOB evidently decided to take no chances and proceeded to arrest about 15 labor leaders as a preventive measure.

title: Foreign Ministers’ Meeting Mexico
text:
Date:
          February 08, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 2218
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Pm-07 H-03 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Nsc-10 Pa-04 Rsc-01 Prs-01 Spc-03 Ss-20 Usia-15 Sam-01 Drc-01 /100 W ——————— 115284 R 082006z Feb 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Foreign Ministers’ Meeting Mexico
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PFOR OCON XM MX BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Bolivian interest increasing in Foreign Ministers’ meeting with Secretary Kissinger. News stories and commentaries appearing in La Paz press almost daily. Meeting and its importance being noted to mission personnel by leading Bolivians. Foreign Ministry officials state they working hard on positions for each agenda item and hope to have constructive and active Bolivian participation in sessions. Embassy believes Bolivian delegation will be helpful in conciliatory role and in drafting committees where felicitous choice of phraseology is important.
Major recurring theme, virtually a consensus, is belief that meeting with Secretary Kissinger is major opportunity to strengthen US-Latin relations. Most Bolivians express open admiration for Secretary’s accomplishments and for his boldness in tackling and solving seemingly impossible international problems.
While we are gratified by rising attention to Foreign Ministers’ meeting, there is risk that Bolivians may be expecting something dramatic to occur in our relations immediately and thus may be disappointed if results of meeting do not match their aspirations. Other difficulty in local interest about meeting with Secretary is generalized assumption that he will “solve” Cuban problem. Although official GOB policy remains anti-Cuba, which most Bolivians share, there is often stated view that Cuban problem is ready-made for Secretary’s style of diplomacy.
We sense the following general views of the GOB: A. Poorer nations deserve greater share of lending agencies resources at long-term low interest rates; B. Less developed countries should have preference in markets of industrialized nations; C. Countries producing basic commodities should have guaranteed protection against sudden and sharp drops in prices or compensation mechanism to offset balance of payments losses; D. Arrangements should be made to continue to supply food to those countries having chronic deficit in domestic production of such commodities as wheat; E. Industrialized countries should establish means of holding down prices of machinery exports so that terms of trade will be more favorable to LDCs. F. Some compensation should be awarded Bolivia by other nations from their exploitation of resources from the sea, since Bolivia has been deprived of her seacoast. G. Hemispheric support for Bolivia’s claim to an outlet to the Pacific should be forthcoming in the same way that Panama obtained hemispheric support for its claim against USG.
If Bolivian Foreign Minister were to have bilateral meeting with Secretary Kissinger, he could be expected to make following points: A. Bolivia is friend of U.S.; B. Bolivia is target for international communist agitation to establish new base of intrigue and conspiracy on continent; C. GOB wishes to have another program loan to finance economic and social development projects managed by the Presidency; D. GOB is unhappy at slow deliveries of military equipment in our military assistance programs; E. GOB would like US support of Bolivia’s aspirations to regain a passage to the sea and to have her own seaport; F. Inter-American system should not be dominated by large Latin American countries; G. US should take more active role in hemisphere affairs, stepping up its cultural, military, political, and economic programs, especially in the less developed countries; H. While admitting price of tin currently high, still Bolivia needs such prices. If tin price drops, GSA sales is partly to blame, so US should consider compensation.

Comment: Really key issues for Bolivia are under paragraph 4C and G. No blast on GSA sales from stockpiles anticipated.

text:
Date:
          January 08, 1979

          Oct-01 Ara-11 Iso-00 Int-05 Eur-12 Eb-08 /041 W ——————098311 090740z /14 R 082015z Jan 79

          TAGS:
          EMIN, EIND, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          BONN 00279
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

The Lead-Silver Smelter project being promoted by Klockner is now being reviewed by the GOB. Perhaps because of its size, this project has been the subject of considerable public controversy in recent months. During October the president of Bolivia’s Central Bank stated publicly that he did not believe the price increases demanded by Klockner (most recently from $137 to $150 million) were justified, or that the internal rate of return expected from the investment was sufficient to support the expenditure. Rather than sign the guarantee required for the project, the Central Bank president resigned.
From what we know of evaluations made of the Klockner proposal, which offers Soviet technology that apparently has not yet been applied on a commercial scale, there are grounds for questioning the profitability of this sizeable investment. As Bolivia is now facing a severe financial crunch (debt service may rise to 34 percent of exports in 1979, and the balance of payments deficit in 1978 is estimated at over $100 million, with exports growing at about five percent and imports at 20 percent per year), it is understandable that the new government would wish to examine the project with care.
FYI. It has been widely rumored that substantial financial payments have been made by Klockner or its local representatives to secure approval of this project.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

MINISTER OF INTERIOR PEREDA ANNOUNCED JULY 24 THAT EXILED MAJOR GARY PRADO WAS ARRESTED IN LA PAZ ON THE PREVIOUS EVENING, WHILE ENGAGED IN A SUBVERSIVE MEETING. PEREDA CLAIMED THAT THE GOB HAS PROOF THAT PRADO HAD JOINED FORCES WITH LEFTIST EXILES TO OVERTHROW THE BANZER GOVERNMENT. FIFTEEN OTHER PERSONS HAVE BEEN ARRESTED WITH PRADO, INCLUDING SECOND LIEUTENANT CARLOS PRADO YEPEZ AND TWO PROFESSORS AT SAN ANDRES UNIVERSITY IN LA PAZ. ACCORDING TO PEREDA, GARY PRADO WILL BE SENT INTO EXILE ONCE AGAIN WITHIN A FEW DAYS.
AT THE SAME PRESS CONFERENCE, MININTERIOR PEREDA ALSO REVEALED THE CONTENTS OF AN ALLEGED LETTER FROM EXILED PDC CHIEF BENJAMIN MIGUEL TO HIS FOLLOWERS INSIDE BOLIVIA, IN WHICH MIGUEL DESCRIBES THE PETTY RIVALRIES AND PERSONALITY CLASHES WHICH DIVIDE THE LEFTIST GROUPS IN EXILE IN BUENOS AIRES. ACCORDING TO THIS LETTER, RECENT MEETINGS OF MIGUEL AND PRA CHIEF WALTER GUEVARA ARCE WITH SUCH EXILED BOLIVIA POLITICIANS AS HERNAN SILES ZUAZO, JUAN LECHIN, EX-PRESIDENTS JUAN JOSE TORRES AND ALFREDO OVANDO, ETC., REVEALED THE ANARCHIC STATE OF THE LEFTIST OPPOSITION RESIDENT IN BUENOS AIRES: IN PARTICULAR, THE MIGUEL LETTER COMMENTS SHARPLY ON THE COMPETING ASPIRATIONS OF SILES,

252151Z
TORRES AND OVADO, EACH OF WHOM HARBORS PERSONAL AMBITIONS TO
PRESIDE OVER A FUTURE LEFTIST GOVERNMENT IN LA PAZ. THE LETTER ALSO INDICATES THAT MIGUEL, GUEVARA AND OTHER EXILES HAVE ESTAB- LISHED CONTACT WITH ARMY OFFICERS EXILED FOLLOWING JUNE 5 1970 ATTEMPT.

RESPONDING TO NEWSMENS’ QUESTIONS, PEREDA STATED THAT THE CURRENT STATE OF SIEGE WILL NOT BE EXTENDED BEYOND ITS PRESENT JULY 28 TERMINATION DATE.
COMMENT: WHETHER AUTHENTIC OR FICTITIOUS, THE MIGUEL LETTER COMES AT A CONVENIENT MOMENT FOR THE GOB FOR SEVERAL REASONS. BY PORTRAYING THE LEFTIST EXILES AS A GROUP OF PETTY CAUDILLOS COMPETING SELFISHLY FOR ABSOLUTE POWER OVER THE OPPOSITION TO THE BANZER GOVERNMENT, THE LETTER DISCREDITS THESE FORCES AT A TIME WHEN THE GOB IS SEEKING TO FORTIFY ITSELF FOR THE 1975 ELECTORAL CONTESTS. AT THE SAME TIME, PUBLICATION OF THE LETTER WILL HELP TO ENSURE FURTHER DISSENSION AND CONFUSION IN THE ALREADY DIVIDED RANKS OF THE EXILE MOVEMENT. FINALLY, THE ALLUSIONS IN THE LETTER TO CONTACTS WITH THE JUNIOR OFFICER MOVEMENT REINFORCE THE CASE WHICH THE MINISTRY OF INTERIOR SEEKS TO MAKE AGAINST GARY PRADO, WHILE DISCREDITING THE POLITICAL MOTIVES OF OTHER MEMBERS OF THE “GENERATIONAL” OFFICERS’ MOVEMENT AS WELL. STEDMAN

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Captain Augusto Sanchez, manager of FANAQUINA and GOB’s negotiator on FARMABOL case, called on EMBOFF March 15. He urged that FARMABOL rep Hathorn respond to Sanchez’s last letter of December 20, 1973 and if possible come to La Paz to pursue negotiations.
Sanchez claims to be under considerable pressure from his superiors to settle FARMABOL matter in Bolivian courts. He said FANAQUINA’s lawyer advises that with evidence available, especially inventory comparisons, legal action would almost certainly result in deposit by FANAQUINA of approximately US$ 5,000 with court as settlement. Owners of FARMABOL would then have to seek funds from court in separate action since Sanchez claims FARMABOL never established legal status in Bolivia. EMBOFF observed that lawyer’s suggestion would unnecessarily complicate case at this point and advised delay until negotiations with Hathorn could be resumed. Sanchez agreed.
Sanchez admitted that he has not yet written directly to Hathorn inviting him to return to La Paz but promised to do so immediately. As Department aware, Hathorn’s fiduciary deposit scheme was turned down by GOB financial advisors but Sanchez believes Hathorn can either convince GOB of value of scheme or offer some other proposal. Sanchez himself seems to prefer amicable negotiated settlement rather than legal action in part because he sees possibility of further capitalizations FANAQUINA and other COFADENA projects.
Action requested: Department may wish to inform Hathorn of Sanchez’ expressed desire for continued negotiations, possibility of court action and Sanchez’ invitation.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

As a soldier formed in discipline and daily sacrifice, I shall call everything by its proper name. I come to tell you that in history and in international affairs, there are no miracles. If we do not face up to this harsh reality with discipline and energy implicit in great historic enterprises, we risk the indefinite continuation of that painful frustration which weighs on our conscience.
Here, before the portrait of the great Andes de Santa Cruz and before the tender but energetic eyes of the Madre Patria, having as a witness the flag which flew over our sea coast, I have come to consult with you about the effort and the sacrifices that the Bolivian people must make, with the dignity which is part of our nature, in order to regain the sea which belonged to Bolivia, and that by the force of logic and justice will definitely be Bolivian again.
I have come to consult with you about the possibility of uniting all Bolivians about the armed forces of the nation in order to attain the historic goal of returning to the sea. Unity within a framework of shared rights and obligations, with strong ties of solidarity and mutual respect, in the common hope of having a prosperous country which enjoys dignity and a connection to the rest of the world.
I have come to consult with you about the general effort which has to be made to attain the development that will permit us to “return to the sea”. Development which includes all aspects of our society, that will be a permanent process to improve and change the economy, culture and politics of the country. But above all, development to give all Bolivians what has been denied for so long: the means by which they can live happily, with faith in the future.
For my government, mere economic growth has little meaning; the greater volume of investments we receive, the use of advanced technology, the use of our natural resources, acquire historic value only insofar as they respond to the needs of the Bolivian people.
I have come to consult with you about the creation of new mechanisms of political participation which will permit us to strengthen the structures of the state for a “return to the sea”.
(I ask for) participation of the broadest sectors of the people in the awareness of discussion about national problems.
For my government, participation is a right but it is also a serious responsibility.
It is not just the use of the advantages and benefits deriving from power, nor the obtaining of positions to satisfy personal interest. Participation is a service to the country which requires discipline, honesty, sacrifice and creative passion.
I have come to consult with you about the possibility of establishing a government of national participation in order to “return to the sea”.
I respect the political parties; there exist organizations with tradition and long years of struggle which form a part of our history. I have witnessed the loyal and consistent manner in which the political parties forming the Nationalist Popular Front have acted. From this supra-party institution I have received sincere and devoted cooperation. But the tasks of development, and the subsequent return to the sea, require a general action, a full mobilization of all the people.
None of the political parties alone, no one institution acting separately from other structures, is in a position to be the protagonist in the creative adventure of development.
The return to the sea requires the conscientious and willing unity of all Bolivians.
A society such as the one we are seeking must widen participation, but at the same time define the norms of social conduct so that such participation will be useful and not disruptive.
Considering that the best of the Bolivian people and a small but worthy representation of Bolivian women is represented here, I have come to talk to you with the responsibilities of a governor who is concerned about the future, with the clarity and sincerity of a man who loves his country with a hard and demanding love, with the modesty of a soldier formed for duty and sacrifice, and with the hope of being understood in the exact meaning of my ideas and concerns.
I ask you for the first time to put aside personal or group interests and to consider the interests of the country, let us make here, at this place, before the Madre Patria and the memory of those who have given their lives fighting against injustice, the decision we are bound to make as men and as Bolivians.
What I ask for is unity, development and national participation, based upon the responsibility we have toward future generations.
In the awareness of the challenge that this consultation implies, I am prepared for any sacrifice that may be necessary, including my withdrawal from the high mission that has been bestowed upon me.
Gentlemen: Our land-locked situation is old, but the conscience of this land-locked situation and the decision to return to the sea is ours today. Let us do everything possible so that later we shall not share the bitter frustration of those who do not wish to work for the fatherland. STEDMAN

122050Z

LA CORTE SUPREMA HA DADO UN EJEMPLO DE INDEPENDENCIA AL IMPONER LA LEY FRENTE AL PRIMER MANDATARIO. MAS ADELANTE AIRMA QUE: “POR DURA QUE PAREZCA LA PRUEBE DE WATERGATE, ES MAS ETICA Y BENIGNA QUE LOS DERROCAMIENTOS DE GOBERNANTES, MENUDO BRUTALES Y SANGRIENTOS QUE CARACTERIZAN A LAS PSUEDO DEMOCRACIAS, PARA NO HABLAR DE LOS REGIMENES TOTALITARIOS EN LOS QUE EL PODER ABSOLUTO DE LOS QUE GOBIERNAN SE NUTRE IMPLACABLEMENTE DE LA LIBERTAD, LOS DERECHOS Y LA VIDA MISMA DE LOS GOBERNADOS. WATERGATE ENCIERRA ENSENANZAS QUE TODOS LOS GOBERNANTES DEBERIAN RECOGER”. EL TABIOIDE “HOY” EN SU EDITORIAL DEL SABADO 10, AL REFERIRSE A LA REUNCIA DEL PRESDIDENTE NIXON, DICE: “LA PIEDAD, SIGNO CONTRARIO A LA CRUEIDAD, ES SENTIMIENTO QUE ENNOBLECE AL QUE LO ABRIGA. SERA EL QUE CONVENGA INSPIRAR LOS JUCIOS QUE SE HAGAN SOBRE EL PRESIDENTE REUNCIANTE”…“LAS PALABRAS DE SU DISCURSO DE DESPEDIDA DE LA CASA BLANCA SON PRUEBA DE LO QUE LE GUIO POR SOBRE TODO EL BIEN DE SU NCION. LASTIMA QUE NO HAYA PENSADO ASI CUANDO TOMO PARTE EN LOS ENTREVEROS DE WATERGATE. SE PERDIO UN PERSONAJE, PERO SE SALVO LA DEMOCRACIA”. EN OTRO EDITORIAL PUBLICADO EL DOMINGO ULTIMO, “HOY” DICE QUE “HABRA QUE TENER CONFIANZA EN QUE LA POLITICA (DE ESTA DOS UNIDOS) CON LA AMERICA LATINA HA DE SEGUIR EL MISMO RITMO DE BUEN ENTENDIMIENTO Y COOPERACION. MAS CONCRETAMENTE,
122050Z
PREGUNTADO EL SECRETARIO KISSINGER POR LOS PERIODISTAS, CONTESTO QUE “NADA HA CAMDIADO DESDE WASHINGTON, MEXICO Y ATLANTA” REFIRIENDOSE SIN DUBA A LOS COLOQUIOS HABIDOS CON PAISES LATINOAMERICANOS EN ESOS TRES LUGARES. SE REFIRIO TAMBIEN A SU POSIBLE VISITA A ALGUNO DE ELLOS. LO QUE QUIERE DECIR QUE PROSEQUIRA EL DIALOGO EN LOS MISMOS TERMINOS ESTABLECIDOS, QUE HAN SIDO LOS DE BUENA AMISTAD Y LEAL AYUDA POR PARTE DE LA NACION DEL NORTE”.

title: Bolivia’s Oil Import Problem-A Brazilian Solution?
text:
Date:
          March 10, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState 5166
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Com-02 Soe-02 Aid-05 Cea-01 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Eb-08 Doe-15 H-01 Inr-10 Int-05 L-03 Nsae-00 Nsc-05 Omb-01 Pm-05 Ica-11 Oes-09 Sp-02 Ss-15 Str-08 Trse-00 Acda-12 /136 W ——————115732 120109z /15 R 101335z Mar 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          Bolivia’s Oil Import Problem-A Brazilian Solution?
        
                    
          TAGS:
          ENRG, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: A combination of Bolivia’s rapidly worsening balance of payments predicament and serious financial problems in YPFB is spurring efforts here to find a way to avoid the country’s again becoming a net petroleum importer. One possible medium-term solution being discussed within the GOB is a petroleum swap with Brazil.
The Problem: Although declining, Bolivia’s current crude production is approximately 31,000 BPD while consumption totals only 24-25,000 BPD. Nevertheless, the extreme lightness of Bolivian crude requires that the entire production be refined in country to supply needed heavy components. However, as consumption continues to rise (it has been increasing at 10 percent annually) and production declines, a point will be reached where local crude production will fail to provide the necessary 10,000 BPD of diesel, kerosene, jet fuel and fuel oil. This could occur as early as mid-1979 even though at that point domestic crude production will still substantially exceed domestic crude consumption. (Bolivia halted crude exports, all of which had been going to Argentina, in October 1978.)
The resulting 2,000-3000 BPD heavy fuel shortfall: Beginning some time during the latter half of this year could, of course, be dealt with by importing either crude or heavy product. However, importation presents a major transportation problem. The existing La Paz to Arica (Chile) pipeline is largely gravity operated and to reverse the flow would require a substantial new investment in pumping equipment. The only other transport alternatives – a narrow gauge railroad from Arica and an often impassable parallel highway– present their own serious problems.
A Brazilian solution? Faced with intermittent gasoline shortages in Western Mato Grosso, Petrobras has privately offered YPFB a trade: Brazilian crude for Bolivian gasoline on a barrel-for-barrel basis. However, according to Bolivian government sources, the Brazilian offer has, at least for now, been declined. The reason given is that with Bolivian gasoline worth more than an equal volume of Brazilian-supplied crude, the deal is inequitable.
Comment: The GOB could of course continue to export its excess gasoline and use the resultant foreign exchange to buy crude. But transportation remains a problem unless Petrobras agrees to simply sell crude rather than swap it for gasoline, a deal the Brazilian entity is reportedly presently unwilling to make. In spite of YPFB head Col. Jose Patino’s initial rejection of the proposed Petrobras swap, it is likely the deal (perhaps sweetened somewhat by the Brazilians) will look increasingly attractive as the need to import the first shipment of crude approaches. In part, the appeal of the Petrobras offer is that a swap will avoid highlighting the continuation of the GOB’s present subsidy of domestic fuel consumption. Importing world-market crude or product at higher unit prices than the fuel is resold for domestically will dramatize the subsidy and embarrass the GOB with local and foreign critics of its economic policies. By contrast, a swap would be far less dramatic and may well in the end prove irresistible to a government which is both loathe to raise fuel prices and embarrassed to highlight the fact that the country’s once widely-touted oil wealth is no longer sufficient to fulfill even its own needs.

Gonzalo Gutierrez, director of metallurgy in Ministry of Mining and Metallurgy, called on Emboff and asked embassy help to obtain 6 to 9 month technical assistance to ministry in connection with World Bank loan of US$ 6,200,000 of which US$ 350,000 is destined to set up following sections in ministry: (1) Sectorial planning regarding mining industry development; (2) Documentation center carrying all information on mines; (3) Taxation system involving search for best mining taxation method to be used in Bolivia; and (4) Prefeasibility study on mineral exploration.

title: Victor Paz Exiled
text:
Date:
          January 09, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Immediate 1888
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Sso-00 Nsce-00 Usie-00 Inre-00 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Pm-07 H-03 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Nsc-10 Pa-04 Rsc-01 Prs-01 Spc-03 Ss-20 Aid-20 Drc-01 /104 W ——————— 054575
        
                    
          Subject:
          Victor Paz Exiled
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          LA PAZ 110
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

The Ministry of Interior announced that on January 8, Victor Paz Estenssoro, MNR chief, along with the following of his aides–Julio Garret Ayllon, Eduardo Olmedo, Eufronio Amurrio, Jose Ugarte Calvi and Juan Loayza were detained and exiled to Paraguay. Charges against the exiles were (in paraphrase): A) Attempt to change the nature of the Revolution of August 1971; B) Attempt to create divisions within the Armed Forces and Police; C) Systematic agitation among the ranks of organized labor to create anarchy and social discord; D) Unwillingness to accept the responsibility these persons had in the passage of the so-called economic package last October-November; E) Contact with the extreme left both within and outside of the country with patently subversive purposes; and F) Extortion of funds from industry for conspiratorial ends. (Note: This last charge evidently refers to the MNR campaign to raise contributions from party members and the public to defray the costs of the proposed convention.)
Also on January 8, Ciro Humboldt issued a communique announcing his assumption of the duties of MNR chief ad interim. Dr. Humboldt stated that he has warned VPE of the need to work for party and national unity but that his efforts had been in vain. Humboldt, with an extraordinary display of cynicism, then criticized VPE for passively accepting his exile and abandoning his followers. Humboldt also announced the postponement of the MNR convention until August 1974. At the same time, the various dissidents to VPE’s leadership, issued a communique in the name of the MNR criticizing Dr. Paz’ autocratic rule and pledging the party’s support to the FPN and President Banzer. Among dissident leaders signing this document were Humboldt, Executive Secretary Ruben Julio, Secretary General Juan Jose Rivero and the MNR ministers in the GOB.
The meeting of Dr. Paz with the Minister of Interior in the morning of January 8 (see reftel) was attended by ranking officers of the Armed Forces so it is clear that the decision to exile the MNR leader had the backing of the upper echelons of the military institution.
It is possible that other followers of Dr. Paz may be exiled in the near future.
Comment: With the exile of VPE, the leader of Bolivia’s largest political party, the government of President Banzer will appear more authoritarian than at any time in the past, both at home and abroad. It remains to be seen, but it appears unlikely that the public will accept the Humboldt-led party as the true MNR. Thus, the military, already considered the significant force behind the administration, will be awarded the primary responsibility for the accomplishments and failures of the Banzer government. This, in turn, should increase the military’s interest in the day-to-day operations of the government. It would appear that although Banzer has removed a rival of great skill, he has limited his room for political maneuver and increased further his already significant dependence on the Armed Forces. Although we do not foresee any imminent political upheavals resulting from this action, there is some concern that the decapitation of the political middle ground may have longer term consequences of polarizing political activity in Bolivia between far right and far left.

title: Petroleum: Production Declines
text:
Date:
          November 27, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 9476
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ara-11 Ads-00 Aid-05 Cea-01 Ciae-00 Com-02 Dode-00 Doe-17 H-01 Inr-10 Int-05 L-03 Nsae-00 Nsc-05 Omb-01 Pm-06 Ica-11 Oes-09 Sp-02 Ss-15 Str-08 Trse-00 Acda-12 /133 W ——————042274 010208z /64 R 271850z Nov 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          Petroleum: Production Declines
        
                    
          TAGS:
          ENRG, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Figures recently made public by YPFB show petroleum production here during January-September 1979 fell 15 percent compared to the same period in 1978. (During the first three quarters of this year YPFB produced 7.61 million barrels; during the same nine months last year production was 8.96 million.)
With the country’s oil production-consumption currently in rough balance (see para 4), further production slippage would soon require Bolivia to begin using its ever scarcer foreign exchange to import costly spot market crude and/or product. However, that painful step may not be necessary in the short or medium run. Increasingly strong inductions are that Dallas-based Tesoro Petroleum’s La Vertiente field in southern Bolivia could soon produce enough petroleum to allow YPFB to avoid imports. After having drilled five holes on the structure (one which, ironically, YPFB drilled unsuccessfully hears ago) Tesoro believes La Vertiente could pump 10 to 12 thousand barrels per day, or one half national consumption. (However, far from being euphoric over their success, Tesoro is seriously worried that it will attract too much attention and generate left-wing sentiment for nationalization.)
Gas marketing remains a problem: It’s increasingly clear that Bolivian hopes of selling additional quantities of higher-priced natural gas to neighboring Argentina are groundless. Moreover, it now appears that the Argentines are unwilling even to agree to a real price hike for the volumes of gas they are now receiving from Bolivia. Recent Argentine gas discoveries support the GOA’s hardline posotion on purchases from Bolivia. The new government is, however, pressing agead with drilling to verify its gas reserves, preparatory to pipeline negotiations with Brazil.
Bolivia’s current supply-demand status: With production falling and demand still increasing Bolivia is still barely able to supply itself with petroleum. By refining all of its current output, YPFB can just supply the country’s demand for diesel, fuel oil and kerosene while producing a modest gasoline surplus.

title: Comment On Applications For Opic Insurance
text:
Date:
          April 10, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 2812
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ara-16 Iso-00 L-03 Come-00 Ftc-01 Sp-03 Aid-20 Eb-11 Nsc-07 Ciep-02 Trse-00 Ss-20 Str-08 Omb-01 Cea-02 Int-08 Agr-20 Ciae-00 Inr-10 Nsae-00 /145 W ——————— 045875 R 102110z Apr 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Comment On Applications For Opic Insurance
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EFIN, EMIN, ENRG, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          (A) LA PAZ 435; (B) LA PAZ 1115; (C) LA PAZ 3126 SUMMARY: EMBASSY RECOMMENDS AGAINST OPIC INSURANCE FOR LONE STAR BOLIVIA GROUP FOR SAME REASONS AS IN UNION OIL CASE, MAINLY THAT OPIC INSURANCE NOT INSTRUMENTAL FOR FIRM’S DECISION AND, ON BALANCE, STILL NOT ADVISABLE DUE TO SENSITIVITY OF SECTOR FROM OVERALL USG POLICY STANDPOINT. EMBASSY MAY RECOMMEND AGAINST INSURANCE FOR NEW JERSEY ZINC ON SIMILAR GROUNDS, BUT LACKS SUFFICIENT INFORMATION. END SUMMARY.
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

On basis of info available to it, Embassy recommends against OPIC insurance for Lone Star Bolivia Group (registration No. 511-74-232) on same grounds on which it based its recommendation against OPIC insurance for Union Oil Co. Embassy’s reasoning is presented in Refs A and B and still appear to be valid. As in case of Union, Lone Star appears quite willing enter into contract in Bolivia without insurance and that it not essential in company’s decision to commit resources over time.
Also on basis limited info now available to it, Embassy may recommend against OPIC insurance for New Jersey Zinc (registration No. 511-74-339). As stated Ref C, para 2, we believe USG now well out or almost out (OPIC still has insurance on SAPI and FNCB interest in COMSUR) of sensitive mining sector, should have bias against insurance for extractive industries and should consider new entries on most carefully selective basis. NJZ appears to have made its decision in advance of assurance that it will have OPIC insurance. It has already paid US$ 240,000 of Tye’s debts (in this case to Banco Minero). In these circumstances OPIC insurance does not appear to be necessary. We view any investment in mining sector as highly risky and greatly exposed to vagaries of Bolivian nationalism.
We suspect GOB will oppose OPIC insurance for NJZ on basis of experience in Mina Matilde settlement in which, even with help of OPIC insured medium term loan, price COMIBOL has to pay increased from US$ 13.4 million to over US$ 18 million due necessity borrowing from banks in order to pay U.S. Steel and Engelhard cash on barrel head.
On other hand, NJZ highly competent and financially strong firm (especially as it is subsidiary of Gulf and Western) and, we understand, is considering taking in strong Bolivian firm, COMSUR, as partners. Huari-Huari Mine is rich and probably will be very rewarding mine if properly developed and adequate mill is constructed to separate zinc, tin and silver from its complex ores. Investment will undoubtedly make strong impact on investment climate, economic development and balance of payments, but, we repeat, investment seems already assured.
Appears that portion of insurance sought by NJZ may cover investments in mine development already made by Frank Tye (Gibraltar Huari-Huari Corp.). Tye reportedly developed about one half million tons of ore.
New factors affecting decisions on mining and hydrocarbons sectors are rising prices and shortages these commodities. These factors usually should tend to induce more investment these sectors without need for OPIC insurance. This appears be true with regard both Lone Star and New Jersey Zinc, but USG may find cases where OPIC insurance desired to help solve problems posed by such shortages.
Embassy investigating Verne Hutchinson Cattle Ranch Project (registration No. 511-74-208) and Clair Peterson Cotton Project (registration No. 511-74-170) and will report.
We note OPIC letters refer to Ministry of Economy which has not existed for several years. Ministry now known as Ministry of Industry, Commerce and Tourism.

title: Pl-480 Wheat And Bolivia
text:
Date:
          January 09, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Immediate 1073
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Aid-20 Iga-02 Agr-20 Eb-11 Come-00 Trse-00 Omb-01 Ss-20 Nsc-10 Spc-03 L-03 Ciae-00 Inr-10 Nsae-00 Rsc-01 Inre-00 Nsce-00 Sso-00 Drc-01 /123 W ——————— 056470 O 092143z Jan 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Pl-480 Wheat And Bolivia
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EAID BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          LA PAZ 15
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Minister of Agriculture, Lt. Col. Natusch Busch, has arranged to call on me Monday, January 14, at 10 a.m. to discuss a matter of great importance. I can only conclude that he wishes to talk about the critical wheat and flour problem in Bolivia. Accordingly, I would very much appreciate having an official position to be able to give him during next week’s meeting.
This morning, January 9, during a courtesy call on the Foreign Minister by Congressman Whalen, I was told by the Foreign Minister how important U.S. cooperation in helping Bolivia with wheat will be in the present critical situation. On January 8, the Subsecretary of the Foreign Ministry, Dr. Cespedes, telephoned me to inquire whether there was any current information on Bolivia’s request for PL-480 wheat. In reply both to the Foreign Minister and the Subsecretary, I said that I had no official reply but I had preliminary indications that the chances were unlikely that there would be any new agreements during the balance of FY 74.
In addition to an official position which I can present to the Minister of Agriculture on January 14, which I hope will provide some help to Bolivia at this critical time, I would like to know what the facts are with regard to supply and demand for US wheat and whether there will be any PL-480 programs at all in this fiscal year and if so, which countries will be receiving allocations. I do not intend to convey this information to Bolivians but would like to have the information for our own understanding of the situation. We recognize the difficulties confronting the agencies in Washington in making determinations under present circumstances but we here feel woefully short of statistics and facts. In another vein, I trust that sympathetic consideration is being given to Bolivia’s request so that helpful alternatives to PL-480 can be offered, if necessary, such as suitable credit.

          LA PAZ 3187
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

TENSIONS ARE RUNNING HIGH IN POLITICAL AND MILITARY CIRCLES ON THE EVE OF THE GEISEL VISIT AND THE SCHEDULED SIGNING OF THE GAS SALES CONTRACT BETWEEN BRAZIL AND BOLIVIA.
THE LATTER, WITH ITS COROLLARY PROSPECTS FOR CREATING A SOUTHEASTERN REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT POLE, DEBATED IN PUBLIC FORA (INCLUDING ESPECIALLY THE PRESS) OVER THE PAST MONTH. IT IS THE KIND OF ISSUE AROUND WHICH PUBLIC OPINION CAN AND WILL POLARIZE, AND IT HAS ALREADY HELPED TO BRING TOGETHER A NUMBER OF HERETOFORE DISPARATE GROUPS OPPOSED TO THE BANZER REGIME.
TENSIONS HAVE BEEN AGGRAVATED IN THE PAST FOUR DAYS BY THE LARGELY UNRELATED DISTURBANCES AT THE UNIVERSITY IN LA PAZ WHERE PROTEST DEMONSTRATIONS INVOLVING THE NAMING OF A NEW RECTOR WERE DISBANDED BY TEAR GAS AND POLICE DOGS (AND POSSIBLY GUNFIRE). A SMALL NUMBER OF STUDENTS HAVE BEEN

221547Z
ARRESTED, AND THE UNIVERSITY HAS BEEN CLOSED INDEFINITELY.

GIVEN THE EXTRAORDINARY SECURITY PRECAUTIONS RELATED TO THE GEISEL VISIT AND THE ALREADY EXISTING STATE OF SIEGE, THE GOVERNMENT IS NOT IN A TOLERANT MOOD AND HAS OVERREACTED TO CRITICISM OF THE PROPOSED GAS SALES CONTRACT. YESTERDAY, FOR INSTANCE, PRA AND PDC CHIEFS WALTER GUEVARA ARZE AND BENJAMIN MIGUEL AND LOCAL MNRI REPRESENTATIVE WERE EXILED FOR THEIR OPEN CRITICISM OF THE CONTRACT. THE MILITARY ARE DIVIDED ON THE ISSUE AND FEELINGS ARE RUNNING HIGH, PARTICULARLY AMONG SUCH INFLUENTIAL YOUNGER ARMY OFFICERS AS LTC RAUL LOPEZ LEYTON, WHO SEE THE CONTRACT AS A SELL-OUT TO BRAZIL.
ALTHOUGH THE SIGNING NO DOUBT WILL TAKE PLACE AS SCHEDULED AND ORDER WILL BE MAINTAINED, THE ISSUE WILL REMAIN. BANZER MAY HAVE TO MAKE SOME OTHER CONCESSIONS TO THE MILITARY TO FORESTALL A SERIOUS WEAKENING OF HIS POWER BASE OVER THIS ISSUE, WHICH HAS SUCH SIGNIFICANT IMPLICATIONS FOR BOLIVIA’S NATIONAL SECURITY. BREWIN

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Embassy transmits with this telegram full text of “Declaration of Cochabamba”, issued on April 5 by the National Consultative Meeting called together by President Banzer in that city:

The institutions and persons invited by the President of the Republic to attend the “National Consultation (Assembly)”, which took place on April 5, 1974 in the city of Cochabamba and who have hereunto affixed their signatures:
Considering that “returning to the sea” is a national, non-partisan desire which requires that all Bolivians take joint action (for its achievement).
Taking fully into account the message of Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez, President of the Republic; the position of the Armed Forces of the Nation; the addresses and suggestions made by the institutions and persons who participated in the National Assembly; the expectations and hopes of the country; the demands of our youth and our duty as men and as Bolivians.
Convinced that the development of the country will be attained only by harmonious development, of a deeply social nature, which will permit us to solve our international problems and face the future in relationship with the general desires of the Bolivian people.
Being prepared to overcome social and political dispersion, to make compatible the interests of the various social sectors with the objectives of the country and to loyally carry out a national political alliance for the execution of concrete tasks related to our prompt return to the sea.
Declare:

First- That the return to the sea is the most important national objective, in which all Bolivians are involved equally.
Second - That in order to attain the national objective of returning to the sea, a general process of development is necessary, which would provide the national state with the capacity to solve its internal problems and face the foreign situation with greater strength.
Third - To commit themselves in maintaining and respecting a political truce and a social peace which will make possible a stable and homogenous historical period.
Fourth - To accept the wider political participation proposed by Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez, President of the Republic, whereby a National Council of Consultation and a Specialized Commission will be established, which will be in charge of studying the problem of Bolivia’s land-locked situation.
Fifth - To agree not to exercise any pressures thereby enabling Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez, President of the Republic, to organize the Executive Power by taking into account the abilities of his co-workers in relation to the great goal of returning to the sea.

By the will of the nationalist institutions and persons who affix their signatures, given in the city of Cochabamba, on the fifth day of April in the year nineteen seventy-four.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

On March 19 I handed text of following Aide Memoire to Acting President General Guzman in the Presidential Palace:

“The Department of State has informed the Embassy that it has carefully reviewed the Government of Bolivia’s request for financial assistance for the reconstruction of flood damage. The Department has expressed the view that there should be first an assessment of the flood damage and the requirements for reconstruction, and that this analysis be conducted with the assistance of representatives of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the Inter-American Development Bank, as well as the Agency for International Development. The Department suggests that the Government of Bolivia consider requesting perhaps through the auspices of CIAP, the multilateral agencies to undertake a joint survey. In any event, the United States is willing to provide experts from AID Washington to assist the Government of Bolivia in this assessment.
“After the assessment of damage and of reconstruction requirements is completed, the Department believes that it could form the basis for a Bolivian Government request for assistance to the financial agencies located in Washington. The United States believes that the IBRD and IDB have resource availabilities sufficient to assist in Bolivian reconstruction without serious distortion of their programs elsewhere. This would not be the case with AID assistance. For AID, any significant financing for reconstruction might necessitate a special authorization and appropriation from the United States Congress. Given the history of Congressional responses to such requests, it appears that the only way AID would be able to help in the near term in reconstruction efforts would be within the existing funding levels. This would mean that assistance for flood reconstruction would have to be subtracted from planned development lending programs. A decision on this would appropriately await the completion of the assessment. Furthermore, the implementation plans for AID loans planned in FY 75 could be designed to have maximum effect in support of reconstruction efforts. The Government of Bolivia may also wish to consider the feasibility of reprogramming local currency generated by prior PL-480 sales and program loans to cover a portion of the reconstruction effort. The United States will actively support Bolivian requests for the multilateral assessment of damage and to examine with the Government of Bolivia the most feasible means of financing those requirements, including the multilateral agencies.”

In addition to the text of the Aide Memoire, I explained to the Acting President that the Department viewed the reconstruction matter in two phases–the first the assessment and the second the financing. It was our preference that both be conducted by multilateral cooperation. Nonetheless, we were prepared to assist in the assessment without the World Bank and the IDB if that were the GOB desire. I explained the limitations on AID financial assistance in line with the two State telegrams under reference. I noted that press information in La Paz suggested that the Bolivians were already preparing a letter to President McNamara of the IBRD asking for reconstruction assistance for railroads and roads. This, I noted, would be a natural area for the IBRD particularly since they were already contemplating additional financial help for railroads. I noted that Bolivia might well take advantage of a high level IDB mission soon to visit La Paz and the Santiago IDB meeting to discuss with IDB participation in the assessment and subsequent financing of reconstruction effort.
Acting President Guzman thanked me for the reply from Washington to the Bolivian request for reconstruction assistance and indicated that he would discuss our conversation and the Aide Memoire with President Banzer as soon as he could after Banzer’s return to La Paz, scheduled for 6 P.M., March 19. He noted that dividing the operation into two parts made sense and that a survey of the damage and requirements was obviously a logical first step. He indicated his understanding of the limitations on AID financial participation but expressed the hope that even though greater reliance might be placed on IBRD and IDB, some USG financial participation be provided in the reconstruction effort which was so important to the country’s economy.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Would appreciate prompt clarification USG response to request by GOB for $50 million AID loan for flood reconstruction. First, would you be kind enough to inform us what is meant by “We are willing to collaborate with the GOB in assessing flood damage and reconstruction requirements.” Next, would appreciate clarification whether statement in para 3 that we would support reasonable request to IDB and IBRD means that we would not be willing to entertain request to AID. Note that para 2 speaks of “limited development loan resources” but does not preclude receipt for consideration of reconstruction loan request. Finally, I would prefer not to use “Bolivia’s windfall petroleum earnings” in discussing reconstruction assistance with Foreign Minister. While prices for Bolivia’s petroleum exports have risen considerably, there is as yet no guarantee that current prices will hold during the year nor that proceeds from taxation on petroleum will not be required to cover budgetary expenditures and investment needs. I would also like to note that Declaration of Tlatelolco in section 4, para 7 states “The Foreign Ministers agree that one of the principal objectives is the accelerated development of the countries of the Americas and the promotion of the welfare of all their peoples. In this regard, the U.S. accepts a special responsibility; and the more developed countries of the Americas recognize that special attention should be paid to the needs of the lesser developed.” As Bolivia has the lowest GNP per capita of any country on the continent of Latin America, it is viewing with special interest this particular section of the Mexico City Declaration.
I would prefer to be able to state specifically that US will collaborate in assessing flood damage and reconstruction requirements together with IDB and IBRD that assessment could be used as basis for GOB request to IDB and also to IBRD and also to AID. It would also seem logical to me that we suggest to the Foreign Minister that Bolivia make use of the forthcoming CIAP country review to articulate its reconstruction requirements. Min-Coordination told USAID Director he is considering this approach.
Regarding assistance for Coca crop substitution, we have enough to go on in view of Ambassador Handley’s Feb. 25 letter, the recent visit by ARA Narcotics Advisor Shankle, and para 4 of reftel. We are planning to initial an initial analysis through AID funding apart from sector analysis.

The following is the text of message yet undelivered to post regarding the Fourth Amendment to the Title I/III PL 480 Agreement of May 31, 1978.
Begin quote: In accordance with GOB requests and Embassy recommendations, and pending receipt NAC clearance and storage/disincentive determination required by Section 401(B), PL 480, you will be authorized septel exchange with GOB note set forth below, accomplishing Fourth Amendment to Title I/III PL 480 Agreement of May 31, 1978.
Purpose of Fourth Amendment is to respond to GOB need for financing for wheat shipments as soon as possible. Dollar amount allocated this amendment represents first tranche of FY 1980 Title I budget allocation for Bolivia. Balance of FY 1980 budget allocation will be programmed as explained Ref (F). However, during negotiation this amendment it should be noted to GOB representatives that debt arrearage of approximately DOLS 3.0 million, some dating back to November 1977, exists on prior Title I agreements. GOB may encounter USG reluctance to proceed expeditiously with programming further amendments in absence of assurance that steps are being taken to remedy delinquent payments situation.
Specifically, amendment provides DOLS 5.0 million to supply approximately 26,000 metric tons wheat/wheat flour in a Calendar Year 1980 supply period. Usual marketing requirements are extended through CY 1980 at level previously established for CY 1979 and import period is so amended. Export limitations are also extended for CY 1980. During negotiations you may explain to GOB representatives that CY 1980 supply period does not prohibit GOB from initiating purchases during December, with deliveries to begin as soon as possible after January 1, 1980.
Note that before purchase authorization can be issued, USDA/OGSM must receive operational reporting cable marked Priority and pass Agriculture electronically, as required by Ref C, Para 11 C. See Ref D for summary of information required.
Following is text draft note (unnecessary words omitted) which you will be authorized exchange with GOB septel.

Begin Text Note –
Excellency, have honor to refer Agricultural Commodities Agreement signed by representatives of our two governments May 31, 1978, as amended by exchanges of notes dated August 31, 1978 and September 1, 1978, May 2, 1979, and September 13, 1979 and September 24, 1979, and to propose that Part II, Particular Provisions of that agreement be further amended as follows:
A. In Item I, Commodity Table, under appropriate column headings, insert a new line as follows: “Wheat/Wheat Flour (wheat basis) - 1980 - 26,000 - 5.0.” On line entitled “Total”, delete “DOLS 22.8” and insert “DOLS 27.8.”
B. In Item III, Usual Marketing Table, under column headed “Import Period”, change “1979” to read “1979 and 1980.” Under column headed “Usual Marketing Requirement (metric tons)”, change “159,700” to read “159,700 in each year.”
C. In Item IV, Export Limitations, Paragraph A, change “United States Calendar Year 1978 and 1979” to “United States Calendar Years 1978, 1979, and 1980.”
All other terms and conditions of May 31, 1978 agreement as amended, remain the same.
If foregoing acceptable to your government, propose that this note, together with your reply thereto, constitute agreement between our two governments, effective date your note in reply.
Accept, Excellency, etc.
End Text Note

When notes exchanged, notify Washington by immediate cable tagged EAID, and marked AIDAC and pass Agriculture electronically, and forward documents per 11 FAM 723.7. Decontrolled upon exchange of notes. End quote. Vance

Summary: The latest Central Bank estimates of Bolivia’s 1978 balance of payments performance show that imports (FOB) increased 23 percent during the year, while exports (FOB) fell 1.1 percent, and the services account deficit rose by more than 39 percent. These unhappy phenomena gave rise to a current account deficit of $385.1 million. Year-end short-term borrowings, which appear to have amounted to approximately $100 million, held the balance of payments deficit to an estimated $123.3 million.
The Padilla government has not and almost certainly will not adopt economic measures that will arrest the deterioration which is so evident from the 1978 results. Import growth is said to be continuing, and we do not expect a net increase in export earnings. The key to Bolivia’s balance of payments results in 1979 will be the management of the capital account. As disbursements under USAID and World Bank loans are being limited by a shortage of Bolivian counterpart funds, thereby reducing inflows from these sources, the capital account balance will depend heavily upon the government’s success in refinancing debt, in securing new credits, and in maintaining public confidence so as to minimize short term capital flight. To date the Padilla government has not performed effectively in any of these three areas. Although we continue to believe the government has a reasonable chance of muddling through financially until elections, a continuing build-up of arrearages on official debt is possible if credit negotiations are not brought to a successful conclusion, and if creditors ultimately balk at rolling over a major portion of the debt service payments due this year. End summary.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

BOLIVIAN DELEGATION TO THIRD UN LOS CONFERENCE WAS APPROVED BY PRESIDENT BANZER ON MAY 28. CHIEF OF DELEGATION WILL BE GUSTAVO MEDEIROS QUERJAZU, EX-FOREIGN MINISTER AND CURRENTLY A MEMBER OF GOB’S MARITIME COMMISSION. IN LIKELY EVENT THAT MEDEIROS DOES NOT REMAIN IN CARACAS FOR ENTIRE CONFERENCE, ALTER- NATE CHIEF OF DELEGATION: DR. FELIPE TREDINNICK ABASTO, WILL HEAD BOLIVIAN TEAM. TREDINNICK ASSUMED POST AS DIRECTOR OF LOS DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN MINISTRY IN APRIL AND IS BOLIVIA’S LEADING EXPERT ON TECHNICAL QUESTIONS INVOLVING LAW OF THE SEA. OTHER MEMBERS OF BOLIVIA’S FIVE-MAN DELEGATION ARE SERGIO PALACIOS, MANUEL FRONTAURA ARGANDONA AND VICTRO TORRES ACHA. ALL MEMBERS OF DELEGATION HOLD PERSONAL RANK OF AMBASSADOR EXCEPT TORRES, WHO AS SECRETARY-GENERAL OF DELEGATION

01 OF 02 010309Z
WILL HOLD TITLE OF MINISTER-COUNDELOR.

FOLLOWING BIOGRAPHIC DATA ARE PROVIDED ON MEMBERS OF BOLIVIAN DELEGATION. DELEGATION CHIEF MEDEIROS IS ONE OF BOLIVIA’S MOST DISTINGUISHED FORMER DIPLOMATS, HAVING SERVED IN A VARIETY OF DIPLOMATIC ASSIGNEMENTS FROM 1938-1952, AND AGAIN FROM 1964 TO 1969. BORN INTO A PROMINENT SUCRE FAMILY ON OCTOBER 15, 1913, MEDEIROS SUBSEQUENTLY OBTAINED HIS LAW DEGREE IN LOCAL UNIVERSITY AND THEN DID POST-GRADUATE WORK IN ARGENTINA BEFORE EMBARKING ON HIS DIPLOMATIC CAREER. FROM 1938 TO 1952 HE SERVED IN VARYING CAPACITIES WITHIN THE FOREIGN MINISTRY AND IN BUENOS AIRES, SANTIAGO, PARIS, RIO DE JANEIRO, THE UNITED NATIONS, GENEVA AND UNESCO. HIS LAST POST DURING THIS PHASE OF HIS DIPLOMATIC LIFE WAS AS DIRECTOR OF POLITICAL DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN MINISTRY. MEDEIROS RETIRED INTO PRIVATE LIFE DURING ENTIRE PERIOD OF MNR’S RULE IN BOLIVIA (1952-64), SERVING AS PROFESSOR OF CIVIL LAW AT UNIVERSITY OF SUCRE, PRESIDENT OF NATIONAL BANK OF BOLIVIA, LEGAL ADVISOR TO SUPREME COURT AND VICE RECTOR OF UNIVERSITY OF SUCRE. FOLLOWING FALL OF MNR, HE HEADED BOLIVIAN DELEGATION TO UNITED NATIONS, WAS NAMED AMBASSADOR TO ARGENTINA IN MARCH 1965, AND SUBSEQUENTLY RETURNED TO WORK IN FOREIGN MINISTRY FROM NOVEMBER 1968 UNTIL HIS APPOINTMENT AS FOREIGN MINISTER BY PRESIDENT SILES SALINAS ON MAY 5, 1969. MEDEIROS, A MEMBER OF PRESIDENT’S MODERATELY RIGHT-WING SOCIAL DEMOCRATIC PARTY, HELD THIS POST UNTIL OVERTHROW OF SILES IN SEPTEMBER 1969 WHEN HE AGAIN RETIRED INTO PRIVATE LIFE. MEDEIROS SPEAKS FRENCH AND PORTUGUESE, BUT IS NOT BELIEVED TO SPEAK ENGLISH. FURTHER DETAILS ON HIS CAREER MAY BE FOUND IN EMBASSY FS-405 REPORT OF MAY 16,
IN EMBASSY’S VIEW, MEDEIROS’ CHIEF ROLE AT CARACAS IS LIKELY TO BE THAT OF A DISTINGUISHED FIGUREHEAD, AND HE IS UNLIKELY TO BE PRESENT THROUGH ENTIRE TWO-MONTH CONFERENCE. MEDEIROS’ LONG ABSENCE FROM ACTIVE DIPLOMACY AND HIS PERSONAL LACK OF FAMILIARITY WITH LOS ISSUES WILL FORCE HIM TO RELY HEAVILY ON TREDINNICK, WHO WILL ALMOST CERTAINLY PROVE TO BE LEADING BOLIVIAN NEGOTIATOR ON KEY POINTS AT ISSUE.
FELIPE TREDINNICK WAS BORN ON NOVEMBER 30, 1930 OF A BOLIVIAN MOTHER AND AN ENGLISH FATHER. HE HOLDS LAW DEGREE FROM UNIVERSITY OF BRAZIL AND DOCTORATE IN INTERNATIONAL LAW FROM UNIVERSITY OF MADRID. HE CURRENTLY IS PLANNING TO PUBLISH

01 OF 02 010309Z
HIS 500-PAGE DOCTORAL THESIS: “LAW OF THE SEA AND MARITIME FRONTIERS,” IN SPAIN DURING 1975. TREDINNICK’S PREVIOUS KIPLO- MATIC POSTS SINCE JOINING THE FOREIGN MINISTRY IN 1964 HAVE IN- CLUDED MINISTER-COUNSELOR IN BRASILIA AND MADRID, CHIEF OF DELE- GATION TO 1974 LANDLOCKED NATIONS CONFERENCE IN KAMPALA AND CHIEF OF DELEGATION TO GROUP OF 77 LOS CONFERENCE IN NAIROBI. HE IS ALSO A PROFESSOR OF INTERNATIONAL LAW AT SAN ANDRES UNIVERSITY IN LA PAZ, AND ATTENDS CLASSES AT PRESTIGIOUS SCHOOL OF HIGHER
MILITARY STUDIES. TREDINNICK IS FORMER MEMBER OF FSB AND WAS EXILED TO BRAZIL BY MNR FROM EARLY 1950’S TO 1964 FOR HIS POLITICAL VIEWS; HE IS STILL PRO-FSB AND VIOLENTLY ANTI-MNR IN HIS POLITICS. HE SPEAKS PORTUGUESE AND A SMALL AMOUNT OF ENGLISH.

IN RECENT EXTENSIVE CONTACTS WITH TREDINNICK, EMBASSY OFFICERS HAVE FOUND HIM TO BE SERIOUS, DEDICATED OFFICIAL WITH WIDE KNOWLEDGE OF LOS ISSUES. HE HAS BEEN OPEN AND FRIENDLY IN ALL OF THESE CONTACTS, AND APPEARS TO HAVE HIGHLY FAVORABLE ORIENTATION TOWARD UNITED STATES. TREDINNICK STATES THAT MANY OF HIS FAMILY RELATIVES LIVE IN US, WHERE THEY HOLD ANNUAL REUNION IN WILKES-BARRE, PENNSYLVANIA; HE HIMSELF EXPRESSES GREAT INTEREST IN POSSI- BILITY OF VISITING US AT EARLIEST OPPORTUNITY. TREDINNICK’S ATTITUDES TOWARD BRAZIL ALSO QUITE FAVORABLE, IN VIEW OF FACT THAT HIS WIFE IS BRAZILIAN; HE ALSO FEELS FROM HIS OWN EXPERIENCE IN BRAZIL THAT BRAZILIANS MAKE GOOD DIPLOMATS AND ARE FLEXIBLE ENOUGH TO MAKE NEGOTIATION POSSIBLE OVER POINTS OF DIFFERENCE. FROM HIS RECENT EXPERIENCES AT KAMPALA AND NAIROBI, TREDINNICK CARRIED AWAY STRONGLY NEGATIVE RE- ACTION TO PERUVIAN AND CHILEAN DIPLOMATS, WHOM HE CHARACTERIZES AS LACKING ANY BARGAINING FLEXIBILITY AND FREEDOM TO NEGOTIATE. BREWIN

          Gob Negotiations With Imf
