DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: According to IMF team leader Caiola, negotiations between the Fund and the GOB are on track and final action by the IMF should take place by mid-December. Caiola believes that the Central Bank’s reserve position is sufficiently good, providing recent credits from Latin American Central Banks are rolled over, for such a schedule to be feasible. End summary.
Marcelo Caiola, the leader of the IMF team currently negotiating with the GOB, and Jorge Sol Perez, the Fund’s local representative, briefed me Friday afternoon on the current state of the negotiations. Caiola indicated that the negotiations were proceeding well, although they were slowed somewhat by difficulties in obtaining some key data. The appointment this week of Jose Justiniano as Central Bank President is viewed by Caiola as a very positive development.
The present schedule is for Caiola to assemble his analysis and recommendations by September 26 so that they can be discussed by GOB and Fund officials during the IMF/IBRD annual meeting in Belgrade. Agreement on the steps to be taken by the GOB should be reached at the meeting or shortly thereafter. The GOB will then begin to implement the measures, especially those concerning the exchange rate, during November. Caiola will prepare his documentation and submit it to the IMF Board at that time. The Board should take action by December 15.
The financial package Caiola has in mind would include: (A) an Extended Fund Facility drawing of $240 to $280 million disbursed as follows—25 percent in December 1979, 50 percent in calendar 1980 and 25 percent in calendar 1981; (B) a credit of about $250 million probably over five years with two years grace from a syndicate led by Citibank to cover $200 million owed to commercial banks with a little extra for the Central Bank’s reserves; (C) a $30 to $40 million loan by the Fundo Andino; and (D) possibly a $30 to $40 million program loan from the IBRD.
Although the Central Bank’s reserve position continues to weaken, Caiola is confident that with the rollover for 180 days of the $140 million borrowed recently (for 90 days) from the Central Banks of Argentina, Brazil and Venezuela, the drawdown of $50 million lines of credit with commercial banks which the GOB has not yet touched, and a tight credit policy, the timetable outlined in paragraph 5 will be feasible.

          LA PAZ 0179 SUMMARY: DURING COURTESY CALL BY CONGRESSMAN CHARLES WHALEN, JR., (R-OHIO) JANUARY 10, PRESIDENT BANZER EXPLAINED EXPULSION OF VICTOR PAZ AND DISUCSSED BOLIVIA’S ECONOMIC PROSPECTS, NARCOTICS AND U.S. ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. END SUMMARY.
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

President had clear idea of topics he wished to cover and did most of talking in one-half hour interview. He began by explaining that the days of Congressman’s visit were unusual because Bolivia experiencing serious food shortages and political scene was agitated. He related shortages and long lines seen in city to world-wide food crisis. He gave lengthy explanation of political problem stating that after several years of instability Bolivians generally agreed on need for national unity. For that reason Government, including military and two major parties, formed in 1971 and he recently seeking to broaden political base even further by including smaller groups. While most of MNR agreed with this concept, unfortunately Victor Paz did not and sought merely to strengthen his party for 1975 elections. He and small group of associates thus had to be expelled.
President asserted that Bolivia’s economic prospects are good. It has excellent resources in energy, minerals and agriculture and must take advantage of favorable world price situation, which he expects to continue for some years. President said he is confident that with help of contracts with U.S. oil companies, large hydro-carbon deposits will be found. He gave special emphasis to Bolivia’s hydroelectric possibilities which he thought may allow it even to export electricity in future years. He reiterated that economic development requires stability and national unity.
President gave high praise to U.S. economic assistance rendered during his time in office. Both PADES and Emergency Plan have had beneficial social effects. He made special mention of community development assistance which has “changed mentality of campesinos.” As example, he said that in contrast to past, campesinos now arrive with one-half funds in hand and only ask Government grant for other half. In future, Government considering loaning its half on very long terms to encourage this mentality.
Regarding U.S. military assistance, President recalled that he had been encouraged when Ambassador Siracusa had told him that program would be raised from approximate average annual level of US$ one million to US$ four million. U.S. and Bolivian personnel had then drawn up plan for expenditures. President said he is disappointed that plan is not repeat not progressing better. Lack of progress had caused Government to make costly expenditures on its own. New equipment, he explained, is necessary for military morale and for internal “persuasive force” that Bolivia is building up to discourage extremists. “When Communists see that the military force is strong,” he said, “they remain outside country.” Congressman Whalen replied indicating that some in U.S. Congress reluctant to appropriate funds for use for internal security forces, but he wished to study problem raised by President.
As final item, President called attention Bolivia’s new narcotics law, a GOB’s determination to fight problem. President said he does not like to see children of friend being hurt by product produced in Bolivia. He said that Bolivia would need assistance and asked Congressman’s support. Speaking for himself, Mr. Whalen opined that Congress would not hesitate to help worthwhile efforts to stop drug traffic.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: Request amendment of FY 1974 NCAP budget to include additional $15,000 for operating expenses.
The USG under a USAID-Bolivia PROAG paid a monthly bonus to members of the drafting committee of the Bolivian narcotics law for the four months it took that commission to complete its work. The law has been promulgated and it establishes the framework and provides the authorization for a Bolivian narcotics control entity capable of dealing with all aspects of the narcotics problem. However, until the GOB approves funding for this entity it will not come into being, which means that the only narcotics control activity in Bolivia for the remainder of FY 1974 will be that of Major Lopez’ police unit against manufacturers and traffickers of cocaine.
The drafting commission of the law should continue in being, as the only nucleus of expertise on narcotics matters in Bolivia, in order to establish the basic working norms of the various components of the new entity; to travel to the departmental capitals of the country to conduct seminars on the law for local authorities; to act as the original management of the new entity, prepare its budget, select its staff, and generally get it into operation.
This essential activity was not foreseen in preparing the FY 1974 NCAP budget. The additional amount requested includes bonuses for seven officials plus one secretary (total of $5,000 for 5 months beginning February 1 through June 30), travel and per diem expense ($5,000), publicity and communications expense ($2,000), office equipment ($2,000), miscellaneous expenses ($1,000).
Approval of funds to keep the Bolivian members of the narcotics law drafting committee working together on the narcotics problem will maintain the momentum behind the narcotics effort and prevent progress to date from being dissipated through lack of attention. Committee head is Sub-Secretary of Justice Gaston Ledesma who is favorably known in Department.
Would appreciate early decision as group still standing by ready to carry out mission, but may begin to break up soon if lack of sufficient funds leaves it with nothing to do for next few months.

          (A) LA PAZ 8232, (B) LA PAZ 7955, (C) LA PAZ 7871, (D) LA PAZ 7471
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: According to the local IMF representative, Jorge Sol Perez, the Bolivian reserve situation is now extremely critical but with luck the country can survive through December. In 1980, however, Bolivia’s debt service burden will be unsustainable without stabilization measures. The GOB is now studying the IMF proposed stabilization program and is likely to make some counterproposals, some of which Sol Perez has not yet communicated to the IMF headquarters in Washington. The GOB opposes a managed float preferring instead a one-step devaluation with a dual exchange system to lessen the social impact. The GOB realizes that the IMF will be reluctant to support such a plan with Extended Fund Facility (EFF) financing. Sol Perez expects the GOB to request the US to persuade the IMF to accept its proposals. (Note: Sol Perez has acquired this information through informal discussions with GOB officials and he enjoined us in the strongest terms from revealing to others–especially IMF headquarters or the GOB–that we are aware of it.) End Summary.

Bolivia’s Debt Service Burden

The GOB had obligations to repay $142.2 million in short-term loans to foreign central banks and commercial banks between July 1979 and January 1980. (These credits from central banks are not really swaps but rather time deposits at rates of interest ranging from 9.9 to over 11 percent.) The GOB has repaid $10.7 million of these obligations recently. The remaining $131.5 were refinanced for six months and therefore are due between January 1980 and July 1980.
In addition, on the way back from the NAM meeting, GOB Foreign Minister Fernandez stopped in Caracas and obtained $43 million more from Venezuela. The GOB has drawn $20 million of this and has $23 million more at its disposal. The terms are six months at 15 percent. GOB also line up $10 million from the Andean Fund (CAF) for three months at 15 percent and has drawn this down. At the Belgrade IMF/IBRD Annual Meeting (or more likely, the Latin American preparatory meeting in Madrid), the GOB obtained a $20 million line of credit from Spain, presumably also for six months, which it has not yet drawn.
Therefore, the GOB has obligations to repay $161.5 million in short-term debts during the first half of 1980. Moreover, if it draws the additional $23 million from Venezuela and $20 million from Spain before the end of 1979, the total principal to repay by mid-1980 will be $204.5 million. Venezuela has the greatest exposure–about $83 million of these short-term obligations. Deutsch Sudamerikanish Bank has about $39 million and Bankers Trust about $10 million.
According to Sol Perez, Bolivia’s contracted medium and long-term public debt with foreign commercial banks totals $500 million.
Payments on Bolivia’s total medium and long-term public foreign debt (with public and private creditors) will amount to $301 million in principal, interest and commissions during 1980. Payments to foreign commercial banks comprise one-half, or $150 million, of this. Thus, total debt service payments in 1980 are likely to total more than $462.5 million–$161.5 in principal on short-term obligations to central banks (interest will be additional) and $301.0 million for medium and long-term debt– and could exceed $500 million.
The IMF estimates that $462 million represents 51 percent of Bolivia’s projected exports (FOB) in 1980. Since Bolivia’s receipts for non-factor services are minimal, this will give Bolivia a debt service ratio in 1980 of approximately 50 percent.

Bolivia’s Reserve Position

The Central Bank’s gross reserves are now about $150 million. Of this $40-50 million is in non-liquid assets–mostly gold. The $110-100 million remaining consists entirely of “depositores de terceros,” i.e., deposits of state enterprises, and reserve deposits of commercial banks. According to Sol Perez, the Central Bank is playing a dangerous game because the possible combination of large withdrawals by state enterprises (COMIBOL, YPFB or ENAF) plus an increase in purchases of foreign exchange by the Bolivian public could consume this $100-110 million rapidly and force the Central Bank to institute foreign exchange controls or halt sales altogether.
Sol Perez believes the GOB can survive until the end of December (if all goes well) because the 500 percent prior-deposit decree has reduced average net daily foreign exchange losses from about $3 million to $1.5 million. Therefore, losses for November and December are likely to total about $90 million. The Central Bank should be able to sustain this with the $43 million in unused credit from Venezuela and Spain and the $50 million in unused lines from New York commercial banks.

Status of GOB-IMF Negotiations

As reported previously, the IMF’s proposed package for Bolivia comprises several basic measures:


Increase hydrocarbon prices by 130 percent;
Rationalize the GOB investment budget;
Refinance foreign commercial debt and limit new foreign borrowing (the IMF has recommended refinancing at this time only $230 million. The remaining $270 million could be refinanced, if necessary, in 1982 or 1983 when interest rates might be lower than at present.);
Adjust taxation of the mining sector to encourage increased investment;
Rationalize monetary instruments (e.g., increase interest rates on savings from current 10 percent, dedollarization of savings accounts, rational GOB credit policy);
Adopt a moderate wage policy;
Devalue the peso by means of a managed float.


From conversations with GOB officials over the last two weeks, Sol Perez has pieced together what he believes is the course of action the GOB seems most likely to take in response to the IMF recommendations. Sol has not yet shared these tentative conclusions with IMF headquarters, so they should be held very closely. Sol Perez believes the GOB could well come up with a proposal along the following lines by mid-November:


The GOB will increase hydrocarbon prices by 130 percent as recommended by the Fund;

text:
Date:

          From:
          SecState WashDC

          Info:
          Oct-00 Ads-00 Ha-05 Icae-00 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Pm-06 H-02 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Nsc-05 Pa-02 Sp-02 Ss-15 Inre-00 Aid-05 Trse-00 Omb-01 /071 R
        
                    
          Subject:
          Q’s And A’s From 11/2/79 Noon Press Briefing
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Following is a transcript of the 11/2/79 noon press briefing given by Tom Reston:
Q. Tom, on another subject, what does the United States think of the direction in which things are moving in Bolivia?
A. Where?
Q. Bolivia – it’s a country –
Q. Land-locked Bolivia. (LAUGHTER)
A. Yes. I do have something I want to say about this. The forced change of government, of course, was by non-constitutional means, and last night’s closing of the Congress was further disruption of the constitutional process. I said yesterday that we would deplore any disruption of the constitutional process there, and I stand on that. It is regrettable that this major step backwards occurred in the Bolivian people’s heartening advance during the last two years toward representative government and respect for human rights.
Q. You alluded yesterday to a review of US-Bolivian relations if the coup in fact succeeded. Can you say that without qualification today?
A. Oh, yes, I can say that without qualification. That review continues; but on the basis of what we learned yesterday and what apparently has taken place on the ground, I want to announce that in response to the situation there the United States has suspended its assistance programs with Bolivia. We will continue to review all aspects of our relations.
Q. What was the size of that assistance program?
A. Military assistance recently has been running at approximately $6 million per year; planned development assistance for fiscal year 1980, including Food for Peace, is approximately $50 million. Out of that $50 million, the Food for Peace amount is $28.5 million.
Q. You’re not suspending that, are you?
A. I have got an expert in the back there. Are we suspending the total $50 million?
Mr. Taylor: Yes. Mr. Reston: We are suspending – including the Food for Peace. It has all been suspended.
Q. Is the Ambassador expected to come home?
A. No. Paul Boeker is going to remain on the scene to report about the evolving situation.
Q. What is his last name?
A. B-O-E-K-E-R is his last name.
Q. What is his first name, Paul?
A. Paul.
Q. In other words, the US action appears to mean that you have now made up your mind about this regime, you don’t like it, and you are going to do what you can to discourage it.
A. I said that we deplore it; we regret it. We continue to review the totality of our relationship with Bolivia; and on the basis of what we learned yesterday about what has taken place, we have taken the concrete actions which I have just announced.
Q. Why are you cutting the Food for Peace, which goes to needy people?
A. The question?
A. The question is, why are we cutting the Food for Peace program? I think I have suggested the reasons which lie behind the announcement which I have just made.
Q. In view of this famous luncheon on October 23 at the Embassy, to which this Colonel Natusch was invited but didn’t go, does the Secretary consider this as not only a setback for US policy but to his own prestige?
A. I think what I want to say about that lunch which we had down there is that the United States does not pretend to control events in every other country in the world.
Q. That’s for sure. (LAUGHTER)
A. At that lunch, the Secretary made the views of the United States known to those at the luncheon. We have stated our deep concern over the departure from constitutional processes, but it is the Bolivians themselves, in the last analysis, who will decide what happens in their country.
Q. Let me follow that up? The American Secretary of State, at the American Embassy, invites four former Presidents, all the Army chiefs, and talks about democracy, and about a week later there is a coup. Is this a setback for US policy and for the Secretary personally?
A. I think what it really – I think the tone of my statement would indicate that we perhaps believe it is a setback for constitutional processes in Bolivia.
Q. Tom, can you tell us whether we have talked to any other Latin American governments about this or are we attempting to coordinate activities in order to bring pressure on Bolivia?
A. I think I took that question yesterday, but I didn’t get an answer to it. I’ll check again, today.
Q. Tom, do you know what the timing would be on the aid cutoff – like would weapons shipments be stopped or training programs be terminated? Or is there something you could reverse if events down there changed in a fairly short time?
A. What I show here is the suspension of these programs, and I assume that that means that they will be frozen.
Q. Tom, could I just follow up on that and one other question?
A. Yes.
Q. When you talk about this total of $56 million, has any part of that already gone down? Are we talking about the entire $56 million being suspended or has most of it already –
A. It’s $50 million.
Q. It’s $50 million plus $6 million military, right?
A. Oh, yes. I’m sorry. You’re absolutely right.
Q. How much is Food for Peace?
A. $28.5 is Food for Peace, economic assistance is $50 million, military is –
Q. What about –
Q. Wait a minute. Let’s get the answer first.
A. The $50 million is planned development assistance for fiscal year ’80, which began October 1 of this year. I will take the question as to what amount has already been sent down there, what amount is in the pipeline, and what amount remains to be sent.
Q. And, of course, military is what?
A. I will get a precise figure for fiscal year ’80 and will break it out in the same manner.
Q. Do you have last year’s?
Q. Then, I just wanted to ask another question: Yesterday, I believe you were under the impression that this Colonel was of the right-wing persuasion, but there have also been stories that –
A. I didn’t say anything about him.
Q. I’m sorry. Well, maybe I saw that somewhere else. Does the State Department have any evaluation yet of where on the political spectrum this gentleman stands?
A. I have some biographical information about him; I don’t have anything to offer about his ideological persuasions except from his actions. He obviously has a particular view of politics.
Q. Not a convicted democrat. (LAUGHTER)
A. Do you want the biographical information?
Q. No, but what I would like, though, is some sense of the whole – and I’d appreciate it if you would take the question – not just of his ideological persuasion, but who the forces are behind him. Do you have any sense of that?
A. Well, let’s see what I can get for you on that.
Q. Do you know if Bolivia receives Development Bank assistance, and if so, will the United States act in those forums to cut aid to Bolivia, which is where it counts, usually?
A. I’ll take that question.
Q. I wondered if pipeline aid was also being suspended – in other words, ships at sea, are they being turned back?
A. We’ll try to find the answer to that question.
Q. Stuff in the FY ’79 budget, sometimes that stuff, you know, even though the year is ended, is still on the way.
A. I’ve said that we are suspending our aid here. We are not going to make up our minds about these things depending on which fiscal year the budgetary cycle is in. I will take the question about whether stuff which is on its way is going down there, but I don’t think we are going to make up our minds about this as to whether it was done before or after October 1.
Q. Is your announcement here the first word to them or have they been formally notified through the Embassy?
A. We have formally notified them through the Embassy.
Q. Tom, you pushed aside what I think was a very legitimate question a couple of minutes ago. It has often been our practice in the past, for example, in dealing with the Somoza government in Nicaragua, not to suspend what we call humanitarian aid that benefited the people of a country. We have expressed a lot of concern about famine in other parts of the world despite our disapproval of governments there. Why is it that we are including Food for Peace and other humanitarian programs in this suspension?
A. Let me take that question and see if I can get you a more elaborate rationale beyond what has obviously happened in the last 24 hours.
Q. Do you consider this government consolidated already?
A. The situation last night in Bolivia appeared to be calm. There does not seem to be active military opposition to the new Bolivian regime. There does, however, seem to be some opposition among civilian groups. Ex-President Paz Estenssoro, the leader of the National Revolutionary Movement, has expressed his opposition as have several other leading political figures and organizations in Bolivia, including former President and Commander of the Armed Forces General David Padilla, and including the principal labor leadership in Bolivia.
Q. Tom, a follow up?
A. Yes, go ahead and follow up.
Q. Democracy in Bolivia was installed in a regional context in which many countries were supporting this process. Why aren’t you able to tell us what kind of contacts you are having with the Andean countries and is there any role for the coup by Brazil and Argentina?
A. Is there any role for the coup?
Q. Yes. Did Argentina and Brazil play any role supporting the coup?
A. I have nothing about purported roles by Argentina or Brazil. As to your other question about, have we been in touch with the Andean Pact, I don’t see any reason why we shouldn’t be able to provide that answer to you, and I would hope that the bureaucratic wheels would start to turn and get an answer to your very legitimate question.
Q. Tom, I know you do not deal with questions of recognition of changes of government, but in view of the fact that there is substantial special civilian opposition, including former President Guevara meeting with a rump session of the National Assembly, do you now recognize Colonel Natusch as the head of the government of Bolivia? Or are you considering that judgment not to be makeable at this point?
A. I can’t make that judgment from this podium here. I think we have our Ambassador on the ground there, who is reporting on what is very clearly an evolving situation. We are reviewing the totality of our relationships with Bolivia, and that means as well, obviously, we are reviewing the nature of our diplomatic relationship with Bolivia.
Q. Tom, do you have anything for comparative purposes of what aid actually went to Bolivia last year?
A. I can get that for you, sure. Q. Tom, you mentioned that Argentina and Brazil are not involved. What about Chile?
A. I mentioned that Argentina and –
Q. And Brazil that there is no apparent role.
A. I said that I didn’t have anything to offer about that.
Q. What about Chile?
A. I really have nothing that I can offer on the nature of the Chilean relationship, if any.
Q. You said that you were examining the nature of our diplomatic relations with Bolivia?
A. I said, yesterday, that we were reviewing the totality of our relationship with Bolivia –
Q. Yes, but we specifically –
A. – and “totality” obviously would include everything, including diplomatic –
Q. Wait a minute, don’t go away –
A. Oh, I am going to have to go away pretty soon, as a matter of fact.
Q. Yes, I know. Yesterday, we excluded diplomatic because your policy used to be that you don’t recognize governments, you recognize countries.
A. Yes.
Q. Is there a question whether – is there a possibility you are saying the United States is considering whether or not to maintain diplomatic relations with Bolivia? Is that what you are saying?
A. I would not want you to write that, frankly, I don’t think that is very –
Q. Well, would they –
A. I don’t think that is where I am trying to take you here.
Q. But you said you were reviewing it.
A. I said we were reviewing our relationship with Bolivia in light of the developments which have taken place there over the last 36 hours or so.
Q. That is not what you said yesterday.
A. Yes, that’s what I said yesterday.
Q. Today you said “diplomatic relationships.”
A. Then I was asked the question: “Well, what does that mean? How much of your relationship?” And I said we were reviewing the totality of our relationship.
Q. Right.
A. Now, diplomatic relations can involve a great many things. I was asked the question earlier in the briefing today as to whether we were going to recall our Ambassador there. I said, no, we’re not going to recall our Ambassador there. That is part of diplomatic relations. We are going to leave the Ambassador there to report on the situation as it developed. I have nothing to offer you.
Q. O.K.
A. Absolutely nothing, one way or the other, about the status or our present diplomatic relations with Bolivia.
Q. Well, you probably want to stay on Bolivia for a while, don’t you?
A. I don’t, but they do. (LAUGHTER)
Q. Tom, do you have any information whether any part of the Bolivian Armed Forces are in touch with the civilian opposition to this coup? In other words, is there some hope of reversal here, or what?
A. I really can’t answer that question because I don’t know the answer. But I have a more official posture to put on it, which is that I know of no military unit in the country which is in opposition at the present time –
Q. Except the Commander-in-Chief.
A. – to the Colonel’s people.
Q. Tom, you took the question about talks with Andean countries. If, when checking, you discovered that the United States has not consulted with Argentina and Brazil, would this indicate that you are thinking that these two countries are playing with the coup?
A. No, I don’t think so. But I will try to check and see whether we have been in touch with the others, as well, about it. We have done a good deal of work over recent months with members of the Andean Pact qua Andean Pact. We worked closely with them to try to help resolve the Nicaraguan situation. The Secretary was in Quito for the installation of the new Ecuadorean President, and he met with the Andean Pact as members of the Andean Pact then. Again at the OAS meeting, we met with them as members of the Andean Pact. Therefore, it seems to me logical in that framework, that we would have been consulting with members of the Andean Pact about what has happened within one of their own countries.
Q. Tom, General Banzer was the other man who didn’t come to lunch last week, I gather. Do you regard him as being involved or behind this coup?
A. I really don’t have anything to offer on that.
Q. Can you take that question?
A. Yes, let me find out what we think the General is up to.
Q. By taking this drastic action, including suspension of food aid – a step which has not even taken with respect to Cambodia where a holocaust is going on – are you trying to promote the restoration of civilian rule? Are you trying to undercut this government?
A. Who runs Bolivia is a matter for the Bolivians to decide. We do not control that. But we, like Bolivia, are a sovereign nation: and we have the right to take actions which are within our control.
Q. That doesn’t answer the question. What is your ultimate objective by taking this drastic action?
A. I don’t want to stand here and give you a tote list of what the ultimate objectives of the United States are. When the Secretary was in La Paz, he made very, very clear to the Bolivians the preference of the United States for democratic processes.
Q. Tom, let me follow that up, please. That’s a general question. Can you recall any other time when the US has cut off food – aid – when it was suspended?
Q. Chile.
Q. When this administration has done it.
A. I will take that question.
Q. Yes, in fact it might help if you could, if you listed instances, because I know there have been precedents – but I don’t know which countries. They were small countries.
A. I will take the question.
Q. Yes, I want to follow up with this question: When you were listing the times recently when you have dealt with the Andean Pact as the Andean Pact, they have tended to be times when the Andean Pact has not followed the preferable US policy in given situations. I would like to ask a philosophical question: If the new government indeed is oriented along the lines of, for instance, Argentina, do you think that they would play a role in tending to be more supportive of the kind of initiatives that the Andean Pact has rebuffed that Secretary Vance made in the instances you mentioned?
A. Oh, Laura, I think that is a speculative question.
Q. I can rephrase it less diplomatically.
A. I am sure you can, Laura.
Q. Tom, I would like to ask you a couple of questions about Cuba.
Q. Still on Bolivia – can you say whether any US officials are meeting or talking with members of the former Guevara government or other opponents of the coup in Bolivia, and are encouraging them to take some steps to restore the democratic processes there?
A. I think you can assume that Ambassador Boeker and his staff at the Embassy in La Paz are in touch with a number of Bolivian political figures to discuss with them the situation. I am not going to detail for you what the Ambassador and his staff precisely might be saying.
Q. Opposition? Including the opposition?
A. A number of Bolivian political leaders.
Q. Tom, there is one inconsistency here that I just can’t reconcile in my mind. You describe this as an evolving situation. You have got the Ambassador talking to opposition political figures. And yet you have taken such a decisive act as to cut off, or suspend all aid. Doesn’t that decision imply that you regard this as pretty much a fait accompli? I don’t see how it can be evolving and while it is evolving you take such a decisive step.
A. I don’t necessarily see any inconsistency in that.
Q. Well, let’s put it this way: do you see this action as being a factor in the evolution of the situation?
A. Well, we will see about that, won’t we? Because –
Q. Is it the contention of this government that it should be a factor in the evolution of the situation?
A. I think that you are just going to have to use your own judgment on that. And as to whether it will turn out to be a factor, that is something that only the future will tell.
Subsequent to the above verbatim exchange, the Department posted a correction as to which economic assistance was being suspended.
A. The correction is as follows: We are suspending military and economic assistance while we follow developments in Bolivia and review our programs in the light of the developments. We do not intend to suspend, or cut off, Title II PL 480 or other humanitarian assistance.

title: (S) The Padilla Government - A Balance Sheet Of Negatives
text:
Date:
          March 08, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 5135
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Ciae-00 Pm-05 H-01 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Nsc-05 Pa-01 Sp-02 Ss-15 Ica-11 Ha-05 Io-14 Eb-08 Trse-00 Com-02 Aid-05 Omb-01 /104 W ——————105952 102259z /21 R 082005z Mar 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          (S) The Padilla Government - A Balance Sheet Of Negatives
        
                    
          TAGS:
          POINT, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: The Padilla government and its cabinet of Young Turk generationalist military officers raised high hopes in many quarters with its announcement of elections, its continuation of the upbeat pattern of respect for human rights, and the pronouncements of individual ministers with regard to the return to democratic government, the withdrawal of the armed forces from the political direction of the country back to the barracks, the revamping of public corporations, and the general improvement in the quality of government in Bolivia. While human rights and the electoral process have thus far fared well, the Padilla regime has in the meantime mired itself down in a shabby display of infectious venality and incompetence that has tarnished its image and raised some doubts about its ability to carry forward its well-advertised objectives for Bolivia’s democratization.
When B/Gen Padilla executed his overthrow of the Pereda regime almost four months ago, a certain euphoria permeated La Paz’ notably rarefied air, emanating mainly from among some of the generationalist officers who constituted the underpinnings of the coup. The immediate tension reliever, of course, was the announcement of elections for July 1979 (instead of May 1980), a move which provided a kind of moral justification for the takeover as well as a mandate for constitutionalism which few could challenge. Utterances of reform, elimination of corruption, a restructuring of the government (and public sector corporations in particular) were heard in loose, uncoordinated statements to the press. The prisoners implicated in the previous months coup plotting were released, and the regime appeared off to a good start in both word and deed.
Exactly who was in charge was not clear. For a time it appeared that Padilla had ridden the tail of the tiger into power and would ultimately disappear from the scene at the pleasure of the younger officers who had used him as their key instrument. Or was Padilla — nobody’s fool — really using these young and ambitious officers, several of whom had been arrested by him only a month previously for plotting, to propel him into the presidency? More than likely, both scenarios were accurate to a degree in that the plotting and execution of the coup as it unfolded revealed a strange coterie of collaborators — conservative Padilla on the one hand, his generationalist officers on the other — who had nothing really in common except the desire to overthrow the incumbent Pereda regime. Surely their reasons were quite different: Padilla wanted personal power, or in any case to avoid being victimized in an overthrow. The most zealous younger officers wanted power, ostensibly for purposes of reform. To determine which side prevailed is only to review what has transpired since last November; i.e., Padilla has accumulated power and encouraged corruption and incompetence in the process; the influence of his generationalist cabinet has waned; and there has been no reform on any front.
What can be said in Padilla’s behalf is that the election schedule remains firm and that there has been no diminution in the respect for human rights in Bolivia. Indeed, the political process appears to be moving forward as a number of political parties have held conventions, named candidates, and as the government has implemented some significant changes in electoral procedures. One has the clear impression that the Padilla government is sincere in purpose and really means to step down come August 6. Human rights and a democratization process apparently well in train are the two positive entries on the ledger.
The negative side of the ledger, however, is bleak with shabby efforts to consolidate power, promote corruption, and burden the civil administration with the appointment of hacks and incompetents in key positions. The problem, of course, is whether ultimately Padilla may not have grabbed another tiger by the tail, i.e., the miring down of his regime in a system of patronage and payoffs involving Bolivia’s Armed Forces to the extent that he loses control in the process so that other powerful and conservative forces — not so willing to give up the game and its rewards — see elections and a new government as a clear threat to their interests.
Corruption A. We have good information that the Bolivian Armed Forces have been engaged in rather extensive arms purchases, possibly amounting to some $103 million. A source close to the President informs us that Army Deputy G-4 Lt Col Javier Alcoreza is currently involved in some of the arms purchases arrangements. The source voiced his impression that Padilla stands to profit personally in a very substantial way. B. We also know that officers of the Armed Forces of Lt Col or equivalent grade have been accorded an exemption from customs duties for importation of two automobiles each, which in Bolivia could mean a windfall profit from the resale of $15-30,000. This exemption is in addition to the recent influx of illegal automobiles into Bolivia as well as the blatant sale of entry permits for automobiles coming in through Santa Cruz.

          OVIP, PDIP, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Mrs. Carter’s program includes buffet dinner at residence on Sunday, August 5, at 1900. We are planning to invite approximately ten Bolivian couples, though we cannot do so until the new president has been named.
Depending on outcome, we would invite Bolivian guests from following list, which capsules individuals’ personal history and language ability. We would appreciate comment before selecting and sending invitations.
Jaime Paz Zamora. The UDP’s vice presidential candidate, Paz, 40, is one of the three kingpins of the left-leaning MIR, which is often characterized as Bolivia’s “party of the future.” Paz is bright, articulate and personable–but he does not speak English.
Luis Ossio Sanjines. The MNR’s vice presidential candidate, Ossio, 47, is a leader of the small but influential Christian Democratic Party. A lawyer with close ties to Bolivia’s private mining sector, he is frank and easily approached. He does not speak English.
Carlos Iturralde Ballivian. Formerly ambassador to Malaysia and to the United States (1978), Iturralde, 39, is a wealthy mine-owner with close ties to the rightist Hugo Banzer sector. He holds degrees in economics and business administration from the University of North Dakota and New York University. Excellent English.
Mario Rolon Anaya. Until recently Bolivia’s permanent representative to the United Nations, Rolon, 52, was vice presidential candidate on Hugo Banzer’s right-wing ADN ticket. Although a lawyer, writer and educator of broad experience, he is not believed to speak English.
Walter Guevara Arze: Founder and guiding light of the small, relatively conservative PRA party, Guevara, 67, was elected Senator from Cochabamba on Victor Paz Estenssoro’s MNR ticket. He has served in previous governments as Minister of Foreign Affairs, Ambassador to Israel and France and permanent representative to the United Nations. English is good.
Guillermo Bedregal Gutierrez. A veteran MNR politician, Bedregal, 52, was elected as a deputy from La Paz on the Paz Estenssoro slate. A lawyer and prolific author on political subjects, he could be appointed Minister of Planning. He does not speak English.
Carlos Antonio Carrasco. A former Minister of Education, Carrasco, 43, is a model technocrat who until recently was employed by the United Nations in Caracas. Elected to a deputy position from Cochabamba on Hernan Siles’ UDP ticket, he speaks excellent English.

          Subject:
          Reaction To Gob Economic Measures
        
                    
          TAGS:
          ECON, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          LA PAZ 0430 SUMMARY: GOB SEEKING TO PROMOTE ACCEPTANCE OF ECONOMIC MEASURES DECREED EVENING JANUARY 20. MINISTERS OF FINANCE AND IND/COM HELD JOINT RADIO/TV INTERVIEW JANUARY 21 AND FINANCE MINISTER AND MINISTER SECRETARY AND MINISTER OF TRANSPORTATION GAVE OTHER RADIO/TV INTERVIEWS JANUARY 22 ATTEMPTING TO ASSURE POPULACE THAT STEPS TAKEN NECESSARY TO ELIMINATE SHORTAGES AND THAT THEY ARE SUFFICIENT AND FURTHER PRICE INCREASES SHOULD NOT BE ANTICIPATED. SUB-SECRETARY OF COMMERCE TOLD EMBOFF THAT HE ESTIMATES FOOD SUPPLIES MUST BE REGULARIZED IN NEXT TEN DAYS OR PUBLIC CONFIDENCE WILL BE LOST AND MEASRES WILL PROVE INEFFECTIVE. END SUMMARY.
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Simple explanation given by government for measures, for instance in signs posted throughout city, is that lines (colas) had to be eliminated. Without clear elaboration, press reported that in interviews ministers referred to four problems as cause of government action: contraband and hoarding, overevaluation of neighboring countries’ currencies, national production and imports. Minister Ind/Com Pereda said that country “not an island” but has long border and although government earlier froze prices, world experiencing worst economic crisis since 1930 and forces of inflation have had local effect. Ministers explained that wheat essentially transportation problem but said that sugar in oversupply and rice harvest delayed. They stated that official meat prices will not be raised. Subsequent press notice stressed that a general price increase not permitted and forty-four basic items still controlled at former prices.
Government took pains to emphasize that there will be no devaluation. One of decrees gave guarantee against devaluation for domestic savings. Minfin stated that this year Bolivia will have favorable balance of payments. He admitted that some additional measures, such as reduction of export taxes and import duties and some internal taxes, are being contemplated to stimulate production and ease burden of new bonus on private concerns.
For benefit of press Minfin gave detailed breakdown of government’s calculation of $B400 bonus showing that it based on effect of new prices on “market basket” survey done by Factory Workers Federation. He said that ministry concluded that $B254 bonus merited but President Banzer personally ruled that higher amount should be paid. Workers who have more than one source of income or who benefit from subsidized commissary will have to negotiate with employers regarding size of bonus. According to press some firms complaining of inability to pay bonus.
Although no announcement made of new public transportation fares Minfin inferred that 30 percent rise can be expected and we understand that negotiations now underway with drivers. He stated that public transportation subsidy will continue and domestic gasoline prices will not be raised because international prices high enough to support present low domestic gasoline price.
Comment: Initial reaction to measure is one of uncertainty and to some extent confusion caused by GOB’s explanation of measures. As result most storekeepers have shut doors and generally retailers have shown hesitancy in dealing with public. Labor highly concerned about price rises while downplaying benefit of bonus (see septel). An economic slowdown and increased unemployment are probably very bad eventualities unless GOB provides some form of relief, possibly tax concessions, restoration of subsidies to some basic food crops, etc. The subsidy may not be reasonable tool if absolute scarcities prevail and tax concessions may be overly costly to fiscal integrity of GOB.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: Since the beginning of the YAR, President Padilla has firmly asserted control over Bolivia’s governing military junta, skillfully deflecting potential challenges to his leadership and the democratization process. At the same time, however, he has resisted taking any significant action to shore up the nation’s sagging economy and has allowed corruption in the armed forces and the government to spread unchecked. Against this background, the civilian political groups have been organizing slowly. Siles Zuazo’s UDP coalition, initially plagued by defections and bitter internal dissension over Siles’ choice of the MIR’s Paz Zamora for the vice presidential slot, finally jelled on April 9. Paz Estenssoro, whose electoral alliance was formalized that same date, superficially appears to be in a better position than Siles Zuazo—but Siles, as last year, could prove to be the more effective vote getter. Bernal, who may hold the key to the presidency in the event of a congressional runoff, thus far has concentrated on cultivating the rural vote in Cochabamba and Oruro, while former President Banzer, the odd man out, has publicly announced that he will launch his own presidential bid.
Since January, President David Padilla has demonstrated shrewd political judgment and, by acting pragmatically, has managed both to strengthen his position in power and to defuse potential threats to the democratization process. Not surprisingly, his first significant challenge came from within his military constituency. From the outset, many questioned whether Padilla would be able to control the headstrong “generationalist” officers who were the architects of the November 24 coup. Most concerned about Padilla’s position were his high-ranked colleagues, many of whom feared that generationalist cabinet ministers Lt. Colonels Rolando Saravia (Agriculture), Victor Ramirez (Labor), and Raul Lopez (Interior) posed a threat to the military’s hierarchical values; some also believed that Saravia and Lopez were “leftists,” ideologically committed to Hernan Siles Zuazo’s UDP.
Whatever the merits of their case, Padilla accurately gauged the mounting anti-generationalist pressure, and—shortly after detecting an incipient conspiracy by pro-Banzer elements—he moved decisively. Taking advantage of the temporary absence from La Paz of such key ministers as General Jorge Echazu (Mines) and Lt. Col. Gary Prado (Planning), who might have opposed him on purely generational grounds, he squeezed Saravia and Ramirez out of the cabinet, leaving Lopez isolated and somewhat beholden to him. The upshot of this maneuver was that the pro-Banzer plotters were undercut, the senior-ranked officers were mollified, and Padilla’s position vis-a-vis the generationalists was strengthened.
Padilla has been equally pragmatic in his dealings with the civilian political sector. In his year-end national address, for example, he categorically rejected the political groups’ recommendations that military troops be withdrawn from the mines, that labor union leaders be permitted to run for national office and that the controversial military-peasant pact be dissolved. His strong stance on these three issues promptly provoked stiff opposition. On the first—the presence of troops in the mines—he sensed he could hang tough—and did. But on the other two he quickly realized that his position was untenable. Within two weeks he reversed his decision on the labor leader question, and by the end of February the High Command formally suspended the military-peasant pact until after the election.
Although Padilla has continually professed neutrality in the electoral process, it has become increasingly clear that he and key members of his government favor the presidential candidacy of Victor Paz Estenssoro. In mid-March, while Padilla was out of the country, military preferences (some for Bernal, some for Paz) translated into subtle pressures on the National Electoral Court. Jealous of their prerogatives, on March 20 the entire court decided to resign en masse—an action that prompted speculation that the election date would be postponed. Confronted by these rumblings, Padilla firmly set the democratization process back on course by rejecting the resignations and putting the court back to work. Later, when 57 separate groups applied for credentials to compete in the elections, Padilla expressed concern that last year’s “political carnival” would be repeated. This concern spawned a tough decree providing for the imposition of severe financial liabilities on any electoral slate that fails to obtain at least 50,000 popular votes. As a result, the number of electoral slates this year will probably not exceed five—thus significantly improving the chances for a stable democratic government.
In his single-minded zeal to keep the electoral process on course, Padilla unfortunately has proved short-sighted in other related areas. One of these is the economy. In a poor state when he took power, it has steadily deteriorated since. Padilla has resisted implementing significant corrective measures because he does not want to open the way for further criticism of the armed forces and because he fears that popular discontent could interfere with the democratization schedule. He has been notably less concerned about the prodigious burden that, as a result of his inaction, will be left for his successor.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

SECRETARY KISSINGER’S LETTER WAS DELIVERED PERSONALLY BY ME TO BOLIVIAN FOREIGN MINISTER GUZMAN THE AFTERNOON OF FEBRUARY 28, SHORTLY AFTER THE FOREIGN MINISTER RETURNED TO LA PAZ FROM THE MEXICO CITY MEETING. HE READ A TRANSLATION IN SPANISH, WHICH WE HAD PROVIDED, AND EXPRESSED HIS GREAT APPRECIATION FOR THE SECRETARY’S LETTER. HE ANTICIPATED SEEING THE PRESIDENT THIS AFTERNOON AND IS DELIGHTED THAT HE HAS THE LETTER TO SHOW TO PRESIDENT BANZER.
THE FOREIGN MINISTER EXPRESSED HIS GREAT ADMIRATION FOR THE MANNER IN WHICH SECRETARY KISSINGER CONDUCTED HIMSELF AT THE MEXICO CITY MEETING. HE SAID HE WAS COMPLETELY SATISFIED WITH THE RESULT OF THE CONFERENCE AND FELT THAT A POSITIVE AND SOUND BASIS HAD BEEN LAID FOR OPENING A NEW CHAPTER IN U.S. - LATIN AMERICAN RELATIONS AND ALSO BETWEEN LATIN AMERICAN THEMSELVES. HE SAID THAT HE HAD NOT ATTENDED PRIOR CONFERENCES AS HE IS A MILITARY MAN, BUT WAS DELIGHTED WITH THE FRANK, INFORMAL EXCHANGE OF VIEWS DURING THIS PARTICULAR MEETING.
HE INDICATED THAT THE BOLIVIAN DELEGATION HAD A CHANCE TO HAVE A BRIEF CONVERSATION WITH SECRETARY KISSINGER DURING WHICH THE

011703Z
FOREIGN MINISTER WAS ABLE TO NOTE THE GOB’S INTEREST IN FINANCIAL
ASSISTANCE FOR RECONSTRUCTION OF FLOOD DAMAGE AND FINANCIAL AID FOR THE SUBSTITUTION OF COCA PRODUCTION IN BOLIVIA. THE FOREIGN MINISTER SAID THAT SECRETARY KISSINGER EXPRESSED INTEREST IN THE PROPOSALS BUT WAS QUITE NATURALLY NOT ABLE TO RESPOND AT THE TIME OF THAT CONVERSATION. THE FOREIGN MINISTER IS OF THE BELIEF THAT THE REQUESTS THAT HE RAISED WITH THE SECRETARY WILL BE PURSUED IIN DUE COURSE BY THE DEPARTMENT.

THE FOREIGN MINISTER SAID THAT HE HAD HAD A VERY FRIENDLY MEETING WITH THE CHILEAN FOREIGN MINISTER WHOM HE HAD KNOWN PREVIOUSLY AS A FELLOW MILITARY MAN. THE MINISTER GAVE HIS OPINION THAT PROSPECTS ARE GOOD FOR IMPROVING BOLIVIAN-CHILEAN RELATIONS, AND THE PANAMA CANAL UNDERSTANDING WITH THE US RAISES HIS HOPES FOR RESOLUTION OF OUTSTANDING ISSUES WITH CHILE. STEDMAN

text:
Date:

          Oct-01 Iso-00 H-03 Iga-02 Pm-07 Nsc-07 Sp-03 Ss-20 Rsc-01 Ciae-00 Inr-11 Nsae-00 L-03 Mc-02 Eb-11 Trse-00 Omb-01 Aid-20 Drc-01 /113 W ——————— 095883 R 232025z Jul 74

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

I WOULD APPRECIATE IT IF A SMALL FMS CREDIT IN THE RANGE OF 2-1/2 TO 4 MILLION DOLLARS COULD BE APPROVED NOW UNDER THE CONTINUING RESOLUTION AUTHORITY FOR BOLIVIA. I UNDERSTAND THE IMPORTANCE OF OUR MULTI-YEAR COMMITMENTS FOR LARGER PROGRAMS INCLUDING SOPHISTICATED EQUIPMENT, BUT WOULD LIKE TO UNDERLINE CERTAIN SIGNIFICANT US INTERESTS HERE THAT CAN BE SERVED WELL BY THE EARLY APPROVAL OF A SMALL FY 1975 FMS CREDIT.
BOLIVIA’S INTEREST IN TANKS HAS RESULTED IN OFFERS FROM UNDESIRABLE SUPPLYING COUNTRIES WHICH WE MAY BE ABLE TO PRE-EMPT BY SUPPLYING PROMPTLY INFORMATION ON A SUTIABLE ALTERNATIVE SUCH AS THE V-150 CADILLAC-GAGE ASSAULT CAR AND ALSO AN OFFER OF FMS CREDIT FOR THE BOLIVIAN ARMY. I UNDERSTAND THAT A REPRESENTATIVE OF CADILLAC-GAGE MAY VISIT LA PAZ IN LATE AUGUST AND WOULD OBVIOUSLY WISH TO DISCUSS THE V-150 ASSAULT CAR WITH THE BOLIVIAN MILITARY. IT WOULD BE AN EFFECTIVE STEP IF WE

232214Z
WERE ABLE TO SUPPORT ANY INTEREST AROUSED WITH AN FMS CREDIT.

WE ARE NOW SUCCESSFULLY PURSUING A LONG-RANGE STRATEGY OF PROGRAMMING A PHASE-DOWN IN MAP GRANTS FOR MATERIEL WITH THE EXPECTATION OF A COMPENSATORY INCREASE IN FMS CREDITS. TO CONTINUE THIS SUCCESSFUL STRATEGY, WE SHOULD HAVE AT HAND FMS CREDITS FOR FY 75. THE $4 MILLION FY 74 FMS CREDIT MADE AVAILABLE TOWARD THE END OT THE FISCAL YEAR HAS BEEN ALLOCATED BY THE GOB TO THE BOLIVIAN AIR FORCE. THE FAB (BAF) IS MAKING ACTIVE EFFORTS TO USE ITS CREDITS IMMEDIATELY. THE BOLIVIAN AUTHORITIES HAVE TOLD ME AND THE MILGP THAT SUBSEQUENT FMS CREDITS ARE TO BE ALLOCATED TO THE BOLIVIAN ARMY. THUS A MODEST CREDIT FOR FY 75 FROM 2-1/2 TO 4 MILLION DOLLARS WOULD SUSTAIN THE PRESENT STRATEGY FOR MILITARY ASSISTANCE IN BOLIVIA.
I FEAR THAT AN ASSOCIATED PRESS WIRE SERVICE STORY FROM LIMA CARRIED IN THE BOLIVIAN PRESS CONCERNING A US OFFER OF $20 MILLION MILITARY CREDIT TO PERU DURING THE VISIT TO LIMA OF ARMY SECRETARY CALLOWAY WILL NOT HAVE ESCAPED THE ATTENTION OF THE BOLIVIAN MILITARY. I CAN WELL UNDERSTAND THAT THE ANNOUNCEMENT MAY NOT BE TRUE, BUT IT WILL COMPLICATE ANY EFFORT TO CONVINCE THE BOLIVIANS THAT THEIR NEIGHBORS HAVE NOT RECEIVED FY 75 FMS CREDIT OFFERS.
IN VIEW OF THE FOREGOING, I EARNESTLY REQUEST A SMALL FMS CREDIT ALLOCATION UNDER CRA TO BE USED NOW IN BOLIVIA. STEDMAN

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

ECLA Sessional Committee on Water Resources (Committee III) completed work on April 20 and reviewed and approved the final report of the Sessional Committee on April 21. This committee was formed at the inaugural plenary session to review the following: (A) Consideration and adoption of the recommendations formulated by the Regional Meeting on the Action Plan of the United Nations Water Conference held in Santiago, Chile in October 1978; (B) ECLA objectives, strategies, organization and work plan with regard to water; and (C) Consideration and adoption of the report of the Sessional Committee on Water. Trinidad was elected Chairman of Committee III with Chile and Canada being elected Vice Chairmen and Mexico elected Rapporteur.
After elections of officers and adoption of the agenda, the Sessional Committee reviewed the report, resolutions and recommendations of the Latin American Regional Meeting on the Action Plan of the UN Water Conference held in Santiago. (Report is outlined on pages 30-39 of ECLA Document 1066 dated April 12, 1979.) The meeting approved all resolutions and recommendations by consensus. US delegation congratulated ECLA on the quality and comprehensiveness of this report. Only major discussion involved Recommendation (B) under Resolution V which identifies ECLA requirement of $300,000 to finance technical cooperation among developing countries in the water field. US delegation indicated that while we support objectives of the resolution, in accordance with US policy we could not support a net increase in the ECLA regular budget for this item. Additional funding would have to come from reallocations from within existing ECLA budget or voluntary contributions. The ECLA Secretariat noted that approval of Resolution V did not commit any delegation to approval of specific budget allocations, and that this would be considered in the Fifth Committee.
The committee then proceeded to consider the ECLA work program with regard to water contained in the following documents: (A) Implementation of the Mar del Plata Action Plan at the regional level (Note by the Secretariat - ECLA Document 1077), and (B) the water resource projects described in pages 85-87 of ECLA’s 1979-81 Work Program (ECLA Document 1068) were reviewed in detail and approved by the committee.
Major discussion of sessional meeting focused on CEPAL Document 1077 (ECLA objectives, strategies, organization and work plan with regard to water) which was approved with the modifications noted below. US delegation expressed general satisfaction with the document but requested following changes: (A) Document 1077 called for regular meetings of government experts or groups of experts outside the regular Sessional Committee meetings. It was indicated that such meetings might be held every six to twelve months. Argentina strongly supported the idea of regular meetings every six months to give guidance to ECLA Secretariat on water related matters. US and Brazilian delegations vigorously questioned the need for these regular meetings and expressed concern about the growing proliferation of international meetings. Text of US statement to the committee on this issue follows. “We agreed last October to create this Sessional Committee as the intergovernmental body for giving direction to the ECLA Secretariat in area of water resources and sanitation. The US delegation is generally concerned about proliferation of international bodies and meetings. If there is genuine widespread interest in having other experts meeting to consider horizontal cooperation in the field of water, such meetings could be scheduled in the future. For the time being, however, it is our delegation’s impression that the structure of this Sessional Committee is adequate. Interested governments can send experts to this Sessional Committee. If evidence shows that the interest of member governments in the water area is such that the Sessional Committee is overwhelmed by its workload, we could then entertain the idea of more frequent ad hoc meetings of government water experts.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

The mission has in a very limited number of special cases supplemented salaries of key Bolivian civil servants whose training, experience and ability make them uniquely qualified to advance crucial elements of the GOB cooperative program with the mission. This is done to encourage such personnel to remain in key positions of leadership within the government in the face of employment offers from other agencies, multinational or private sector, which offer remuneration substantially above GOB civil service scale. In this sense we top off the salary for a fixed time period until, hopefully, GOB civil service scale for the position is adjusted upward and encourage the key leader not to leave the country or the GOB.
Winston Estremadoiro is a Bolivian leader who fits these criteria. He completed a Bachelor’s degree at the University of Houston, a Master’s degree at the University of California, Los Angeles, and is a candidate for the Ph.D. at UCLA (lacking only his dissertation for graduation). His fields of expertise are rural sociology and social anthropology. In addition to having worked with indigenous leaders in most geographic areas of Bolivia, he organized, then administered, PRODES (Project for the Development of the Chapare and Yungas) for two years with a high degree of success.
Mr. Estremadoiro is a natural leader, is highly motivated, and knows how to move programs and projects through the Bolivian government and society. In our opinion he will be a key element in any development effort we help finance in the coca zones. He has had several attractive offers to leave the GOB (from the Andean Pact and the Organization of American States among others). We propose to supplement his salary as Executive Director of PRODES, now fixed by the GOB at US \(736 per month (\)B 15,000), if he agrees to return to that important position. While no negotiations have been completed with Mr. Estremadoiro pending approval of relevant USG agencies, we would propose to supplement his GOB salary by up to US $1,025 per month. This would bring his total salary up to a level equal to his current earnings under contract and would approximate the offers he has received from other non-GOB entities.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM

Summary: The Bolivian Congress recently passed a resolution seeking confiscation or nationalization of the Bolivian Power Company, a Canadian (Nova Scotia) registered company whose major shareholders are US citizens or corporations, including Baldwin United of Cincinnati, Ohio which owns 49 percent of Bolivian Power’s common stock. The resolution resulted in the appointment of a special technical committee of the Lower House, consisting of lawyers, engineers and other experts to study the issue and make recommendations. Bolivian Power responded with its own initiative, i.e., a lease-sale arrangement with fees to be paid over twenty years after which the Bolivian Government would receive title to the company’s assets for no additional costs and with no interest payments. In a conversation with the Ambassador on October 16, Energy Minister O’Connor stated that Bolivian Power’s proposal was an acceptable basis for negotiation, but that a number of specific elements of the proposal were unacceptable to the GOB.
The company.


Compania Boliviana de Energia Electrica, S.A.–Bolivian Power Company Limited, produces and supplies hydro-electric energy to the cities of La Paz and Oruro, Bolivia, the adjoining areas, and nearby tin mines. Bolivian offices are located in La Paz and the company’s head office is in St. John’s, Antigua, West Indies. In 1978, the company sold 415.3 million kilowatt hours generating gross revenue of $US 11.3 million with net income of $US 3.4 million.
Bolivian Power is incorporated in Nova Scotia, Canada, and until October 1977 was owned by Canadian International Power Company, Ltd. On June 30, 1978 Bolivian Power formed a partnership, Hemisphere Leasing Associates, with Baldwin United Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio, which holds 49.8 percent of Bolivian Power’s common stock. In September 1978 Dayton Hydraulics Company became a general partner and October 1978 the partnership was reorganized as an Antiguan partnership.
In January 1979 the shareholders approved the contribution of Bolivian Power’s beneficial interest in substantially all of its electric utility property, plant and equipment which had a recorded book value of about $US 40 million to its partnership, Hemisphere Leasing, in exchange for 50 percent partnership interest. Bolivian Power retains legal title to the assets. The other partners contributed $US 10 million to be used for purchasing property or equipment to be leased to or financed for third parties primarily in the US. Bolivian Power then entered into a ten-year lease with Hemisphere Associates for rental of all assets; the lease can be renewed through September 30, 1999 when Bolivian Power’s franchise to operate in Bolivia expires.


Background.


According to a July 24, 1964 agreement with the GOB, Bolivian Power is entitled to earn an annual return of nine percent on its asset base and in any period that it does not earn nine percent, it is entitled to recoup the deficiencies. In 1977 and 1978 Bolivian Power’s rate of return was 7.7 and 6.5 percent respectively. As of December 21, 1978 the accumulated deficit totaled $US 18.3 million. To increase the rate of return, to cover past deficits, and to cover increasing costs, Bolivian Power asked for rate increases of 27.32 percent on December 13, 1977, 72.51 percent on December 12, 1978, and most recently a modified request of 64.03 percent in January 1979. These rate increases were not granted. The latest one is being studied by the GOB and has generated a great deal of publicity.
Sparked by the publicity from the rate increase request, a resolution seeking confiscation or nationalization of Bolivian Power was submitted in the new Congress. The resolution was modified creating a special Technical Commission of the Chamber of Deputies to prepare recommendations and report back to the Congress. The commission is composed of the following members: Jorge O’Connor, Ministry of Energy; Engineer Oscar Morales; Dr. Hugo Urquieta (lawyer); and Jose Raul Garzon.

title: Establishment Of Narcotics Advisor Position In Usaid/Bolivia
text:
Date:
          March 25, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 2630
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Mms-03 Deae-00 Snm-02 Aid-20 Per-05 Ss-20 Abf-01 Spc-03 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Juse-00 Trse-00 Rsc-01 Drc-01 /077 W ——————— 081841 R 251348z Mar 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Establishment Of Narcotics Advisor Position In Usaid/Bolivia
        
                    
          TAGS:
          SNAR BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          STATE 055765
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Embassy appreciates opportunity to give more detailed assessment of its need for a new narcotics advisor position. Annex B of Survey Report of Narcotics Law Enforcement Study Team No. 4 (April-May 1972) gives a good picture of problems faced by GOB in coming to grips with the narcotics problem in Bolivia and proposes a strategy and plan of action for USG assistance which this Embassy through its Narcotics Control Action Plans has been trying to implement since that time.
While considerable progress has been made, e.g., the passage of a comprehensive narcotics law, the assignment of a DEA unit to the US Embassy, fairly extensive training to Bolivian enforcement officers both in the US and in-country, and the provision of equipment and operating funds to the narcotics unit in the police force, we are still in Phase I of the two-phase approach recommended in the Survey Report.
In the advisory category, the narcotics advisor would help the GOB in the difficult initial task of developing rationally the various segments of a comprehensive program of narcotics control, to be implemented by new units authorized under Bolivia’s recently enacted Narcotics Control Law, (especially the high level entity with many added functions beyond enforcement). Certain of these activities probably will be formalized into various project agreements involving reasonable US financial and appropriate technical assistance.
In the institution building phase, the narcotics advisor would assist the GOB in working out a system of coordination and control of the various groups in Bolivia that have an interest or role in narcotics control efforts, e.g., various units in the police force, National Customs, Agricultural Customs, provincial authorities and the four Ministries members of the National Narcotics Control Board. The new overall narcotics entity authorized in the recent law should come into official being in the next few months, but needs our technical help. During its formative stage, when the institutional battles are being fought which will determine to a considerable degree what practical authority and influence this entity will have, it would be in our interest to provide support in the form of close, full-time liaison as well as some financial and appropriate technical assistance.
With regard to paragraph 2, reftel, we do indeed wish to retain the services of David S. Arroyo, USAID Public Safety Officer, for the new position. We do not suggest that Public Safety experience per se would be utilized in basic research to develop statistics on coca production, distribution and consumption. Basically the need is to bird-dog the Bolivians to do this job and it would be but one of several insignificant tasks of the narcotics advisor. We wish to keep Arroyo because he already has a deep knowledge of Bolivia and Bolivians, a demonstrated capacity to be effective, and the personal qualities of persuasiveness, tact, and charm that will assure this Mission of maximum effectiveness in the pursuit of our interests in the narcotics field during this complicated, ground-breaking period. Arroyo is bilingual. Arroyo already is preparing the groundwork for the relationships envisioned above, and the Ambassador has received personal requests from both the new Minister of Interior and the Sub-Secretary of Justice (at present the highest authorities in narcotics matters) that Arroyo be assigned to the new narcotics entity as a full-time advisor.
Regarding comment in paragraph 3 reftel, we believe that DEA representatives here will continue to be effective in their enforcement role if they are the primary contacts with the Bolivian Narcotics Enforcement Unit, which we conceive of being an arm of the overall narcotics unit. Due to his previous experience with the Bolivian Narcotics Enforcement Unit and his pioneering work in getting that unit established and operating, Arroyo will be of great service in providing counsel to DEA. However, we do not wish to encourage any confusion in the minds of the leaders of that police enforcement unit as to whom they must do business with in the US Mission, and we have therefore given DEA that responsibility. Furthermore, we believe that substituting DEA for OPS in the performance of duties in narcotics support work formerly done by OPS should remove any doubts that may remain in Washington that the establishment of a narcotics advisor position is merely a way of retaining the old OPS relationship here. Of major importance, however, is our belief that once confirmed in his new role as described above, Arroyo would be able to devote only a very small percentage of his time to the needs of the enforcement unit, whereas DEA can do this on a day-to-day basis. Finally, the Ambassador feels strongly that the retention of Mr. Arroyo here and his assignment to this position would make a meaningful contribution to the US Government’s efforts on the narcotics front in Bolivia.

title: Jubilation Marks Bolivia’s Return To Democracy
text:
Date:
          November 19, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Niact Immediate 9346
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ads-00 Ciae-00 Pm-06 H-01 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Pa-01 Sp-02 Ss-15 Nsce-00 Sso-00 Icae-00 Inre-00 Ha-05 Aid-05 Eb-08 Omb-01 Trse-00 /073 W ——————084194 190221z /64
        
                    
          Subject:
          Jubilation Marks Bolivia’s Return To Democracy
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINS, PINT, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

The parliamentary election of Deputy Lidia Gueiler Tejada on November 16, 1979, as President of Bolivia set two precedents: the first lady president in the nation’s history, and apparently the first time a military overthrow has ever been reversed through democratic processes. These rather extraordinary events were acclaimed by a rather extraordinary reaction in La Paz on Friday evening as a cheering crowd jammed the Plaza Murillo in front of the Congressional and government palaces while elsewhere citizens’ shouting and honking of automobile horns–as if Bolivia had won the American Cup Soccer Competition– signaled their jubilation over this remarkable return to constitutionalism after two weeks of grim, suppressive military government. Indeed, the change was akin to the sudden abrupt termination of a protracted nightmare.
According to press reports, the Cabinet–expected to be announced Monday Nov 19–will be one of “National Unity,” which can be interpreted to signify participation by some of the major political groups, particularly Victor Paz’ MNR Alliance. We are already reliably informed that Augusto Cuadros Sanchez, Minister of Economy in one of the Paz administrations, will be the new Finance Minister. Cuadros Sanchez is described as a conservative economist and one who can be expected to take a firm hand in confronting Bolivia’s critical economic situation.
On the international front, President Gueiler reiterated Bolivia’s close adherence to the Andean Pact and called for all democracies to support the new Bolivian return to constitutionalism, particularly in confronting Bolivia’s economic problems. Front page press treatment was given the Department’s description of events here as a “dramatic victory for the Bolivian people,” with the expectation of a normalization of diplomatic relations. We might add that we have already received several calls from various sectors, including Bolivian deputies and public servants, expressing appreciation and gratitude for U.S. policy not to do business with Natusch.
In the meantime, the Parliament’s unanimous choice of Lidia Gueiler is reflected in a similar closing of ranks among other sectors. Former President Walter Guevara Arze announced the end of his “clandestine government,” noting that it had effectively accomplished its purpose in contributing in no small measure to Bolivia’s return to democracy. Labor leaders described the events as a triumph for the workers, and Bolivia’s National Labor Federation (COB) in a message to workers hailed their contribution and called for continued unity and vigilance. These reactions are typical elsewhere in Bolivia as press reports indicate jubilation and a relaxation of the tense atmosphere in Bolivia’s major urban centers.
With the exception of an announcement that Bolivia’s banks are closed until further notice–a continuation of the banking holiday declared last week after the Central Bank closed its foreign exchange window–La Paz is expected to return to normal very quickly. The new government has officially lifted the state of siege, which in a sense had already become an unobserved anachronism by the weekend.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

FNCB manager La Paz states FNCB considered direct dollar financing as well as guarantee for subject sale. Decided against any participation in financing because study prepared by Asociacion de Consultores, LTA. of Santa Cruz for Cooperacion Agricola Warnes showed barely sufficient cash flow would not begin until 1975 crop (harvested in May, 1975). Warnes study showed total investment of US$ 568,000 including for working capital (US\(361,000 for gin F.A.S. Southern U.S. port). Cotton supply estimated at 87,000 quintales annually from 6,000 hectares or 14.5 quintales per hectare which higher than average yield in Santa Cruz. Warnes planned charge US\) 3 per quintal generating US$261,000. After deduction costs including interest (calculated at 11 percent by FNCB) about US$79,000 in first year and US$104,000 in fourth year remain in net profit and depreciation allowance to cover roughly US$99,000 per year loan amortization.
Financing might be more acceptable if cooperative could give “second pledge” on its total income.
According Wenhpslao Alba, president of Union de Bancos de Bolivia (a new association of Bolivian-owned banks) states that other members have joined in project and that a corporation will be formed with US$100,000 capital. The new members will increase cotton land supplying gin to 8,000 hectares and cash flow should improve accordingly. According Alba, Banco Industrial, Banco Mercantil, Banco Hipotecario, Banco Boliviano-Americano and Banco de Santa Cruz will take participation in a US$360,000 guarantee on credit.
Will attempt provide more data, if requested, on February 27.
