title: Request For Usia Preparation Comprehensive News Story On Pl 480 Developments.
text:
Date:
          February 06, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 2172
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Aid-20 Agr-20 Eb-11 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Inr-10 Nsae-00 Pa-04 Rsc-01 Usia-15 Prs-01 Spc-03 Sam-01 L-03 Drc-01 /111 W ——————— 080426 R 061219z Feb 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Request For Usia Preparation Comprehensive News Story On Pl 480 Developments.
        
                    
          TAGS:
          SUBJECT: REQUEST FOR USIA PREPARATION COMPREHENSIVE NEWS
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

I SENSE A NEED FOR A COMPREHENSIVE NEWS STORY ON THE PL-480 SITUATION AS IT AFFECTS ALL RECIPIENT COUNTRIES AROUND THE WORLD. THERE IS A GROWING FEELING WHICH HAS BEEN EXPRESSED TO MANY OFFICERS AT THE MISSION THAT THE DIFFICULTIES THAT BOLIVIA IS ENCOUNTERING IN ACQUIRING NEW AGREEMENTS FOR PL-480 IS THE RESULT OF A FUNDAMENTAL SHIFT IN US POLICY FROM HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE TO COMMERCIAL SALES. THERE IS ALSO EQUAL MISUNDER- STANDING THAT THIS SHIFT IN POLICY MAY BE APPLIED ONLY TO BOLIVIA. MEMBERS OF THIS MISSION HAVE DONE A GOOD JOB IN ATTEMPTING TO EXPLAIN THAT THE PL-480 PROGRAM IS BASED ON THE EXISTENCE OF EXCESS COMMODITIES AND THAT IN SPITE OF LARGE US PRODUCTION, THE COMMERCIAL SALES PRECLUDE PL-480 PROGRAMS ON THE SCALE OF PREVIOUS YEARS. WE HAVE ALSO ATTEMPTED TO EXPLAIN THAT THIS AFFECTS BOLIVIA BUT IS NOT POINTED AT BOLIVIA. I DO NOT THINK THAT WE ARE GETTING OUR MESSAGE ACROSS AND KNOW THAT THERE ARE MANY PEOPLE WITH WHOM WE DO NOT HAVE DIRECT CONTACT WHO MIS- UNDERSTAND RECENT COMMODITY DEVELOPMENTS. I AM NOT INTER- ESTED IN A STORY TAILORMADE FOR BOLIVIA; RATHER IT SEEMS TO ME THAT THERE MUST BE IN COUNTRIES OTHER THAN THIS ONE, SERIOUS QUESTIONS

061614Z
AND DOUBTS BEING RAISED WHICH COULD WELL BE PUT TO REST BY A
SKILLFUL PRESENTATION OF THE FACTS SURROUNDING CHANGES IN OUR ABILITY TO CARRY ON PL-480 OF THE MAGNITUDE OF PREVIOUS YEARS.

THE PUBLIC AFFAIRS OFFICER OF THIS POST HAS REQUESTED USIA TO DEVELOP A STORY ALONG THESE LINES WHICH REPORTS THAT IT HAS ENCOUNTERED NEGATIVE REACTIONS FROM AID, STATE AND AGRICULTURE. THE ASSERTION IS THAT TRYING TO EXPLAIN THE SITUATION MIGHT DO MORE HARM THAN GOOD. THIS IS A POSITION WHICH NO ONE HERE AT THIS MISSION IS ABLE TO UNDERSTAND. IT HAS ALSO BEEN ASSERTED THAT A STORY ABOUT THE PL-480 SITUATION COULD DO SOMETHING WITH THE MARKET WHICH IS EQUALLY DIFFICULT FOR US HERE TO FATHOM
THE PURPOSE OF THIS MESSAGE IS TO ATTEMPT TO ELICIT A FAVOR- ABLE RESPONSE FROM WASHINGTON AGENCIES TO OVERCOME BY A WELL DEVELOPED STORY THE HALF TRUTHS AND MISINFORMATION ALREADY APPEARING IN US AND FOREIGN NEWSPAPERS. WE HERE RECOGNIZE THAT BOLIVIA HAS HAD GOOD FORTUNE WITHIN THE PL-480 ALLOCATIONS BUT THIS HEIGHTENS RATHER THAN LESSENS THE NEED FOR A WELL REASONED STORY FOR WORLDWIDE CONSUMPTION. I CAN VISUALIZE THE INCLUSION IN SUCH A STORY OF SOME OF THE SIGNIFICANT ACCOMPLISH- MENTS OF PL-480 PROGRAMS BASED ON THE USE OF LOCAL CURRENCY. INCLUDED IN SUCH SUCH INFORMATION MIGHT BE A PRESENTATION OF PROGRAMS WHICH HAVE HAD SUCCESS IN RAISING DOMESTIC PRODUCTION OF FOODSTUFFS.
IF IT IS NOT POSSIBLE FOR USIA TO PUT OUT SUCH A STORY, COULD WE NOT COMMISSION ON A CONTRACT A SKILLED JOURNALIST TO PRODUCE SUCH A STORY POSSIBLY FOR PUBLICATION IN AN ACCEPTABLE US PUBLICATION. THIS THEN COULD BE REPRODUCED IN THE LOCAL MEDIA FOR SUBSTANTIAL BENEFIT IN ACHIEVING UNDERSTANDING OF OUR SITUATION. STEDMAN

text:
Date:

          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Pm-07 H-03 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Nsc-07 Pa-04 Rsc-01 Prs-01 Sp-03 Ss-20 Usia-15 Aid-20 Drc-01 ( Iso ) W ——————— 079414 R 261252z Apr 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Applegate-Youngquist Case
        
                    
          TAGS:
          BIZCQB, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

ARA/BC OFFICE DIRECTOR KARKASHIAN, ACCOMPANIED BY DCM AND EMBOFF, CALLED ON MIN IND/COM APRIL 23. CONVERSATION QUICKLY SETTLED ON APPLEGATE-YOUNGQUIST LAND EXPROPRIATION DISPUTE. MINISTER CALLED IN SEVEN HIGH-LEVEL MINISTRY OFFICIALS WHO ARE DEALING WITH CASE, AND HOUR-LONG WIDE-RANGING CONVERSATION FOLLOWED.
ANTONIO TAPIA OF SUGAR INSTITUTE WAS PRINCIPAL SPOKESMAN AND ARGUED THAT LEGAL CONTROVERSY INVOLVING BOLIVIAN LAW COULD NOT BE SETTLE OUTSIDE BOLIVIA. THIS NORMAL PRACTICE AND IN PAST INVESTMENT DISPUTES U.S. FIRMS OR THEIR REPRESENTATIVES HAD COME TO BOLIVIA FOR NEGOTIATIONS. HE CONCLUDED THAT APPLEGATE, YOUNGQUIST OR THEIR REPRESENTATIVE MUST COME TO BOLIVIA TO NEGOTIATE MATTER. TAPIA NOTED THAT BOLIVIAN LAW PROVIDES THAT LAND EXPROPRIATIONS COMPENSATED BY 25 YEAR 2 PERCENT BONDS BUT THAT “HIGHEST LEVELS” OF GOB IN RECENT PAST HAD ORDERED THAT CASE BE SETTLE BY EX- CEPTIONAL MEASURE OF OFFERING COMPENSATION IN LAND.
KARKASHIAN STATED THAT HE UNDERSTOOD TAPIA’S LEGAL POSITION BUT THERE HAVE BEEN CONTRADICTORY STATEMENTS BY PARTIES THAT LEFT GOB POSITION UNCLEAR AND CONFUSED RESOLUTION OF ISSUE. HE URGED GOB TO SET DOWN DETAILS OF ITS CASE AND AS PRACTICAL AID

261534Z
TO RESOLUTION OF ISSUES BE MORE SPECIFIC. FOR EXAMPLE, HE
SUGGESTED THAT GOB MAKE REQUESTS FOR SPECIFIED DOCUMENTS THAT IT LACKS RATHER THAN DEMANDING APPLEGATE-YOUNGQUIST SUBMIT “ALL DOCUMENTS.” THE BOLIVIAN OFFICIALS VOICED GENERAL AGREEMENT WITH SUCH AN APPROACH.

MINISTER NOTED THAT IMPORTANT FACTS IN CASE REMAIN TO BE DETER- MINED BUT THIS CAN MOST APPROPRIATELY AND MOST EASILY BE DONE IN BOLIVIA WHERE DOCUMENTARY EVIDENCE AVAILABLE. HE SAID THAT GOB FLEXIBLE AND READY TO NEGOTIATE SIZE AND LOCATION OF LAND FOR COMPENSATION. HE REPEATED EARLIER STATEMENT THAT ONCE CASE SETTLED, APPLEGATE AND YOUNGQUIST COULD SELL LAND FOR CASH. HE CONCLUDED BY STATING THAT HE WAS CONFIDENT THAT WITH GOOD WILL ON BOTH SIDES, CASE COULD BE CONCLUDED IN MONTH AND ONE HALF.
COMMENT: MEETING WAS CLEAR INDICATION THAT GOB READY TO NEGOTIATE SETTLEMENT OF CASE IN GOOD FAITH, ALTHOUGH IT WILL INSIST THAT NEGOTIATION TAKE PLACE IN BOLIVIA. ARGUMENT THAT THIS PRESENTS HARDSHIP TO U.S. CLAIMANTS LESS PERSUASIVE SINCE APPLEGATE HAS RETURNED TO BOLIVIA AND IS FARMING IN SANTA CRUZ AREA. STEDMAN

title: Guevara Bids To Extend His Term, Amid An Atmosphere Of Military-Civilian Confrontation
text:
Date:
          October 05, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Immediate 8493
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ads-00 Sso-00 /026 W ——————028467 052238z /73
        
                    
          Subject:
          Guevara Bids To Extend His Term, Amid An Atmosphere Of Military-Civilian Confrontation
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: President Guevara told me October 4 that he had on the previous evening asked Hernan Siles and Victor Paz to support the extension of Guevara’s term in office to mid-1981, when general elections would be held. Guevara told them that in his view Paz’ and Siles’ choice was elections in ‘81 or a return to military government, since a call for May 1980 elections would maintain the current political climate at a confrontational pitch which would provoke a military coup before elections. Guevara claimed that with Paz’ and Siles’ support for a two-year term, special economic powers and reduction of the charges against Banzer, Guevara could assuage the military, stabilize the economy and hand over a working civilian democracy to someone else in 1981. Without this support, he feared the worse. Neither Paz nor Siles has given Guevara a response. The fat is now in the fire and Guevara’s government, and maybe civilian rule, are headed for a showdown by early November on a complex set of questions – the two-year Guevara term, economic stabilization and changes in the military high command. End Summary.
In an October 4 meeting with me, President Guevara said he was deeply worried by the deterioration of the political climate that he found on his return from Panama. The military – with good reason – felt threatened by the looming indictment of General Banzer and associates. The Congress was handling this badly and everything else not at all. The military, Congress and labor were exchanging charges and threats at a pitch which Bolivia’s fragile democracy could not long survive. General Padilla was losing his authority within the military and hotter heads now sensed an opportunity to hatch their own political plans, including some to close down the Congress. In the course of our 90-minute meeting, Guevara elaborated on each of these points of concern.
Both the military and the Congress, Guevara said, were at fault in the current confrontation over the likely indictment of Hugo Banzer. The military had a shabby record of corrupt administration and should have anticipated that no representative government could protect them from an airing of this record. Also, the military had to recognize that the General Staff’s views on what was desirable for Bolivia were now not the last word but one of several voices in a complex process of accommodation. The Congress, on the other hand, was a “mediocre lot” which had let Marcelo Quiroga Santa Cruz and his tiny party dominate the agenda and the tone of the Congress and to use this position to goad the military in a way which would weaken the moderate elements as well as imperil civilian government. The two major coalitions, the MNR Alliance and the UDP, should never have allowed consideration of an indictment of the undefined group of “Banzer and his associates” since a large group of officers could see themselves as potential associates in seven years of military government. Guevara said Paz and Siles in their meeting with him on October 3 had agreed to seek an indictment resolution (to emerge from committee at the end of October) which would charge only Banzer and a few named associates with specific offenses, particularly corruption, but the damage of arousing the whole officer corps had already been done.
Guevara was distressed that the exchange of threats between the Congress and the military over the Banzer indictment had now been augmented by an exchange of accusing communiques between the military and the Labor Union Federation (COB) over the military budget. Before Guevara left for Panama, Padilla had promised that no more communiques would be issued by the military without coordination with Guevara.
To Guevara, the fact that Padilla felt compelled to issue the attack on the COB was one of several indications that Padilla was losing his grip on the military. In his recent consultations with unit commanders, Padilla was apparently playing with the idea of military intervention to keep himself at the front of the pack. Guevara feared that if Padilla could not control the military some hothead would try a coup against the Congress, Guevara or both. The COB would respond with a general strike and civilians and the military would be in a confrontation without a peaceful solution.
Guevara believed that several groups within the military were cooking political plots and if anyone could bring them together on one strategy, there could be a coup. He felt that Army Chief of Staff Julio Herrera was the one hothead who had the will and position to bring the malcontents together. Therefore, he had to move to replace Herrera. Guevara said he had to change his cabinet soon in any event, to replace at least ineffective ministers of mines and health. He wanted to use this occasion to kick Herrera upstairs to the Minister of Defense position and to replace him with General Jorge Terrazas, commander of the Seventh Division in Cochabamba. (Terrazas would then move up to Army Commander position when General Azero retires in December.) Guevara said he also planned to replace the commander of the Military Police Battalion, Captain Luis Montero, who insists on being Guevara’s watchdog. Guevara said he would present these changes to Padilla this weekend.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

SUMMARY: LA PAZ MORNING PAPERS REPORTED CROWDS AT THE “ANTI- IMPERIALIST” DEMONSTRATIONS AROUND BOLIVIA OCTOBER 25, AS WELL AS THE MARCH IN LA PAZ, WERE SIGNIFICANT. MOST SPEECHES DURING THE RALLIES ATTACKED THE UNITED STATES AND DENOUNCED THE PROS- PECTIVE SALE OF TIN FROM ITS STRATEGIC RESERVES. CHILE, ITS GOVERNMENT, AND ITS OAS REPRESENTATIVE ALSO WERE ATTACKED FOR DENYING BOLIVIA ACCESS TO THE SEA. SEVERAL POLITICIANS JOINED MARCHERS IN LA PAZ, BUT NOTABLEY ABSENT WAS LABOR LEADER JUAN LECHIN. END SUMMARY.
TO MOST OBSERVERS THE OCTOBE R 25 “ANTI-IMPERIALIST” MARCH IN LA PAZ APPEARED TO BE THE BEST ORGANIZED AND BEST ATTENDED

290743Z
DEMONSTRATION SPONSORED BY THE CONFEDERATION OF BOLIVIAN WORKERS (COB) IN RECENT YEARS. ESTIMATES OF CROWD SIZE VARY. TWO OF LA PAZ’ NEWSPAPERS, HOY AND PRESENCIA, ESTIMATED THE CROWD TO “NUMBER IN THE THOUSANDS.” EL DIARIO, ANOTHER LA PAZ MORNING PAPER, REPORTED 15,000 PEOPLE PARTICIPATED IN THE DEMONSTRATIN. BY WAY OF CONTRAST, POLICE COLONEL SALINAS, WHO COMMANDED THE RIOT POLICE DETACHMENT OUTSIDE THE SHERATON DURING THE 80 MINUTE
       Sheryl P. Walter 

      Sheryl P. Walter 
PARADE, CALCULATED THE MARCHERS NUMBERED SIX OR SEVEN THOUSAND PEOPLE.

MOST SPEECHES BEFORE AND AFTER THE MARCH DENOUNCED THE US AND THE PROSPECTIVE SALE OF TIN FROM STRATEGIC STOCKPILES. FELIX LACUMSA, STUDENT LEADER AT SAN ANDRES UNIVERSITY, ACCUSED THE US OF “DEALING A HARD BLOW TO BOLIVIA’S ONGOING DEMOCRATIZATION PROCESS” WHILE GENARO FLORES, A CAMPESINO LEADER, CHARGED THE US WITH BEING “THE FIRST TO VIOLATE HUMAN RIGHTS.”
CHOICE WORDS WERE ALSO RESERVED FOR THE CHILEAN GOVERNMENT AND ITS OAS REPRESENTATIVE FOR DENYING BOLIVIA ACCESS TO THE SEA. OSCAR SALAS, A LEADER OF THE MINERS, ANNOUNCED “THE PEOPLE WILL CONTINUE FIGHTING UNTIL BOLIVIA RETURNS TO THE SEA.” CHANTS DURING THE MARCH ALSO CALLED FOR “DEATH TO DAZA (CHILEAN OAS REP) AND PINOCHET” AND “DOWN WITH CHILEANS.” SOME PLACARDS CARRIED BY FACTORY WORKERS CALLED FOR THE DISMISSAL OF CHILEANS WORKING IN BOLIVIAN FACTORIES.
ABSENT FROM THE LA PAZ MARCH WAS JUAN LECHIN, EXECUTIVE SECRETARY OF THE COB. BUT, AMONG MARCHERS LABATT IDENTIFIED MARCELO QUIROGA SANTA CRUZ, PS-1 LEADER AND ITS DEPUTY FOR COCHABAMBA; OSCAR EID, MIR LEADER; AND JAIME PAZ ZAMORA, MIR LEADER AND UDP VICE PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE IN 1979. THEY WERE WELL RECEIVED BY THE CROWD OUTSIDE THE SHERATON HOTEL.

290743Z

LA PAZ NEWSPAPERS OF OCTOBER 26 ALSO COMMENTED BRIEFLY ON SIMILAR DEMONSTRATIONS IN ORURO AND COCHABAMBA. SPEECHES APPERAED TO BE SIMILAR IN CONTENT. PRESENCIA ESTIMATED THE COCHABAMBA MARCH DREW TWO THOUSAND PEOPLE. HOY CLAIMED “THOUSANDS” OF PEOPLE PARTICIPATED IN THE ORURO RALLY.
COMMENT: THE LARGE TURN OUT AT THE COB DEMONSTRATIONS THROUGHOUT BOLIVIA CAN BE EXPLAINED BY THE FACT THAT: (1) TIN AND ACCESS TO THE SEA ARE THE TWO ISSUES IN BOLIVIA ON WHICH THERE IS WIDESPREAD CONSENSUS; (2) STUDENTS JOINED THE COB MARCH; AND (3) THE DEMONSTRATIONS WERE SCHEDULED FOR MID-AFTERNOON INSTEAD OF AFTER WORKING HOURS. DESPITE THE DEPTH OF BOLIVIAN FEELINGS ON THESE ISSUES, THE DEMONSTRATIONS WERE IMPRESSIVE FOR THEIR DISCIPLINE AND PEACE- FULNESS. BOEKER
   Sheryl P. Walter

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Late Nov 14, the Central Bank ordered commercial banks and the money exchange houses throughout Bolivia to close Nov 15 and Nov 16. The order stated that this measure was being taken to permit fundamental adjustments in the country’s financial system and to avoid unnecessary confusion in normal banking operations.
This came after the Central Bank’s Nov 13 decision to close its foreign exchange window. Banks were open Nov 14 but only for peso transactions; the banks were busy but there was no “run” on pesos. On Thursday, Nov 15, banks and money exchange houses were closed throughout Bolivia catching many people without sufficient pesos to seem them through the four day period until the banks reopen on Monday. The market exchange rate reached as high as 38 pesos to the dollar in La Paz.
Adding to the unrest and devaluation expectations created by the bank holidays, on Nov 15 newspapers and the radio carried news items indicating that the GOB was conducting conversations with the IMF and would announce an economic package shortly. Leaving Thursday’s early morning cabinet meeting, Minister of Finance Agapito Monzon told reporters that an economic package worked out with the IMF had been discussed at the meeting. He assured reporters that the package would not include devaluation and would not raise prices of gasoline, kerosene, and diesel. Resigned to economic measures, the general public remains unconvinced although hopeful that no devaluation will take place. Rumors abound and in Santa Cruz, where surplus contraband dollars frequently move the official exchange rate downward; dollars were not even available from the many street traders.
Santa Cruz has been particularly affected by Bolivia’s economic situation. Importers, an important component of its economy, have been unable to obtain the foreign exchange necessary to meet their foreign credit obligations. Other local businesses have been affected by the GOB’s failure to reimburse the sugar mills for the 1979 harvest causing the impact to be felt and multiplied throughout the local economy.

title: Initiative To Name Guevara Interim President May Prosper
text:
Date:
          August 06, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Niact Immediate 7623
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ads-00 Sy-05 Sye-00 Usss-00 Trse-00 Aid-05 Ciae-00 Nsae-00 Nsce-00 Sso-00 Icae-00 Inre-00 Pm-05 H-02 Inr-10 L-03 Pa-02 Sp-02 Ss-15 Anae-00 A-02 Opr-02 Oc-06 Cco-00 /075 W ——————105036 061344z /40 O 060850z Aug 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          Initiative To Name Guevara Interim President May Prosper
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

An initiative tabled by an ADN senator on August 5 aimed at permitting Senate leader Walter Guevara Arze to be named as Bolivia’s interim president has gained considerable momentum and may be near implementation. Such a compromise would seem to be consonant with the constitution, which provides for the head of the Senate to preside over the government in the absence of the elected President and Vice President.
The Guevara arrangement is being brokered exclusively between the MNR Alliance and the UDP. Representatives of both these groups have pointed out that such a possibility has been under consideration for some time and that the ADN thus has no claim to paternity. As a condition prior, Victor Paz and Hernan Siles reportedly have already renounced their claims on the Presidency.
In the late evening of August 5, an agreement in principle was reached, and Guevara gave a press conference to describe the government he intends to head. He said his purpose would be national conciliation and that both the MNR and the UDP would play important roles. He added that he expected to have the full support of the armed forces, which would retain the defense portfolio. During his “transitional” tenure, Guevara said, he would address the economic situation, which he described as serious but manageable and, with the Congress, attempt to rewrite the electoral law so as to avoid a repetition of the 1979 impasse. In recorded remarks, PDC leader Benjamin Miguel said renewed elections would be called for May 1980, but Guevara himself is reported to have remarked that they might have to slide until 1981.
The compromise was expected to have been formalized by the Congress in the early morning of August 6. However, at the last moment some snags developed and the MNR asked for more time. After some unhelpful interventions by PS-1 Deputy Marcelo Quiroga, the Congress suspended session until 10 AM on August 6.
Although the inauguration will not take place in the morning as scheduled, optimism persists that the Guevara compromise will be firmed up soon—perhaps before August 7. Boeker

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

I told the President that subsequent to his observations to Congressman Whalen about our military assistance program, I had made an investigation with our MILGP to determine the causes and remedies for the delays in the delivery of military equipment. I noted that I have presented new recommendations to Washington for expediting certain equipment for the Bolivian Tipos. As to economic assistance, I noted the continuous and comprehensive efforts of our AID mission to work in the agricultural, public health and education fields, giving me every confidence of a sustained and effective economic cooperation program with his government. I told him I could not understand where his representatives in Washington could have obtained views that our government felt he would soon fall. I indicated our policy was unchanged and it was one of continued support for the GOB and its effort to bring progress and development to the country. I asked for guidance as to which Bolivian authorities the US Mission should work with in attempting to devise a more concrete project for agricultural assistance along the lines he had suggested. I attempted to probe as to whether he thought he had a financial problem or a supply problem. His response was most general and indicated that he had needs both financial and equipment. As I departed Presidential Palace, I met Brazilian Ambassador entering, who, I had been informed informally, was being summoned also for requests for assistance.
Comment: While there may be elements of fact in the synthesis of international concentration of extremists on Bolivia, I have been told that the Zenteno story has not been confirmed and that much of the difficulty in the Cochabamba area is home grown. I agree with his lament about our inability to have kept up the rhythm of deliveries of military equipment for the Tipos. I believe also that the style and pace of our AID economic assistance programs is appropriate and well focused. However, given our continued policy to attempt to support this President and his administration, I do intend to search with the help of our AID and economic people for some ways to assist in the agricultural area, possibly through the device of re-programming counterpart, local currency accumulations and the use of ongoing project activities.
I would appreciate prompt reaction from State and Defense as to ways and means in which we might meet the request for expedited action on MAP equipment submitted in La Paz telegram 608. It would go a long way, I believe, to helping the psychological mood here and to meeting our foreign policy objectives. If State/AID have any suggestions with regard to the requests for emergency economic assistance, I would of course be delighted to have them as promptly as possible. It would also be of interest to me if there is any way of ascertaining the basis for the report that Bolivian representatives in Washington are informing President Banzer that USG has reached the conclusion that he is soon to fall.

Stedman

title: Ambassador’s Comments On Ara/Ecp Paper On Bolivian Economy And Us Lending Options
text:
Date:
          March 14, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Priority 5237
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Eb-08 Ss-15 L-03 Inr-10 Sp-02 /054 W ——————033450 150204z /62 P 142052z Mar 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          Ambassador’s Comments On Ara/Ecp Paper On Bolivian Economy And Us Lending Options
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PFOR, EFIN, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

C - Entire Text
While ARA/ECP paper is a good, professional job, its analysis of Bolivia’s economic problem is too sanguine and its prescription of remedial measures, therefore, too mild.
Recent data indicate that the Bolivian financial situation is deteriorating faster than indicated in ECP paper. Paper uses semi-official estimate of eight percent increase for imports in ’79, whereas ’78 increase was 23 percent (FOB) and preliminary data indicate January ’79 imports soared more than 50 percent above same month last year. On ’79 exports paper uses 10 percent increase for B/P estimates and 8-12 percent for calculating debt service rations, whereas we now expect no increase in ’79 exports (as result continuing fall in tin production, delays in gas pipeline expansion, to Argentina, and impact of flooding on agricultural exports). These trends indicate a very large current account deficit this year in range of $500-$550 million and an over-all deficit of maybe $250-$300 million. Reserve loss in first two months of ’79 was $20 million, but would have been much higher but for special factors. Liquid reserves are nearing rock bottom and government will probably increase its arrears on official debt significantly in March. Separate cable covers recent economic picture in more detail.
The financial situation is, therefore, likely to reach critical stage by July to September timeframe, not 1980, as cited in ECP paper. There are some factors associated with the July/August election and change of government which will themselves accelerate deterioration. Some banks are now holding up on new loans to GOB, pending clarification of political prospects. Proverbial uncertainty with political change in Bolivia should also lead to more capital flight. Very large peso deposits with (shaky) maintenance of value guarantee are a potential source of large capital flight whenever psychological worm turns. The military’s rushing to take care of itself in dying days of military government will aggravate B/P situation (DOLS 100 million in arms purchases being most blatant example).
Equally important political factors argue clearly for a stabilization program shortly after August inauguration. The elected government, as Vic Paz indicated to me, will want to try to survive the popular backlash to economic stabilization measures by 1) fixing the blame squarely on previous governments and 2) making use of its fresh electoral mandate. That government will want to weather this storm at a time when the military is not yet ready to challenge it and hope to be on the up side of “J” curve before the military begins to look critically at the civilian government’s record.
A US program loan can play an important part in this–not because of the amount, which is helpful but not critical, but because of the timing and politics. A US program loan early in the period of the elected government, close in time to a stabilization program, lends significant international blessing and, therefore, domestic weight to that government and its program. What the US thinks and does still carries great clout in Bolivia, and a program will be easier to adopt, at the right time, with overt US support. There are undoubtedly a dozen Latin American countries where this is not true, but Bolivia is different.
In considering US program lending, we should consider both FY79 and FY80 funds. As far as I am concerned, only one project in these two years is untouchable–the Chapare agricultural development loan; that we need to do for our own interests.
As regards the content of a stabilization program, it is not correct to view the IMF’s October 1978 program as an on-the-shelf program, ready to go in August 1979 or whenever. With the continuing deterioration of the financial situation, the corrective measures needed have changed and may change further. The IMF’s program of “de-dollarization” of guaranteed deposits is totally unfeasible at this point. With the existing state of low confidence a ten percentage point differential in interest rates would not move investors out of dollar-guaranteed deposits. New, more drastic solutions are needed, such as a succession of exchange rate changes, with the guarantee not renewed after the initial change and pay-off. Regardless of monetary consequences, exchange rate reform can no longer be avoided. With a debt service ration headed past 40 percent, I do not see how debt rescheduling can be avoided either. The ceilings on new borrowings, Central Bank credit to the public sector, etc., have to be reworked as well. We should encourage the IMF and IBRD on one hand, and the leading Bolivian electoral candidates on the other, to start developing the elements of a new program for August/September.

BIO NOTES FOLLOW BELOW ON SEVEN NEW MINISTERS IN THE ALL-MILITARY CABINET SWORN IN BY PRESIDENT BANZER ON 8 JULY 1974:
JUAN LECHIN SUAREZ - MINISTER OF COORDINTION - THE 53- YEAR OLD LECHIN IS ARETIRED BRIGADIER GENERAL. A FULL BIO- REPORT ON HIM DATED JANUARY 1971 IS CONTAINED IN THE BIO- GRAPHIC HANDBOOK, THE REPORT CARRIES HIS CAREER UP TO HIS APPOINTMENT AS AMBASSADOR TO THE UK AND THE NETHERLANDS, A POST HE HELD UNTIL ABOUT A MONTH AGO. LECHIN IS A MODERATE CONSERVATIVE WITH BROAD ADMINISTRATIVE EXPERIENCE (E.G. PRESIDENT OF THE BOLIVIAN MINING CORPORATION FROM 1964 TO 1968). LECHIN HAS A GOOD REPUTATION AMONG MILITARY AND CIVILIANS ALIKE.
VICTOR CASTILLO SUAREZ - MINISTER OF FINANCE - COL CAS- TILLO WAS BORN IN 1924. HE WAS UNTIL RECENTLY HEAD OF THE MILITARY SCHOOL IN COCHABAMBA (INCLUDING THE COMMAND AND GENERAL STAFF SCHOOL). THE ARMA HAS BEEN IMPRESSED WITH HIS

110327Z
SOLID COMPETENCE, BUT HE APPARENTLY HAS NO SPECIAL QUALIFI-
CATIONS FOR THE MINISTRY OF FINANCE. SOME COLLEAGUES BELIEVE HE MAY BE EASILY INFLUENCED BY HIS STAFF. 4. GENERAL RENE BERNAL ESCALANTE-MINISTER OF DEFENSE A 50- YEAR OLD ARMY OFFICER, HE HAS UNTIL RECENTLY BEEN CHIEF OF THE COMBINED STAFF. HE HAS SERVED AS MILITARY ATTACHE IN WASHINGTON (A HAPPY MEMORABLE EXPERIENCE FOR HIM) AND HAS BEEN VERY CLOSE AND HELPFUL TO MEMBERS OF THE USMILGRP IN BOLIVIA. HE WAS ONE OF THE PRINCIPAL HIGH RANKING OFFICERS INTERESTED IN EXAMINING THE ACQUISITION OF SOVIET MILITARY EQUIPMENT. HOWEVER, HE RECE DENIED REAL INTEREST AND EXPLAINED HIS PARTICIPATION TO THE AMBASSADOR BY SAYING THAT HIS ROLE CONSISTED SOLELY IN REPLYING POLITELY TO OFFERS PRESSED ON HIM BY THE SOVIET EMBASSY. BERNAL WAS MINISTER OF CAMPESINO AFFAIRS FROM 1964 TO 1966 AND IS BELIEVED TO BE HIGHLY IN- TERESTED AND INFORMED ON CAMPESINO MATTERS. 5. LT COL WALDO BERNAL PEREIRA MINISTER OF EDUCATION A FORTY YEAR OLD AIR FORCE OFFICER, BERNAL WAS CHIEF OF THE PRESI- DENTIAL HOUSEHOLD. HE HAS BEEN TO THREE US AIR FORCE SCHOOLS AND SPEAKS GOOD ENGLISH. HE DISTINGUISHED HIMSELF AS COMMANDER OF THE SANTA CRUZ AIR FORCE ACADEMY. HE HAS BEEN DESCRIBED AS HIGHLY PROFESSIONAL, PREGMATIC AND VERY CLOSE TO PRESIDENT BANZER BOTH POLITICALLY AND PERSONNALLY. 6. COL ANTONIO ZELAYA S. MINISTER OF MINING ZELAYA IS A 47 YEAR OLD ARMY ENGINEER WHO IS A GEOGRAPHER AND GEODESIST. HE HAS HELD MANY MILITARY AND CIVILIAN SCIENTIFIC AND ACA- DEMIC POSITIONS (INCLUDING RECTOR OF THE UNIVERSITY OF LA PAZ VERY BRIEFLY). HE IS THE MILITARY PRESIDENT OF THE CENTER OF GRADUATES OF THE SCHOOL OF HIGH MILITARY STUDIES. HIS TECHNICAL BACKGROUND SHOULD BE USEFUL, AS THE MINISTRY GIVES GREATER EMPHASIS TO EXPLORATION FOR NEW MINING SITES. 7. CAPTAIN WALTER NUNEZ RIVERO MINISTER OF TRANSPORTATION AND COMMUNICATIONS NUNEZ IS A 44 YEAR OLD NAVAL OFFICER. HE RETURNED FROM LIMA WHERE HE WAS BOLIVIAN NAVAL ATTACHE TO TAKE OVER THE MINISTRY. OLD REPORTS INDICATE THAT HE WAS DYNAMIC AND RESPECTED NAVAL OFFICER, BUT THAT HE APPEARED TO HAVE ENRICHED HIMSELF FROM SEVERAL OF HIS ASSIGNMENTS. HE IS STRONG PROPONENT OF DEVELOPING THE WATERWAYS TRANS- PORTATION IN THE NORTH AND EAST SECTIONS OF THE COUNTRY.
110327Z

LT COL MARIO VARGAS SALINAS MINISTER OF LABOR VARGAS WAS UNTIL RECENTLY PRESIDENT OF THE BOLIVIAN DEVELOPMENT CORP- PRATION (CBF). HE WAS REPORTEDLY GIVEN THE CBF BECAUSE OF HIS HIGH STANDING AMONG THE YOUNGER OFFICERS AND TO REMOVE HIM FROM THE RANKS OF THOSE PLOTTING AGAINST THE BANZER REGIME. HE HAS LOST STANDING WITH THE YOUNGER OFFICERS BUT SENIOR OFFICERS CONSIDER HIM A STRONG PERFORMER. HE USED HIS POSITION WITH THE CBF TO DEMONSTRATE HIS ORGANIZATIONAL ABILITIES. HE IS POLITICALLY AMBITIOUS AND AS MINISTER OF LABOR WILL BE IN AN IDEAL POSITION TO BUILD A POLITICAL FOLLOWING.
WE EXPECT TO SEND ADDITINAL FACTS AND COMMENTARY ON THESE INDIVIDUALS OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS. STEDMAN

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Reftel reported our T0013, an invitation for preselection of bidders to design and build two refineries and one lubricants plant, with financing by IDE.
Rolanda Prada, general manager, Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales Bolivianos (YPFB), the Bolivian government’s petroleum corporation which issued invitation, at dinner at Ambassador Stedman’s residence on January 8, mentioned to Emboffs that YPFB may forswear use of IDB credit to finance building refineries at Cochabamba and Santa Cruz. As originally planned, project will cost US $58 million, 20 percent of which will be paid by YPFB and the remainder financed by IDB. He stated IDB demands too many requisites and takes too long to disburse. He added that loan negotiations for refineries and lubricant plant have been going on now for over two years and may continue for an additional six months. He added that it is just as convenient financially to borrow commercially (has had offer of 10-year credit from First National Bank of Boston) and roll over credit as it is to borrow from IDB ordinary capital.
He said YPFB tired of waiting and has issued cited invitation with deadline of February 18. YPFB expects to get favorable bid from Japanese firms which may agree to receive payment in crude petroleum.
Prada also said Santa Cruz refinery is to be constructed with 10,000 barrel per day capacity, expandable to 15,000.
Refair is 1972 “Petroleum Report”, containing more detail on Bolivian petroleum industry. Invitation’s specifications were sent to USDOC (BIC-267) January 3, 1973.
Bolivia’s petroleum exports in 1973 estimated at 11.9 million barrels up from 10.9 million in 1972.
Comment: Should be borne in mind that, if Japanese get contract it will be major entree for them as seller to YPFB as well as buyer of Bolivian crude. Embassy believes that, as indicated to Emboffs earlier on January 8, YPFB would be receptive to a similar offer from U.S. firm.
Action Requested: Encourage U.S. firms to communicate directly with YPFB ASAP at address shown Reftel. Also, make available to interested U.S. firms the detailed IDB documents on this project.

Local reaction to meeting of Foreign Ministers Mexico City thus far limited to statement issued by Foreign Ministry on February 23, and February 25 editorial in leading morning newspaper Presencia. Text of Foreign Ministry statement read as follows: “The delegation of Bolivia proposed today in the conference of Foreign Ministers that the following points should be included in the proposals which are presented to the Secretary of State of the United States of America, Henry A. Kissinger: (1) That in the area of Development Assistance, the United States grant most favorable treatment to the least developed countries, and even more to those nations with geographic limitations, such as a land-locked status. (2) That the United States avoid policies and measures which affect the economies of Latin American states which produce minerals and other basic products. Both suggestions received the unanimous support of the Latin American countries meeting in the Mexican capital. The spokesman of the Foreign Ministers presented the first point to Secretary of State Kissinger, who accepted fully this orientation for inclusion in the program of Development Assistance.”
Presencia editorial, following up on views quoted in reftel, stated that conference had created “a new spirit in hemispheric relations with the United States.” Editorial greets Declaration of Tlatelolco as beginning of “new political order” in which USG will no longer seek to impose unilateral decisions on Latin America. Nonetheless, editorial concludes by warning that such a change cannot be expected to occur suddenly, and calls upon United States to exercise continuing “good will” and “desire to cooperate” with Latin America as proof of its willingness to establish new relationship with the region.

title: The Bolivian Economy Limps Into 1979
text:
Date:
          January 09, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 4258
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Aid-05 Ciae-00 Come-00 Eb-08 Frb-03 Inr-10 Nsae-00 Ica-11 Trse-00 Xmb-02 Opic-03 Sp-02 Lab-04 Acda-12 Sil-01 Omb-01 Nsc-05 Ss-15 Str-07 Cea-01 Pa-01 Doe-15 Soe-02 Int-05 Gsa-02 /131 W ——————111255 092210z /66 R 092020z Jan 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          The Bolivian Economy Limps Into 1979
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EGEN, EFIN, ECON, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Entire text.
By mid-January we expect Minister of Finance Alba to make a presentation to the Cabinet on the state of the Bolivian economy. He will be hard pressed to find any good news for his colleagues as he describes the economic results of 1978, and he can scarcely be hopeful in discussing the prospects for 1979. The Central Bank’s latest official (but unpublished) estimate of the 1978 balance of payments deficit is $132 million. Year-end international reserves of the consolidated banking system are now expected by the bank to be approximately $60 million. (Comment: Reserves appear to have been bolstered by short-term borrowings but details are not yet available.) Unless foreign exchange purchases by private citizens are halted, which is unlikely, or new financial credits are obtained, banking system reserves may fall to zero in January or February.
This message deals with the performance of the Bolivian economy in 1978, touching as well on structural problems that will continue to affect economic performance in 1979. A subsequent cable will describe the political context in which economic stabilization measures are being considered, and will speculate on the short-term economic policies of the Padilla government. All data in the following paragraphs are drawn from official sources unless otherwise stated. Embassy estimates, which are somewhat more pessimistic, are contained in Table I.
Current account: Central Bank estimates prepared in mid-December project a current account deficit of $370 million. Bolivian export revenues rose by only an estimated 3 percent, to $668.7 million in 1978, despite record world market tin prices. Tin production declined five percent during the year. Petroleum exports, which had been falling since 1974, ended temporarily in October 1978. Sales of gas condensates brought revenues of $79.3 million, $11.9 million more than in 1977. Exports of agricultural products earned $92.3 million, an increase of $9.5 million over 1977. Imports in 1978 increased approximately 20 percent by value to $785 million, despite announced GOB efforts to reduce import growth through public sector budget cuts and changes in monetary policy. The services account deficit is estimated by the GOB to have amounted to $275.6 million, 46 percent greater than the deficit of the previous year. The increase is attributed to higher freight and insurance costs, as well as rising debt service payments.
Capital account. Net long-term capital inflow in 1978 was approximately $379 million, an increase of 12 percent over the previous year. Estimates of short-term capital flight, which increased in the second half of 1978, are being reformulated at this time. Until mid-December the Central Bank projected a net deficit in the short-term capital account of $141 million. By the first week of January this estimate had been revised downward by $60 million to $80 million, resulting in a figure which seems unrealistic to US. Both the IMF and the Central Bank are now checking for errors in the latest calculations.
Net balance and international reserves: The deficit in the balance of payments for 1979 is estimated by the Central Bank to be between $120 and $130 million. The Central Bank will reportedly end the year with net international reserves of approximately $162 million, and the international reserves of the consolidated banking system will be about $60 million. These figures, obtained from the Central Bank January 3, 1979, appear to reflect some short-term year-end borrowing which may have been specifically designed to inflate reserves.
Public sector deficit: The total deficit of Bolivia’s public sector for 1978 will be between $450 and $500 million. A high level of investment by the state enterprises (investments exceeded $550 million in 1977) continued in 1978, despite a shift in their current account balance from a surplus of $50 million in 1977 to a deficit of approximately $35 million the following year. During 1978, Central Bank credit to the public sector increased by 93 percent as compared with 1977. The IMF (which places the deficit at $469 million) estimates that the public sector deficit equalled 11.4 percent of GDP. According to the IMF, 65 percent ($304 million) of the deficit was financed with foreign credits.
Debt and debt service: Bolivia’s disbursed external debt is estimated by the IMF to have increased by 23 percent in 1978 to $1.797 billion. The debt service ratio for the year was 28.9 percent. If no refinancing is done in 1979, the debt service ratio will rise to at least 34 percent ($250 million). Not only is the magnitude of Bolivia’s debt increasing with discouraging rapidity, the terms of the debt are hardening, and foreign borrowings are being used to cover current expenses, including tax payments to the Central Government by the public corporations.
Inflation: According to official statistics, inflation was held to 18 percent in 1978. This relatively reasonable rate is explained by the relatively low growth in the money supply (M2) (9 percent), which is in turn accounted for by the heavy demand for foreign currency and the consequent decline in international reserves.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED
2. **Introduction:** Since August, there have been several changes in Bolivia's political/military environment which bear on our security assistance relationship. First, the Government of Air Force General Juan Pereda proved to be short-lived: it was deposed on November 24, 1978, by a military junta headed by Army General David Padilla. The Padilla government promptly declared general elections for July 1, 1979, setting August 6 as the date of transferring power to the new constitutional government. Second, the economy, which began to decline toward the end of the Banzer regime, has, under Pereda and Padilla, deteriorated exponentially. Padilla has been reluctant to implement necessary corrective measures for two reasons: (1) he fears that attendant social unrest could threaten the electoral timetable, and (2) he does not want to invite popular criticism of the armed forces. Despite the deepening economic crisis, Padilla and his colleagues have been careful not to sacrifice their institutional interests. Aware that funds are in ever shorter supply, they are determined to purchase necessary military equipment before surrendering power on August 6. In our view, at least some of these purchases, although hardly timely, may be necessary. In the past several years, Bolivia's armed forces have been undersupplied and underequipped. Withdrawing from the government, they will require new equipment in order to recoup the professional esprit that has atrophied in recent years. Finally, although the threat of conflict between Chile and Peru has diminished, top commanders still worry that Bolivia's borders can be violated with impunity. This perception impels them to refurbish their inventories. Justified or not, they are not likely to feel secure until they have done so.

3. **US Interests/Objectives:**
A. The security assistance program is directly tied to the pivotal United States' interest of maintaining stability in the Andean region. In addition, the program helps develop interpersonal relationships between US and Bolivian officers. Such relationships facilitate valuable exchanges of views and serve as a conduit for expressions of US interest in matters such as democratization, respect for human rights, arms control and the reduction of tension in the Andean region. Finally, security assistance complements programs in support of economic development and helps sustain an environment in which the US has access to domestic raw materials and in which US products may be marketed competitively.
B. Security assistance objectives are postulated on the maintenance of a constructive relationship with the Bolivian military. They entail encouraging the military: (1) to display restraint and moderation in its renovation efforts; (2) to continue to emphasize its nation-building and civic action roles; and (3) to respect human rights and the democratic development process. Within this context, we must remain responsive to requests for assistance in acquiring reasonable amounts of military equipment and be able to provide appropriate CZ and CONUS training for armed forces personnel.

4. **External/Internal Threats:** The likelihood of conflict between Chile and Argentina over the Beagle Channel issue appears to have diminished significantly in the past few months; similarly, nearly halfway through the centenary year of the War of the Pacific, a Peruvian attack against Chile seems most improbable. Nonetheless, the specter of such conflicts, however unlikely, has made a strong impression on the Bolivian military. Whatever strategies the potential combatants may consider, Bolivian officers view their national boundaries as all but defenseless. They are acutely aware that since gaining independence in 1825, Bolivia has lost territory to all five neighboring countries. With a land area approximately twice that of France and with a population of less than five million, they need not resort to sophisticated analysis to demonstrate that it remains vulnerable to armed incursion and cultural encroachment.

title: (C) Prospects For Labor Peace Through The July Elections Remain Good
text:
Date:
          March 16, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 5282
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Com-02 Ciae-00 Eb-08 Inr-10 Lab-04 Nsae-00 Sil-01 Ica-11 /052 W ——————087946 182223z /42 R 162041z Mar 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          (C) Prospects For Labor Peace Through The July Elections Remain Good
        
                    
          TAGS:
          ELAB, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          LA PAZ A-05
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: The relatively quiet labor scene that prevailed in Bolivia during 1978 has continued into the first part of 1979. The trade unions, eager to avoid strikes that could jeopardize the democratization process, have been moderate in their wage demands, which the business sector and the GOB have been willing to accommodate. The result has been 14 months of relative labor peace. While most observers expect quiescence to continue through the July elections, there are three factors that could destabilize the situation: (A) increasing pressure from the rank and file for additional wage increases because of the rising rate of inflation; (B) a public posture by the GOB not to grant any wage increases to public sector employees and leave this question to the incoming elected government; and (C) the upcoming (May 1) congress of the Bolivian Workers Center (COB) and the possibility that longtime COB leader Juan Lechin Oquendo might try to provoke labor agitation in order to enhance his reelection bid. Nevertheless, with labor’s wanting to avoid any disruption of the democratization process, the chances of avoiding serious strikes appear to be reasonably good. End summary.
During the first ten weeks of 1979, the relatively tranquil state of labor-management relations that prevailed in Bolivia during 1978 has continued. As discussed in the 1978 Annual Labor Report (REFAIR), the Bolivian labor movement, having been badly burned by the suspension of labor freedoms from 1974 to 1978 under the Banzer regime, has been a strong supporter of the democratization process and the return of elected civilian government. Accordingly, in order to avoid possibly disruptive strikes that could jeopardize this process, the unions have been deliberately modest in their wage demands.
In turn, the private sector has been forthcoming in its willingness to accommodate these demands. Bolivian entrepreneurs have recognized that the workers have been caught in an inflationary squeeze (with inflation running at 18 percent in 1978 and around 30 percent (annual rate) thus far this year, according to informed sources), and they have responded with wage increases that have compensated the workers in full or in large part for losses in purchasing power.
In the public sector, both the Pereda and Padilla administrations have pursued a similarly moderate wage policy. The result has been that in the 14 months since labor freedoms were restored in January 1978, there has not been a single major strike in Bolivia, and what strikes and work stoppages that have occurred have been few and of short duration.
Although most leaders and observers in both the labor and business sectors believe that this relative stability will continue through July 1, there are a few problems ahead.
The great majority of labor leaders remain as committed as before to the democratization process, but they are feeling increasing pressure from the rank and file to obtain additional wage increases this year to compensate for the sharply increased rate of inflation.
Nevertheless, this pressure may not necessarily present insurmountable problems in the private sector because business leaders in most cases appear to be prepared to negotiate wage increases sufficient to meet at least the minimum demands of the rank and file.
Negotiations are presently continuing with the factory workers and construction workers confederations. The issue in the former case is not salary (at least not yet), but whether the wage increase to be granted should be negotiated between the Chamber of Industry and the Labor Confederation (labor’s position) or between each individual factory and its union (business’s position). Although both sides appear to want to avoid a strike, negotiations have been prolonged and patience may be drawing short. A prolonged strike, though, would appear unlikely.
The situation in the public sector may be somewhat more difficult because in February President Padilla announced that the GOB would be unable to grant any wage increases to government employees due to the economic problems facing the country. Requests for wage increases would have to be decided by the civilian government taking office on August 6. Amazingly, a secret salary increase granted by Padilla to military officers has not become generally known.
Nevertheless, there may be some flexibility in the GOB’s position. Bolivia’s two teacher confederations have been trying to negotiate a wage increase for months, but the Minister of Education, Colonel Jose Olvis (who may be on his way out), has refused to discuss the issue and has simply reiterated the GOB’s public position on public sector wage increases. However, President Padilla, according to the leader of the La Paz Urban Teachers Federation, met with the teachers before departing on his trip to Venezuela and Brazil and told them that he would resolve the problem in their favor on his return to Bolivia. The teachers appear eager to avoid a strike and thus some solution appears probable.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM

Summary: A recent (January 30 - February 2) visit to Santa Cruz by an Embassy officer revealed that support for the electoral process is growing in this key regional capital, and that most business and political observers, with the exception of the FSB, believe Victor Paz Estenssoro will carry the Santa Cruz department in the coming elections. Private businessmen in Santa Cruz have pledged approximately $500,000 of the $3.5 million Paz estimates is necessary to run his campaign, and the private sector has also agreed to pay the expenses of Santa Cruz delegates to the MNR convention in La Paz.
The consensus among political parties and business leaders at the moment is that ex-President Banzer will not become a presidential candidate. Most believe that the majority of the supporters of the ex-President are disposed to back Victor Paz. End Summary.
With the emergence of the Victor Paz Estenssoro presidential candidacy seemingly assured, and divisions appearing in the UDP coalition, the political atmosphere in Santa Cruz has calmed considerably during the past three weeks. Paz met personally with prominent Santa Cruz businessmen before travelling to La Paz for the MNR convention, and according to a participant in that meeting, approximately $500,000 was pledged to the Paz campaign. The MNR leadership is said to have discussed agricultural policy at some length with the Santa Cruz cattlemen and major farmers and to have made commitments regarding the agricultural policies that would be followed by a Paz government.
When asked by an Embassy officer about the prospects for broadening the party’s support in the Santa Cruz area, local MNR leaders made it clear that they are opening the doors, albeit quietly, to the followers of ex-President Hugo Banzer. Although denying direct contact with either Banzer or his advisers, MNR officials said they expect support from this quarter because they intend to make it known that an MNR government would concentrate on dealing with problems at hand rather than dwelling on the past. (Comment: This approach is obviously designed to reassure those who would not welcome an investigation of their performance as members of the Banzer government.)
According to an adviser and relative of ex-President Banzer, the former president does not now intend to participate as a candidate in the coming elections. Asked whom Banzer followers might be expected to support, the source commented that they would probably back Paz, although he inferred this might be done indirectly via General Bernal and the PDC. He added that at this point whatever risks might be entailed in carrying out the electoral process seem preferable to the certain reaction that would follow a cancellation or unwarranted postponement of elections.
As might be expected, leaders of the Falange (FSB) in Santa Cruz claim to be confident of victory in the July elections. Outlining a strategy which calls for strong attacks on Victor Paz and his policies as President of Bolivia, FSB representatives explained that they plan to polarize the electorate by showing that there is no political difference between Paz and Siles Zuazo. Having identified these two candidates in the minds of the voters, the FSB expects both the military and the Santa Cruz region to find Paz “as unacceptable as Siles.” At this point the field would be clear for the FSB candidate, Mario Gutierrez. (Comment: Although Santa Cruz remains a stronghold of the FSB on the local level, i.e., FSB candidates are routinely elected to the powerful Pro-Santa Cruz Committee, and serve as Rector of the University, etc., non-FSB political observers in the area find the above scenario implausible. The FSB is not thought to be in a strong position to attack Paz, as it entered into an alliance with the MNR of Paz in 1971. In addition, FSB support outside Santa Cruz – particularly in rural areas – is considered weak. The influential private sector of the region, whose support would be essential to the FSB, does not believe the party or its presidential candidate have significant national appeal, and the lion’s share of the campaign contributions from businessmen is being committed to Paz Estenssoro.)
Conclusions: So long as the Paz candidacy appears viable, and he seems to have a reasonable chance of victory, support in Santa Cruz for the electoral process is likely to remain relatively firm. However, given the deep animosity among influential political and economic groups in the Santa Cruz area toward the UDP (and antipathy toward Siles Zuazo dating back to the late 1950s), should Siles Zuazo at some point in the campaign appear to be a probable victor, pro-election sentiment in Santa Cruz could evaporate rapidly. If the UDP coalition wins the elections, it will be faced with formidable opposition in the Santa Cruz department.

text:

          Subject:
          Ypfb–Rescheduling Of Gulf Settlement And Implications For Budget And Balance Of Payments
        
                    
          TAGS:
          BDIS EFIN BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          STATE 034718; LA PAZ 1277
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

During courtesy call made on him March 11, recently appointed Minister of Energy and Hydrocarbons Jimenez asked me to consider recommending to Washington the use of our “good offices” to assist in the rescheduling of payments to Gulf. He said that at present prices for sales, Bolivia will be paying $2 million a month to Gulf and thus will liquidate remaining approximately $70 million of debt in three or four years. Minister said that government is receiving criticism in several quarters for maintaining rates of payment to Gulf in face of desperate need for use of these resources for budgetary and investment purposes. While he realized government could defend itself to some extent by asserting that percentage arrangement was beneficial to Bolivia in event production and sales declined, this argument hardly satisfies solicitants for increased budgetary allocations under present high world prices of petroleum. According to Minister, Gulf has offered to accept lump sum payment at somewhat smaller amount, but this would place GOB in position of having to negotiate commercial bank credit over short period at high interest rates. Minister Jimenez said that Bolivian representatives had put several alternatives forward to Gulf which is expected to respond within a week or so. Minister not optimistic that Gulf will accept any of these alternatives and hence asked for USG “good offices” so as to free up sorely needed funds for current uses now being derived from high petroleum prices. Minister was well briefed on conversation reported in State 034718 but asked us to reconsider position outlined by BC Deputy Director Lowenthal.
I indicated that our position at the moment was not to become involved in rescheduling negotiations, but in view of Minister’s earnest request to me, I would pass on to Washington by telegram his request and solicit a Washington comment.
In La Paz 1277 it was requested that Dept. might wish to obtain from Gulf estimates of current payments at existing prices so as to clarify the facts of on-going GOB payments to Gulf. As was mentioned in La Paz 1277, if high levels of payments to Gulf are correct, Embassy estimate of 1974 balance of payments surplus would fall from a forecasted $11.4 million to a deficit of $6.9 million. If this is so, it may very well be in USG interest to consider extending “good offices” so as to facilitate over the near term proceeds from GE and petroleum sales for domestic investment needs.

          Ref:
          (A) STATE 310299, (B) STATE 316945 A. THE SETTING
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Bolivia is now trying to emerge from a two-year period of political turbulence, short-lived and ineffective governments, economic decline and intense military-civilian tension. The most consistent trends during this period have been broad popular pressure for civilian government and growing anti-military sentiment, culminating in the strident repudiation and undoing of the Natusch coup and installation of the Gueiler government in November 1979.
US-Bolivian relations are excellent and US prestige in the country has reached a new high, primarily because the US in both good times and bad (the Natusch coup) has been consistently on the right side of the popular ground swell for human rights and civilian, representative government. Our support in the OAS for Bolivia’s aspiration for access to the Pacific has also added significantly to US prestige here. Our relationship with the military has weakened concomitantly because of our association with the tarnished respectability and political decline of military government and because of the supplanting of US training and orientation by the much harder line of Argentine military institutions in particular.
The sharp cuts in the FY 80 aid program have threatened the image of the US as a provider of significant economic support for Bolivia, at a time when the government is courageously and successfully laying the financial policy base for renewed development momentum. At the same time the highly successful PL-480 Title III program has proved an ideal developmental and political instrument for the Bolivian environment (and has been widely publicized by USICA and Bolivian media). On the other hand, prolonged US consideration of GSA tin disposals has been and will remain the most volatile and negative factor in the US-Bolivian relationship as Bolivia enters an election campaign and continues efforts to consolidate civilian government.
The near-term prospects for that consolidation remain precarious as a weak, if determined, Gueiler government enforces an unpopular economic stabilization program and tries to guide an uncertain and possibly turbulent electoral process. The longer-term prognosis is brighter, both economically and politically.

B. Bilateral Issues

The three areas of weakness in the US-Bolivian relationship remain our so-far inadequate response to Bolivia’s current economic plight, weak US influence on the military, and backlash to current US policy on tin disposals.
As Bolivia tries to emerge from virtual financial insolvency the PL-480 Title III program has been a most effective and widely applauded instrument of US support. We should now take advantage of the program’s strong development record to increase the FY 80 allocation and thereby the short-term financial impact. This will both allow the government to maintain a higher level of investment in rural areas and help relieve the severe foreign exchange bind. As political stability increases the government’s ability to administer additional project funds, this important program to achieve longer term economic strength and structural reform should increase accordingly.
As our IMET levels have declined over the last decade, so has the influence of the US and US ideals in a Bolivian military which desperately needs reorientation toward an apolitical and military professional role. Some blame the US counter insurgency doctrine of the 60s for the Bolivian military’s fixation with imaginary internal security problems, but this is pure scapegoat seeking. In fact, the military’s interventionism pre-dates our training programs and our more recent inability to finance training in the US has coincided with the evolution of arrogant and power-hungry attitudes in a faction of the officer corps. Increased IMET to finance military training in the US would not in itself solve the problem of military reorientation, but it would contribute importantly to parallel Bolivian efforts.
The most persistently negative issue in bilateral relations remains US tin disposals. Over the past two years continuing Congressional consideration of a disposal authorization, even in the absence of actual sales, has produced constant abrasion in an otherwise smooth bilateral relationship. We understand milling of PL-480 wheat in Arequipa has stopped. We unable get definite information from MININD/COM officials who say Subsecretary Zamorano is only official who has facts on this matter at his command. Zamorano has been out of La Paz.
With reference para 2 ref A, GOB decision mill flour in Arequipa not a premeditated conscious violation of PL-480 regulations, during which GOB could take into consideration purchase of flour from U.S. GOB decision was taken in emergency situation created by a) Peruvian Southern Railway strike, b) need obtain storage space at Matarani for incoming shipments, and c) need insure adequate flour supply to La Paz at time when local mills were unable meet demand due their limited capacity and usual supply of flour from Argentina was not forthcoming. In these unforeseen and probably unforeseeable circumstances, we do not see that there is a U.S. domestic issue raised.
We have serious reservations about telling MININD/COM, at this time at least, that his action to mill PL-480 wheat in Peru will automatically convert PL-480 purchase to commercial purchase. Bolivia is now undergoing great stress from GOB decisions to increase control prices on basic food items by more than 100 percent (see ref B). Street demonstrations, store break-ins and attempts, kidnapping of police officers, dynamitings, exchanges of gun fire with injuries between police and crowds have all occurred over the last few days. GOB feels none too secure. GOB also unhappy and shaken by USG decision not grant further PL-480 this FY and USG advice to not count on PL-480 for FY 1975. MININD/COM has already shown tendency to try to put as much blame for his present wheat and flour troubles on USG as he can (see ref C). We believe USG could come in for major public accusations that it is responsible for world wheat shortage, high wheat prices, and withdrawal of badly needed support at critical time if this situation is not handled carefully. Moreover, conversion to commercial sale would deny GOB about $20 million in generations which sorely needed. As ref A ignores 1) transport problems in moving wheat from Matarani to La Paz, etc., and transport and other problems in moving Argentine flour to Bolivia and 2) important factors presented in paras 3 and 4 above, request instruction ref A be carefully reconsidered.

title: Election Day Impressions
text:
Date:
          July 02, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Niact Immediate 0000
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ads-00 Sso-00 Nsce-00 Inre-00 Icae-00 Ciae-00 Pm-05 H-01 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Pa-01 Sp-02 Ss-15 /053 W ——————032945 020934z /10
        
                    
          Subject:
          Election Day Impressions
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

By all accounts thus far, the July 1 elections have come off extremely smoothly with virtually no violence and few reports of fraud or irregularities. Turnout appears to have been heavy. These may well be the cleanest elections in Bolivia’s history, as promised by the Padilla regime from its inception last November.
Conagents in Cochabamba and Santa Cruz confirm for their areas what we have heard officially from the Ministry of the Interior as being the situation throughout the country, that the whole process has been peaceful and orderly with only a few incidents of no political significance being reported.
According to unofficial results, as of 2300 hours local time July 1, some 578,000 votes had been counted (31 per cent) of the total registered vote. The breakdown is as follows:
A. Hernan Siles Zuazo (UDP) - 199,000 (34 percent) B. Victor Paz Estenssoro (MNR) - 150,000 (26 per cent) C. Hugo Banzer Suarez (ADN) - 133,000 (23 per cent) D. Marcel Quiroga Santa Cruz (PS) - 52,000 (9 per cent) E. Rene Bernal Escalante (APIN) - 28,000 (5 per cent)
In the city of La Paz, Siles is leading with 43 per cent of the vote, to win handily in the department, but the big surprise is Banzer’s lead over Paz in the city itself.
Elsewhere in the Altiplano (Highlands), early returns are as follows:
A. Oruro - Paz has a narrow lead over Siles (29-28 pct) overall. Final results show that Paz captured the capital city with 30 pct, but most of the countryside vote has not yet come in and could well give the department ultimately to Siles. Bernal appears not to have been a factor in his home department.
B. Cochabamba - With results thus far only from the city of Cochabamba, Banzer is leading Siles 17,304 to 16,268 with Quiroga Santa Cruz having won 14,506. Paz is fourth with 7,155. With about 20 pct of the countryside vote in, Siles is leading Paz 33 pct to 27 pct with Banzer in third place with 13 pct.
C. Chuquisaca - Final results from the city of Sucre show Siles won 52 pct followed by Banzer with 14 pct and Paz with 11.5 pct. No results are in yet from the countryside.
D. Potosi - Siles has a narrow edge over Paz, 41 pct to 39 pct with about 60 pct of the city vote in. Scattered returns from the countryside show both Paz and Siles doing well but with no pattern yet apparent. None of the other candidates appears to be a factor in this department.
In the eastern departments of Beni, Santa Cruz, Pando, and Tarija, Paz is, as expected, doing very well, and Banzer surprisingly is beating out Siles for second place. In the Pando, final results from the capital city Cobija show Paz winning 42 pct to Banzer’s 33 pct and Siles’ 20 pct. In Santa Cruz, Paz is leading in the capital city by 36 pct to 34 pct over Banzer, and apparently doing even better in the countryside. With returns from only three towns, Paz’ majorities range from 53 pct to 67 pct. In Paz’ home department of Tarija, he was leading in the capital city with 43 pct, and in the countryside with 65 pct of the vote. Finally, in the Beni, with an estimated 55 pct of the total vote in, Paz was leading Banzer 41 pct to 31 pct, with Siles in third place (17 pct).
According to officials of the Permanent Assembly on Human Rights (PAHR), there have been very few incidents of fraud or violence thus far reported. The only incident of violence reported involved the theft of three voting boxes Saturday night in the department of Beni. Allegations of fraud have also been few, and, according to the PAHR, minor. The only incident of any importance involved the nullification of the results at two voting stations in Beni because of “irregularities.” All radio broadcasts thus far monitored support the impression the election day 1979 was remarkably tranquil throughout the country.
Comment: The major surprise thus far is Banzer’s strength manifested by early returns. This may wane somewhat, however, as returns from the provinces of Potosi, Cochabamba, Oruro and Chuquisaca departments come in where Banzer is generally much less influential. The above overall percentages will therefore fluctuate (somewhat) until the final returns come in, but it would appear at this time that Siles will win his plurality, but not big, and certainly not the majority of the popular vote.

          Oct-01 Ads-00 Ciae-00 Pm-06 H-01 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Pa-01 Sp-02 Ss-15 Sph-01 Eb-08 Aid-05 Trse-00 Nsce-00 Sso-00 Icae-00 Inre-00 /068 W ——————043116 130444z /73 O 130325z Nov 79 Zff4
        
                    
          Subject:
          Tripartite Negotiations Continue
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINS, PINT, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Since approximately 5:30 p.m. November 12, tripartite negotiations have been in process in the Bolivian Senate between the Armed Forces, the Bolivian Labor Federation (COB) and representatives of the Congress in search of a political solution to the current crisis. Gen Eden Castillo, Armed Forces Commander, is heading that delegation. COB Secretary General Juan Lechin along with his Deputy Oscar Sanjines, Congressman Simon Reyes and other Executive Committee members represent labor, and the Congress is represented by each chamber’s officers as well as the parties’ respective floor leaders. The current focus appears to remain on the idea of a governing triumvirate whereby a member of Congress, labor, and the Armed Forces would form Bolivia’s executive. Thus far the COB and the Congress have resoundingly rejected Col. Natusch as the Armed Forces’ representative in such an arrangement, which in turn has caused the military to take the position that if the COB and the Congress can elect their own to the triumvirate, then the Armed Forces should be no less entitled to do the same. The impasse, then, is over Natusch. According to one MNR source, a sounding of the Armed Forces garrisons in La Paz and the interior reveals an overwhelming sentiment that Natusch continue. This appears borne out by Alfredo Arce, close Banzer advisor, who informs us that events are moving closer to a purely military (castrense) solution. Arce – who earlier in the day (November 12) noted that Banzer is in town – also mentioned “consultations” with the garrisons, which he characterized more as briefing sessions than soundings, but with the same result, i.e., total support for Natusch. Hence, Arce noted, if the Congress and the COB continue to hold out against Natusch in the current negotiations over the triumvirate, then the Armed Forces will simply end the discussion and effectively suspend the Congress. This would not preclude civilians in the cabinet and other positions, he suggested, but the conclusion is that civilian participants would come largely from Banzer’s and coalition which Arce confirmed is now supporting the regime.
In the meantime, the Natusch government has embarked on a rather tortured campaign to put the best face on the November 1 takeover. Natusch himself took pains to explain on television and in the press that the putsch was not just a military movement but one that was civic and political in character as well. He reiterated previous promises to readjust salaries without devaluation; to incorporate workers in the management of state enterprises; to seek an equilibrium between capital and labor; and to consolidate the process of democratization. With respect to the United States, Natusch noted his government’s “respect and admiration for the people of the United States,” but referring to the U.S. decision to “freeze” economic aid to Bolivia, Natusch expressed doubts this would be carried out, since “it would constitute an outrage (atentado) against the Bolivian people rather than the present government.”
Along the same vein, Foreign Minister Guillermo Bedregal – also on television and in the press – emphasized that “the revolutionary movement of November 1 1979 from the very initial gestation period counted upon the knowledge, acquiescence, and support”of” Victor Paz. According to Bedregal, the MNR and MNRI were “united in this struggle together with the Armed Forces; Paz Estenssoro was in agreement with this solution….”
Finally, a mass was held Monday morning in the San Francisco Church facing one of La Paz’ main squares for the dead of last weeks’ conflagration. Former Presidents Walter Guevara Arze and Hernan Siles were among those attending.

text:

          Banzer Announces Election Timetable
        
                    
          TAGS:

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

IN A SPEECH TO THE NATION ON THE EVENING OF JULY 23, PRESIDENT BANZER ANNOUNCED THAT PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS WILL BE HELD IN THE SECOND HALF OF OCTOBER 1975, WITH THE FORMAL INAUGURATION OF A NEW PRESIDENT TO OCCUR IN DECEMBER OF THAT YEAR. BANZER ALSO REVEALED THAT THE NEW NATIONAL COUNCIL ON STRUCTURAL REFORMS, CREATED ON JULY 23, WILL PRESENT A SERIES OF MAJOR PROPOSALS TO THE NATION BY JANUARY 23, 1975. THESE PROPOSALS, INCLUDING A “PROGRAM OF NATIONAL OBJECTIVES”, A REVISED CONSTITUTION, A SERIES OF ADMINISTRATIVE, ECONOMIC AND JURIDICAL REFORMS, A POLITICAL PARTIES LAW AND AN ELECTORAL STATUTE, WILL BE SUBMITTED TO A NATIONAL REFERENDUM ON MARCH 23, WHATEVER THE RESULT OF THE REFERENDUM, ELECTIONS WILL STILL BE HELD IN LATE OCTOBER 1975, EITHER UNDER THE OLD CONSTITUTION OR UNDER THE NEW CONSTITUTION AND LAWS TO BE PROPOSED BY THE COUNCIL.
COMMENT: THE NEWLY-CREATED COUNCIL ON STRUCTURAL REFORMS HAS BEEN THE SUBJECT OF WIDESPREAD SPECULATION SINCE IT WAS FIRST ANNOUNC ED IN EARLY JULY. DESPITE THE BREADTH OF THE COUNCIL’S MANDATE AND THE SHORT AMOUNT OF TIME IN WHICH IT MUST PREPARE THE NEW CONSTITUTION AND OTHER IMPORTANT NEW LEGAL PROCEDURES, ONLY THE PRESIDENT HIMSELF

251126Z
APPEARS TO HAVE ANY CLEAR IDEA OF THE NATURE OF THE REFORMS TO BE
PROPOSED BY THE COUNCIL, AND HE IS NOT REVEALING HIS THINKING AT THIS TIME. CLEARLY, HOWEVER, THE COUNCIL’S RECOMMENDATIONS WILL REFLECT A CONSENSUS OF VIEWS HELD BY LOYAL PRO-GOVERNMENT ELEMENTS: THE THIRTY-MEMBER COUNCIL WILL REPORTEDLY CONTAIN FOUR REPRESENTATIVE S EACH OF THE MNR, FSB, FUERZAS REVOLUCIONARIAS BARRIENTISTAS, CAMPESINOS AND ARMED FORCES, THEREBY ASSURING THE GOB OF A TWO-THIRDS MAJORITY IN THE COUNCIL’S INTERNAL DELIBERATIONS.

BANZER’S ANNOUNCEMENTS ALSO COME AT A PSYCHOLOGICALLY-IMPORTANT MOMENT, SINCE MANY OF THE GOVERNMENT’S CRITICS HAVE RECENTLY BEGUN TO CHARGE THAT THE LACK OF AN ELECTION TIMETABLE WAS EVIDENCE OF A GOB PLAN TO FURTHER POSTPONE ELECTIONS BEYOND 1975. OPPOSITION SPOKESMEN PRESUMABLY WILL NOW CONCENTRATE THEIR FIRE ON THE BANZER GOVERNMENT’S REFUSAL TO PROCLAIM A GENERAL POLITICAL AMNESTY OR TO ALLOW SUCH EXILED OPPOSITIONISTS AS WALTER GUEVARA ARCE AND PDC CHIEF BENJAMIN MIGUEL TO RETURN TO BOLIVIA. STEDMAN
