text:
Date:
          January 25, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC Priority 2046
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 L-03 Eb-11 Inr-10 Drc-01 Rsc-01 /047 W ——————— 090669 P 251724z Jan 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Farmabol Case
        
                    
          TAGS:
          BDIS, EIND, BBAK, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          A) STATE 14854; B) LA PAZ 470; C) STATE 13866; D) BINNS’ MEMO OF JAN. 3, 1974
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

As of six p.m. Jan 24, Capt. Sanchez had not returned from his trip. His office promised to have him telephone Embassy immediately upon his return.
Comment: We are in complete accord with Department’s desire that the USG’s role in this case be essentially that of honest broker and are satisfied that the GOB officials concerned with this dispute so regard us. When Capt. Sanchez was informed of substance of Ref D, he seemed more appreciative of the demonstration of the USG’s willingness to act as an honest broker than disturbed by what he clearly understood to be merely an initial and fragmentary report. We are confident that the GOB continues to regard settlement of the Farmabol dispute as in its interest and continues to see Atty. Hathorn’s packages as a promising vehicle for resolution. (Obviously, confirmation of our impression must await Sanchez’ return.) Clearly, however, Hathorn’s packages must stand on their own merits.
As Department is aware, Atty. Hathorn came to Bolivia with three arrows in his quiver: A) Settle the Farmabol dispute; B) Offer the Dominick & Dominick loan, and C) offer the complex “fiduciary deposit” loan package described in La Paz 7639 and La Paz 7614. As reported in our A-268, Hathorn said the loans and the Farmabol settlement need not be directly tied together. While here, he clearly gave impression that he was more interested in arranging the “fiduciary deposit” loan package than either or both of the other matters. Moreover, Hathorn said purpose of his December trip here was to establish parameters of discussion. He left satisfied he had done so and clearly aware that next step would be satisfaction of GOB’s inquiries about his own, his firm’s and his backers antecedents and bona fides.
Department will recall that GOB was embarrassed last summer by a $US 225 million loan offer (among several others) that could not be closed after public announcement. If for no other reason, GOB officials would today approach any package with healthy caution which we feel should be encouraged and which, to the extent that U.S. citizens are involved, we feel we should help satisfy.
On the other hand, while we are indeed anxious to see Farmabol dispute resolved, we do not feel that Atty. Hathorn’s packages constitute only opportunity history will offer. Capt. Sanchez was the only GOB official informed of Ref D and we believe he should continue to be the channel of information, any other approach, in our view, would put USG in the position of seemingly endorsing a specific transaction. End comment.
Action requested: Ref. C reported Dominick & Dominick President Kennedy said quote he would be aware of a transaction of this magnitude end quote and also reported that Dominick & Dominick’s S.A. Megeath quote confirmed Hathorn was authorized to propose $US 15 million transaction to GOB end quote. To close circle, Department is requested to seek confirmation from Kennedy that Megeath is empowered to commit Dominick & Dominick in this matter. Stedman

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

REGRETABLE THAT SUBJECT MESSAGE NOT CLEARED OR COORDINATED WITH THE EMBASSY’S POLITICAL SECTION. APART FROM MINOR ERRORS FROM SOURCES SUCH AS STATEMENTS THAT THE ARMY HAS A ROLE IN PRICE CONTROLS (IT DOES NOT), OR THAT PRICE INCREASES WERE ABOUT 300 PERCENT (THEY WERE ABOUT 100 PERCENT) WHICH COULD HAVE BEEN CORRECTED IN THE COMMENT, THE COMMENT ITSELF IS IN ERROR WHEN IT SUGGESTS THAT THE PRESIDENT’S VERY DIFFICULT DECISION TO IMPLEMENT THE LATEST ECONOMIC PACKAGE WAS MADE TO PLACATE THE POLITICIANS AND THEREBY STAY IN OFFICE. POLITICIANS IN BOLIVIA AT THIS TIME HAVE NEITHER THE DESIRE TO ALIENATE THE PUBLIC AT LARGE NOR THE CLOUT TO DETERMINE WHETHER OR NOT THE PRESIDENT STAYS IN OFFICE.
THE EMBASSY DOES NOT WISH TO SUGGEST THAT THE ARMY IS SOLIDLY BEHIND BANZER. IT ISN’T NOW AND NEVER HAS BEEN. IT MAY EVEN BE LESS SOLIDLY BEHIND THE PRESIDENT NOW THAN A FEW MONTHS AGO BECAUSE THERE HAS BEEN, AFTER ALL,

292338Z
RATHER WIDE-SPREAD CRITICISM OF THE WAY THE GOV HAS HANDLED
NATIONAL ECONOMIC PROBLEMS SINCE LAST OCTOBER. ON THE OTHER HAND, IT IS HIGHLY IMPROBABLE THAT GENERAL ALCOREZA WOULD HAVE TOLD A LARGE GROUP OF CADETS THAT THE ARMY WOULD DUMP BANZER IF HE APPEARS TO LOSE SUPPORT, AS STATED IN REFTEL.

THE EMBASSY AGREES THAT THERE MAY BE GROWING SENTIMENTS WITHIN THE MILITARY FOR A CHANGE IN THE PRESIDENCY. THE EMBASSY HAS REPORTED THE RATHER PERSISTENT TALK ABOUT THE PROSPECTS OF A MILITARY JUNTA OR AN ALL-MILITARY CABINET. HOWEVER, WE DO NOT BELIEVE THIS IS THE TIME FOR EITHER, BECAUSE NEITHER WOULD BE ABLE TO PRESENT NEW SOLUTIONS TO THE EXISTING PROBLEMS. THE MILITARY DOES NOT WISH TO BEAR THE FULL BRUNT OF GENERAL CRITICISM AND IS UNLIKELY TO PUT ITSELF IN THIS POSITION. ALSO REPORTED IN THE PAST HAS BEEN THE EXTRAORDINARY EFFECTIVENESS OF THE GOB IN DISCOVERING AND CRUSHING COUP PLOTS.
IN SUM, THE GOB IS FACING PROBLEMS AT THIS TIME AS THE DEPARTMENT KNOWS, BUT WE BELIEVE BANZER’S SURVIVAL PROSPECTS CONTINUE TO BE GOOD. STEDMAN

title: Fiat Concord Tractor Monopoly; Violation Of U.s.- Bolivian Commercial Treaty
text:
Date:
          April 24, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState WashDC 2924
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ara-16 Iso-00 L-03 Come-00 Trse-00 Tar-02 Aid-20 Iga-02 Agr-20 Xmb-07 Opic-12 Drc-01 Rsc-01 /096 W ——————— 062379 R 242055z Apr 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Fiat Concord Tractor Monopoly; Violation Of U.s.- Bolivian Commercial Treaty
        
                    
          TAGS:
          ETRD, BL
        
                    
          Ref:
          STATE 44074 (NOTAL)
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Trade sources handling U.S. made tractor sales to Bolivia estimate that impact on their sales of the Fiat monopoly will be small. (In terms of total U.S. tractor exports, impact would be negligible.) They are not inclined to protest to GOB. Most believe that greatest gains in tractor sales will be above 112 h.p. maximum reserved for Fiat. We concur large farmers with good credit standing are now looking for bigger tractors.
We agree with Reftel assessment of applicability of treaty provisions. We also believe that Fiat arrangement can set precedent for further monopoly arrangements. U.S. firm, Dresser, may be next firm to receive such monopoly. We understand Dresser investment contract has been signed but decree similar to one issued in Fiat case has not been issued thus far to cover Dresser investment.
Similar cases may have arisen possibly on basis of GATT obligation if not FCN treaties in other Andean Pact or still other countries on de facto basis if not de jure. Department in best position to judge importance of this case as precedent.
We believe approach probably advisable on grounds this case may set significant new precedent in Bolivia at least. Following factors, however, should be taken into consideration: (a) If similar cases have occurred in other countries, multilateral approach should be considered. (b) Must be borne in mind that GOB may simply respond that U.S. firm, Dresser, will be favored in same degree as Fiat. (c) GOB may refer to exception USG requested in 1946 to reciprocal MFN for U.S. - Philippine trade which GOB readily granted. Thus, GOB could ask for exchange of notes waiving MFN for six year period provided for in Fiat arrangement.
If Department believes an approach advisable, we would propose an initial approach to Subsecretary for Industry Pereira who at right level and most knowledgeable GOB official on Andean Pact ramifications. Fiat investment made in hopes of obtaining Andean Pact programmed industrial sector assignment and Dresser investment being made in subsector already assigned to Bolivia under Andean Pact.

text:
Date:

          Oct-01 Ads-00 Sso-00 /026 W ——————033178 011304z /53 P 312205z Aug 79

          Gob Discussions With Imf
        
                    
          TAGS:

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

(Text Removed)
Summary: Convinced by the August 22-25 visit of the IMF’s Marcelo Caiola, President Walter Guevara and the GOB’s economic leadership now support negotiations with the IMF and realize that economic measures must be taken. The IMF and the GOB agreed that the package of economic measures must include an immediate increase in the domestic price of petroleum products and some form of devaluation. The IMF has stated that it can send a mission to Bolivia within a few days of receipt of the GOB’s invitation. Possible obstacles are the GOB’s insistence that it needs about $US 50 million prior to the negotiations, so it will not be negotiating under the gun of imminent reserve exhaustion, and the risk that wage pressures will surge beyond what the GOB can offer in the context of a coherent program. End summary.
At his own initiative, returning from Uruguay, Marcelo Caiola of the Western Hemisphere Division of the IMF, arrived in La Paz August 22 and spent three days discreetly visiting with GOB officials. Caiola held the following meetings:

A. Enrique Garcia, President of the Central Bank;
B. Guido Hinojosa, Minister of Finance and Carlos Miranda, Minister of Planning and Coordination;
C. The President’s economic cabinet–Carlos Miranda, Guido Hinojosa, Tommas Guillermo Elio (Minister of Industry and Commerce), Gustavo Fernandez (Minister of Foreign Relations).
D. President Walter Guevara. The President, who would normally have attended the economic cabinet meeting, was sick so Caiola and Jorge Sol Perez, the resident IMF representative, visited him at his home.

According to Sol Perez, the meetings were most productive but were characterized by a degree of ignorance of international finance on the part of the GOB officials. The economic leadership is made up of people well experienced in rural development, project financing, and integration but not international finance. After the candid discussion, the GOB decided in favor of economic measures and negotiations with the IMF. President Guevara Arze, in consonance with what he termed his implicit mandate from Congress to address the economic situation, followed the discussions closely and ultimately agreed that the GOB must negotiate with the IMF.
Current Situation: Bolivia’s financial situation grows more serious each day. On August 29, the Central Bank’s net reserves totaled $US 49 million. Apparently, this included about $US 10 million in German credits for the Karachipampa Lead and Silver Smelter Project. In addition, the Central Bank has about $US 100 million in the “Depositos Al Terceros,” which are foreign exchange deposits of the state enterprises and commercial banks held in the Central Bank. Normally, with good monetary management, the Central Bank would not use these deposits, but recently the Bolivian Central Bank has dipped into them to meet their foreign exchange demands. The Central Bank also has about $US 50 million in credit lines with New York banks which have not been used. If necessary, both the “Depositos Al Terceros” and the bank credit lines could be drawn down.

A. Presently, Bolivia’s average daily foreign exchange transaction loss is running about $US 2 million. Some days’ losses have been much higher. On Monday, August 27, triggered by an interview with Central Bank President Enrique Garcia published in Saturday’s newspapers, losses approached $US 8 million. Even assuming minimum reserve losses of $US 2 million daily, the Central Bank’s net reserve position would turn negative before the end of September.
B. From now through the end of the year, Bolivia must pay about $US 244 million in debt service, according to Sol Perez. This includes $US 100 million in amortization and interest for various loans to the GOB and $US 144 million to repay the Central Bank swaps obtained by the GOB in June.
C. Gross Central Bank reserves totaled $US 236.7 million on August 20 as compared with $US 215.2 million on June 30. Net reserves on June 30 were $US 82.04 million. Net domestic credit expanded from $US 440.86 million on June 30 to $US 509.3 million on August 20. The money supply increased by 7 percent to $US 321.3 million from June 30 to August 20. Through July, imports were increasing at a rate almost 40 percent over that of last year.
D. Sol Perez states that Bolivia’s consolidated public sector deficit is enormous and without any measures will approach $US 580 million by the end of the year. Even if public sector revenues were increased via tax increases, better customs enforcement, and price increases of state enterprise produced goods, the fiscal gap could not be closed. The GOB currently finances about one-half of this deficit with short-term credits.

Measures: After talking with IMF officials, the GOB opted for the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) instead of a one year standby agreement, which would provide less than $US 100 million in financing.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM

ACCORDING TO HECTOR ORMACHEA, DIRECTOR OF INSTITUTO NACIONAL DE FINANCIAMIENTO (INDEF), PLANNING AND PROJECT DEVELOPMENT ENTITIES OF GOB WILL SOON BE REVAMPED AND IMPROVED WITH A VIEW TO INCREASING THE NUMBER OF FINANCE- WORTHY PUBLIC SECTOR PROJECTS. ORMACHEA SAID MOST OF REORGANIZATION WAS HIS IDEA AND HAD BEEN ACCEPTED BY MINISTER FOR COORDINATION LECHIN.
ORMACHEA SAID MINISTER FOR COORDINATION WOULD SOON HAVE THREE SUBSECRETARIES: MACROECONOMIC PLANNING, COORDINATION, AND DECREE PREPARATION. (LATTER WOULD TAKE OVER RESPONSIBILITIES OF SECRETARY GENERAL TO THE PRESIDENCY). SUBSECRETARY FOR MACROECONOMIC PLANNING WOULD WORK OUT OVERALL DEVELOPMENT STRATEGY AND SECTOR INVESTMENT EMPHASES UPON BASIS OF WHICH INITIAL PROJECT PRIORITY RANKING WOULD BE ESTABLISHED.
PLANNING OFFICES IN EACH MINISTRY WOULD DEVELOP SECTOR AND SUBSECTOR STRATEGIES AND PROJECTS UP TO LEVEL OF PREFEASIBILITY STUDIES. PROJECT STUDIES WOULD BE SUBMITTED TO LOAN COMMITTEE OF CONEPLAN

122121Z
COUNCIL (CONEPLAN SECRETARIAT TO BE BROKEN UP) WHICH
WOULD ASSIGN PRIORITY RANKING AND SEND ON TO DEPENDECY TO BE CREATED UNDER MINISTER OF COORDINATION TO BE CALLED INSTITUTO NACIONAL DE PREINVERSION (INALPRE).

INALPRE (DRAFT DECREE TO ESTABLISH IT ALREADY PREARED AND BEING STUDIES) WOULD EITHER COMPLETE PREINVESTMENT STUDY OR CONTRACT WITH PRIVATE CONSULTANTS TO DO IT AND PERHAPS FEASIBILITY STUDY. ORMACHEA REFERRED TO COLUMBIAN GOVERNMENT INSTITUTION, FONADE, AS MODEL BOLIVIANS HAVE IN MIND. (PROBABLY THIS ARISES FROM ADVICE OF OMAR BOTERO, THE FORMER DIRECTOR OF FONADE, WHO HAS VISITED BOLIVIA ON BEHALF OF THE IDB TO GIVE ADVICE TO THE GOB ON THE ESTABLISHMENT OF INDEF.)
AS STUDIES COMPLETED BY EITHER INALPRE OR STATE ENTERPRISES THEY WOULD BE REFERRED TO INSTITUTO NACIONAL DE FINANCIAMIENTO (SEE LA PAZ A-154, AUG 2, 1974) FOR ARRANGMENT OF FINANCING. ACCORDING TO ORMACHEA, CURRENT PLANS ARE TO DISBURSE SUCH FINANCING TO EXECUTING AGENCY THROUGH CENTRAL BANK AND DCCP. ACCORDING TO ORMACHEA, EACH OF KEY ORGANIZATIONS, LOAN COMMITTEE INDEF AND INALPRE, WILL HAVE SAME KEY MEMBERS (ON THEIR BOARDS IN CASES OF INDEF AND INALPRE) INCLUDING MINISTER OF COORDINATION, MINISTER OF FINANCE, REPRESENTATIVE OF THE PRESIDENCY (PROBABLY GASTON VALLA), PRESIDENT OF THE CENTRAL BANK AND THE EXECUTIVE DIRECTORS OF INDEF AND INALPRE. ORMACHEA BELIEVES THIS STRUCTURE, TO BE IN PLACE IN TWO OR THREE WEEKS, WILL IMPROVE COORDINATION AND STRENGTHEN PROJECT DEVELOPMENT PROCESS.
COMMENT: PLANNED REORGANIZATION APPEARS TO STRENGTHEN POSITION OF MINISTER OF COORDINATION WHO IS ALREADY BEING VISITED AS A KEY OFFICIAL BY FOREIGN BUSINESSMEN CONSIDERING INVESTMENTS OR INVITATIONS TO BID. NEED FOR MORE RAPID DEVELOPMENT OF PUBLIC SECTOR PROJECTS WAS BROUGHT HOME WHEN GOB FOUND IT DIFFICULT TO USE US $25 MILLION BORROWED FROM GROUP OF BANKS LED BY BANK OF AMERICA. WE BELIEVE THAT THE NATIONAL ACCOUNTS OFFICE PRESENTLY IN CONEPLAN WILL PROBABLY BE SHIFTED TO CENTRAL BANK. IMF EXPECTED TO FINANCE NATIONAL ACCOUNTS

122121Z
SPECIALIST TO IMPROVE PRESENTLY NEARLY USELESS ACCOUNTS. STEDMAN

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

THE NEW ALL-MILITARY CABINET HAS NOT MET TOGETHER AS YET, BUT ALREADY THERE IS SPECULATION THAT THE FOURTEEN MEMBERS ARE DIVIDING INTO THREE OR FOUR CLIQUES, ONE OF WHICH, HEADED BY COLONEL JUAN PATINO AYOROA, IS BASICALLY HOSTILE TO PRESIDENT BANZER. THESE DIVISIONS, HOWEVER, APPEAR TO RESULT FROM POLITICAL AMBITIONS AND PERSONAL LOYALTIES RATHER THAN FROM ANY SIGNIFICANT DIFFERENCES IN POLITICAL VIEWS. THERE ARE NO SO-CALLED GENERATIONAL GROJP OFFICERS IN THE CABINET, AND THE OVERALL PHILOSOPHICAL CAST OF THE NEW GOB IS CONSERVATIVE. IT IS LIKELY TO PLAY A CARETAKER ROLE IN THE VARIOUS MINISTRIES RATHER THAN ATTEMPT TO LAUNCH BOLD NEW VENTURES.
PRESIDENT BANZER SHOULD HAVE LITTLE DIFFICULTY IN EXERCISING HIS LEADERSHIP IN THIS CONTEXT AS LONG AS HE

192214Z
MAINTAINS A DEGREE OF FLEXIBILITY IN HIS DEALINGS WITH THE
ALLEGED FACTIONS WITHIN THE CABINET AND THE HIGH COMMAND OF THE ARMED FORCES. AT THE PRESENT TIME, IT APPEARS TO US THAT BANZER WILL REMAIN IN OFFICE UNTIL SOME SUCCESSION PROCESS, SUCH AS ELECTIONS, IS ARRANGED IN 1975. HE MIGHT BE PRESSURED INTO RESIGNING IN FAVOR OF A MILITARY JUNTA NINETY DAYS OR SO BEFORE ELECTIONS IN ORDER TO ADD TO THE PROSPECTS OF GOVERNMENT IMPARTIALITY IN THE ELECTORAL PROCESS. SO LONG AS BANZER AND HIS CABINET MANAGE WHAT IS NOW GENERALLY VIEWED AS A GOVERNMENT OF TRANSITION, HE IS NOT LIKELY TO CONFRONT ANY SERIOUS OR BROADLY BASED COUP ATTEMPT. HOWEVER, SHOULD IT APPEAR THAT HIS PLANS TO MODIFY THE POLITICAL STRUCTURES OF THE COUNTRY ARE A COVER TO STAY IN OFFICE, OR TO POSTPONE ELECTIONS INDEFINITELY, HE WOULD RUN A GRAVE RISK OF BEING THROWN OUT OF OFFICE.

THE PROCESS OF RECOMMENDING AND ADOPTING THESE POLITICAL REFORMS IS IMPORTANT, THEREFORE, TO THE STABILITY OF THE PRESENT GOVERNMENT. THERE IS ALREADY GRUMBLING OVER THE NON-WORKING OF THE NATIONAL COUNCIL FOR STRUCTURAL REFORM, AND ITS PREDECESSOR THE NATIONAL CONSULTATIVE COUNCIL(NEVER FORMED, THOUGH ANNOUNCED IN EARLY APRIL), AND THE LENGTHY TIME PERIOD GIVEN TO THE COUNCIL (180 DAYS) TO MAKE ITS RECOMMENDATIONS. SOME PEOPLE ARE NOW SUGGESTING THAT IT WOULD BE MORE DEMOCRATIC, MORE CONSTITUTIONAL AND MORE CONDUCIVE TO POLITICAL TRANQUILITY, TO CALL FOR A CON- STITUENT ASSEMBLY TO PROPOSE AND APPROVE CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS. THESE PEOPLE SUGGEST THAT THE NATIONAL COUNCIL FOR STRUCTURAL REFORM SHOULD BE LIMITED TO PROPOSING THE RULES FOR CONVENING A CONSTITUENT ASSEMBLY, WHICH COULD THEN BE CALLED WITHIN A MONTH OR SO. THERE IS ALSO TALK THAT WITHOUT A BROAD POLITICAL AMNESTY AND FREEDOM TO CAMPAIGN POLITICALLY, THE GOVERNMENT’S CREDIBILITY IN FORMING THE ALL-MILITARY CABINET WILL BE SHOT FULL OF HOLES.
REPORTEDLY, THE SO-CALLED GENERATIONAL GROUP OF OFFICERS LED BY GARY PRADO CONTINUES TO AGITATE FOR BANZER’S REMOVAL AND FOR PROMPT GENERAL ELECTIONS, BUT THE BANZER GOVERNMENT SHOULD HAVE A BREATHING SPELL NOW OF SEVERAL WEEKS BEFORE THE OPPOSITION PRESSURES GROW TO DANGEROUS PROPORTIONS. AS NOTED ABOVE, THESE PRESSURES NEED NOT GROW

192214Z
UNDULY IF THE GOVERNMENT SHOWS SUFFICIENT SIGNS OF FORWARD MOVEMENT LEADING TO A PROMISED GOVERNMENTAL SUCCESSION.

THE EMBASSY EXPECTS THAT THE PRESIDENT WILL USE AUGUST 6, INDEPENDENCE DAY, AND AUGUST 7, ARMED FORCES DAY, TO MAKE SOME MAJOR ANNOUNCEMENTS SURROUNDING THE TIME TABLE FOR ELECTIONS AND PERSONNEL CHANGES (E.G., A SHAKE UP IN THE MILITARY AND CHANGES IN THE MINISTRIES AT THE SUB-SECRETARY

LEVEL).

COMMENT: THE EMBASSY BELIEVES THAT THE FORMATION OF AN ALL-MILITARY CABINET IF IT CARRIES OUT ITS STATED PURPOSE OF GOVERNING DURING A TRANSITIONAL PERIOD LEADING TO NATIONAL ELECTIONS NEXT YEAR SHOULD BENEFIT U.S. INTERESTS IN BOLIVIA. POLITICAL TENSIONS HAVE BEEN LESSENED AND DEMOCRATICALLY ORIENTED POLITICAL GROUPS SHOULD HAVE A CHANCE TO RECOVER THEIR FOLLOWING AND GREATLY REDUCE THE PROSPECTS OF A GOVERNMENTAL TAKE-OVER BY EXTREMIST ELEMENTS. BEFORE THE FORMATION OF THE MILITARY CABINET AND THE ANNOUNCED FORTHCOMING CONSTITUTIONALIZATION OF THE COUNTRY, THE ODDS WERE RISING FOR A COUP BY JUNIOR MILITARY OFFICERS WHO MIGHT HAVE BECOME RADICALIZED IN THEIR QUEST FOR SUPPORT.
THE ALL-MILITARY GOVERNMENT WILL ALMOST INEVITABLY LEAD TO SUBSTANTIALLY INCREASED MILITARY EXPENDITURES, PRINCIPALLY ON PAY, BENEFITS AND ALLOWANCES SIDE. THE BOLIVIAN ARMED FORCES, LIKE MOST OTHER SECTORS OF BOLIVIAN SOCIETY, ARE IN VERY POOR SHAPE. TO THE EXTENT THAT BETTER PAY AND FACILITIES HELP INSURE THE COHESIVENESS AND LOYALTY OF THE MILITARY UNITS TO THE PRESENT GOB, THE PROSPECTS FOR POLITICAL STABILITY ARE ENHANCED AND OUR OVERALL INTERESTS IN BOLIVIA ADVANCED. STEDMAN

          Subject:
          President Convokes “National Assembly” To Discuss Access To The Sea Issue
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, PFOR, BL, CI, PE
        
                    
          Ref:
          LA PAZ 2024
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

As reported in Reftel, President Banzer announced his decision March 31 to meet with group of distinguished Bolivians (ex-presidents and foreign ministers, political party and labor leaders, etc.) to discuss possible strategies for regaining the country’s access to the sea. In subsequent days, response to Banzer’s proposal in press and public opinion has been unanimously favorable: In the view of prestigious La Paz daily El Diario, “few political initiatives have been so well received in recent times.” Even opposition politicians such as Christian Democratic Party chief Benjamin Miguel and PRA leader Walter Guevara welcomed the President’s invitation to attend meeting, although both complained that exiled oppositionists such as ex-presidents Paz Estenssoro, Siles Zuazo, Ovando and Torres should also have been permitted to attend.
Sessions of this meeting, called a “National Assembly” by President Banzer, will commence at 10 a.m. on April 5 in Command and General Staff School in Cochabamba. Together with President Banzer, government officials and members of Joint Command of Armed Forces, five former Presidents of Bolivia (David Toro, Mamerto Urriolagoitia, Enrique Hertzog, Hugo Ballivian and Luis Adolfo Siles Salinas) and many former foreign ministers (including Guevara, Alberto Crespo Gutierrez and Mario Gutierrez) will attend meeting, which is expected to conclude on April 6. Banzer will announce results of sessions to nation in a speech to be delivered following closing of conference.
Comment: Consultative meeting in Cochabamba reemphasizes decision by Banzer government, reported in Reftel, to give renewed policy emphasis to century-old theme of “Return to the Sea.” Meeting will also serve government’s goal of uniting diverse strands of domestic political opinion behind this foreign policy issue, while distracting public attention from such pressing internal problems as food shortages and inflation. We expect that government will continue to generate high level of official activity and public debate over access to the sea question until either popular interest wanes or new issues arise to take priority over this familiar theme in Bolivian foreign policy.

          LA PAZ 3504: LA PAZ 3295
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

BEGIN SUMMARY: POLITICAL UNREST STIMULATED BY SEPARATE ISSUES OF ECONOMIC AGREEMENTS WITH BRAZIL AND UNIVERSITY SITUATION, REPORTED IN REFTELS, IS NOW BRINGING TOGETHER DIS- PARATE ANTI-GOVERNMENT GROUPS AND MOVEMENTS IN RISING CAMPAIGN OF AGITATION AGAINST BANZER REGIME. AMONG OPPOSITION ELEMENTS WHO CONTRIBUTED TO INCREASED POLITICAL TENSION OF PAST FEW DAYS ARE PRO-VALVERDE FLANGISTAS, LARGE NUMBER OF UNIVERSITY STUDENTS, A GROUP OF JUNIOR AND MIDDLE-GRADE MILITARY OFFICERS, SOME LABOR UNIONS AND VESTIGES OF PDC-PRA-MNRI POLITICAL ALLIANCE. GOVERNMENT IS AWARE OF DANGER IT FACES, AS DEMONSTRATED BY EMERGENCY MEETINGS OF PRESIDENT BANZER WITH MILITARY HIGH COMMAND AND SECURITY OFFICIALS, AND IS PREPARING COUNTER-MEASURES TO DEAL WITH SITUATION. END SUMMARY.

312240Z

AS REPORTED IN REFTLS, POLITICAL TENSIONS HAVE BEEN

KEPT AT RELATIVELY HIGH LEVEL THROUGHOUT MAY BY SEPARATE ISSUES OF ECONOMIC AGREEMNTS WITH BRAZIL AND SUBSEQUENT DETERIORATION IN UNIVERSITY SITUATION. WITHIN PAST FEW DDAYS, EMBASSY HAS GATHERED NEW INFORMATION INDICATING THAT CURRENTS OF UNREST SYMBOLIZED BY THESE TWO ISSUES ARE NOW UNITING INTO BROADER ANTI-GOVERNMENT CAMPAIGN OF AGITUATION. ONE KEY ELE- MENT IN NEW SITUATION IS INCREASED ACTIVITY OF GROUP OF YOUNGER MILITARY OFFICERS, AT JUNIOR AND MIDDLE GRADES, WHO HAVE OFTEN BEEN REPORTED IN PAST TO ENGAGE IN LOW-LEVEL PLOTTING AGAINST GOVERNMENT. THESE OFFICERS, WHO INCREASINGLY APPEAR TO HAVE BEEN MAJOR PROVOCATIVE ELEMENT IN JANUARY DISTURBANCES IN COCHABAMBA, ARE DEEPLY CONCERNED OVER ISSUE OF BOLIVIA’S ECONOMIC “DEPENDENCY” ON BRAZIL AND MAY ALSO HAVE HELPED TO STIMULATE RECENT STUDENT DISORDERS IN LA PAZ AND SUCRE. ON EDUCATIONAL SCENE, ALL UNIVERSITY AND SECONDARY SCHOOL STUDENTS ARE CURRENTLY ON STRIKE IN LA PAZ AND SUCRE. IN LATTER CITY, FOUR DAYS OF DEMONSTRATIONS HAVE LEFT ESTIMATED THIRTY STUDENTS AND TEN POLICE INJURED: REPORTS OF MORE SERIOUS CASUALTIES AMONG STUDENTS CANNOT BE CONFIRMED AT PRESENT. SUPPORT BY ALL AMJOR LABOR UNIONS FOR STUDENT’ DEMANDS IN PAST TWO WEEKS ALSO CREATES IMPRESSION OF GROWING ALLIANCE OF OPPORTUNITY BETWEEN VARIOUS OPPOSITION FORCES. IN FACE OF THIS SITUATION, FSB DECLARED NATIONAL MOBILIZATION OF PARTY MEMBERS “IN ARMS” ON MAY 30, IN ORDER TO OPPOSE ALLEGED SUBVERSIVE MOVMENT AIMED AT GOVERNMENT’S OVERTHROW. ON SAME DAY, FOUR MEMBERS OF FALANGE AND EX-COMMANDER OF MILITARY AVIATION SCHOOL COL HUGO MUNOZ DEPARTED SANTA CRUZ INTO “VOLUNTARY EXILE” ALL FIVE MEN HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED IN PAST WITH PRO-VALVERDE FORCES IN SANTNTA CRUZ AREA. FINALLY, SPOKESMEN FOR PDC-PRA- MNRI ALLIANCE CONTINUE TO ISSUE SHRILL COMMUNIQUES DENOUNCING BANZER GOVERMENT FOR HAVING “ERASED LAST VESTIGES OF DEMONCRACY IN BOLIVIA” BY ITS RECENT ARRESTS OF STUDENT LEADERS, LABOR OFFICIALS AND POLITICIANS.

GOVERNMENT CONCERN OVER THIS GROWING THREAT TO POLITICAL STABILITY WAS EVIDENCED DRAMATICALLY ON MAY 29 WHEN PRESIDENT BANZER CUT SHORT VISIT TO COCHABAMBA IN ORDER TO RETURN TO LA PAZ FOR POST-MIDNIGHT CONFERENCE WITH MILITARY HIGH COMMAND. SUBSEQUENTLY, BANZER CONFERRED WITH MILITARY AND SECURITY OFFICIALS THROUGHOUT DAY OF MAY 30 BEFORE DEPARTING THAT EVENING

312240Z
FOR SANTA CRUZ. MINISTER OF INTERIOR HAS BEEN HIGHLY ACTIVE IN PAST FEW DAYS, VISITING SCENE OF DISTURBANCES IN SUCRE AND ISSUING FREQUENT DENOUNCEMENTS OF “SUBVERSIVE”ACTIVITY IN STUDENT AND LABOR CIRCLES. VARIOUS GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS HAVE CANCELLED THEIR PLANS TO TRAVEL OUTSIDE BOLIVIA OR TO INTERIOR OF COUNTRY AS GOB PREPARES MEASURES TO DEAL WITH PRESENT SITUATION.

COMMENT. RELIABLE EMBASSY SOURCE INFORMS US THAT

BANZER RETURN FROM COCHABAMBA WAS DUE TO DISCOVERY OF ASSASSINATION PLOT THERE, WHICH WAS TO SET OFF COUP LED BY ONE OR TWO REGIMENTS, UNION STRIKES AND STUDENT DEMON- STRATIONS. BANZER TOLD MILITARY LEADERS HE COULD UNDERSTAND LEFT OR OPPOSITION PARTIES TRYING TO KILL HIM, BUT NOT MEMBERS OF HIS OWN MILITARY INSTITUTION. SUBSEQUENTLY HE TOLD THIS IN RESERVE TO FALANGE TOP LEADERSHIP AND DECISION WAS TAKEN TO HAVE FALANGE COME OUT IN MOBILIZATION IN SUPPORT OF BANZER, HOLDING MILITARY IN RESERVE FOR LATER CONTINGENCIES. MNR NOT TRUSTED BECAUSE OF ALLEGED LINKS TO COUP PLOT OF SILES, OTHER EXILED MNR LEADERS: GOB FEARED SOME IN-COUNTRY MNR LEADERS MIGHT HAVE LINKS TO COUP PLOTTERS.

IN PLOT ARE SOME MILITARY OFFICEFS (UNKNOWN) WHOM IDENTITY BANZER HIMSELF IS CURRENTLY HOPING TO DETERMINE. SUSPICIONS EXIST THAT SOMEONE AT HIGH LEVEL IS PATRONIZING THESE OFFICERS, SINCE IN BOLIVIA NO ONE ATTEMPTS A COUP UNLESS THERE IS SOMEONE IN THE GOVERNMENT TO “HOLD OPEN THE DOOR” FOR HIM. SOME FEELING THAT KEY SENIOR OFFICER RESPONSIBLE MAY BE MENDIETA OR GENERAL ALVAREZ. SOME PROPAGANDA SHEETS REPORTEDLY CIRCULATING IN ARMED FORCES CALLING FOR JUNIOR OFFICERS TO ASSUME COMMAND. ALSO, THERE IS SUSPICION AMONG LOYAL ARMY OFFICERS THAT NUMBER OF OFFICERS IN POLICE FORCES, JUST BELOW SENIOR LEVEL, ARE INVOLVED IN THE COUP PLOTTING. EVIDENCE OF PRIOR ORGANIZATION OUTSIDE BACKING ALO FOUND AT SUCRE, WHERE SOME OF STUDENTS THROWING MOLOTOV COCKTAILS AT POLICE WERE FOUND TOHAVE INSTRUCTION SHEETS ON HOW TO MAKE THESE, HOW TO FORM BARRICADES, PROTECT SELVES AGAINST TEAR GAS, ET.
BANZER ASKED THAT FSB, OTHER CIVILIAN SUPPORTERS OF REGIME GIVE HIM”THREE OR FOUR DAYS” TO DISCOVER WHO IS INVOLVED IN PLANNED COUP. CARLOS VALVERDE ALSO IS REPORTED TO BE

312240Z
IN COUNTRY, AND IS VERY LIKELY INVOLVED IN WHATEVER IS GOING ON. BREWIN

          Subject:
          Bolivian Foreign Minister Releases Secretary Kissinger’s Letter And Announces Request To U.s. For Financial Aid
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PFOR EAID BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Bolivian Foreign Minister, General Guzman, has released to the press the letter from Secretary Kissinger delivered Feb. 28 by the ambassador and announced that the secretary took under consideration a Bolivian request for financial assistance for reconstruction of flood damage. In his press conference remarks, Guzman said that he had also presented to Secretary Kissinger the Bolivian case for special preference for loans because of its state of underdevelopment compounded by its lack of a sea-coast. He said too that he asked the secretary for special “non-reimbursable” financing for the substitution of coca production. These remarks, he said, were well received by the U.S. Secretary of State, although no formal response given.
The minister sought with Secretary Kissinger. He stated that Latin Americans, especially Bolivians, believe they will receive answers to propositions put to the secretary at the April OAS meeting in Atlanta, if not before.
Ample press coverage was given to the minister’s press conference. U.S. assistance was featured as if it were assured. An editorial in Diario the following day credits the U.S. with its generosity in coming to Bolivia’s assistance with reconstruction loans.
Unless Department instructs us to the contrary, we shall attempt to steer any requests to us for financial aid for flood damage reconstruction toward IBRD and IDB as well as to AID. We also believe the GOB should be encouraged to present its needs in this regard to the CIAP in the country review scheduled for next month. The request for a crop substitution credit will be reviewed with Perry Shankle, ARA Bureau Narcotics Advisor, now in La Paz.
We shall be most appreciative for any guidance Dept can give us. Stedman

title: Bolivia’s Return To Constitutional Rule Via Indirect Election Of President-Elect Walter Guevara Arze
text:
Date:
          August 07, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          SecState Immediate 7626
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ads-00 Ciae-00 Pm-05 H-01 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Pa-01 Sp-02 Ss-15 Nsce-00 Sso-00 Icae-00 Inre-00 Ha-05 /058 W ——————110034 070502z /21
        
                    
          Subject:
          Bolivia’s Return To Constitutional Rule Via Indirect Election Of President-Elect Walter Guevara Arze
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PINT, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: On August 8 Bolivia will install Walter Guevara Arze as the country’s first constitutionally-elected president in 13 years. Under Bolivia’s current election laws (which virtually everyone wants to change before the next election in May 1980) this election took place in the new Bolivian Congress, since neither of the major candidates, Victor Paz and Hernan Siles, received a majority of the first-round popular vote. After five congressional ballots and a deadlock in which neither Paz nor Siles could achieve the required majority in the indirect election in the Congress, that body, under a provision of the Constitution, chose Senate President Walter Guevara Arze as president for a period of one year pending new elections under a revised electoral law.
From the standpoint of the US objective of successful transition to constitutional, civilian rule, how should we evaluate the second-round election in the Congress of Senate President Walter Guevara Arze rather than either of the major candidates in the popular vote? On first blush, one might judge this indirect result of Bolivia’s already indirect election to be a flawed one with less than clear legitimacy. Our judgment is the opposite: that a Guevara transitional government, given the indecisive result of the popular vote, is probably the best outcome possible. End summary.
The indecisive popular vote and the current Constitution’s provision for subsequent indirect election in the new Congress sent both Paz and Siles into that Congress with bitterly competing and in the end irreconcilable claims to the presidency. Paz’ claim was based on his larger congressional delegation, resulting from the present law’s over-representation of regional units. Siles’ claim was based on his narrow margin in the popular vote and the possibility that this margin might have been larger if the National Electoral Court had done its job better. These disparate claims and the unexpectedly strong party discipline in upholding them raised the prospect of Paz (or remotely Siles) eeking out the presidency without a congressional majority or, perhaps more important, without a modicum of opposition tolerance for his government. The stark regional split of the popular vote, La Paz rejecting Victor Paz Estensoro and the eastern lowlands Siles, could have meant bitter regional resistance in either case. In these circumstances, the risk of fratricidal opposition clouded the prospects for survival of that government and of the democratization process. A Victor Paz government based only on his own MNR-Historico could have faced early-on the bitter choice of collapse or repression as its means of survival. To some extent it was a sincere fear of the latter possibility that kept any of the small political groups that could have made a Victor Paz government from doing so.
Ironically, a Guevara government may be stronger and more durable. A Guevara government, emerging from a congressional consensus and with broad commitment to completion of its transitional task, has a fighting chance of surviving and meeting its recognized priorities of economic stabilization and preparation of a better political and legal base for the next election. The Guevara government could also form a bridge over Bolivia’s stark generation gap in civilian political leadership. Paz and Siles are both aged and divisive figures from Bolivia’s colorful but bitter past. Neither has inspired a broad following among the generation that now dominates the electorate, as the voting result clearly showed. While in 1978 and 1979 these two warhorses necessarily filled the void in political leadership caused by the rapid collapse of military rule, the recent campaign may have been the last for both (although in the case of Siles this depends more on his frail health than his choice). The dispersion of the popular vote and the congressional stand-off can be read as a low-confidence vote in all three ex-presidents (Paz, Siles and Banzer) and a desire for new faces from a new generation. In a transitional governing period some of these new faces will have a chance to show.
Guevara the man is an excellent choice for the job handed him, as the Senate undoubtedly had in mind when electing him President of the Senate, since the possibility of his assumption of the presidency was recognized at that time. He is an intelligent politician and serene, dignified statesman. His impressive and even-handed chairmanship of the first two days of the combined Senate/Chamber body, carried on national television, set him a good cut above his fellow politicians. He is more rational and pragmatic than the emotional, intransigent character that has set the tone of Bolivian politics up to now. While he was Interior Minister under Siles, Guevara was associated with part of Bolivia’s violent past, but he has somehow managed to maintain an aura of the non-divisive father figure. He and his PRA party were coldly cut down to size by Victor Paz in the last 9 months. In general Guevara is not a strong political infighter, but he could be a good healer. He was picked for this role, probably with some sense that his small party base, together with his personality and skills, while impressive, do not readily lend themselves to his catching the bug of power to the extent of mounting a successful effort to succeed himself in 1980.
There are weaknesses in the Guevara solution as well. The badly-drafted Bolivian Constitution, which simply does not foresee the possibility of deadlock in which the Congress found itself, can be interpreted otherwise than it was in the resolution electing Guevara president. Opponents could challenge the legal basis for Guevara’s interim presidency. Also, the UDP, while supporting Guevara’s election has left itself free to assume the role of full opposition to his governing program, including economic stabilization measures.

text:
Date:
          November 19, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz

          Info:
          Oct-01 Ara-11 Ads-00 Aid-05 Ciae-00 Com-02 Frb-03 Inr-10 Nsae-00 Trse-00 Xmb-02 Opic-07 Sp-02 Lab-04 H-01 Sil-01 Omb-01 Icae-00 Inre-00 Sso-00 Nsce-00 Io-14 /072 W ——————089537 191748z /50 O 191710z Nov 79

          Bolivian Negotiations With The Imf
        
                    
          TAGS:
          EFIN, BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

(C - ENTIRE TEXT.)
SUMMARY: THE RESIDENT IMF REPRESENTATIVE HAS BEEN IN NEGOTIATIONS THIS PAST WEEKEND WITH AUGUST QUADROS SANCHEZ, EXPECTED TO BE NAMED FINANCE MINISTER LATER TODAY, AND ANTICIPATES THAT THE MAJOR ELEMENTS OF A STABILIZATION PROGRAM WILL BE IMPLEMENTED WITHIN THE NEXT 72 HOURS. QUADROS HAS AGREED TO A FLOAT, RATHER THAN ANY OF THE SPLIT MARKET FORMULAS UNDER DISCUSSION EARLIER. ON THIS BASIS, THE RESIDENT IMF REP IS WILLING TO RECOMMEND A THREE-YEAR EXTENDED FUND FACILITY PROGRAM OF SDR 240 MILLION. IN A CONVERSATION WITH THE AMBASSADOR TODAY, NOVEMBER 19, THE IMF REP READILY AGREED THAT A THREE-YEAR PROGRAM WAS WARRANTED, NOW THAT THE GENERAL CONTINUITY OF CIVILIAN RULE APPEARED PROBABLE, EVEN THOUGH UNDER A NEW GOVERNMENT AFTER AUGUST 1980. DEPARTMENT SHOULD UNDERLINE WITH IMF IN WASHINGTON THAT A THREE-YEAR PROGRAM FOR BOLIVIA IS HIGHLY DESIRABLE. END SUMMARY.

191731Z

THE IMF RESIDENT REPRESENTATIVE, JORGE SOL PEREZ, INFORMS US THAT QUADROS HOPES TO COMPLETE WORK ON THE DRAFT DECREES BY TOMORROW AND TO PROMULGATE THEN ON TUESDAY OR WEDNESDAY. THE MAJOR MEASURES WILL BE A. A FLOAT IN THE EXCHANGE MARKET; B. AN INCREASE IN PETROLEUM PRODUCT PRICES OF 100, 130 OR 150 PERCENT (AMOUNT STILL UNDECIDED);
     Sheryl P. Walter 

   Sheryl P. Walter 

C. A WAGE “BONO” (EXTRA PAYMENT, ONCE ANNUALLY) OF 800 PESOS, WITH MAYBE MORE IN 1980; D. A 1980 PUBLIC SECTOR BUDGET FIXED AT THE 1979 (NOMINAL) LEVEL, PLUS THE $75 MILLION COST OF THE WAGE ADJUSTMENT–RECOGNIZING THAT SOME SUPPLEMENTALS MAY HAVE TO BE CONSIDERED LATER.

SOL PEREZ SAID HIS MAJOR CONCERN WAS THAT THE EXTREME PSYCHOLOGICAL DISRUPTION OF NOVEMBER SO FAR, COMBINED WITH THE CENTRAL BANK’S MINIMAL RESOURCES TO CUSHION EXTREME MOVEMENTS IN THE MARKET, COULD CAUSE ERRATIC INITIAL FLUCTUATION BEFORE THE RATE SETTLED AT A STEADY LEVEL. TO INTERVENE IN THE MARKET THE CENTRAL BANK NOW HAS ONLY ABOUT $15 MILLION IN FOREIGN EXCHANGE, PLUS 180-DAY LINES OF $50 MILLION WITH US COMMERCIAL BANKS WHICH IT HOPES TO ACTIVATE TODAY. IN A FEW DAYS THE GOB HOPES THE VENEZUELANS ($20 MILLION) AND SPANISH ($20 MILLION) WILL RELEASE THE UNDISBURSED PORTION OF EARLIER CREDITS.
PEREZ EXPECTS THAT AN IMF “MISSION” WOULD COME IN A FEW DAYS ONLY TO POLISH A LETTER OF INTENT WHICH IS ALREADY DRAFTED AND HE HOPES IMPLEMENTED BY THEN.
IN ADDITION TO THE SDR 125 MILLION WHICH WOULD BE AVAILABLE IN THE FIRST YEAR OF AN IMF PROGRAM, SOL

191731Z
PEREZ ANTICIPATES $25 MILLION FROM THE ANDEAN RESERVE FUND AND A $50 MILLION PROGRAM LOAN FROM THE WORLD BANK BY JANUARY OR FEBRUARY. (WE WOULD APPRECIATE WASHINGTON COMMENT ON THIS POSSIBILITY.) ADDITIONAL FINANCING WILL ALMOST CERTAINLY BE NEEDED, PARTICULARLY FROM THE COMMERCIAL BANKS. BOEKER

title: Codel Whealen: Meeting With Minister Of Engergy And Hyrocarbons
text:
Date:
          January 16, 1974
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz

          Oct-01 Ara-10 Iso-00 Ss-07 Aid-01 Nsc-06 Drc-01 Rsc-01 /030 W ——————— 116819 R 161330z Jan 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          Codel Whealen: Meeting With Minister Of Engergy And Hyrocarbons
        
                    
          TAGS:
          OREP EIND ENRG BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Congressman Whalen was cordially received by Minenergy/Hydro-carbons Capriles January 8. Minister remarked that US economy resisting Arab oil embargo remarkably well: certainly much better than Europe or Japan. Latter had proven be extremely vulnerable. Congressman described gasoline/fuel situation in US as spotty with some areas suffering considerably and others almost untouched.
Minister said he did not agree with Arab policy and labeled it aggressive. Said preferred cooperate with net importers and observed that prices must eventually fall. Said he expected Bolivian price within next few months might well be under current level of US: 16 per barrel. Congressman and Minister then discussed level to which crude oil prices might eventually fall on basis of competing fuel sources such as shale oil.
Minister said GOB monthly price level is minimum that now applies to all Bolivian crude exports as GOB is now free of all restraining contracts. He observed that Santa Cruz Department royalties will now be on order of US$ 1.5 million per month and that GOB was now telling Santa Cruz Public Works Committee that it will have to finance more of infrastructure projects in Santa Cruz from its own resources rather than looking to GOB for support.
Minister said hydropower extremely important in Bolivia and that there are many possibilities for expanding hydropower capacity. Said major project is multipurpose Bala Dam and that it would be undertaken soon by joint corporation made up of ENDE (state owned power company serving region extending from Oruro to Cochabamba to Santa Cruz), COFADENA (Armed Forces Development Corporation) and CORDEPAZ (La Paz Department Development Corporation).
In response to question Capriles stated that distribution under new AID rural electrification would be taken care of by government. He stated that Bolivian Power Company wishes to sell out unprofitable operation here but government not repeat not in position to take over assets at this time. Nonetheless, he said that government monopoly over power production increasingly the pattern in Latin America.
In earlier conversation Bolivian Power’s local manager told Congressman that government had ignored company’s offer three years ago to sell out. Said that more recently company offered to keep distribution function which it most capable of handling and to sell production side of business to CORDEPAZ. He reported feasibility study by CORDEPAZ due to be finished this week.

text:
Date:
          June 20, 1974
        
                    
          From:

          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Arae-00 Sso-00 Nsce-00 Usie-00 Inre-00 Aid-20 Iga-02 Pm-07 Nsc-07 Sp-03 Ss-20 Rsc-01 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Inr-10 Nsae-00 Pa-04 Prs-01 Omb-01 Trse-00 Eb-11 Swf-02 Pc-10 Fdre-00 Drc-01 /121 W ——————— 093530 O 201455z Jun 74
        
                    
          Subject:
          C-130 Aircraft For Bolivia
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PFOR MASS EAID BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

AS DEPARTMENTS OF STATE AND DEFENSE AWARE, GOB HAS EXPRESSED STRONG INTEREST IN PURCHASING PROMPTLY TWO C-130 TRANSPORT AIRCRAFT. PRESIDENT BANZER HAS MADE THIS INTEREST KNOWN TO ME EXPLICITY. THE BOLIVIAN AIR FORCE HAS BEEN IN TOUCH WITH OUR MILITARY MISSION ABOUT THESE AIRCRAFT. WHILE THE BOLIVIAN AUTHORITIES WOULD PREFER NEW UNITS, THEY WOULD BE SATISFIED WITH PROMPT DELIVERY OF USED EQUIPMENT PROVIDED, NATURALLY, IT IS IN SERVICEABLE CONDITION. I HAVE JUST RECEIVED PRICE AND AVAILABILITY DATA FOR NEW C-130 AIRCRAFT THROUGH U.S. MILITARY CHANNELS INDICATING A COMPLETE PRICE PER UNIT OF ABOUT $8 MILLION AND A DELIVERY TIME OF 1977. WE SHALL APPRRIATELY INFORM THE BOLIVIAN AUTHORITIES OF THIS INFORMA- TION WHICH WILL DISAPPOINT THEM AND ADDITIONALLY HEIGHTEN THEIR INTEREST IN USED C-130 AIRCRAFT.
I WOULD THEREFORE APPRECIATE, ON AN URGENT BASIS, AN AGGRESSIVE EFFORT BY STATE AND DEFENSE TO LOCATE TWO OR AT LEAST ONE USED C-130 AIRCRAFT WHICH CAN BE OFFERED FOR PURCHASE BY BOLIVIA AS SOON AS POSSIBLE. THE C-130 IS AN IDEAL TRANSPORT

201513Z
AIRCRAFT FOR THIS COUNTRY FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND CIVIC
ACTION PURPOSES. THIS HAS BEEN AMPLY PROVEN IN THE PAST THROUGH EFFECTIVE AIRLIFTS PROVIDED BOLIVIA BY C-130 AIRCRAFT FROM SOUTHERN COMMAND. C-130’S HAVE MADE POSITIVE CONTRIBUTIONS HERE IN AIRLIFTING CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE EQUIPMENT FROM ONE AREA OF THE COUNTRY TO ANOTHER THROUGH WHICH NO OTHER TRANSPORTATION MEANS AVAILABLE. DURING EMERGENCIES SUCH AS ANNUAL FLOODING, WHEN RAIL AND ROAD TRANSPORT BROKEN, C-130 AIRLIFTS HAVE MOVED FOOD FROM STORAGE LOCATIONS TO POPULATION CENTERS. BOLIVIA HAS, AS IS WELL KNOWN, A WEAK TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM AT BEST, OVER SOME OF THE MOST DIFFICULT TERRAIN IN THE WORLD. THE ADDITIONAL TRANSPORTATION CAPABILITY PROVIDED BOLIVIA BY THE POSSESSION OF C-130 AIRCRAFT WOULD BE EXTREMELY BENEFICIAL.

I URGE PROMPT ACTION TO MEET BOLIVIA’S DESIRES TO PURCHASE C-130 AIRCRAFT FOR POLITICAL REASONS AS WELL. THE BENEFITS TO THE U.S. FROM THE PRESENCE IN BOLIVIA OF A U.S. MANUFACTURED C-130 AIRCRAFT PROVING ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND CIVIC ACTION ASSISTANCE WOULD BE GREAT. I BELIEVE THAT AT THE COST OF SOME INTERNAL ADMINISTRATIVE EFFORT, WE CAN DERIVE SUBSTANTIAL POLITICAL GAINS HERE.
IF USED C-130’S ARE BECOMING AVAILABLE FROM U.S. AIR NATIONAL GUARD, I RECOMMEND ALLOCATION OF AT LEAST ONE FOR BOLIVIA. IF THIS SOURCE IS NOT VIABLE, THEN I SINCERELY HOPE MAXIMUM EFFORT WILL BE MADE TO LOCATE ANOTHER.
PLEASE ADVISE. STEDMAN

text:
Date:
          April 24, 1974
        
                    
          From:

          SecState WashDC Priority 2909
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Iso-00 Aid-20 Eb-11 Omb-01 Trsy-11 Iga-02 Ciae-00 Dode-00 Pm-07 H-03 Inr-10 L-03 Nsae-00 Nsc-07 Pa-04 Rsc-01 Prs-01 Sp-03 Ss-20 Usia-15 Agr-20 Snm-02 Faa-00 Dote-00 Come-00 Drc-01 /163 W ——————— 049256
        
                    
          Subject:
          Conversation With Bolivian President Banzer: Economic And Military Assistance And The State Visit
        
                    
          TAGS:
          PFOR MASS OVIP EAID BL
        
                  
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

PRESIDENT BANZER MADE THE FOLLOWING POINTS DURING COURTESY CALL ON APRIL 23 BY COUNTRY DIRECTOR KARKASHIAN AND AMBASSADOR:

A. THE GOB AND HE, PERSONALLY, ARE DEEPLY GRATEFUL TO THE USG FOR CONTINUING U.S. ECONOMIC ASSISTANCE, WITH SPECIAL REGARD FOR THOSE LOANS MADE FOR EMERGENCY ACTIVITIES SHORTLY AFTER HE ASSUMED POWER. THE GOVERNMENT WOULD VERY MUCH LIKE TO HAVE THE U.S. CONSIDER AN ADDITIONAL PADES LOAN SINCE IT HAS PROVEN TO BE AN EFFECTIVE DEVELOPMENT TOOL AND A POSITIVE FACTOR FOR STABILITY IN THE COUNTRY.
B. THE GOVERNMENT IS SERIOUSLY CONSIDERING OUR RECENT OFFER OF $4 MILLION FMS CREDIT AND WILL COMMUNICATE ITS RESPONSE PROMPTLY. THE GOB MAY WISH TO USE THE LINE OF CREDIT FOR TRANSPORT AIRCRAFT, HEAVY CONSTRUCTION MACHINERY, AND OTHER HARDWARE WHICH MIGHT HAVE A PRODUCTIVE PURPOSE.
C. THE GOVERNMENT IS PLEASED TO LEARN THAT A TEAM COMPOSED OF
241827Z
IDB, IBRD, AND AID TECHNICANS WILL SOON ARRIVE IN BOLIVIA TO ASSESS
FLOOD DAMAGE. BASED ON THAT ASSESSMENT, THE PRESIDENT SAID, HE HOPED THAT PROJECTS MIGHT BE DEVELOPED TO PREVENT FUTURE FLOODING AND TO RELOCATE AND HOUSE REFUGEES
D. THE PRESIDENT WAS PLEASED TO LEARN THAT USG TECHNICIANS WILL ARRIVE SOON TO STUDY THE POSSIBILITIES OF SUBSTITUTION OF ALTERNATIVE CROPS FOR COCA. HE SUGGESTED EXAMINATION OF POSSIBLE COURSES OF ACTION
SUCH AS PURCHASE OF COCA LEAF PRODUCTION AND ITS DESTRUCTION, OR INCENTIVE PAYMENTS DIRECTLY TO FARMERS TO PRODUCE OTHER COMMODITIES.
E. PRESIDENT EXPRESSED HIS CONTINUED INTEREST IN PROMPT DELIVERY OF MILITARY EQUIPMENT FOR THE TIPOS IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNDERSTANDINGS REACHED WITH US. THE AMBASSADOR DESCRIBED THE CURRENT DELIVERY FORECASTS AND REPORTED ON THE ARRIVAL OF SIGNIFICANT MILITARY ITEMS IN RECENT WEEKS AND WITHIN THE COMING MONTH. PRESIDENT SEEMED PLEASED BUT REPEATED HIS FIRM DESIRE THAT THE TIPOS BE BROUGHT UP TO STRENGTH AS QUICKLY AS POSSIBLE TO RAISE THE MORALE OF THE TROOPS AND TO CREATE A DISSUASIVE FORCE TO INHIBIT THE OUTBREAK OF INTERNAL DISORDER.

COUNTRY DIRECTOR KARKASHIAN EXPLAINED THE OPERATIONS OF AN FMS CREDIT, NOTED THE INCREASING DIFFICULTIES OF ACQUIRING MAP GRANT AID AND POINTED OUT THE DESIRABILITY OF BOLIVIA’S UTILIZATION OF FMS CREDIT. KARKASHIAN EXPRESSED THE APPRECIATION OF WASHINGTON AUTHORITIES FOR BOLIVIA’S CONTINUED EFFECTIVE COOPERATION IN COMBATTING DRUG TRAFFICKING. WHILE STATING THE U.S. POLICY OF CONTINUED SUPPORT AND ASSISTANCE FOR THE BOLIVIAN GOVERNMENT, HE CAREFULLY AVOIDED SPECIFIC COMMITMENTS FOR LOANS FOR CROP SUBSTITUTION, NEW PADES OPEATIONS, AND FOR RECONSTRUCTION.
IN THE DISCUSSION OF FMS CREDIT, PRESIDENT BANZER SAID THAT IT WAS HIS HOPE THAT COFADENA WOULD BECOME AN EFFECTIVE INSTRUMENT FOR ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT. HE SAID IT SHOULD CONCENTRATE ITS ACTIVITIES RATHER THAN CONTINUING AS AT PRESENT TO AGGRESSIVELY ENTER A WIDE RANGE OF ACTIVITIES. HE EXPRESSED HIS HOPE THAT EXTERNAL CREDITS MIGHT FACILITATE CONFADENA ACQUISITION OF PRODUCTIVE

241827Z
EQUIPMENT AND THAT ITS FUTURE PROFITS COULD THEN BE TURNED TO BENEFIT THE LOT OF THE COMMON SOLDIER WITH BETTER HOUSING AND MEDICAL CARE. IN THIS WAY HE HOPES TO REDUCE THE DEMANDS ON THE TREASURY FOR MILITARY EXPENDITURES AND BURDENING THE NATION WITH CREDITS FOR NON-PRODUCTIVE MILITARY EQUIPMENT.

PRESIDENT BANZER TOLD KARKASHIAN THAT HE REGRETTED HAVING TO POST- PONE THE STATE VISIT TO THE U.S. SCHEDULED FOR LAST FALL, BUT DOMESTIC POLITICAL FACTORS ARISING FROM ECONOMIC MEASURES PRECLUDED HIS DEPARTING THE COUNTRY. THE PRESIDENT SAID HE HOPED THAT HE BE ABLE TO MAKE THE TRIP SOMETIME IN THE FUTURE AT PRESIDENT NIXON’S AND HIS MUTUAL CONVENIENCE. KARKASHIAN RESPONDED THAT THIS WAS ALSO THE DESIRE OF THE USG AS SET FORTH IN PRESIDENT NIXON’S LETTER TO PRESIDENT BANZER. STEDMAN

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

IN ACCORDANCE WITH REFTEL, I CALLED ON BOLIVIAN FOREIGN MINISTER GUZMAN ON JULY 19 TO PROVIDE HIM AND THE GOB WITH TEXT OF SECTION 32 OF FAA. I EXPLAINED THAT WHILE SENSE OF CONGRESSIONAL PROVISION IS NOT MANDATORY REQUIREMENT UPON THE PRESIDENT, IT DOES EXPRESS CONTINUING CONGRESSIONAL CONCERN WITH POLITICAL PRISONERS AND HUMAN RIGHTS. I NOTED THAT SECTION WAS IN FOREIGN ASSISTANCE ACT AND THAT APPROPRIATION OF FUNDS FOR ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS NOW BEING CONSIDERED. I NOTED THAT BOLIVIA WAS NOT BEING SINGLED OUT BUT THAT ALL AID RECIPIENT GOVERNMENTS WERE BEING INFORMED OF THIS PROVISION. I INDICATED THAT SECTION 32 DESERVES SERIOUS CONSIDERATION BY THE GOB.
FOREIGN MINISTER GUZMAN READ SPANISH TEXT I PROVIDED HIM OF SECTION 32 AND INDICATED HIS GENERAL APPROVAL OF THE CONGRESSIONAL SENTIMENT. HE NOTED DIFFERENCE BETWEEN GOVERNMENT TAKING ACTION AGAINST CITIZENS FOR POLITICAL PURPOSES AND CITIZENS ENGAGING IN ILLEGAL ACTS AGAINST GOVERNMENT REQUIREING PROTECTIVE MEASURES BY AUTHORITIES. HE NOTED THAT NEWLY INSTALLED MILITARY CABINET SHOULD IMPROVE

192224Z
POLITICAL STABILITY IN BOLIVIA AND THAT EPISODES SUCH AS
THE RECENT ABORTIVE PLOT OF JUNE 4/5 SHOULD NOT RECUR. THEREFORE, GOB NEED NOT RESORT TO REPRESSIVE MEASURES BECAUSE POLITICAL TRAQUILITY SHOULD BE INSURED NOW. FOREIGN MINISTER SAID FOREGOING REMARKS SHOULD BE TREATTED AS HIS IMMEDIATE PERSONAL REACTION TO READING TEXT OF SECTION 32 OF FAA. HE SAID HE WOULD HAVE EARLY OPPORTUNITY TO MEET WITH PRESIDENT AND WOULD REVIEW WITH HIM THE CONGRESSIONAL CONCERNS SO AS TO GIVE ME AN OFFICIAL GOB POSITION. STEDMAN

title: Anglo Bolivian Land And Cattle Co.
text:
Date:
          August 01, 1979
        
                    
          From:
          AmEmbassy La Paz
        
                    
          To:
          AmEmbassy Buenos Aires
        
                    
          Info:
          Oct-01 Ads-00 Eb-08 /024 W ——————084670 031445z /46 R 011230z Aug 79
        
                    
          Subject:
          Anglo Bolivian Land And Cattle Co.
        
                    
          TAGS:
          SOCI, BL, BBAK
        
                    
          Ref:
          A) 78 LA PAZ 3489, B) 78 USDOC 08830, C) 78 USDOC 12337, D) 78 AMSTERDAM 693, E) 78 LONDON 10982, F) BUENOS AIRES 5925
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

The effective world-side advertising campaign of the Anglo-Bolivian Land and Cattle Co. (ABLC) deluged US with inquiries about the company. In July 1978 we completed our investigation and sent our report to USDOC and SECSTATE. Our efforts have continued but with virtually no new information. We have found it extremely difficult to obtain information about this company.
The Anglo-Bolivian Land and Cattle Company is the international sales department of Varangian Investments Ltda. We do not know in which country Varangian Investments is registered. According to a document sent to the Santa Cruz, Bolivia Prefect, Varangian Investments was founded about 1964 and has operated throughout Central America and the Caribbean, where the firm has engaged in agriculture, cattle, and real estate activities. Varangian Investments appears to be related to the Inter-American Finance Corp. in London. Amembassy London has been unsuccessful in its efforts to contact this firm for additional information (REFTEL E). According to our information, neither Varangian Investments nor the Anglo-Bolivian Land and Cattle Company are registered in Bolivia. These two companies apparently formed three Bolivian companies, Santa Teresita Ltda., El Parnaso Ltda., and Los Milagros Ltda., to acquire and develop land near Santa Cruz.
Mr. James M. Rodengen was and may still be the general manager of Santa Teresita Ltda., the only active one of the three Bolivian companies associated with ABLC. Mr. Rodengen worked for seven years as the Varangian Investments director of sales for the Central America region before Varangian Investments transferred him to Santa Cruz. His address was the following: Casilla 3746, Santa Cruz, Bolivia; Phone: 30022 - Telex: CABINA PUBLICA BX 7600 ANBOL.
Mr. Alan D. Hutchinson is an attorney who is the managing director of the Anglo-Bolivian Land and Cattle Co. He is also director of the Inter-American Finance Corp. Although apparently residing in London, he travels to Santa Cruz frequently.
Through Santa Teresita Ltda., the Anglo-Bolivian Land and Cattle Co. purchased three parcels of contiguous land totaling 11,000 hectares near Santa Cruz during the last quarter of 1977. Supposedly, each piece of property that is for sale is well-marked and has an access road. Sales prices are about US$ 34 to US$ 40 per hectare. These prices are considered to be above the area’s current market prices. Property values are not expected to reach current sales prices for two or three more years. Therefore, the firm’s offer appears to be a highly speculative one. Anglo-Bolivian Land and Cattle Co. guarantees clear title to the property. Money may be placed in escrow until title is received.
The following mail addresses for Anglo-Bolivian Land and Cattle Co. have appeared in the sales literature which we have seen: A. Box 58, 15 Central St., Woodstock, Vermont 05091 B. Barclays Bank Building, P.O. Box 265, Grand Cayman, British West Indies C. Schiphol Airport East, P.O. Box 7766, Amsterdam, The Netherlands USDOC found the Vermont mail is merely forwarded to Mr. Hutchinson in London (REFTEL B). Also, AmConsul Amsterdam reports that the Amsterdam P.O. Box is used only by an air transport firm (REFTEL D).
On December 26, 1978 the Bank of America branch in Santa Cruz told US that ABLC is not a client but that they are supported financially by Inter-American Finance Company domiciled in Grand Cayman and that any financial figures on both companies could be available through the Barclay’s International Bank in the same city.
The Bolivian Consejo Nacional de Reforma Agraria makes no guarantee as to the soundness of this investment and recommends that persons interested in purchasing lots visit the property first to verify the company’s assertions and to find out the real cost of the property.
An Undersecretary in the Ministry of Agriculture told US in February 1979 that the GOB had virtually no information about ABLC. He suggested that the new tracts of land now being sold by ABLC are public lands. (The initial three tracts were sold out). He was going to investigate this matter and report to US, but so far, he has no new information.

La Paz agrees completely with Quito 0059. After considerable consultation with appropriate country team members we do not feel that having a seminar in Lima would benefit mission objectives in La Paz. Our representative to Andean PAO meeting did not understand simultaneous seminars to mean sending participants to other country.
Normal spin-off benefits from seminars include: A. Strengthening contacts with key individual through close proximity over a period of time. B. Being able to present points to further local CASP and CPM courses of action. C. Using local media to convey to a larger audience the key points brought out during the discussions. D. Using the STAG’s as entre to groups with whom one would not ordinarily have easy access.
None of these benefits would accrue to Bolivia if we participated in Peru’s seminar. Under the circumstances we prefer not to participate in the proposed Vogel, Pollack, Turpin seminar. Like Quito we feel our money could be better spect in a locally produced seminar later in the fiscal year. Are consulting WPTH Economic/Commercial Section on practical aspects to be covered and will submit details and STAG requests later.

          TAGS:
          EAGR, CH, BL, CO
        
                    
          Ref:
          PEKING 939
        
            
    
    
  

DEPARTMENT OF STATE TELEGRAM
UNCLASSIFIED

Summary: In late March the delegation from the Cotton Import Department of CHINATEX (REFTEL) visited Bolivia. The delegation did not purchase any Bolivian cotton but indicated interest in future purchases. Also, the delegation did invite several members from the Bolivian Cotton Producers Association, ADEPA, to visit the PRC in the immediate future.
Comment: Recent, severe flooding had an adverse impact on Bolivia’s 1979 cotton crop. Because of the resulting low yields, the CHINATEX delegation probably decided to postpone purchases of Bolivian cotton.
